(m)  Rule 13, blanks to be filled, etc. When a blank is to be filled, and different sums or times proposed, the question shall first be put upon the largest sum or the longest time. 
(n)  Rule 14, vote necessary for passage of ordinance. Unless otherwise required by statute of the State, the concurrence of a majority of all the members elected to the board of trustees, including the president, shall be necessary for the passage of any ordinance. This means at least four trustees must concur on the proposition, or three trustees and the president. When a vote greater than the majority of the corporate trustees elected is required by the statutes to adopt an ordinance, the president may vote. Any trustee present and not voting when a vote is being taken shall be recorded in the negative, unless excused under rule 8 as set forth in subsection (h) of this section. 
(o)  Rule 15, introduction and adoption of ordinances. Except when this rule may be suspended, the board of trustees shall consider and act upon all ordinances in the following manner: an ordinance shall be listed on the meeting agenda when first introduced and it shall be announced that copies thereof are available for public distribution. The board may consider and discuss the ordinance at such first meeting, but no ordinance shall be passed at such meeting when it is so introduced. The ordinance shall be considered again at the next regular meeting of the board, at which time it shall also be listed on the meeting agenda. At the next regular meeting of the board, the ordinance shall either be passed, passed as amended, continued to a subsequent meeting, rejected or otherwise acted upon. All ordinances shall be numbered consecutively by the clerk after passage. 
(p)  Rule 16, report of committees. All special committees to whom any matter may be referred shall report thereon, in writing, at the next regular meeting, giving the recommendation of the majority of the committee. Those not in favor may present a minority report. Every committee, in reporting upon the subject referred to it, shall attach to its report all resolutions, petitions, remonstrances and other papers in its possession relating to the subject matter referred to, and any such report, after being read, shall be referred for final action to the next regular meeting of the board of trustees upon the request of any two trustees present. 
(q)  Rule 17, questions containing several propositions. When a question before the board of trustees contains several distinct propositions, any member may call for a division of the question so as to take a vote on each proposition separately. 
(r)  Rule 18, petitions. All petitions addressed to the board of trustees shall be in writing and filed by the clerk, unless withdrawn by leave of the board of trustees, except as otherwise provided by statute. 
(s)  Rule 19, filing and preservation of records, etc. All reports made by committees, and all resolutions and ordinances adopted by the board of trustees shall be filed and preserved by the clerk. The Village manager shall publish all ordinances, maps and other documents and instruments required by law to be published either in a newspaper, or by printing in book or pamphlet form, in the manner provided by law. Where publication is by printing in book or pamphlet form, the printing shall contain the legend "Published by Authority of the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Glenview, Illinois," and the date of publication. 
(t)  Rule 20, resolutions and motions entered in minutes. In all cases when a resolution or motion shall be entered in the minutes of the board of trustees, the name of the member moving the resolution or motion shall also be entered in the minutes. 
(u)  Rule 21, reconsiderations. A member who votes with the prevailing side or any trustee who was absent at the time the vote was taken may move a reconsideration, but no such motion shall be in order after the expiration of the next meeting of the board of trustees. 
(v)  Rule 22, contracts. No contract in writing, to which the Village is a part, shall be considered as entered into until it has first been read in an open meeting of the board of trustees, and where a bond is required, the amount of the bond for the faithful performance thereof shall be fixed by the board of trustees, the sureties approved and the president and clerk directed to execute such contract by a vote of a majority of the members elected to the board of trustees. 
(w)  Rule 23, payment of bills. All bills, before being paid, shall be certified to by the Village employee having knowledge that the material or services charged for has been properly and fully supplied, furnished or rendered and that the charge is a just and proper one for the quantities or services stated and shall be further approved by the Village manager. Upon the submission of an itemized list of bills so certified and approved, the board of trustees may authorize and direct the Village treasurer to pay the bills. 
(x)  Rule 24, nonmembers addressing board. It shall not be allowable for any person not a member of the board of trustees, except the Village officers, to address such board without the unanimous consent of the members present, and then only once on the same subject, without further consent. 
(y)  Rule 25, censorship or expulsion of members. Any member acting or appearing in a disgraceful manner, or using violent and insulting language to or about any member of the board of trustees, or who does not obey the orders of the chair, shall, on motion, be censured by a majority vote of the members present, or expelled by a two-thirds vote of all members elected. 
(z)  Rule 26, ayes and nays. The individual ayes and nays shall always be taken on the voting upon all ordinances, resolutions and motions and entered on the journal, and the roll shall be called in rotating order. 
(aa)  Rule 27, adherence to rules. The rules or procedures set forth in subsections (a)—(z) of this section and order of business shall be adhered to invariably by the board of trustees, unless suspended as provided in subsection (dd) of this section. 
(bb)  Rule 28, new business. All new business introduced at any meeting shall be referred to the appropriate committee, lie over until the next meeting or be acted upon at once. 
(cc)  Rule 29, Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. Whenever a question of parliamentary law, not fully covered by the rules set forth in subsections (a)—(bb) of this section, shall arise, such question shall be decided in accordance with the rules of parliamentary law as laid down in Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(dd)  Rule 30, suspension, etc., of rules. Any or all of the rules set forth in subsections (a)—(cc) of this section may be suspended or amended, or additional rules adopted by the affirmative vote of four trustees. 
(ee)  Rule 31, attendance by members of boards and commissions at open meetings other than by physical presence. 
(1)  If a quorum of the members of a public body is physically present as required by Section 2.01 of the Act, a majority of the public body may allow a member of that body to attend the meeting by other means if the member is prevented from physically attending because of: (i) personal illness or disability, (ii) employment purposes or the business of the public body, or (iii) a family or other emergency. "Other means" is by video or audio conference. 
(2)  If a member wishes to attend a meeting by other means, the member must notify the recording secretary or clerk of the public body before the meeting unless advance notice is impractical. 
(3)  A majority of the public body may allow a member to attend a meeting by other means only in accordance with and to the extent allowed by Public Act 094-1058 adopted by the corporate authorities. The rules must conform to the requirements and restrictions of this section, may further limit the extent to which attendance by other means is allowed, and may provide for the giving of additional notice to the public or further facilitate public access to meetings. 
(Code 1959, § 2.14; Ord. No. 4926, § 2, 11-21-2006; Ord. No. 5830, § 2, 8-5-2014)  
Secs. 2-72—2-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-81. - Appointive officers. 
Unless otherwise provided, all appointive officers of the Village shall be appointed by the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, at the first regular meeting of the board held after the regular election of members of the board of trustees, or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, and shall hold their office for such time as the board, by ordinance or resolution, provides. Any officers so appointed may be suspended or removed from office at any time by a majority vote of the entire board at any regular meeting or at any special meeting called in accordance with law. All such vacancies may be filled in the manner provided in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 2.1)  
Sec. 2-82. - Oath of office. 
All elected or appointed officers of the Village shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe to the following oath or affirmation: "I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the ordinances of the Village of Glenview, and that I will faithfully discharge all the duties of ___________, according to the best of my ability," which oath or affirmation so subscribed shall be filed in the office of the Village clerk. 
(Code 1959, § 2.2)  
Sec. 2-83. - Bond—Required. 
All officers of the Village shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, give such bond may, by ordinance or resolution, be provided, or as may be required by the statutes of the State in such case made and provided. If any such officer shall not take the oath or affirmation as required, and present such bond to the Village clerk within ten days after notification by the Village clerk of his election or appointment, his office shall be declared vacant. Such bond, however, if not already approved as to form and sureties by the president and board of trustees, shall be received by the clerk, subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees, and if the president and board of trustees shall, at the next regular meeting, require a different form of bond or other sureties, the Village clerk shall immediately notify the officer filing such bond of the required changes, and in case a new bond is not filed complying with such requirements within ten days after such notification, the office of the principal in the bond shall be declared vacant. 
(Code 1959, § 2.4)  
Sec. 2-84. - Same—Amount; payment of premiums. 
All officers and employees shall post a bond in such amount and with such sureties as the board of trustees shall, by resolution, require. The premiums of all such bonds shall be paid from the Village treasury. 
(Code 1959, § 2.5)  
Sec. 2-85. - Same—Execution, sureties and approval. 
The bond of each officer or employee of the Village, as required, shall be executed in favor of the Village and shall be secured by any surety company licensed to do business in the State and shall be approved by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 2.6)  
Sec. 2-86. - Delivery of books and other property to successor. 
Any person whose term of office shall have expired as an officer of the Village shall, within five days after notification and request by the Village president, deliver to his successor in office all books, property and effects of every description that may be in his possession, and belonging to the Village, or pertaining to his office. 
(Code 1959, § 2.7)  
Sec. 2-87. - Additional duties, etc. 
Each officer shall perform such other and further duties, besides the specific ones called for in this Code, and be subject to such other lawful rules and regulations as the board of trustees may require from time to time, or by other ordinances establish, including regulations established by the Village manager. 
(Code 1959, § 2.8)  
Sec. 2-88. - Access to books, etc. 
The president or any member of the board of trustees and the Village manager shall, at any time they so desire, have free access to the examination of all books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries of accounts of each and every such office, and upon a resolution adopted by the board of trustees, or an order promulgated by the Village manager, demand a written report on any matter which may be designated in such resolution or such order of the Village manager, and within the time so set forth. 
(Code 1959, § 2.9)  
Sec. 2-89. - Eligibility for office of president or trustee. 
No person shall be eligible for the office of Village president or Village trustee unless he is a qualified elector of the Village and has resided therein for at least one year preceding his election or appointment. 
(Code 1959, § 2.80)  
Sec. 2-90. - Eligibility for Village office, board or commission. 
No person shall be eligible for any other Village office, board or commission unless he has resided in the Village for 30 days next preceding his election or appointment. Such requirement shall not apply to the Village engineer, Village finance director, Village treasurer created under section 2-251, director of development or other officers who require technical training or knowledge, nor to the environmental review commission, Village attorney, Village firefighters or police officers, or appearance commission members who meet the requirements of being an owner or officer of a corporation owning business, commercial or industrial property in the Village as noted in chapter 54, article III. 
(Code 1959, § 2.81)  
Secs. 2-91—2-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MANAGER 
 
Sec. 2-131. - Creation of office. 
The office of Village manager is hereby created. 
(Code 1959, § 2.17)  
Sec. 2-132. - Appointment and removal; qualifications; vacancy. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees for an indefinite term. He shall be chosen on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, with special reference to his actual experience in, or his knowledge of, accepted practice in respect to the duties of his office as set forth in this division. At the time of his appointment, he need not be a resident of the Village or the State, but, during his tenure of office, he shall reside within the Village. Neither the Village president, nor any of the Village trustees shall receive such appointment during the term for which he shall have been elected or within one year after the expiration of his term. 
(b)  The Village manager may be removed by the Village Board by a majority vote of the entire board at any time. The manager may demand written charges or a written statement of the reasons for removal, which the Village Board shall furnish to the manager within 20 days after the filing of such request. During such 20-day period, the manager may be suspended from office with or without pay. The action of the Village Board in removing the manager from office shall be final. 
(c)  Any vacancy in the office of Village manager shall be filled within 60 days after the effective date of such vacancy. 
(Code 1959, § 2.18)  
Sec. 2-133. - Powers and duties. 
Purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget in accordance with the procurement policy and procedures ("procurement policy") which may be amended from time to time. Amendments to the procurement policy shall be approved by the Village Board; however, the Village Manager retains the authority to approve procedural changes. He/she may not purchase any items or approve any change order which exceeds any budget appropriation until the Village Board has increased the appropriation, provided that, for competitively bid purchases of more than $25,000.00, he/she shall be required to receive sealed bids and shall present such bids to the Village Board for approval or rejection and the Village Board shall determine the responsibility of bidders. He shall be responsible to the Village Board for the proper administration of all affairs of the Village. He shall have the power, and be required, to: 
(1)  Appoint and remove officers. Appoint or remove all non-elective officers and employees of the Village, except the Village prosecutor, Village collector, Village treasurer, members of boards and commissions or ad hoc committees as defined herein, and the Village attorney. Such appointments or removals shall be based upon merit and the qualifications of such officers or employees, without regard to any political belief or affiliation. Any removal of an officer by the Village Manager shall be reported to the Village Board at or prior to the next regular meeting of the Village Board. 
(2)  Appoint and remove employees. Employ and discharge all employees, other than those referred to in subsection (1) of this section. 
(3)  Annual report on finances and administrative activities. Prepare and submit to the Village Board, at the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the Village for the preceding year. 
(4)  Advise and make recommendations to Village Board on financial conditions and future needs. Keep the Village Board advised of the financial condition and future needs of the Village and make such recommendations as he may deem desirable. 
(5)  Recommend salaries and employee compensation packages Recommend to the president and board of trustees the salaries and compensation packages to be paid and provided to each appointive officer and subordinate employee of the Village and otherwise provide for full and meaningful disclosure of employee compensation in the yearly budget for review and approval by the corporate authorities as a part of the yearly budget process. 
(6)  Make general recommendations. Recommend to the president and board of trustees, in writing, from time to time, for adoption, such measures as the Village manager may deem necessary and expedient. 
(7)  Consolidate offices, positions, departments and units; department head. Consolidate or combine offices, positions, departments or units under his jurisdiction, with the approval of the president and Village Board. The Village manager may be the head of one or more departments. 
(8)  Attend Village Board meetings. Attend all meetings of the Village Board, unless excused therefrom by the board, except when his removal is under consideration. The Village manager shall have the privilege of taking part in the discussion of all matters coming before the board. He shall be entitled to notice of all meetings, regular and special, of the board. 
(9)  Purchase materials, supplies and equipment. Purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget, but he/she may not purchase any items or approve any change order which exceeds any budget appropriation until the Village Board has increased the appropriation, provided that, for competitively bid purchases that will exceed $25,000.00, he/she shall be required to receive sealed bids and determine the responsibility of bidders. Such procurement is not, however, undertaken pursuant to section 8-9-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/8-9-2, and the Village Board expressly reserves the right to make any award which, in its sole discretion, best serves the public interest. The Village manager shall advise the Village Board as to whether or not any contract offered is desirable, or which of several contracts offered is most desirable for the Village. He may issue such rules and regulations governing requisitions and the transactions of the business of purchasing between himself as purchasing agent and the heads of the departments, officers and employees of the Village as the Village Board may approve. In case of accidents or other circumstances creating an emergency, the Village manager may award contracts and make purchases for the purposes of repairing damages caused by such accident or meeting such public emergency, but he shall promptly file with the Village Board a certificate showing such emergency and the necessity of such action, together with an itemized account of all expenditures. 
(10)  Enforce ordinances. Ensure that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced. 
(11)  Authorize to investigate Village affairs or departments and divisions. Make investigations into the affairs of the Village or any department or division thereof, and investigate all complaints in relation to all matters concerning the administration of the government of the Village and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the Village, and ensure that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the Village are faithfully observed. 
(12)  Ex officio Village collector and Village treasurer. The Village manager shall act as ex officio as both Village collector and Village treasurer, and exercise and perform all duties and be subject to all the requirements and obligations appertaining to such officers. 
(13)  Devote to duty. Devote his entire time to the discharge of his official duties. 
(14)  Coordinator of the emergency management agency. The Village manager or his nominee shall act as the coordinator of the emergency management agency to carry out the directives of the Village president during any period in which an emergency has been declared pursuant to the applicable provisions of chapter 26, article II of the Code. 
(15)  [ Decision-making. ] Make decisions where currently required to be made by department director(s) or department heads, in lieu of said department director(s) or department head, unless otherwise explicitly prohibited in the village municipal code or state statute. In the event a vacancy exists, and where the Code provides for any position with decision-making authority consistent with the job description of said vacant position, the Village manager may assume the decision-making authority of the vacant position or delegate such authority to his or her designee. Unless otherwise provided in the municipal code or state statute, the decision of the Village manager shall be final. 
(16)  Perform additional duties. Perform such other duties as may be required of him by the Village Board or president, not inconsistent with the Village ordinances or the law. 
(Code 1959, § 2.19; Ord. No. 4455, § 2, 11-19-2002; Ord. No. 4882, § 2, 6-20-2006; Ord. No. 5032, §§ 2—4, 10-2-2007; Ord. No. 5568, § 2, 6-19-2012; Ord. No. 5636, § 5, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5674, §§ 2, 3, 4-16-2013; Ord. No. 6188, §§ 2, 3, 9-4-2018)  
Sec. 2-134. - Interference of Village Board with administrative service. 
Individual members of the Village Board shall deal with the administrative service solely through the Village manager and no board member shall give orders to any subordinates of the Village manager, either publicly or privately, or direct their appointment or removal. 
(Code 1959, § 2.20)  
Sec. 2-135. - Bond and compensation. 
(a)  The Village manager shall furnish a surety bond to be approved by the Village Board, and such bond is to be conditioned for the performance of his duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the Village. The bond shall name the Village manager as principal in his capacity as Village manager and also in his capacity as ex officio treasurer and collector of the Village. 
(b)  The Village manager shall receive such compensation as the Village Board shall fix from time to time by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1959, § 2.21)  
Secs. 2-136—2-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ATTORNEY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Appointment, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5(a)(5). 
 
Sec. 2-161. - Creation of office; term. 
There is hereby created the office of Village attorney. The term of such office shall be for and during the fiscal year in which the Village attorney is appointed, and until his successor has been appointed and has qualified by taking the oath of office. 
(Code 1959, § 2.51)  
Sec. 2-162. - Appointment; qualifications. 
The office of Village attorney shall be filled by appointment by the president and board of trustees, and shall be made immediately after the biennial installation of the trustees, or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, and annually thereafter. The Village attorney shall be a regularly licensed and practicing member of the bar of the State. It shall not be a condition of his employment that he reside within the corporate limits of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 2.52)  
Sec. 2-163. - Duties. 
The duties of the Village attorney shall be to advise the president and board of trustees, the committees thereof, and the officers of the Village on legal questions; attend the regular meeting of the board, when required; render a legal opinion on questions submitted to him; draft ordinances and legal documents on behalf of the Village; appear for and represent the Village in all legal proceedings to which it may be a party, and perform such other duties in behalf of the Village as pertain to the position of Village attorney; and, at the request of the president and board of trustees, make and file with the Village clerk a written report showing the business transacted, the services rendered by him, the status of pending litigation and unfinished business, and all other material facts of public interest pertaining to the legal business of the Village for the preceding fiscal year. It shall further be the duty of the Village attorney to spend one-half day each week within the Village for the purpose of consulting with municipal officers of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 2.53)  
Sec. 2-164. - Compensation. 
(a)  The compensation of the Village attorney shall be such sum as shall be established from time to time by ordinance or resolution adopted by the president and board of trustees. In special assessment projects, he shall be paid such amount as may be allowed by State statute. 
(b)  The Village attorney shall also be paid out of the Village treasury such expenses as may be necessary in the performance of his duties as Village attorney, provided that such expenses have been previously authorized to be incurred by the president and board of trustees or subsequently approved by them. 
(c)  The Village attorney shall be paid for services in other proceedings before courts and commissions, and any other litigated or contested matters on behalf of the Village that may be required of him, and such reasonable fees as may be fixed by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 2.54)  
Secs. 2-165—2-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CLERK 
 
Sec. 2-191. - Duties in general. 
The Village clerk shall keep the corporate seal, to be provided under the direction of the president and board of trustees, and all papers belonging to the Village. He shall attend all meetings of the president and board of trustees, and keep a record of its proceedings; and copies of all papers duly filed in his office and other records and files of his office, certified by him under the corporate seal, shall be evidenced in all courts in like manner as if the originals were produced. 
(Code 1959, § 2.22)  
Sec. 2-192. - Issuance of notices to the board of trustees, etc. 
The Village clerk shall, in addition to the duties imposed upon him by section 2-191, issue notices to the members and all officers of the board of trustees and other persons, when directed to do so by the board or the chairman of any committee of such board and when required by law. 
(Code 1959, § 2.23)  
Sec. 2-193. - Attesting licenses and other documents. 
The Village clerk shall attest all the licenses granted by the president and board of trustees under the ordinances of the Village, and all other documents required to be signed by the president. 
(Code 1959, § 2.24)  
Sec. 2-194. - Delivery of communications, resolutions and ordinances. 
(a)  The Village clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the officers of the Village and all committees of the board, all resolutions and communications referred to such officers or committees by that body. 
(b)  The Village clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the president of the Village, all ordinances or resolutions under his charge, which may be required to be approved or otherwise acted upon by the president, with all papers on which such ordinances or resolutions were founded. 
(Code 1959, § 2.25)  
Sec. 2-195. - Notification of successful candidates or appointments. 
(a)  The Village clerk shall, within five days after the result of any election shall be declared, or appointment made, notify such person so elected or appointed to any Village office of his election or appointment, and, unless such person shall qualify within ten days after such notice, the office shall become vacant. 
(b)  In any election for Village office, not more than three of the judges in any one precinct shall be supporters of any one organization listing candidates on a certificate of nomination filed with the Village clerk for such election. 
(Code 1959, § 2.26)  
Sec. 2-196. - Appointment of deputy. 
The Village clerk may appoint a deputy, by and with the consent of the president and board of trustees, who, in the temporary absence of the Village clerk, in case of sickness or otherwise, shall be empowered to perform all the duties of the Village clerk. 
(Code 1959, § 2.27)  
Sec. 2-197. - Filing and preserving official bond, oath of office, etc. 
The Village clerk shall file and preserve, in a convenient form for reference and use, according to the date of filing and subject matters, all official bonds, oaths of office, written reports of officers and committees, vouchers and all papers and documents filed with him or deposited in his care, and promptly turn over such materials to his successor in office, taking a receipt therefor. 
(Code 1959, § 2.28)  
Sec. 2-198. - Salary. 
The salary of the Village clerk shall be in such amount as shall be fixed by the president and the board of trustees from time to time by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1959, § 2.29)  
Sec. 2-199. - Additional duties and functions. 
In addition to the duties specified in this division, the Village clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by the ordinances of the Village and the statutes of the State. 
(Code 1959, § 2.30)  
Secs. 2-200—2-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - COLLECTOR 
 
Sec. 2-221. - Creation of office. 
There is hereby created the office of Village collector. The Village manager shall act ex officio as Village collector and shall exercise and perform all duties and be subject to all requirements and obligations pertaining to such office. 
(Code 1959, § 2.39)  
Sec. 2-222. - Bond. 
The Village collector shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, execute to the Village a bond in such sum as may be required by the board of trustees and the statutes of the State, with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office, and the bond shall be filed in the office of the Village clerk within ten days after the approval and confirmation by the board of trustees of his appointment. The bond of the Village manager, in his ex officio capacity as treasurer and collector, shall satisfy the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1959, § 2.40)  
Sec. 2-223. - New bond or additional sureties. 
The board of trustees shall have the right to demand a new bond or further and additional sureties from time to time as, in its opinion, may be necessary for the protection of the Village, and if the original bond filed by such collector shall not be approved, or having been approved by the board of trustees, further or additional sureties shall thereafter be required, notice of such action by the board of trustees shall be delivered to the collector, whereupon, within ten days after the receipt of such notice, he shall file a new bond or furnish additional sureties, as the case may be. Failure to file such new bond or furnish such additional sureties as required by the board of trustees, within ten days after receipt of notice as set forth in this section, shall create a vacancy in such office. 
(Code 1959, § 2.41)  
Sec. 2-224. - Books of account. 
The Village collector shall keep books of account, which shall show all moneys received by him and all other matters pertaining to his office. Such books shall be kept in a clear and methodical manner and shall be open at all times to the inspection of the president, any member of the board of trustees and any person or other officer of the Village authorized by law to inspect such books, and he shall keep such books as the president and board of trustees shall direct from time to time. 
(Code 1959, § 2.44)  
Sec. 2-225. - Annual reports. 
The Village collector shall annually, between April 1 through April 10, file with the Village clerk and the Village treasurer a complete list of all assessments returned as delinquent by him to the county collector, stating the amount returned on each assessment, and he shall make an annual report of the business of his office on April 30 of each year. 
(Code 1959, § 2.46)  
Sec. 2-226. - Serving, posting and publishing notices of special assessments, special taxes and other warrants and matters for collection; annual returns to County officials of unpaid collections. 
(a)  The Village collector shall serve, post and publish, or cause to be served, posted and published, all notices required by law or ordinances of the Village to be served, posted or published in connection with the collection of various special assessments, special taxes and other warrants and matters in his hands for collection. 
(b)  The Village collector shall annually make returns to the county treasurer and ex officio county collector of all delinquent special assessments and special taxes, and any and all other taxes in his hand for collection which he has been unable to collect at the time and in the manner required by law and which, by law, this Code or other ordinances of the Village, he is required to return to such county collector. 
(Code 1959, § 2.47)  
Sec. 2-227. - Duties upon expiration of term of office. 
At the expiration of his term of office, the Village collector shall deliver to his successor in office all warrants, books, files, stationery and other property in his possession relating to the conduct of such office, taking a complete detailed itemized receipt therefor, in duplicate, and he shall deliver to the Village treasurer a complete detailed and accurate statement of all moneys collected by him subsequent to the date of his last report and pay such amounts over to the treasurer, taking his receipt therefor, in duplicate, and shall submit to the president and board of trustees a report of all moneys collected by him subsequent to the date of his last report from any and every source whatsoever and shall file with such report a receipt from his successor in office for the warrants, books, files, stationery and other property turned over to him, and a receipt from the Village treasurer for the moneys collected by him as set forth in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 2.48)  
Secs. 2-228—2-250. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - TREASURER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Duties, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-40. 
 
Sec. 2-251. - Office created; duties in general; bond. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of the treasurer of the Village. The Village manager shall act ex officio as the Village treasurer and shall exercise and perform all duties and be subject to all the requirements and obligations pertaining to such office. 
(b)  The treasurer of the Village shall furnish a surety bond from an approved surety company in such sum as may be required by the board of trustees and the statutes of the State in such case made and provided. 
(Code 1959, § 2.31)  
Sec. 2-252. - Receipt and payment of moneys. 
(a)  The Village treasurer shall keep a true and accurate account of all moneys paid into the treasury, from whom and from what account received, and pay out all such sums of money on warrants signed only by the president and attested by the Village clerk, as may be ordered by the president and board of trustees. Such warrants, in all cases, must state upon what particular fund they are drawn, but all bonds and interest coupons issued by the Village, which may be due and payable, shall be considered as warrants, and shall be duly paid by the Village treasurer. 
(b)  No money shall be paid by the Village treasurer upon any warrant, bond or coupon, except from moneys in the particular fund or appropriation designated in such warrant, bond or coupon, or upon which they have been drawn, nor shall any amount be transferred by the Village treasurer from one fund to another, after being received and credited by him, nor appropriated to any other purpose than the one for which it has been paid, without the necessary proceedings to such ends. 
(Code 1959, § 2.32)  
Sec. 2-253. - Method of keeping books generally. 
The Village treasurer's books must at all times show the exact condition of the funds under his control, of each account and appropriation, and all receipts and disbursements, and such books, together with all orders, blanks and other papers, belonging to the Village, and in his custody, shall be handed over by him to his successor. He shall, upon all receipts of money, enter and place such receipts under the proper appropriation, to the credit of the several accounts upon which such moneys were paid, and state from whom they were received. He shall keep a separate account with each fund or appropriation, stating the amount of such appropriation and the several debits and credits belonging thereto. 
(Code 1959, § 2.33)  
Sec. 2-254. - Special assessments. 
The Village treasurer shall keep an account with each special assessment, under its general description and number, and show the amount assessed for public and special benefits, and all moneys received on any special assessment shall be held by the Village treasurer for that fund, only to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and such money shall not be used for any other purpose whatsoever, except as may have been provided in the ordinance for the improvement, or as may be otherwise permitted by statute or order of court. 
(Code 1959, § 2.34)  
Sec. 2-255. - Monthly report of finance committee. 
The Village treasurer shall, at the first meeting of each month, render a report in writing, under oath, to the committee on finance, showing, in detail, the receipts and disbursements during the second month previous, and the state and condition of every account not closed on his books, thereby showing a balance sheet of the financial sheet of the financial affairs of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 2.35)  
Sec. 2-256. - Cancellation of paid warrants. 
The Village treasurer shall cancel all warrants paid or redeemed by him, and shall attach the warrants as paid, each month, to his monthly report, as well as duplicate receipts for moneys received, and such other vouchers as may cover, in detail, all his transactions for the month, as shown in such report. Upon examination and approval by the committee on finance and the president and board of trustees, the Village clerk shall take charge of the report, warrants and vouchers and place them on file in his office. He shall keep an accurate list of all warrants canceled by him. 
(Code 1959, § 2.36)  
Sec. 2-257. - Annual report. 
The Village treasurer shall annually, within 30 days after the close of the fiscal year, make out and file with the Village clerk a full and detailed account of all receipts and expenditures, and all his transactions as Village treasurer during the preceding fiscal year, and shall show in such account the state of the treasury at the close of the fiscal year, which account the Village clerk shall immediately publish in accordance with law. 
(Code 1959, § 2.37)  
Sec. 2-258. - Personal use of Village funds. 
The Village treasurer shall keep all moneys belonging to the Village that may be in his possession separate and distinct from his own moneys, and is prohibited from using, either directly or indirectly, the Village money or warrants in his custody or keeping for his own benefit or the benefit of any other person whatsoever. 
(Code 1959, § 2.38)  
Secs. 2-259—2-280. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - BUDGET OFFICER 
 
Sec. 2-281. - Creation of office; appointment. 
The office of budget officer is hereby created. The Village manager or his designee shall serve as the budget officer. 
(Code 1959, § 2.74)  
Sec. 2-282. - Duties. 
The budget officer shall exercise the statutory powers and duties of his office as provided and set forth in 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1, and pursuant to these duties, he shall: 
(1)  Permit, encourage and establish the use of efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal management procedures. 
(2)  Compile an annual budget in accordance with section 2-283. 
(3)  Examine all books and records of the Village which relate to moneys received and paid out by the Village, as well as debts and accounts receivable, and amounts owed by or to the Village. 
(4)  Obtain such additional information from the Village departments as may be useful to the budget officer for compiling an annual budget, and such information is to be furnished in the form required by the budget officer. 
(5)  Establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no expenditures are made by the Village, except as authorized by the budget. 
(Code 1959, § 2.75) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.2.  
Sec. 2-283. - Annual budget contents. 
(a)  The budget officer shall compile a budget, which shall contain estimates of revenues available to the Village for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures for the Village. 
(b)  Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations shall be presented in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal management practices. Substantial conformity to a chart of accounts recommended by the National Committee on Governmental Accounting, the comptroller of the State or the department of local government affairs of the State or successor agencies shall be deemed proof of such conformity. 
(c)  The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. As far as possible, the fiscal data for such two preceding fiscal years shall be itemized in a manner which is in conformity with the chart of accounts approved as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made. 
(Code 1959, § 2.76)  
Sec. 2-284. - Capital equipment purchase, repair or replacement fund. 
(a)  In the preparation by the budget officer of the annual budget, no more than three percent of equalized assessed value of property subject to taxation by the Village may be accumulated in the capital equipment purchase, repair or replacement fund. 
(b)  Expenditures from the capital equipment purchase, repair or replacement fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the purchase, repair or replacement of capital equipment will occur. 
(Code 1959, § 2.77)  
Sec. 2-285. - Public inspection, notice and hearing on annual budget. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees shall make the tentative annual budget conveniently available to public inspection for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget. 
(b)  Not less than one week after the tentative annual budget is made available for public inspection, and prior to final action on the budget, the president and board of trustees shall hold a public hearing on the tentative annual budget, after which hearing, the tentative budget, without any further inspection, notice or hearing, may be further revised and adopted by vote of the president and board of trustees. Notice of the public hearing shall be given by publication of a legal notice in a newspaper having a general circulation in the Village at least one week prior to the time of the hearing. 
(Code 1959, § 2.78)  
Sec. 2-286. - Adoption of annual budget. 
Adoption of the annual budget by the president and board of trustees shall be in lieu of adoption of the appropriation ordinance as required by statute. The annual budget need not be published, except in a manner provided for in section 2-285. The annual budget shall be adopted by the president and board of trustees before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies. 
(Code 1959, § 2.79)  
Secs. 2-287—2-310. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - PROSECUTOR 
 
Sec. 2-311. - Creation of office; term. 
There is hereby created the office of Village prosecutor. The term of office shall be for and during the fiscal year in which the Village prosecutor is appointed and until a successor has been appointed and is qualified by taking the oath of office. 
(Code 1959, § 2.59)  
Sec. 2-312. - Appointment; qualifications. 
The office of Village prosecutor shall be filled by appointment by the president and board of trustees. The Village prosecutor shall be a regularly licensed and practicing member of the bar of the State. It shall not be a condition of his employment that he reside within the corporate limits of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 2.60)  
Sec. 2-313. - Duties. 
The duties of the Village prosecutor shall be to represent the Village in proceedings before the police magistrate of the Village, or elsewhere as cases may be properly transferred, insofar as matters arising as the result of violations of traffic ordinances of the Village or upon appeal thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 2.61)  
Sec. 2-314. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the Village prosecutor shall be such sum as shall be established from time to time by ordinance or resolution adopted by the president and board of trustees. The Village prosecutor shall also be paid out of the Village treasury such expenses as may be necessary in the performance of his duties as Village prosecutor, provided such expenses have been previously authorized to be incurred by the president and board of trustees or subsequently approved by them. 
(Code 1959, § 2.62)  
Secs. 2-315—2-390. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS[4]

Secs. 2-391—2-410. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DEPARTMENT HEADS 
 
Sec. 2-411. - Director of public works. 
The office of the director of public works is hereby created. The director of public works shall serve as the head of the department of public works and shall be appointed by the Village manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to the supervision, direction and control of the Village manager. The director of public works shall be charged with the planning, budgeting, management, direction and control of the maintenance and operation of the utilities and capital plant of the Village, and other duties as set forth in this Code or delegated by the Village manager. 
(Code 1959, § 2.56) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 82.  
Sec. 2-412. - Director of community development. 
The office of director of community development is hereby created. The director of community development shall serve as the head of the department of community development and shall be appointed by the Village manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to the supervision, direction and control of the Village manager. The director of community development shall be charged with the planning, budgeting, management, direction and control of the construction-related regulatory activities of the Village, including planning, building and zoning, health and sanitation and engineering, and other duties as set forth in this Code or delegated by the Village manager. 
(Code 1959, §§ 5.2.2, 5.2.4; Ord. No. 5879, § 2, 12-9-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5879, § 2, adopted December 9, 2014, amended § 2-412 to read as set out herein. Previously § 2-412 was titled director of development.

ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5636, §§ 2a, 3, adopted Feb. 19, 2013, repealed the former Art. V, §§ 2-441—2-520, and enacted a new Art. V as set out herein. The former Art. V pertained to similar subject matter. For a complete derivation of former Art. V, see the Code Comparative Table. Ord. No. 5636 supplied provisions to be added as §§ 2-441—2-573. In order to maintain the established numbering style of this Code, at the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been redesignated as §§ 2-441—2-520 to read as set out. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-441. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to compile into one location the ordinances establishing and regulating Village boards, commissions, and committees. In some cases, however, it has been deemed advantageous to maintain these regulations with the ordinance related to the subject matter to the board, commission, or committee. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-442. - Applicability. 
Except as set forth elsewhere in these ordinances, in state law, or in the document establishing a given board, commission, or committee, this section shall apply to all such bodies, regardless of how established or whether termed a board, commission, committee, work group, task force, or similar name or whether standing or ad hoc. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-443. - Definitions. 
As used in this section: 
Authority or district means an entity that is a separate political body from the Village of Glenview. 
Board or commission means a commission of the Village, that is established by State statute, local ordinance, or resolution and that is given some independent power to make determinations on behalf of the Village or recommendations to the Village President or Board of Trustees. The Zoning Board of Appeals, Plan Commission, Appearance Commission and Board of Fire and Police Commissioners are examples of boards or commissions. Members of Boards or Commissions shall be considered "Public Officials" as that term is defined and used in chapter 2, article I. 
Ad hoc committee means any group other than a standing board or commission, and generally is limited to making recommendations or reports to the Village President or Board of Trustees or some other body, unless explicitly empowered otherwise. An ad hoc committee is generally created to meet a specific purpose or project. Any group called a task force, work group or similar name is an ad hoc committee. 
Administrative committee means any group of individuals appointed by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-444. - Creation and dissolution. 
Unless otherwise provided by State statute, commissions and ad hoc committees may be created and dissolved by ordinance or resolution adopted by the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-445. - Appointments. 
Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or state statute, all appointments shall be made as follows: 
(1)  Appointments to commissions, ad hoc committees and non-Village committees shall be made by the Village President with the approval of the Board of Trustees. 
(2)  Appointments to ad-hoc commissions shall be subject to the rules set forth in the resolution or order establishing the commission. If not otherwise provided, appointments shall be made by the Village President with the approval of the Board of Trustees. 
(3)  Commission members must be residents of the Village unless otherwise provided herein. 
(4)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as other appointments. 
(5)  Alternates. If the commission is authorized to have alternate members, the alternates shall be given numerical appointments (first alternate, second alternate etc.). When a member or members of the commission are absent, the alternates shall act as full members of the commission in their numerical order, that is, the first alternate shall first act as a full member; the second alternate shall be then next to so act, etc. 
(6)  Compensation. All members are to serve without compensation except as otherwise provided by local ordinance or state statute; authorized expenses may be reimbursed in accordance with applicable Village regulations. 
(7)  Removal of members. Any member of any commission may be removed from office by a majority vote of the Board of Trustees at any regular or special meeting, provided however that a member of the Zoning Board of Appeals may only be removed for cause by the Board of Trustees after first conducting a public hearing in accordance with chapter 98, subsection 98-43(b)(1). 
(8)  Members of commissions or ad hoc commissions shall be subject to the Village Ethics Code (chapter 2, article I, section 2-1). 
(9)  Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all commission members shall take and subscribe the oath or affirmation required by the Illinois Constitution, and set forth in section 2-82 of the Municipal Code. The oath of office may be administered by the Village President or Commission Chairman. The subscribed oath or affirmation shall be filed in the office of the municipal clerk. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-446. - Terms of appointment. 
Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or state statute: 
(1)  All commission members shall be for a term of four years or until a successor is appointed. 
(2)  The initial term of any person appointed to fill a vacancy shall be until the end of the term for which the vacancy was filled. 
(3)  Any ordinance amendment or resolution affecting the terms of or the qualifications of members of boards, commissions, or committees shall, unless otherwise explicitly provided therein, have prospective application only, and shall not have any effect upon the remainder of any terms of office nor upon the appointment of any member of a commission in existence on the date said ordinance amendment or resolution becomes effective. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any fixed term of office, the terms of board, commission, and committee members shall run until their successors are appointed and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 5, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-447. - Officers; chairperson. 
Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or state statute: 
(1)  The Village President shall appoint one of the members of the commission to serve as a chairman. The chairman shall have the power to administer oaths. 
(2)  The Chairman of a commission shall serve until a successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 5, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-448. - Attendance, quorum, and voting. 
Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or state statute: 
(1)  If at any board, commission, or committee meeting, a quorum is not secured within 15 minutes of the officially scheduled meeting time, the commission shall adjourn without taking any action, except that it may set a date and time for its next meeting. 
(2)  The Chair of each board, commission, or committee (or staff if delegated by the Chair) shall report to the Village Manager and President and Board of Trustees each instance in which a member is absent from three consecutive meetings or more than 50 percent of the regularly scheduled meetings in a calendar year. For purposes of reporting this only, a regular meeting that is not held due to lack of a quorum shall count towards a missed meeting by any member not present. The Village President shall take appropriate action to secure the attendance of such members including, in the Village President's discretion, requesting their resignation. In the absence of any statute or ordinance that establishes the quorum for any board, commission, or committee, the quorum of any such body is the number that constitutes a majority of the authorized voting membership. Vacant positions shall be counted in determining the quorum of such a body. 
(3)  Except as provided in section 98-47 of the Code which provides that the concurring vote of four members of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be necessary to grant a variation, in the absence of any other statute or ordinance to the contrary, motions before the board, commission, or committee shall be passed by an affirmative vote of not less than a majority of the quorum of the board, commission, or committee. The chair of a commission shall not vote unless the chair's vote would affect the outcome of the matter before the board, commission, or committee. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 5, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-449. - Minutes, rules of procedure, hearings, public comment. 
Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or state statute: 
(1)  The Village Manager shall designate a secretary for each commission. The secretary shall: 
a.  Take minutes of each commission meeting, originals of which shall be kept by the secretary. 
b.  Provide administrative and technical assistance to the commission to assist in making the decisions and findings as provided hereunder, and 
c.  Publish and distribute to the commissioners copies of the minutes, reports, and decisions of the commission. 
d.  The secretary shall have no vote. 
(2)  Boards, commissions, and ad hoc committees shall utilize the rules of the Board of Trustees, chapter 2, article II, division 3, section 2-71 of the Municipal Code. 
(3)  Hearings and public notice. 
a.  All hearings required by this Code to be conducted by the board and/or the commission shall be open to the public. Any person may appear and testify at a hearing either in person or by a duly authorized agent or attorney. All testimony shall be given under oath. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, shall administer oaths and may compel the attendance of witnesses. 
b.  Unless otherwise provided in the Code, notice of a public hearing shall be published not more than 30 days, nor less than 15 days before the hearing, in one or more of the newspapers in general circulation within the Village. The published notice may be supplemented by such additional form of notice as the board may provide. The Village Manager or his designee shall also cause one or more signs to be posted on the subject property, not more than 30 days, nor less than 15 days prior to the hearing. The number and location of signs shall be determined by the Village Manager or his designee. Each sign must be a minimum of 24 inches by 24 inches in size, have letters with a minimum of three-eighths-inch wide stroke by 2½ inches high, and contain the following information: 
1.  The fact that a public hearing will be held regarding the subject property; 
2.  Direction to interested members of the general public to call the appropriate Village office for further information concerning the date, time, place and subject matter of the public hearing; and 
3.  The telephone number of the Village office. 
4.  The absence of a posted sign shall not deprive the Plan Commission or Zoning Board of the authority to conduct a public hearing provided all other notice requirements are met. 
c.  Where the Village Manager or designee has administrative discretion, a notice of administrative relief shall be sent to all adjacent property owners on a one plus one basis, allowing 15 days for response. If there is no response, the Village Manager or designee may grant administrative relief, where applicable. If an adjacent property owner responds with a concern regarding such administrative relief, the Village Manager or designee shall forward the case to the Zoning Board of Appeals in the form of a variance request for disposition. 
(4)  Public comment. Every board, commission, or committee, shall establish a period for public comment at or near the beginning of each meeting. The public comment section of the meeting allows comments on any matter on the agenda, provided, however, that the board, commission, or ad hoc committee shall not take action on a matter raised in the public comment portion of the meeting unless that matter is otherwise on the agenda. The board, commission, or committee may allow public comment on any agenda item at the time that item is taken up. Members of the public who comply with applicable rules, including registering to speak prior to the board, commission, or committee beginning discussion on any agenda item, on registration forms established by the Village, shall be permitted at least three minutes to speak. If the speaker requires an interpreter, either because of his/her limited English proficiency or because of a disability, he/she shall be allowed no less than six minutes. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 5, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-450. - Meetings. 
Except as otherwise provided by ordinance or state statute: 
(1)  All meetings of all commissions shall be held in compliance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act, 65 ILCS 120/1 et seq. as amended from time to time. 
(2)  Each commission shall, at the beginning of each calendar or fiscal year, submit to the Village Manager for publication, a written schedule of the date, time, and location of its regular meetings for the following calendar year in accordance with state statute. Each commission shall meet at least four times per year unless otherwise provided herein. 
(3)  No meetings election day. No board, commission, or committee shall meet on any general election day for local, state or national offices, or referenda unless otherwise provided for above. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 5, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-451. - Reports. 
(a)  Every board, commission, or committee, whether created by ordinance, resolution, or order shall act on items the Village Board refers to it, where the votes are contested, by roll call vote. Its report to the Village Board shall include a list of members who voted and the vote of each. 
(b)  Annual report: On or before January 31 of each year, each board, commission or committee shall file a report with the Village President and Board of Trustees that summarizes the actions of the previous year and identifies the goals and objectives of the board or commission for the coming year. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-452. - Mandatory training session. 
All members of boards or commissions must complete any training mandated by state or local ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3, 2-19-2013)  
Secs. 2-453—2-455. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - APPEARANCE COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-456. - Established. 
There is hereby established an Appearance Commission which shall be comprised of seven members. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-461), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-457. - Composition. 
Members of the Appearance Commission shall possess the following qualifications: 
(1)  Two members shall have one or both of the following qualifications: 
a.  Be a registered architect; or 
b.  Be a professional who possesses a design background in at least one of the following: architecture, landscape architecture or design, graphic arts, graphic design and/or advertising. 
(2)  The remaining five members of the Commission shall preferably have at least one of the following qualifications, listed in order of preference: 
a.  Be a landscape architect or landscape designer. 
b.  Be an architect. 
c.  Have a design background including graphic arts, graphic design or advertising. 
d.  Be the owner or officer of a corporation owning a business, commercial or industrial property in the Village, and is preferred to be a member of the Chamber of Commerce. Such member is preferred, but not required, to be a resident of the Village. 
e.  Be an at-large Glenview citizen with relevant skills, including government, business, law, real estate development, or management. 
(3)  All members of the appearance commission, except the business member referenced in subsection (2)(d), shall be residents of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-462), 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5919, § 2, 7-7-2015)  
Sec. 2-458. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
The Appearance Commission is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and authority to: 
(1)  Consult and cooperate with the Plan Commission, other Village departments and any other municipal or governmental bodies on matters affecting the appearance of the Village. 
(2)  Study exterior design drawings, landscape and site plans, and materials for any proposed public works or public improvements and make recommendations to the Board of Trustees or Village Manager as to the architectural or aesthetic aspects thereof. 
(3)  Hold hearings, when required, on the issuance of certificates of appropriateness as provided in section 54-65 in connection with questions pertaining to applications for building permits and issue or deny such certificates pursuant to the provisions of section 54-65. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-463), 2-19-2013)  
Secs. 2-459, 2-460. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS 
 
Sec. 2-461. - Established. 
There is hereby established a Zoning Board of Appeals "Zoning Board" which shall be comprised of seven members. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-471), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-462. - Composition. 
Members of the Zoning Board shall be residents of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-472), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-463. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
The Zoning Board is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and authority to: 
(1)  Hear and pass upon appeals in which it is alleged that there is an error in any interpretation, requirement, decision, or determination (referred to collectively in this section as "interpretation") made by the Village Manager or his designee under this chapter, in the manner and subject to the standards set forth in section 98-48. 
(2)  Hear and pass upon applications for variations from the regulations and restrictions imposed by this chapter, in the manner and subject to the standards set forth in section 98-47. 
(3)  Hear and decide all matters referred to it or upon which it is required to pass under chapter 98. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-473), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-464. - Finality of decisions of the Zoning Board. 
(a)  Interpretations. Decisions of the Zoning Board on an appeal from the decision of the Village Manager or his/her designee may be taken to the Board of Trustees in the manner provided in section 98-48. 
(b)  Multi-family residential, commercial and industrial variations. Decisions of the Zoning Board, upon application for a variation after a hearing, with regard to lots located within the RT-8, R-18, PD, B-1, B-2, B-3, D-D, H-1, MURC, SLE, I-1, or I-2 zoning districts, or lots located in the R-1, R-1.3, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5 R-6, R-E or P-1 districts and are utilized for multi-family, commercial or industrial uses shall be subject to the procedures contained within subsection 98-50(b) which shall apply to applications for variations to commercial and industrial lots or parcels. 
(c)  Residential variations. Decisions of the Zoning Board upon application for a variation after a hearing, for lots located in the, R-1, R-1.3, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5 R-6, R-E or P-1 shall be final administrative determinations and shall be subject to review by a court in the manner provided by applicable State statutes. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-474), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-465. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING COMMISSION

Sec. 2-467. - Composition.

Sec. 2-468. - Jurisdiction and authority.

(2)  To make recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees regarding the adoption of building codes and related rules and regulations necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the residents and businesses of the Village of Glenview. 
(3)  To hear and decide all matters referred to it by the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-483), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-469. - Meetings.
