DIVISION 5. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION 
[6]
Footnotes: 
 
Sec. 2-471. - Established. 
There is hereby established a Historic Preservation Commission, which shall be comprised of seven members. 
(Ord. No. 5762, § 4, 2-4-2014; Ord. No. 6152, § 2, 3-6-2018)  
Sec. 2-472. - Composition. 
The Historic Preservation Commission shall be comprised of the following: 
(1)  The seven members of the Appearance Commission. Such members shall serve terms consistent with their membership on the Appearance Commission. 
(2)  The chairman of the Appearance Commission shall serve as chairman of the Historic Preservation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 5762, § 4, 2-4-2014; Ord. No. 6152, § 3, 3-6-2018)  
Sec. 2-473. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
The Historic Preservation Commission is hereby vested with the following jurisdiction and authority: 
(1)  To conduct an ongoing survey of the Village using the criteria identified in section 98-536 to identify buildings, structures, and property by address or location that are of historic, cultural or architectural significance, and potential landmarks. 
(2)  To investigate, hold public hearings and recommend to the Village Board of Trustees the consideration of ordinances designating as landmarks certain Village properties or structures having special historic, community, or architectural value. 
(3)  To compile information concerning designated landmarks. 
(4)  To prepare, keep current, and publish maps and/or registers of designated landmarks. 
(5)  To develop and maintain technical information pertaining to the physical and financial aspects of preservation, renovation, rehabilitation and reuse, and on procedures for inclusion on the National Register of Historic Places and to make such information available to the owners of potential and designated landmarks. 
(6)  To inform and educate the residents of the Village concerning the historic and architectural heritage of the Village by publishing appropriate maps, newsletters, brochures and pamphlets, by other appropriate means and by holding programs and seminars. 
(7)  To investigate, hold public hearings and recommend to the Village Board of Trustees to consider certain Village areas as having special historic, community or architectural value as historic districts. 
(8)  To keep a register of all property and structures which have been designated under this article, including all information required for each designation. 
(9)  To seek grants and donations to achieve the purposes of this article and, upon authorization by the Village Board of Trustees, to seek the certifications or approvals necessary to qualify the Village, the Commission or the owners of designated landmarks, for financial or other assistance. 
(10)  To determine an appropriate system of markers and make recommendations for the design and implementation of specific markings of the street and route leading from one landmark historic district to another. 
(11)  To advise and assist interested owners of landmarks and property or structures within the historic districts on physical and financial aspects of preservation, renovation, rehabilitation and reuse and on procedures for inclusion on the National Register of Historic Places. 
(12)  To nominate landmarks and historic districts to the National Register of Historic Places. 
(13)  To hold hearings and to review public building permit applications for construction, alterations, removal or demolition of designated landmarks or structures within historic districts, and to recommend to the Village Board of Trustees issuance or denial of certificates of appropriateness, for which applicants may be required to submit plans, drawings, elevations, specification and other information as may be necessary to make decisions. 
(14)  To consider and make recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees on applications for economic hardship that would allow the performance of work on any structure for which an application for certificate of appropriateness has been denied. 
(15)  To develop specific criteria for the alteration, construction, or removal of landmarks or property or structures within the historic district. 
(16)  To review applications for proposed subdivision or site plan review, zoning amendments applications for conditional uses or application for zoning variances that affect historic districts. The Secretary shall send copies of applications to the members of the Historic Preservation Commission prior to the date of the hearing by the Commission, Plan Commission, or Zoning Board of Appeals. 
(17)  To make recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees about possible amendments to this chapter, but not limited to, this article, that relate to the protection and continued use of designated landmarks or property and structures within historic districts. 
(18)  To testify before all Village boards and commissions on any matter affecting historically and architecturally significant property and landmarks. 
(Ord. No. 5762, § 4, 2-4-2014)  
Sec. 2-474. - Meetings. 
The Historic Preservation Commission shall meet a minimum of four times per year unless otherwise necessary to hold hearings related to the designation of a landmark or historic district, confirmation of eligibility, certificate of appropriateness, or certificate of economic hardship. 
(Ord. No. 5762, § 4, 2-4-2014)  
Sec. 2-475. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - PLAN COMMISSION. 
 
Sec. 2-476. - Established. 
There is hereby established a Plan Commission under the authority of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-12.4 et seq., which shall be comprised of seven members. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-501), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-477. - Composition. 
Members of the Plan Commission shall be residents of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-502), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-478. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
The Plan Commission is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and authority pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-12.4 et seq., with respect to land within the corporate limits and to contiguous territory not more than 1½ miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any municipality, to: 
(1)  Hear and report to the Board of Trustees applications for planned developments and amendments, subject to the standards set forth in the Village's Zoning Code. 
(2)  Hear and report to the Board of Trustees applications for conditional uses, subject to the standards set forth in the Village's Zoning code. 
(3)  Hear and report to the Board of Trustees applications for site plan review and amendments subject to the standards set forth in the site plan review ordinance herein. 
(4)  Hear and report to the Board of Trustees applications for amendments to the regulations imposed or the districts created in the Zoning Code of the Village. 
(5)  Prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the Village. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted by the Board of Trustees, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the Village. Such plan may include, but need not be limited to, provisions for the: 
a.  Establishment of reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and re subdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements; 
b.  Establishment of reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public streets, highways, alleys and ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds and other public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewerage collection and treatment; and 
c.  Designation of land suitable for annexation to the Village, and the recommended zoning classification for such land, upon annexation. 
(6)  Recommend changes, from time to time, in the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof. 
(7)  Prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities, from time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of such official plan. 
(8)  Draft and recommend ordinances directed toward the implementation of the official comprehensive plan, or specific improvements included therein. Such ordinances may pertain to any aspect of the official comprehensive plan and may provide for the full exercise of the constitutional and statutory powers of the Village. 
(9)  Assist officials of the Village charged with carrying out the official comprehensive plan or specific improvements included therein, and, generally, promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(10)  Propose and draft an official map of the area which may be included as a part of the official comprehensive plan. 
(11)  Upon request of the Board of Trustees, hold any public hearing which may be required by law as a prerequisite to adoption of an official comprehensive plan or official map, or any amendment thereof or for any other matter under the authority granted under 65 ILCS 5/11-13-22 et seq. 
(12)  Exercise all powers incidental to the powers set forth in this section and such other powers germane to the powers granted by this article as may be conferred by the Board of Trustees of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-503), 2-19-2013)  
Secs. 2-479, 2-480. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - NATURAL RESOURCES COMMISSION. 
 
Sec. 2-481. - Established. 
There is hereby established a Natural Resources Commission comprised of five members. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-511), 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5882, § 2, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 2-482. - Composition. 
(a)  The Natural Resources Commission shall be comprised of individuals who possess training, interest or experience in such areas as ecology, biology, environmental law, education, pollution control, engineering, science and public health. 
(b)  The Natural Resource Commission shall also include one ex-officio non-voting member who shall be a high school student, or a college student resident having an interest in the natural resources commission. Student members shall serve a maximum term of two years. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-512), 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5882, § 2, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 2-483. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
The Natural Resources Commission is hereby vested with the following jurisdiction and authority to: 
(1)  Make such investigations and such recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees as it may deem appropriate to carry out the following functions: 
a.  Preserve, conserve, enhance, and protect the environment, natural resources, and environmental values of the Village including the quality of land, air, and water and the interrelationships that exist among and between them and all living things within the limits of the Village. To further these goals, the following list identifies activities which might be undertaken by the natural resources commission: 
b.  Conduct and maintain an inventory of the natural resources of the Village. 
c.  Develop and recommend a plan for protection and restoration of the natural resources of the Village. 
d.  Review and comment on management plans as such plans are developed by Village staff with respect to areas of specific interest, including but not limited to the: 
1.  West Fork of the Chicago River; 
2.  Techny Basin; 
3.  Natural Areas of Gallery Park, including Lake Glenview and wetlands surrounding the lake. 
(2)  Strive to create an interest and awareness of the problems of land, water and air pollution and of the need to preserve, conserve, protect, and enhance the environment, natural resources, and environmental values of the Village among the citizens of and visitors to the Village. 
(3)  Hear appeals from any decision of the Director of Public Works (1) issuing or revoking a tree permit, (2) denying a tree permit application, or (3) granting or denying an exemption pursuant to subsection 20-11(f) of Ordinance Number 4235 Regarding Tree Protection and Preservation. With respect to this subsection (3), the decision of the natural resources commission shall be final. 
(4)  Act as a liaison between the Village and other governmental, public and private agencies such as the Glenview Park District, area schools, Friends of the Chicago River, Chicago Metropolitan Agency for Planning, Chicago Wilderness, and others to encourage development of programs and management of land that supports recognition and conservation of native species and natural ecological communities, and the improvement and enhancement of the environment. 
(5)  May propose an annual budget to the Village Board of Trustees for the purpose of furthering the goals and objectives of the Natural Resources Commission. Such budget, if approved, shall be administered by the Village Manager. 
(6)  All recommendations of the Natural Resources Commission shall be forwarded to the Village Manager for final action. Appeals to the Village Manager's decision shall be heard by the Village Board of Trustees. 
(7)  Advise the Village Board of Trustees on such matters as may be requested. 
(8)  The Natural Resources Commission shall have no authority to act in any way which is contrary to or inconsistent with respect to the powers, duties and jurisdiction of the Environmental Review Committee as set forth in this Code. 
(9)  Nothing in this section shall operate or be construed to authorize the regulation, direction or management of Glenview Park District natural resources assets. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-513), 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5882, § 2, 1-6-2015)  
Secs. 2-484, 2-485. - Reserved.

Members of the Environmental Review Committee shall be appointed for terms consistent with section 2-475.

DIVISION 9. - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-492. - Established. 
There is hereby established an Electrical Commission which shall be comprised of five members. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-531), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-493. - Composition. 
Members of the Electrical Commission shall possess qualifications in accordance with the statutory qualifications provided in the State Municipal Code, as amended from time to time, which are presently as follows: 
(1)  One shall be a registered professional engineer. 
(2)  One an electrical contractor. 
(3)  One a journeyman electrician. 
(4)  One a representative of an electricity supply company. 
(5)  One a representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the fire underwriters, if one resides in the Village, however, if no such representative resides in the municipality, then the chief of the fire department. 
(6)  If there is no person residing in the municipality who is qualified under any one of these descriptions, president may appoint some other person to fill that position.

The Electrical Commission is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and authority to:

(2)  To make recommendations to the Board of Trustees regarding the adoption of electrical Codes and related rules and regulations necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the residents and businesses of the Village of Glenview. 
(3)  To hear and decide all matters referred to it by the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-533), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-495. - Meetings. 
The Electrical Commission shall meet only on such occasion as a pending matter is referred to them. 
(Ord. No. 5657, § 6, 4-2-2013)  
DIVISION 10. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS 
 
Sec. 2-496. - Generally. 
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall operate under the provisions of an act to provide for the appointment of a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1-10-2.1-30. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-541), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-497. - Authority to suspend pending disciplinary hearing. 
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall have the authority to suspend any officer or sworn member of the fire or police department without pay, not to exceed 180 calendar days, pending the outcome of a disciplinary hearing. If, after a hearing, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners determines that an officer or sworn member of the fire or police department is guilty of the charges which were the subject of the hearing, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may, but shall not be obligated to, add an additional period of suspension of up to 180 days, without pay, as provided under [section 2-498]. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-542), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-498. - Authority to suspend in excess of thirty days. 
The provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17, which limit suspensions of officers and sworn members of the fire and police departments to no more than 30 days, is hereby amended and deemed superseded by this subsection, which hereby grants to the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners the authority to suspend an officer or sworn member of the fire or police department for a period not to exceed 180 calendar days, without pay. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-543), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-499. - Additional disciplinary sanctions. 
In addition to the suspension provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17 as modified in [section 2-497], the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall, as part of a disciplinary sanction after a due process hearing, have the authority to: 
(1)  Demote any officer or sworn member of the fire or police department one grade or rank; 
(2)  Remove the name of any officer or sworn member of the fire or police department from the current promotional eligibility list; 
(3)  Cause a forfeiture of longevity pay and/or holiday pay for any officer or sworn member of the fire or police department during the term of the suspension; 
(4)  Remit to the Village payment for health insurance during the term of the suspension; and 
(5)  Order performance of random drug testing of any officer or sworn member of the fire or police department for any offense relating to the use of narcotics or who may be found to be otherwise in violation of the Village's drug and alcohol policy. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-544), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-500. - Application of sanctions. 
All of the sanctions set forth in [sections 2-497—2-499] may be individually or cumulatively applied. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-545), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-501. - Application of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17. 
In all other respects not inconsistent with the expansion of disciplinary authority of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners set forth in this section, including the continued right to discharge any officer or sworn member of the fire or police department pursuant to the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17, the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17 shall continue to apply to all officers and sworn members of the fire and police department of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-546), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-502. - Authority to supersede 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-17. 
The ordinance from which this section is derived is adopted pursuant to Article VII, Section 6 of the State constitution and shall be in full force and effect from and after its adoption and approval by the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-547), 2-19-2013)  
Secs. 2-503—2-505. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 11. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-506. - Established. 
There is hereby established the Glenview Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Board ("Foreign Fire Tax Board"). The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall exercise the powers as designated herein consistent with 65 ILCS 5/11-10-2. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-551), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-507. - Membership, officers, term of office, vacancies. 
(a)  The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall consist of seven trustees; the fire chief, who shall hold office by virtue of rank, and six members who shall be elected at large by the sworn members of the Glenview Fire Department ("Department"). If there is an insufficient number of candidates to fill all these positions, the number of board members may be reduced, but not to fewer than three trustees. All members of the department shall be eligible to be elected as trustees of the Foreign Fire Tax Board. 
(b)  The trustees shall annually elect officers from among the trustees, consisting of a chairman and a treasurer. The trustees may also elect a vice chair and secretary. 
(c)  Each trustee, with the exception of the fire chief, shall serve a three-year term. In the event no successor trustee assumes office prior to the expiration of the three-year term, then the trustee shall serve until a successor trustee assumes office. The initial terms of office of the trustees shall begin 30 days after completion of the election. Each trustee shall hold office during his or her term unless the trustee resigns from the department, retires from the department, or is discharged from the department. If any of these three events occur, the trustee shall automatically be removed from the board and the position shall be deemed vacant. 
(d)  Vacancies on the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall be filled by election by the members of the department, and such election shall be for the balance of the unexpired term. Any person elected to fill a Foreign Fire Tax Board trustee vacancy shall assume office immediately upon completion of the election. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-552), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-508. - Election procedure. 
(a)  The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall adopt rules and regulations governing the nomination of candidates for trustee. All rules and regulations with respect to the nomination process shall be established and posted throughout the department a minimum of 60 days prior to the expiration of the trustees' terms of office. 
(b)  The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall adopt rules and regulations for the final election of candidates for trustee. The final election procedure shall be established and posted throughout the department a minimum of 30 days prior to the expiration of the trustees' terms of office. 
(c)  The Board may adopt rules and regulations governing the selection of officers of the Board. All rules and regulations with respect to the selection of Board officers shall be established and posted throughout the department a minimum of 30 days prior to the selection of officers. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-553), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-509. - Powers, duties, and procedures. 
(a)  The trustees of the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to the Foreign Fire Tax Board and the management of the money to be appropriated to the Foreign Fire Tax Board. 
(b)  The officers of the Board shall develop and maintain listings of those items that the Foreign Fire Tax Board feels are appropriate expenditures under the State statutes. 
(c)  All expenditures by the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall be in accordance with all State statutes and/or Village of Glenview ordinances and policies, concerning expenditure of monies. The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall follow good and sound accounting principles regarding the holding and spending of any monies. 
(d)  The funds of the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall be annually reviewed as part of the Village of Glenview audit. The audit shall verify that purchases are by the Foreign Fire Tax Board and for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Glenview Fire Department. 
(e)  The treasurer of the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall give a sufficient bond to the Village of Glenview. This bond shall be approved by the President of the Village's Board of Trustees. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his or her duties under the State statutes, ordinances, and the rules and regulations adopted by the Board. 
(f)  The funds collected pursuant to the levy of the Foreign Fire Insurance Company Tax shall be appropriated annually to the Foreign Fire Tax Board. 
(g)  The treasurer of the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall receive funds appropriated by the Village and shall pay out money and or otherwise make expenditures upon the order of the Foreign Fire Tax Board. Any expenditure made by the treasurer, pursuant to the order of the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall be solely for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department. 
(h)  The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall establish a list of items and/or services from which it shall select items and/or services to be purchased for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Department. The list shall be updated from time to time as the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall determine, but no less than annually on January 1 of each year. 
(i)  Prior to the purchase of any item(s) and/or service from the list which the Foreign Fire Tax Board intends to place within any fire station(s), the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall submit a written statement to the fire chief stating the descriptions of the items and/or services and the proposed locations within any fire station(s). The fire chief has the right to refuse to allow any such item(s) and/or service(s) into any fire station(s). If the fire chief decides to allow any such item(s) and/or service into any fire station the fire chief shall also have the right to refuse the Foreign Fire Tax Board's proposed physical location of any such item(s) or rendering of service in any fire station. The fire chief must respond in writing to any written statement of the Foreign Fire Tax Board within 30 days from his receipt of same and the fire chief must explain the basis for his decision(s). Upon the purchase of any approved items, title to same shall be placed in the name of the Village. 
(j)  The Foreign Fire Tax Board may appeal any such decision rendered pursuant to subsection (i) above to the Village Manager, or his designee, who shall render his decision in writing within 30 days of his receipt of the fire chief's rejection. The decision of the Village Manager may be appealed to the Village board through a written request for review by the Village board of the Village Manager's decision within 21 days of the issuance of the Village Manager's decision. This written request for review shall be submitted to the Village president. The Village board of trustees shall consider the appeal as soon as is practicable. The decision of the Village board of trustees shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-555), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-510. - Quorum, special meetings. 
The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings; and publish notice of same. The Foreign Fire Tax Board shall be subject to the provisions of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. The chairman shall preside at Foreign Fire Tax Board meetings; the secretary shall keep record of the proceedings and actions of the Foreign Fire Tax Board and may certify the same. Four members of the Foreign Fire Tax Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The chair may call a special meeting at any time, subject to the requirements of the Open Meetings Act. A special meeting may also be called upon the written notice of five members of the Foreign Fire Tax Board. Such notice shall describe in brief the nature or object of the special meeting. Any person shall be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter before the Foreign Fire Tax Board. Minutes of Foreign Fire Tax Board meetings shall be filed with the Village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-556), 2-19-2013)  
Secs. 2-511, 2-512. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 12. - FIRE PENSION BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-513. - Established. 
There is hereby established a firefighter's pension fund, as required by state statute, 40 ILCS 5/4, which shall be administered by the Fire Pension Board. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-561), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-514. - Membership, meetings, elections. 
(a)  The fire pension board shall consist of two members appointed by the Village President with the approval of the board of trustees, two firefighters elected by the active firefighters, and one pension beneficiary elected by the firefighter pensioners. 
(b)  Appointed members shall serve the following terms: One member shall be appointed for a term expiring the third Monday of April, 2014, and the other member for a term ending the third Monday of April, 2015. Following the initial term, appointed members of the fire pension board shall be elected for a term of two years. 
(c)  Elected members of the fire pension board shall be elected on the third Monday of April of each applicable year, and shall serve for a term of three years. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-562), 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 9, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-515. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
(a)  The firefighters' pension fund provides retirement benefits to firefighters subject to the Municipal Code. Pursuant to state statute, the State of Illinois is authorized to establish benefit levels and the Village is authorized to approve the actuarial assumptions used in the determination of contribution levels. The firefighter's pension fund shall consist of a contribution rate, established by the State, from the pay of each firefighter. In addition, there shall be levied an annual tax sufficient to maintain the reserve of the fund at the minimum required by law and to meet all obligations payable from the fund. 
(b)  The Firefighter's Pension Fund shall operate in all other respects in compliance with the applicable state statute. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-563), 2-19-2013)  
Secs. 2-516, 2-517. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 13. - POLICE PENSION BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-518. - Established. 
There is hereby established a Police Pension Fund, as required by state statute, 40 ILCS 5/3, which shall be administered by the Police Pension Board. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-571), 2-19-2013)  
Sec. 2-519. - Membership, meetings, elections. 
(a)  The police pension board shall consist of two members elected from and by the active police, one elected from and by the beneficiaries, and two are appointed by the Village President with the approval of the board of trustees. 
(b)  Appointed members shall serve the following terms: One member shall be appointed for a term expiring the second Tuesday of May, 2014, and the other member for a term ending the second Tuesday of May, 2015. Following the initial term, appointed members of the police pension board shall be elected for a term of two years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(c)  Elected members of the police pension board shall be elected biennially on the third Monday of April of each applicable year, and shall serve for a term of two years. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-572), 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 5657, § 8, 4-2-2013)  
Sec. 2-520. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
(a)  The police pension board administers the police pension fund, as prescribed by state statute for the benefit of its police officers and of their surviving spouses, children, and certain other dependents. Pursuant to state statute, the State of Illinois is authorized to establish benefit levels and the Village is authorized to approve the actuarial assumptions used in the determination of contribution levels. 
(b)  The police pension fund shall consist of a contribution rate established by the State of Illinois from the pay of each police officer. 
(c)  In addition, there shall be levied an annual tax sufficient to maintain the reserve of the fund at least at the minimum required by State law and to meet all obligations payable from the fund. 
(d)  The Police Pension Fund shall operate in all other respects in compliance with the municipal code and applicable state statute. 
(Ord. No. 5636, § 3(2-573), 2-19-2013)  
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE 
 
Sec. 2-521. - Director of finance. 
The office of the director of finance is hereby created. The director of finance shall serve as the head of the department of finance and shall be appointed by the Village manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to the supervision, direction and control of the Village manager. The director of finance shall be charged with preparing and maintaining all financial records of the Village. He shall exercise and perform such further duties relating to Village finance, accounting, purchasing and information, and other duties as set forth in this Code or delegated by the Village manager. 
Cross reference— Enforcement officer of the hotel and motel tax, § 70-64.  
Secs. 2-522—2-550. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-551. - Creation. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority of section 5/1-2.1-1, et seq., of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1, which authorizes a municipality to implement a system of administrative adjudication for code violations, and pursuant to section 11-208.3 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, et seq., which authorizes a municipality to provide a system of administrative adjudication for vehicular standing, parking and compliance violations, there is hereby created a system of administrative adjudication of charges of code violations, including vehicular standing, parking and compliance violations for the Village of Glenview. 
(b)  The Village adopts 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1, et seq., as it may be amended from time to time, and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, as it may be amended from time to time. In the event of a conflict between either of those statutes and this chapter, this chapter shall prevail. 
(c)  The adoption of this chapter does not preclude the Village from using other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(1-101), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-552. - Establishment and composition. 
(a)  There is hereby established within the Village manager's office an office of administrative adjudication, which shall be authorized to conduct administrative adjudication proceedings for departments and agencies of the Village. 
(b)  The office shall provide for the prompt disposition of alleged infractions of the Village Code of Ordinances (the "Code") and to afford such other adjudications as provided by law. When a hearing is set by the adjudication administrator, it must be set no sooner than 15 days from the date of the issuance of the violation unless an emergency involving public health and safety or the general welfare of the community is involved in which instance a hearing could be set immediately. 
(c)  The Village manager shall appoint an adjudication administrator who is authorized to: 
(1)  Operate and manage a system of administrative adjudication; 
(2)  Adopt, distribute and process violation notices; 
(3)  Establish procedures necessary for the prompt, fair and efficient operation of the administrative adjudication system; 
(4)  Certify copies of the final determinations of liability and factual reports, verifying that the final determination of violating liability was issued in accordance with this division and 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3; 
(5)  Certify reports to the Illinois Secretary of State concerning initiation of driver's license suspensions in accordance with the provisions of this article and 625 ILCS 5/6-406.5; 
(6)  Promulgate rules and regulations pertaining to the hearing process, the content of forms and procedures, and the daily operation of the administrative adjudication system; 
(7)  Compile and maintain complete and accurate records relating to all municipal ordinance violation notices issued pursuant to this article and the dispositions thereof. 
(d)  Hearing room personnel may be appointed by the chief of police, and if so appointed, shall be any police officer or community service officer, and such persons are hereby authorized and directed to: 
(1)  Maintain hearing room decorum; 
(2)  Execute authority as is granted to courtroom deputies of the circuit court; 
(3)  Perform such other duties or acts as may reasonably be required and as directed by the administrative hearing officer or the adjudication administrator. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(1-102), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-553. - Administrative hearing officer—Powers and duties. 
(a)  An administrative hearing officer shall be appointed by the Village manager. The term of the administrative hearing officer shall be one year. The administrative hearing officer shall be an attorney admitted to the practice of law in the state for at least three years. 
(b)  The administrative hearing officer shall have all powers necessary to conduct fair and impartial hearings including, but not limited to, the power to: 
(1)  Hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues; 
(2)  Administer oaths and affirmations; 
(3)  Hear testimony; 
(4)  Rule upon motions, objections and the admissibility of evidence; 
(5)  At the request of any party or on the administrative hearing officer's own motion, subpoena the attendance of relevant witnesses and the production of relevant books, records or other information; 
(6)  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
(7)  Regulate the course of the hearing in accordance with this article, or other applicable law; 
(8)  Issue a final order which includes findings of fact and conclusions of law; and 
(9)  Impose penalties and fines as set forth in section 30-1 herein, and issue orders that are consistent with applicable code provisions and assess costs, including but not limited to, court costs, upon finding a party liable for the charged violation; an order may include the recommendation for suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of a business license, pursuant to section 22-8. However, in no event shall an administrative hearing officer have the authority to impose a penalty of imprisonment or a fine in excess of $50,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(1-103), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-554. - Jurisdiction. 
Those matters subject to the administrative adjudication system provided for by this chapter are charges of violation of any Village ordinance, except the following: a) any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or this Code governing the movement of vehicles; b) any reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, 5/6-204; c) violations punishable by a penalty of incarceration; and d) violations punishable by a fine in excess of $50,000.00 per violation, excluding allowable costs; provided, however, that the maximum fine amount of $50,000.00 does not apply to cases brought to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(1-104), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-555. - Compensation of personnel. 
Authorization for compensation for each of the above-stated positions shall be made by the Village Board through the annual budget process. Compensation shall be determined by the Village manager within approved budget limitations. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(1-105), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-556. - Rules and regulations—Available for public inspection. 
The rules and regulations promulgated for the conduct of administrative adjudication proceedings shall be published and kept on file in the office of the Village manager where they shall be available to the public for inspection and copying at nominal rates during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(1-106), 6-7-2011)  
Secs. 2-557—2-565. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURES 
 
Sec. 2-566. - Instituting administrative adjudication proceedings. 
(a)  Any authorized department or agency of the Village may institute an administrative adjudication proceeding with the office of administrative adjudication by forwarding a copy of a notice of violation or a notice of hearing, which has been properly served, to the office of administrative adjudication, which office shall coordinate hearing dates from the various departments and agencies. 
(b)  Respondents shall be served with a copy of the written sworn pleading or complaint along with a notice of adjudicatory hearing in any manner reasonably calculated to give them actual notice of the proceeding instituted against them, including: 
(1)  Personal service upon a party or its employees or agents; 
(2)  Service by certified mail return receipt requested at the party's address; 
(3)  Service by first class mail postage prepaid at the party's address; or 
(4)  Service by posting a copy of the sworn pleading or complaint upon the property where the violation is found when the party is the owner or manager of the property. 
(c)  Notices of the adjudicatory hearing shall include: 
(1)  The type and nature of the ordinance violation to be adjudicated; 
(2)  The date and location of the adjudicatory hearing; 
(3)  The legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held; and 
(4)  The penalties for failure to appear at the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-101), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-567. - Subpoenas. 
(a)  An administrative hearing officer may issue a subpoena only if he or she determines that the testimony of the witnesses or the documents or items sought by the subpoena are necessary to present evidence that it: 
(1)  Is relevant to the case; and 
(2)  Relates to a contested issue in the case. 
(b)  A subpoena issued under this article shall identify: 
(1)  The person to whom it is directed; 
(2)  The documents or other items sought by the subpoena, if any; 
(3)  The date for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena; 
(4)  The time for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena; and 
(5)  The place for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena. 
(c)  In no event shall the date identified for the appearance of the witnesses or the production of the documents or other items be less than seven days after service of the subpoena. 
(d)  Within three business days of being served with a subpoena issued in accordance with this article, the recipient of the subpoena may contest the order authorizing the issuance of the subpoena to the administrative hearing officer, setting forth in detail the recipient's objections to the subpoena. Upon receipt of the contest to the subpoena, the administrative hearing officer shall review the objections and, upon review, enter the appropriate order. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-102), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-568. - Representation at hearings. 
(a)  The case for the Village may be presented by any Village employee or by an attorney designated by the Village. 
(b)  The case for the respondent may be presented by the respondent, any agent of the respondent or an attorney. An agent shall present a written authorization signed by the respondent giving the agent power to act and to bind the respondent to any orders entered by the administrative hearing officer. An attorney who appears on behalf of any person shall file with the administrative hearing officer a written appearance on a form provided by the adjudication administrator for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-103), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-569. - Conduct of hearings. 
(a)  The administrative hearing officer shall conduct the hearings in an orderly manner and insist upon proper decorum by all persons present at the hearings. The intent of the hearings is to provide the Village and the respondent with full and fair presentation of the issues. 
(b)  All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation, which shall be administered by the administrative hearing officer. Parties may present witnesses and cross-examine opposing witnesses. 
(c)  The hearing officer may issue subpoenas to secure the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of relevant documents; provided, however, that a respondent who appears by an attorney shall not be compelled to attend the hearing and may submit his or her testimony, if any, by affidavit. In addition, the witnesses who have not been subpoenaed to attend the hearing may submit their testimony, if any, by affidavit. 
(d)  No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of the evidence; provided, however, that a violation notice, or a copy thereof, issued in accordance with this article, shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts specified therein. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-104), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-570. - Hearing testimony. 
The strict laws of evidence shall not apply. Hearsay testimony may be admitted and relied upon by the administrative hearing officer in making his or her determination. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-105), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-571. - Documentary evidence. 
Relevant documents may be received into evidence without formal proof of authenticity. The administrative hearing officer shall determine the weight, if any, to be afforded documents received into evidence. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-106), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-572. - Transcript of proceedings. 
Either party may request that the proceedings be taken and transcribed by a certified court reporter. The cost of the reporter shall be borne by the party requesting the reporter. The Village may, at its cost, tape record the proceedings. If a tape recording is made, a respondent may obtain a transcript at respondent's cost. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-107), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-573. - Continuances. 
All administrative law proceedings shall be conducted on the date set for hearing. For good cause shown, a postponement may be granted in the discretion of the administrative hearing officer. The purpose of administrative law proceedings is to provide a prompt resolution of alleged code violations and, accordingly, the request for and the grant of, continuances shall be curtailed to the extent fairness permits. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-108), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-574. - Hearing—Determination of liability or of no liability—Petition to set aside. 
(a)  Upon conclusion of a hearing under this article, the administrative hearing officer shall issue a written determination of no liability or of liability in the amount of the fine for the relevant violation as provided in the Code, and the basis therefor. 
(b)  If a person fails to respond to the violation notice and opportunity for the administrative hearing and fails to appear, a determination of liability shall be entered against the respondent pursuant to this article. Such determination shall become final for purposes of judicial review under the Illinois Administrative Review Act upon the denial or, the expiration of the time in which to file a timely petition to set aside the determination as provided in this article. 
(c)  Within 14 days from the issuance of a determination of liability pursuant to this division, the person against whom the determination was entered may petition by submitting a written request to the adjudication administrator to set aside the determination, provided, however, the grounds for the petition shall be limited to: 
(1)  The person not having been the owner or lessee of the cited property or vehicle on the date the violation notice was first issued; 
(2)  The person having already paid the fine or penalty for the violation in question; 
(3)  The person stating he or she never received the notice; or 
(4)  Excusable failure, based upon criteria established by the administrative hearing officer, to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. 
(d)  The adjudication administrator shall set a hearing date on the petition and provide written notice of that date to the petitioner. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-109), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-575. - Final determination. 
A final determination of liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine and/or penalty after the administrative hearing officer's determination of violation liability, and the exhaustion of or failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures, including denial of a timely petition to set aside or failing to file the set aside petition within 21 days of the determination. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-110), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-576. - Notice of final determination. 
If any fine or penalty is owing and unpaid after a determination of liability under this Code has become final, and the respondent has exhausted or failed to exhaust judicial procedures for review, the adjudication administrator shall cause a notice of final determination of liability to be sent to the respondent in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-111), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-577. - Enforcement of judgment. 
(a)  Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the Illinois Administrative Review Act are a debt due and owing the Village and may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the Illinois Administrative Review Act may be sought for a final determination of an ordinance violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the findings, decision, and order of the administrative hearing officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  In any case in which a respondent has failed to comply with a judgment ordering that respondent correct an ordinance violation or imposing any fine or other sanction as a result of an ordinance violation, any expenses incurred by the Village to enforce the judgment entered against that respondent, including, but not limited to, attorney's fees, court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer, shall be a debt due and owing the Village and may be collected in accordance with applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by the administrative hearing officer pursuant to this subsection (c), the Village shall provide a notice to the respondent that states that the respondent shall appear at a hearing before the administrative hearing officer to determine whether the respondent has failed to comply with the judgment. The notice shall set the date for such hearing, which shall not be less than seven days from the date that notice is served. If notice is served by mail, the seven-day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was deposited in the mail. 
(d)  Upon being recorded in the manner required by Article XII of the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure (735 ILCS 5/12-101, et seq.), or by the Uniform Commercial Code (810 ILCS 5/1-101, et seq.), a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the respondent in the amount of any debt due and owing the Village under this chapter. The lien may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(e)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the Village manager, or his/her designee, may petition the administrative hearing officer to request the vacation of any final judgment and dismiss any administrative hearing action following final judgment or otherwise decline to pursue collection of any fine when the Village manager determines: 
(1)  That any such judgment was erroneously entered; 
(2)  That any such judgment previously entered is uncollectible; or 
(3)  That the party against whom such judgment was entered is in fact the wrong party in interest. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-112), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-578. - Compliance bond. 
In order to ensure that code violations are remedied or fines are paid in a timely manner, an administrative hearing officer, upon issuing a final determination of liability, may require a code violator to post with the Village a compliance bond or, as appropriate, to consent to the granting and recording of a lien against titled property. Bonds and liens shall be approved by the Village manager as to form and amount. Whenever it is necessary for the Village to make repairs or otherwise expend funds relating to a code violation for which a bond was posted, or whenever fines or costs remain unpaid after a code violator has exhausted or failed to exhaust judicial review procedures, the administrative hearing officer may, after giving the parties notice and opportunity to be heard, issue an order permitting the Village to draw against the bond in an appropriate amount, or to foreclose on the lien. The administrative hearing officer shall order the bond or the titled property or proceeds from the titled property, less the costs incurred by the Village, returned to the code violator upon proof of compliance with the applicable code provisions and the payment of applicable fines or costs. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-112), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-579. - Violations of orders. 
Any person, having received notice and an opportunity for a hearing as provided in this Code, who knowingly fails to comply with an order issued by an administrative hearing officer under this article, including the issuance of a subpoena, shall, if the order is not stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction prior to its effective date, be guilty of contempt. Contempt shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $500.00 for each offense. Each day that the violation continues shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. In a prosecution under this section, it shall not be a defense that a person came into compliance with an order, sought judicial review of it, or made efforts to comply with an order, subsequent to its effective date. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-113), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-580. - Fines payable to the finance department. 
All fines and other monies paid to the Village in accordance with this article shall be remitted to the finance department. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-114), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-581. - Election of remedies. 
In no case may the office of administrative adjudication conduct an administrative adjudication proceeding for an alleged violation of this Code where the requested remedy is a punishment of imprisonment. Nothing in this article, however, shall preclude the Village from seeking the remedy of imprisonment in a court of law, including imprisonment for failure to comply with the order of an administrative hearing officer, pursuant to section 2-576 herein. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-115), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-582. - Administrative adjudication procedures not exclusive. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, neither the authority of the office of administrative adjudication to conduct administrative adjudication procedures nor the institution of such procedures under this article shall preclude the Village from seeking any remedies for code violations through the use of any other administrative procedure or court proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-116), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-583. - Other provisions not limiting. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code, all provisions of the Code, except for those specified in subsection (c) hereof, may be enforced by instituting an administrative adjudication proceeding with the office of administration adjudication as provided in this article. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code, any enforcement action, including but not limited to, license suspension or revocation, which may be exercised by another department or agency of the Village may also be exercised by the office of administrative adjudication. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall affect the jurisdiction of the Village liquor license commission, firefighters pension fund, police pension fund, the zoning board of appeals, or the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-117), 6-7-2011)  
Sec. 2-584. - Judicial review. 
Any final determination by an administrative hearing officer shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Act, 735 ILCS 5/3-101, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 5454, § 2(2-118), 6-7-2011)  
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— At the direction of the Village, as a part of Supp. No. 19, ch. 6 was amended in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former ch. 6 pertained to similar subject matter. 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; driving while under the influence of alcohol, other drugs, intoxicating compounds or any combination thereof, § 90-41. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
The provisions of section 1-2 and the definitions in the Liquor Control Act of 1934, 235 ILCS 5/1-2, et seq. (the "Act"), apply to this chapter. The following definitions also apply to this chapter and in the event of a conflict between section 1-2 or the Act and any of the following definitions, the following definitions shall prevail: 
Agent of licensee means any owner, partner, director, officer, manager, and employee or authorized agent of a licensee but only while engaged in the business of such licensee or present on the licensed premises of such licensee. 
Applicant means any person, whether an individual, partnership or co-partnership, corporation or clubs who submits a written application to the local liquor control commissioner for one or more alcoholic liquor licenses. 
Keg means any original package container capable of holding more than three gallons of beer. 
Licensed premises means the place or location described in a local liquor license where alcoholic liquor is allowed to be stored, displayed or offered for sale. Not included are sidewalks, streets, parking areas and grounds adjacent to any such place or location unless expressly authorized in the applicable license. 
Licensee means a person holding a local liquor license. 
Minor means a person under the age of 21 years. 
Movie theater means any building to which the public is invited and pays consideration for the purpose of viewing motion pictures. Such premises may also broadcast via live video feed special performances. However, the main function of the theater shall be the presentation of motion pictures rated by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) or similar commercial film industry organization, or would otherwise meet such ratings standards based on content. 
Movie theater auditorium means that portion, or those portions, of a movie theater where patrons are seated for the actual viewing of motion pictures. 
Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals are actually and regularly served, such space being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for patrons. 
Sale of keg means any sale of beer in a keg, even though the keg is to be returned by the purchaser to the seller. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 5901, § 2, 4-21-2015)  
Sec. 6-2. - Additional regulations not prohibited. 
Nothing in this chapter shall excuse or release the owner, proprietor or person in charge of any licensed premises in the Village where alcoholic beverages are sold from the restrictions and requirements of any other provisions of this chapter or of the ordinances of the Village or of State or Federal statutes. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-3. - State law adopted. 
The Act, as amended, and the rules and regulations issued by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission as the same may, from time to time, be amended are hereby adopted by reference. In the event of a conflict between such Act and/or regulations and this chapter, this chapter shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-4. - Local liquor control commissioner. 
(a)  The Village president shall be the local liquor control commissioner for the Village (the "Commissioner") and shall be charged with the administration of the provisions of this chapter. The Commissioner may appoint deputies to assist in the administration of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The Commissioner shall exercise the following powers, functions and duties with respect to licensing of other than distillers, brewers, rectifiers, railroads and airplanes: 
(1)  Issue local licenses to qualified persons for premises in the Village. 
(2)  Issue renewal licenses on an annual basis to qualified licensees. 
(3)  Suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to this article for any violation of any provision of this chapter, or for any violation of any State law pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor, or for failure to promptly pay any installment of the license fee upon the date on which such fee is due. 
(4)  Enter upon, or authorize law enforcement personnel to so enter, for the purpose of determining whether any provisions of this chapter or any rules or regulations promulgated by him or by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission have been or are being violated and at such time, to examine the premises of the licensee involved. 
(5)  Act upon any valid complaint from any citizen that any provision of this chapter or any rules or regulations is being violated by any local licensee. 
(6)  Receive local license fees and forward same forthwith to the Village treasurer for proper deposit and accounting. 
(7)  Extend, by written order, closing hours upon occasion for good cause, as follows: 
a.  A class A license holder shall be entitled to sell alcoholic liquor for two hours beyond the normal closing hour on two different days per year. The license holder has the privilege of choosing the dates when he desires to utilize such two late closings by written notification to the Commissioner of such dates, delivered at least two weeks prior to such late closing or early opening dates. 
(8)  Permit, by written order, without payment of license or fee, the serving of alcoholic beverages for a fee or without charge for no more than 13 hours on unlicensed premises when such activity is secondary to a fund raising event sponsored by a nonprofit, charitable organization; application must be made in writing to the Commissioner at least two weeks prior to the event; unless the alcohol is served by a licensed caterer, the host shall provide evidence of dram shop insurance to the Commissioner with the application. 
(9)  Permit, by written order, the serving or giving of alcoholic beverages without charge by for-profit entities for events which are open to the public such as, but not limited to, grand openings, product introductions, anniversary celebrations, celebrity visitations, and similar public relations functions. Application must be made in writing to the Commissioner at least two weeks prior to the event. No for-profit entity may host more than three events in any calendar year. Unless the alcohol is served by a licensed caterer, the host shall provide evidence of dram shop insurance to the Commissioner with the application. 
(10)  Permit, by written order, a Class C or G licensee under this chapter to conduct wine or beer tasting events, wherein the donation of wine or beer in small and limited amounts is offered by such licensee for tasting purposes and immediate consumption on the premises, but only in conjunction with sales promotional efforts or educational programs within the premises of such licensee, and authorized and sponsored by such licensee ("Tasting Events"). Tasting Events shall be subject to the following conditions and limitations: 
a.  The licensee shall submit a request in writing to the Commissioner for permission to conduct Tasting Events. The Commissioner may issue a written order granting permission to conduct Tasting Events (the "Order") at his or her sole discretion, including taking into account the licensee's past conduct and the licensee having an area sufficient to conduct Tasting Events. The Order shall provide permission for Tasting Events for a period of the lesser of: 
1.  Twelve months; 
2.  The time remaining on the licensee's current license; or 
3.  any lesser period of time deemed appropriate by the Commissioner; 
b.  The Tasting Event shall be attended and supervised by a full-time employee of the licensee, servers must be BASSET certified and in compliance with section 6-39, and the Tasting Event shall only be held in a designated area on the licensed premises as approved by the Commissioner and designated in the Order; 
c.  The actual amount of wine or beer sampled shall not exceed the limits set forth in Section 6-31(a) of the Liquor Control Act; 
d.  The sampling shall be served in a container that shall be disposed of immediately following the sampling; and 
e.  The Commissioner may revoke the order should the licensee violate any of the foregoing provisions or if the licensee's license is suspended, revoked or terminated in any manner. 
(11)  Impose conditions on local licenses as set forth in a duly adopted resolution by the president and board of trustees. 
(12)  Conduct hearings in accordance with applicable State law for purposes of fulfilling any of the foregoing powers, functions and duties; provided, however, that all such hearings shall be on a record prepared by a certified court reporter or certified shorthand reporter. The licensee shall be responsible for all fees associated with such hearings as provided in section 6-33. 
(c)  If, in a liquor license violation hearing before the Commissioner, the person is found guilty, such person shall be subject to the general penalty provided in section 1-16, as well as the penalties set forth in section 6-5. 
(d)  All appeals to the State liquor control commission by a Village liquor licensee of a decision, order or action by the Commissioner or designee having the effect of fining the licensee and/or suspending or revoking the Village liquor license shall be limited to review of the official record of the formal proceedings before the Commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 5891, § 2, 2-3-2015)  
Sec. 6-5. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Unless provided otherwise in this chapter, the Village President may suspend or revoke any liquor licensee's license for any violation of any provision of this chapter or for any violation of the Act or other any State law pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  If, in a liquor license violation hearing before the Commissioner, the person is found guilty, such person shall be subject to the general penalty provided in section 1-16, as well as the fees and costs set forth in subsection 6-33(c). 
(c)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as provided in subsection (a), as well as the general penalty provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-6. - Intoxicated persons. 
(a)  Public drunkenness. No person shall be drunk or in a State of intoxication on any street, avenue or public place, to the disturbance of any other person. 
(b)  Sales prohibited. No licensee, and no agent of any licensee, shall sell, give or deliver any alcoholic liquor to any person who is, or who appears to be, intoxicated. 
(c)  Secondary transfer prohibited. No person after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to any person who is, or who appears to be, intoxicated. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-7. - Persons under 21 years of age obtaining liquor by false pretenses. 
Any person under 21 years of age who shall obtain from any establishment licensed under this chapter, or from his agent or servant any intoxicating liquor, under false pretense of being then of age, shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-8. - Sales and service to and employment of underage persons. 
(a)  No licensee, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years, or any intoxicated person or any person known by him to be an habitual drunkard or mentally deficient. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of 21 years, except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any person under the age of 21 for whom he may be the parent or guardian to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(c)  The minimum age to draw, pour, mix or sell any alcoholic liquor in any licensed retail premises or to be employed as a bartender therein shall be 21 years. The minimum age to serve any alcoholic liquor in any licensed retail premises shall be 18 years. 
(d)  No licensee, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall suffer or permit any person under the age of 21 years to be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining, adjacent to or situated in the room or place where such licensed premises is located, provided that this subsection shall not apply to any person under the age of 21 years on any licensed premises which derives its principal business from services or other commodities other than alcoholic liquor. It shall be unlawful for the parent or guardian of any person under the age of 21 years to knowingly permit, sanction, allow, suffer or authorize such child or ward to violate any provision of this chapter. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant of any premises located within the Village to knowingly allow or permit any person under the age of 21 years to remain on such premises while consuming alcoholic liquor thereon or while in possession of alcoholic liquor in violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to draw, pour or mix any alcoholic liquor in any licensed retail premises or otherwise to tend bar therein. In addition to all other fines and penalties, the president may suspend or revoke the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-9. - Purchase or acceptance of gifts of liquor by persons of non-age; identification cards; warnings. 
(a)  Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age shall not purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor, or have alcoholic liquor in his possession. 
(b)  If a licensee or his agent or employee believes, or has reason to believe, that a sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification, containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties. For the purposes of this section, "positive identification" means a document issued by a federal, State, county or municipal government, including by not limited to, a motor vehicle Operator's license, a registration certificate issued under the Federal Selective Service Act, an Illinois Identification Card, or an identification card issued to a member of the armed forces. 
(c)  No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification card; use the identification card of another; carry or use a false or forged identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false information. No person shall purchase, accept the delivery of or have the possession of alcoholic liquor in violation of this section. 
(d)  In every tavern or other place in the Village where alcoholic liquor is sold there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place a printed card which shall be supplied by the Village and which shall read substantially as follows: 
"Warning to all persons under the age of 21 years. You are subject to a fine up to $500.00 under the ordinances of the Village of Glenview if you purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor or have alcoholic liquor in your possession, or if you have in your possession a false, forged, altered or defaced identification card which misrepresents your age." 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-10. - Loitering on licensed premises. 
Each liquor licensee licensed under this chapter shall post signs in two conspicuous places on or about the licensed premises stating that it is unlawful for any one or more persons in the possession of alcoholic liquor, whether packaged or not, to congregate or remain within 300 feet of the licensed premises, unless otherwise permitted by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-11. - Obligations of purchasers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any one or more persons in the possession of alcoholic liquor, whether packaged or not, to congregate or remain within 300 feet of an establishment selling or offering to sell alcoholic liquor, whether packaged or not. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume alcoholic liquor in the parking area adjacent to any restaurant, tavern, liquor store, club or other business where alcoholic liquor is sold, or in any public way, whether or not adjacent to a business establishment that sells or offers to sell alcoholic liquor, whether packaged or not. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-12. - Use of alcohol in public parks. 
Consumption of alcohol in any park is prohibited. Violators shall be subject to the general penalty provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-13. - Village officials; manufacture or sale of liquor. 
The Village president or any member of the Village Board shall have no interest in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor in the Village, except as otherwise permitted by 235 ILCS 5/6-2(14). 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
ARTICLE II. - RETAIL ESTABLISHMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 6-14. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a class A, B, D, F, or H license holder to sell or offer for sale alcoholic beverages in the Village between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on each day of the week, except that on Sunday, the closing hours shall be from 2:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. Licenses which held Class B licenses as of January 1, 2008, and are in good standing as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, shall be permitted to maintain their existing hours of operation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a class C and G license holder to sell or offer for sale at retail any alcoholic liquor in the Village between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  All customers must be cleared from the premises of all licensed establishments in accordance with the hours set forth in this section for the cessation of sale of alcoholic beverages where the license permits consumption on the premises, provided, however, that other business or social functions of a retail store in which the sale of alcohol liquor is secondary, hotel, club or motel establishment may continue beyond such hours, provided that no alcoholic beverages are sold or served to the public, patrons, employees and/or the membership during such hours. The alcoholic beverage preparation areas shall be closed and secured in advance of the closing hours during which service of alcohol is prohibited and no service provided thereafter to ensure full and complete cessation of the prohibited activity for the applicable license. Cleaning and management personnel employed by the licensee may continue to be present upon the premises to perform assigned duties and responsibilities including, but not limited to, cleaning of the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 5121, § 2, 7-15-2008)  
Sec. 6-15. - Doors, etc. 
All doors and entryways provided for public use to the premises licensed under this article shall remain open and unlocked while customers of the licensed establishment remain within the premises. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-16. - Sanitary conditions. 
All premises used for the retail sale or storage for sale of alcoholic beverages shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be maintained in full compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter and other Village ordinances regulating the conditions or premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-17. - Health of retail establishment employees. 
No person, while affected with a disease in a communicable form that can be transmitted by foods or who is a carrier of organisms that cause such a disease or while afflicted with a boil, or infected wound, or an acute respiratory infection, shall work in a food service establishment in any capacity in which there is a likelihood of such person contaminating food or food-contact surfaces with pathogenic organisms or transmitting disease to other persons. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-18. - Sale of kegs. 
(a)  A licensee who sells a keg shall affix to each keg sold a tag, furnished by the liquor control commissioner, containing an identification number enabling the purchaser to be identified in accordance with subsection 6-18(b). 
(b)  The licensee shall keep a logbook of all kegs sold, showing the identification number on the tag affixed to each keg, and the purchaser's name, address, telephone number, driver's license/state identification number, date of birth, and signature. The logbook shall be available for inspection by the Village police department during normal business hours. 
(c)  The licensee shall require the purchaser to deposit, at the time of the sale of a keg, at least $70.00 for sale of a keg with pumper and at least $20.00 for sale of a keg without a pumper. The deposit shall be refunded only upon the return of the keg with the tag properly affixed. Only one deposit fee will be required from a purchaser of more than one keg at any one time. 
(d)  The licensee shall require the purchaser, at the time of the sale, to sign a form to be provided by the liquor control commissioner, setting forth the provisions of this section and informing the purchaser that the deposit will be forfeited if the keg is not returned with the tag properly affixed. The licensee shall retain this form for 90 days after the sale. 
(e)  Any keg not returned with the tag properly affixed within 60 days following the date of sale shall be considered lost, and the deposit shall be forfeited. The licensee shall notify the Village police department on a monthly basis of all deposits that are forfeited. 
(f)  A licensee may retain the forfeited deposit. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful to possess a keg within the Village which does not have a proper tag affixed or, if the keg was purchased outside the Village, without proof of purchase for the keg, including the name and address of the seller. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-19. - Additional business licenses. 
All liquor licensees shall be required to maintain a valid business license in the Village. The fee for such license shall be established by the Village in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 6-20. - Required.
