No. 5937, § 2, 11-17-2015; Ord. No. 5980, § 4, 4-19-2016; Ord. No. 6144, § 6, 1-2-2018; Ord. No. 6153, § 3, 3-6-2018; Ord. No. 6161, § 2, 6-5-2018; Ord. No. 6260, § 2, 6-18-2019)  
Secs. 6-25, 6-26. - Reserved.  
Sec. 6-27. - Location near churches, schools, etc. 
(a)  No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within 100 feet of any building primarily devoted to religious worship, a school other than an institution of higher learning, a hospital, a home for aged or indigent persons or veterans, their spouses or children, or any military or naval station, provided that such prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs or restaurants, food shops or other places where the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business carried on; nor to the renewal of a license for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on a premises within 100 feet of any church or school where the church or school has been established within such 100 feet since the issuance of the original license. The distance of 100 feet shall be measured from the property boundaries of the applicant's premises to the property boundaries of the building used primarily for religious worship, school other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for aged or indigent persons or veterans, their spouses or children, or any military or naval station. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the issuance of a license to a church or private school to sell at retail alcoholic beverages if any such sales are limited to periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages as provided by subsection 6-4(b)(9), such sale complies with that section and all other applicable sections of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-28. - Requirements for restaurant and club licenses. 
No person shall receive a license to sell alcoholic beverages upon any premises as a restaurant or as a club unless the licensed premise complies with the definitions of those terms as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-29. - Examination of applicant. 
(a)  The local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the right to examine, under oath, any applicant for an alcoholic beverage license or for a renewal thereof, or any person who must qualify for an alcoholic beverage license on behalf of an applicant or licensee, or any licensee upon whom notice or revocation or suspension has been served in the manner hereinafter provided; to examine, or cause to be examined, the books and records of any such applicant, person, or licensee; to hear testimony and take proof for his information in the performance of his duties. The Commissioner shall have the authority to issue subpoenas for such purpose which shall be effective in any part of the State and to authorize an agent to act in his behalf in obtaining the information desired. 
(b)  The local Liquor Control Commissioner, or his authorized agent, may require any persons involved in an application for an alcoholic beverage license to be fingerprinted and investigated by the police department for the purpose of verifying individual qualifications for such license. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-30. - Supplemental applications. 
If the information provided pursuant to this article by any applicant, licensee, or person who must qualify for an alcoholic beverage license on behalf of an applicant or licensee should change or become incomplete or inapplicable, the applicant or licensee shall, within 60 days, supplement the information in his alcoholic beverage application so that the information remains correct and complete. The applicant or licensee shall pay a supplemental application fee in an amount equal to one-half of the annual license fee. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-31. - Notice of application receipt; objections; hearings; appeals. 
Upon receipt of an application for license for a liquor license, the liquor Commissioner shall cause to be mailed to the owners of all adjacent properties two lots deep in all directions a written notice of receipt of an application for a liquor license. Such written notice shall specify the name and address of the applicant and the license classification applied for, and advise the adjacent owners of the time, date and location that the board of trustees will consider the application and make a recommendation to the liquor Commissioner. The decision of the liquor Commissioner will be final. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-32. - Death of licensee. 
(a)  In the event of the death of a person holding a liquor license during the period in which such license is in effect, a liquor license may, subject to all other provisions of this chapter, be issued to a person who is the father, mother, brother, sister, husband, wife, son or daughter of the licensee, for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor at the premises designated in such decedent's license, and thereafter, such licensee shall enjoy all the privileges appurtenant to the decedent's license. 
(b)  In the event any one of the licenses provided for shall lapse, be revoked or terminated in any manner, the board of trustees may reduce the maximum number of such licenses. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-33. - Fees. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  The fees for alcoholic beverage licenses shall be as established in section 30-1. Any applicant who has not previously been issued a liquor license by the Village under this section shall pay a pro-rated portion of the fees established in section 30-1 based on the number of full months that the applicant is licensed in the first calendar year, and thereafter the annual license fees shall be as established in section 30-1. 
(c)  Every licensee who is requested to appear before the Commissioner shall be subject to a non-refundable hearing fee in the amount established in the annual fee ordinance, plus the actual cost, as hereinafter defined, incurred by the Village in conducting such hearing. For the purpose of calculating the additional, "actual cost" fee due pursuant to this subsection, the actual costs incurred by the Village in conducting a hearing before the Commissioner shall be deemed to include, without limitation, the following items of direct and indirect expense: 
(1)  Court reporter (direct cost). 
(2)  Administrative preparation and review (hourly salary times a multiplier to be established from time to time by the Village manager at a level sufficient to recover 100 percent of the direct and indirect cost of such service). 
(3)  Document preparation and review (hourly salary times a multiplier to be established from time to time by the Village manager at a level sufficient to recover 100 percent of the direct and indirect cost of such service). 
(4)  Legal review, consultation and advice (direct cost). 
(5)  Copy reproduction (direct cost). 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 5162, § 2, 11-18-2008; Ord. No. 5269, § 2, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 5285, § 3, 12-8-2009)  
Sec. 6-34. - Personal privilege; refund of fees; renewals. 
(a)  A license issued under this article shall be purely a personal privilege to expire on the next December 31 following the issuance thereof, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or be subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. In the event of the death of a person holding a liquor license during the period in which such license is in effect, a liquor license may, subject to all other provisions of this chapter, be issued to a person who is the father, mother, brother, sister, husband, wife, son or daughter of the licensee, for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor at the premises designated in such decedent's license, and thereafter, such licensee shall enjoy all the privileges appurtenant to the decedent's license until the expiration of the license. Such license shall not descend by the laws of the State or intestate devolution, but except as provided above, it shall cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license, but no longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such license in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. No other refund of license fees paid shall be made. 
(b)  Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided, he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purpose, and, provided further, that the renewal privilege provided for in this subsection shall not be construed as a vested right which shall, in any case, prevent the president from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within the jurisdiction. 
(c)  Except as may be provided in this section as to the bankruptcy of a licensee, any sale, transfer or assignment of more than 50 percent of the outstanding shares of a corporation holding any license shall terminate such license, and the initial license issued to the same named corporation shall be subject to a payment of fee for an initial license as provided in section 6-33. 
(d)  Except as may be provided in this section as to the bankruptcy, insolvency or death of a licensee, any sale, transfer or assignment of any copartner or copartner's interest in any license held by a co-partnership, where such copartner or copartner's interest being so transferred exceeds 50 percent of the total partnership, shall terminate such license, and the initial license issued to the new co-partnership shall be subject to a payment of a fee for an initial license as provided in subsection (d); provided, however, that a transfer of interest to a father, mother, brother, sister, husband, wife, son or daughter shall not be deemed to be a sale, transfer or assignment under the provisions of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-35. - Reserved.  
Sec. 6-36. - Change of location. 
A retail dealer's liquor license shall permit the sale of alcoholic beverages only on the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be changed only upon formal permission issued by the local liquor control Commissioner. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages under the laws of this State, this chapter and the ordinances of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-37. - Display. 
Every licensee shall cause his current alcoholic beverage license to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-38. - Special conditions for all licenses. 
Every alcoholic beverage license shall be subject to such conditions and restrictions of operation as the Commissioner, with approval of a majority of the board of trustees, may deem necessary and appropriate in connection with the public health, safety and welfare. Any such conditions and restrictions shall be approved by a resolution duly adopted by the board of trustees, which resolution shall be incorporated by reference into the license itself by the local liquor control Commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Sec. 6-39. - Training requirements for beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and training program (BASSET). 
(a)  For the purposes of this section and this chapter, the term "BASSET Program" shall mean and refer to a State certified Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers Education Training Program (BASSET) or its equivalent, meeting the minimum curriculum requirements of Title 77, Part 3500 of the Illinois Administrative Code. 
(b)  With respect to all classes of liquor licenses described in section 6-23 except for Class E licenses (collectively for purposes of this section, "Licenses"), all new managers and all persons who sell or serve open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail and anyone whose job description entails the checking of identification for the purchase of open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail or for entry into the licensed premises (collectively for purposes of this section, "Alcohol Servers") shall be required to complete a BASSET program by July 1, 2015, or within 120 days after the Alcohol Server begins his or her employment, whichever comes later, unless previously issued a valid server training certificate by a certified BASSET trainer between July 1, 2012, and July 1, 2015. Verification of completion of a BASSET program by all applicable personnel shall be maintained on file by the licensee and submitted by that licensee along with the next application for annual license renewal. 
(c)  All applicants for renewal of licenses shall submit proof of completion of a BASSET program by the manager of the licensed premises and all Alcohol Servers at the licensed premises. 
(d)  All applicants for licenses shall be required to submit, within 90 days after issuance of the initial license, proof of completion of a BASSET program by the manager of the licensed premises and all Alcohol Servers. If at such time any Alcohol Servers have not yet completed their BASSET training in accordance with subsection (b), the licensee shall submit such proof of training as soon as it is completed. 
(e)  Failure of a licensee to: 
(1)  Require its manager and all Alcohol Servers to complete a BASSET program as required by this section or to renew his or her BASSET training certificate upon its expiration; 
(2)  Maintain records of such completion; or 
(3)  Submit evidence of such completion when requested or required to do so, shall be cause for any one or more of the following: 
a.  Denial of an application for, or renewal of, licenses; 
b.  Imposition of a fine; 
c.  Suspension or revocation of licenses; and 
d.  Other action taken by the Commissioner as provided in section 6-5. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 5892, § 2, 2-3-2015)  
Sec. 6-40. - Alcoholic beverage sales cash register requirements. 
Any class "G" license whose primary business is not the retail sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption off premises shall be required to utilize persons over the age of 21 (who have completed a BASSET training program as stated in section 6-39) to effect the sale of alcoholic beverages. The sales may be made at any cash register. In instances where the licensee is using persons under the age of 21 to staff cash registers, an adult that has completed its BASSET training program must be called to the cash register to handle the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 5089, § 2, 4-1-2008)  
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; amusement tax, § 70-101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Public place of amusement means and includes any building, space, room or enclosure to which the public may be admitted, with or without the payment of an admission fee or charge of any kind or character, where the public may engage in or witness the performance of any amateur theatrical entertainment, any exhibit, show, amusement, cabaret entertainment, whether musical or otherwise, or any dance or skating, either of patrons or other persons. 
(Code 1959, § 16.1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-2. - License required. 
No person, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent of any restaurant or public place of refreshment, whether an admission fee is charged or not, shall give, conduct, produce, present or offer any cabaret or other entertainment therein without having first obtained the license required for public places of amusement as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 16.2)  
Sec. 10-3. - License application; issuance. 
(a)  The application for a license to conduct a place of public amusement within the Village shall be made to the president of the Village, setting forth the full name of the applicant, the members of the firm, if the applicant shall be such, and if a society, club or corporation, the full names and residences of the principal officers of such society, club or corporation, and a description of the place where it is proposed to conduct such place of amusement, and a description of the kind and class of entertainment the applicant proposes to give and the seating capacity of such place. 
(b)  Upon such application being made, the president shall make, or cause to be made, an investigation, and if, upon such investigation, he shall be of the opinion that the applicant is or are persons of good moral character and proper and suitable persons to be so licensed, and that the premises where such amusement is to be held are suitable for the purpose for which a license is desired, and in proper sanitary condition, he shall report such findings to the board of trustees, which may thereupon approve the issuance of such license, which shall entitle the licensee to conduct, produce, present, operate and offer the class of entertainment provided in such license at the time described in such application and for the period designated, upon payment of the license fee provided for in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 16.3)  
Sec. 10-4. - Refusal to grant license. 
If the place at which the public amusement is to be held or given shall not be a fit or proper place and not constructed, maintained and operated or conducted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter or any ordinances of the Village governing and controlling such places, including the building code of the Village, or if the amusement or entertainment desired to be produced or offered is of an obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), nature, or will constitute an immediate danger to life or property, or if the applicant for such license shall not be of good moral character, the president and board of trustees may refuse to approve the application, and no license shall be issued by the Village manager. 
(Code 1959, § 16.4)  
Sec. 10-5. - License fees generally. 
The fee to be charged for a license to produce, present, operate and offer any of the amusement places as defined in section 10-1 shall be as provided in chapter 30, provided, however, that the president and board of trustees may grant a term license for any of the amusement places defined in section 10-1 for the specific number of successive days, or for such days as may be designated in the license, at the rate provided in chapter 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 16.5; Ord. No. 5113, § 3, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 10-6. - Additional fees. 
The licensee of any place of public amusement which shall or may be conducted or operated in conjunction with any restaurant or any soft drink or ice cream parlor or any room or place where malted or vinous non-intoxicating beverages, as defined by law, are sold, shall pay, a restaurant or food establishment license fee as provided in chapter 30, in addition to the entertainment license fee as provided in chapter 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 16.6; Ord. No. 5113, § 3, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 10-7. - Reserved.  
Sec. 10-8. - Bond or insurance required. 
No license shall be issued under this article until after the applicant has filed a good and sufficient security or indemnity bond or insurance, guaranteeing that the Village will be held harmless from any and all claims for damages arising out of the exercise of such license or the conduct of the business authorized by the license. The form and content of the bond and the surety thereto shall be subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees. Such security or indemnity bond, or insurance shall cover a liability in the amount of $10,000.00 with respect to each license issued under this article, and, in the case of an insurance policy, shall include a statement to the effect that the issuing company shall not cancel the policy until after ten days' notice to the president and board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 16.8)  
Sec. 10-9. - Closing hours. 
All places of public amusement, except bowling alleys and pool halls, within the Village, shall be closed on or before 1:00 a.m.; provided, however, that upon the application of a bona fide and responsible organization or society, the president is authorized, in his discretion, to grant such organization or society a permit to continue a dance or other amusement specified in this section until 3:00 a.m., provided further, that no tickets shall be sold or accepted for the admission and no persons admitted thereto after 1:00 a.m. 
(Code 1959, § 16.9)  
Sec. 10-10. - Violations; penalties. 
Each violation of this chapter or other laws or ordinances applicable thereto shall be punished as provided in section 1-16, and the president is authorized to revoke the license granted under this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 16.10)  
Secs. 10-11—10-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COIN-OPERATED GAME MACHINES 
 
Sec. 10-41. - License required. 
No licensee shall have on or about his premises any coin-operated game machine without having first secured a license under this chapter.  
Sec. 10-42. - Number permitted. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to have or maintain more than eight coin-operated game machines upon or within a single premises. 
(Code 1959, § 10.95)  
Sec. 10-43. - Acting without license. 
Any person who fails to license coin-operated game machines and/or exceeds the maximum limit per establishment violates this article and is subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 10.96)  
Secs. 10-44—10-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COIN-OPERATED MUSICAL DEVICES 
 
Sec. 10-71. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to locate, install, keep, maintain or use, or permit the location, installation, maintenance or use upon his premises of any automatic, coin-controlled or coin-operated music box or device which furnishes what is commonly referred to as "canned music," without first having obtained a license therefore, and such license shall be issued upon payment of an entertainment license fee as provided in chapter 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 16.13; Ord. No. 5113, § 3, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 10-72. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful to use, or permit the use of, such automatic, coin-controlled or coin-operated music box or device between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays, and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Sundays. 
(Code 1959, § 16.14)  
Sec. 10-73. - Nuisance declared. 
It shall be unlawful to use such coin-controlled musical devices in the Village in a manner which interferes with the health, peace and comfort of any person in the neighborhood thereof, and such use is hereby declared to be nuisance. 
(Code 1959, § 16.15)  
Sec. 10-74. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to any coin-controlled or coin-operated music box or other device furnishing music which is operated in schools or other public buildings. 
(Code 1959, § 16.16)  
Sec. 10-75. - Violations. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16 for each offense, and the license provided for in this article may be revoked by the president. 
(Code 1959, § 16.16)  
Secs. 10-76—10-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BILLIARDS, BOWLING AND SIMILAR AMUSEMENTS 
 
Sec. 10-101. - License required. 
No person shall have or keep for his profit within the Village any billiard or pool table, bowling alley or coin-operated game machine without first obtaining a license therefor, as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 16.17)  
Sec. 10-102. - License fees. 
Every person who shall run for profit billiard and pool tables, bowling alleys or coin-operated game machines shall, upon application to the president and board of trustees for approval thereof, pay an annual entertainment license fee as provided in chapter 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 16.18; Ord. No. 5113, § 3, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 10-103. - Closing hours. 
All bowling alleys, pool halls and public billiard rooms shall be closed on or before 1:00 a.m. each day; and no such establishment shall be open to the public prior to 8:00 a.m. each weekday, except that on Sunday, no such establishment shall be open to the public prior to 12:00 noon. 
(Code 1959, § 16.19)  
Sec. 10-104. - Violations; penalties. 
For each violation of any of the provisions of this article or other laws or ordinances applicable thereto, offenders shall be punished as provided in section 1-16, and the president is authorized to revoke the license granted under this article. 
(Code 1959, § 16.20)  
Secs. 10-105—10-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SHOWS AND OTHER ENTERTAINMENT 
 
Sec. 10-131. - License required; exceptions. 
No person shall give, within the limits of the Village, any show or entertainment for gain within any hall, opera house or building, or under canvas, or in any open space, without first procuring a license to do so, subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16 for each and every violation of this section, provided that, for musical, theatrical, minstrel, school, church or other entertainment given by the citizens of the Village, and who are not engaged in the giving of such entertainment as a business, no license shall be required. Each day such offense shall continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1959, § 16.11)  
Sec. 10-132. - License fees. 
All entertainment held in any hall, opera house or building, or under canvas or other covering, or in any open space, of a dramatic or operatic character, or lectures, public readings, recitations, exhibitions of paintings, statuary or panoramas, performances or any feats of jugglery, sleight of hand, variety, or athletic or public dances, and all other exhibitions, performances and entertainments, including circuses and similar performances not enumerated in this section, shall pay a license fee as provided in chapter 30-1, provided that the president and board of trustees may grant a term license for any of such exhibitions, performances or entertainments for a specific number of successive days or for one or more specific days of successive weeks at such rate as they may determine, which rate shall be the same, more or less than the rate charged for the entertainment license as set forth in chapter 30-1, and, provided further, that the full amount of such term license shall be paid in advance. 
(Code 1959, § 16.12; Ord. No. 5113, § 3, 6-17-2008)  
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Dog kennels, catteries and pet shops, § 22-301 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 38. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal means any living creature with an exoskeleton or vertebrate, such as insects, snakes, fish, birds, reptiles and amphibians, either domesticated or wild, excluding humans. 
Cat means all animals of the feline species, both male and female. 
Dog means all animals of the canine species, both male and female. 
Owner means any person having right of property in a dog, cat or other animal, or who keeps or harbors a dog, cat or other animal, or who has such dog, cat or other animal in his care, or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits a dog, cat or other animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by such person. 
(Code 1959, § 4.8; Ord. No. 5346, § 2, 5-18-2010) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-2. - Running at large. 
It shall be unlawful to permit any dog or dangerous, unruly, fierce or mischievous animal to run at large in the Village at any time. Dogs or dangerous, unruly, fierce or mischievous animals which are on any street, sidewalk, alley, other public place, or on the property of a person other than the owner or keeper thereof, without being held securely on a leash, shall be deemed to be running at large. A dog that is in a marked "dog-friendly" area or dog park is not considered to be running at large if the dog is monitored or supervised by a person, and such "dog-friendly" area or dog park complies with such regulations as may be issued by Cook County for the operation of outdoor off leash areas. 
(Code 1959, § 4.1; Ord. No. 5138, § 2, 9-16-2008)  
Sec. 14-3. - Disturbances. 
No person shall keep any dog, cat or other animal in the Village which, by barking, howling, meowing or other noise, shall disturb the peace and quiet of any family, individual or neighborhood. 
(Code 1959, § 4.2)  
Sec. 14-4. - Dead animals. 
No person shall allow any dead animal, being the owner or keeper thereof, to remain for 12 hours within the Village without being buried. 
(Code 1959, § 4.3) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 58.  
Sec. 14-5. - Cruelty to animals. 
No person shall overload, overwork, cruelly beat, ill treat, torture, mutilate or cruelly kill any animal or allow such to be done. 
(Code 1959, § 4.4)  
Sec. 14-6. - Killing or wounding animals and birds. 
No person shall hunt game or shoot at, kill or wound, by the use of a firearm, bow and arrow, slingshot, blow airgun, pelting with stones or by any other weapon or means, any animal or bird within the Village, or enter upon any private enclosure or public ground in the Village for the purpose of doing any act prohibited in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 4.5)  
Sec. 14-7. - Diseased animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow an animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease to be exposed in any public place whereby the health of a human being or animal may be affected; nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner or person in control of such animal except under the supervision of a veterinarian licensed by the State of Illinois or by the Illinois Department of Agriculture, Animal Welfare Division. 
(b)  It is the duty of the owner or person in control of any diseased animal to secure the disposal of such diseased animal and treatment of the affected premises so as to prevent the communication and spread of contagious or infectious diseases from such animal in conformance with state law and the rules and regulations adopted thereto. 
(Code 1959, § 4.6; Ord. No. 5346, § 3, 5-18-2010)  
Sec. 14-8. - Keeping of swine, poultry, poisonous snakes and boa constrictors. 
No person shall keep, or suffer to be kept, any swine, poultry, poisonous snake or boa constrictor within the Village, except for poisonous snakes or boa constrictors which may be maintained for educational purposes at the Grove National Historic Landmark. 
(Code 1959, § 4.7)  
Sec. 14-9. - Maximum number of animals allowed to be kept. 
(a)  Except for fish which are kept in an aquarium or pool, or bees maintained in a hive, it shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, care for, have custody of or knowingly permit at any time more than ten animals per dwelling unit, including but not limited to any garage, yard or other structure associated with said dwelling unit. Not more than five of such animals shall be dogs and/or cats. 
(b)  The limitations of this section shall not apply to properly established and zoned veterinary hospitals, pet shops, pounds, or animal shelters. 
(Code 1959, § 4.9; Ord. No. 5346, § 4, 5-18-2010)  
Sec. 14-10. - Preventing the spread of rabies. 
The owner of any dog or other animal which exhibits symptoms of rabies, and any dog or other animal in direct contact with such dog or other animal that is known to have bitten a person, until such dog or other animal has been vaccinated, shall immediately notify the director of development and shall promptly confine such dog or other animal, or have it confined, under suitable observation, for a period of at least ten days, unless officially authorized by the director of development or his representative to release such dog or other animal sooner. 
(Code 1959, § 4.17)  
Sec. 14-11. - Nuisances prohibited. 
No person owning, keeping or harboring a dog or cat, or other animal shall permit any offal, fecal matter or noisome substance from such animal to remain on any public or private property in any place in the Village, other than the property of such owner or keeper. 
(Code 1959, § 4.18) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 38-281 et seq.  
Sec. 14-12. - Animals prohibited in food service establishments 
(a)  Live animals, including birds and turtles, shall be excluded from within the food service operational premises and from adjacent areas under the control of the establishment including outdoor dining areas which have been issued permits by the Village. This exclusion does not apply to edible fish, crustacea, shellfish, or to fish in aquariums. Patrol dogs accompanying security or police officers and support animals, e.g. animals, such as canines and primates trained to assist handicapped persons, accompanying such persons shall be permitted in said areas. 
(b)  The Village may post notice to such effect, in conspicuous positions within the food service establish and must not be removed, destroyed or defaced by any person. 
(c)  Nothing in this section, however, shall be deemed to prohibit the owner or proprietor of such an establishment from keeping a watch dog or cat on such premises as long as such dog or cat is barred from access to the rooms in such establishment where food is dispensed or stored. 
(Code 1959, § 4.19; Ord. No. 5346, § 5, 5-18-2010)  
Sec. 14-13. - Removal of excrement. 
No person shall appear with an animal or permit an animal upon the public ways, within public places or upon the property of another, without such other person's consent, without some means for the removal of excrement, nor shall any person fail to remove any excrement deposited by such animal. This section shall not apply to a blind person while walking his guide dog. 
(Code 1959, § 4.21)  
Sec. 14-14. - Training attack dogs or other animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the Village to teach, practice with or otherwise train any dog or other animal to attack or inflict bites on a human being or other animal, unless such training is a part of a recognized licensed business within the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 4.26)  
Sec. 14-15. - Violations; penalties. 
In addition to the impoundment and destruction provisions provided in section 14-101, any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16 for each offense. Each violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 4.23)  
Secs. 14-16—14-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER 
 
Sec. 14-41. - Position created; powers and duties. 
There is hereby created the position of animal control officer within the organization of the police department. The individual filling the position of animal control officer shall be appointed and removed by the chief of police. The animal control officer or his agent, or any officer of the law may: 
(1)  Enter upon private premises to apprehend a stray animal, vicious animal, wild creature or an animal suspected of being infected with rabies; 
(2)  Enter upon private premises to investigate complaints of irresponsibility or inhumane animal care; and 
(3)  Seize, impound or dispose of any vicious animal of any kind when necessary for the protection of any person or property. 
(Code 1959, § 4.24)  
Secs. 14-42—14-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS 
 
Sec. 14-71. - Identification. 
(a)  Every dog or cat, when off the property of the owner, shall wear a collar, attached to which shall be an identification tag which may be issued by the Village or provided by the owner. Such tag shall include the name and address and/or telephone number of the dog's or cat's owner. Every dog or cat shall also wear a serially numbered tag issued by the Cook County Department of Animal and Rabies Control, or similar agency of another county, evidencing the dog's or cat's rabies inoculation in compliance with section 14-73. 
(b)  Identification tags shall be available through the Village. There is no fee for said tag. The identification tag provided will have an identification number for cross reference to an application that contains the name and address of the owner, and the name, sex and breed of the dog or cat, and such other description of the dog or cat, and shall fully identify such animal, and presentation of proof of rabies inoculation as required by section 14-73. Such identification tags shall be successively numbered and shall specify the year for which the dog or cat is registered. The Village shall maintain a register of issued tags which shall contain the information provided in this section. 
(c)  Every dog or cat found in the Village without such collar and identification shall be impounded as provided in this chapter. The owner shall be deemed to be in violation of this chapter and shall be subject to the penalty section as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 4.10; Ord. No. 5113, § 4, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 5346, § 6, 5-18-2010)  
Sec. 14-72. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5346, § 6, adopted May 18, 2010, deleted § 14-72. Former § 14-72 pertained to tags; registration of dogs and cats and derived from Code 1959, § 4.11.  
Sec. 14-73. - Antirabies vaccination required. 
Every dog and cat over four months of age shall be inoculated against rabies. No identification tag shall be issued to the owner of any dog or cat within the corporate limits of the Village unless the owner of such dog or cat shall present, at the time of the making of application for each identification tag, a certificate of a licensed veterinarian that such dog or cat has been, prior to such application, inoculated with an antirabies serum. No such tag shall be issued for any dog or cat if the immunization period certified by the veterinarian has expired prior to the date of the application for a tag. 
(Code 1959, § 4.12; Ord. No. 5113, § 4, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 14-74. - Impoundment of dogs and cats running at large. 
(a)  All dogs, whether wearing a collar with owner identification or not, if found running at large within the Village, are hereby declared a public nuisance which may be summarily abated. The police, or any person that the president of the Village may designate, may take up and impound in any kennel or other place designated by the board of trustees, either within or outside the limits of the Village, any dog, whether wearing a collar with owner identification or not, found running at large within the Village, and any dog or cat which is not wearing a collar with owner identification of the cat or dog attached, along with the serially numbered tag issued by the Cook County Department of Rabies Control, or similar agency of another county, evidencing the dog's or cat's anti-rabies inoculation. If any dog impounded for running at large shall be found wearing a collar with owner identification attached as provided for in this article, the police or other person 
(b)  Any dog or cat impounded under the provisions of this section shall be held in a kennel or other place designated by the board of trustees for a period of not less than five days from the time of such impounding, and if such dog or cat is not redeemed as provided for in this section before the expiration of such five-day period, it shall be the duty of the police or such other designated person to cause such dog or cat to be slain in a humane manner, and to arrange for the removal and burial of such dog or cat; provided, however, that at any time during or at the termination of such initial five days of impoundment, the Village may release such dog or cat to the custody of a not-for-profit corporation established for the purpose of caring for stray or abandoned animals and to reimburse such not-for-profit corporation for the expenses of boarding such dog or cat for no more than five days. Fees incurred for animal impound or animal impound to a kennel shall be as provided in chapter 30-1. 
(c)  Such redemption and other payments shall be made to the Village manager, who shall issue a receipt for such amounts, and, upon presentation of such receipt to the police or other person designated to act in the premises, such dog or cat shall be released and turned over to the person presenting such receipt; provided, however, before such release, the owner must have complied with all the licensing requirements of sections 14-71 and 14-72. 
(Code 1959, § 4.15; Ord. No. 5113, § 4, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 14-75. - Dog, cat and animal bites. 
(a)  Any owner of a dog, cat or other animal which has bitten any person shall promptly notify the animal control officer or his authorized representative and shall immediately confine such dog, cat or other animal in the custody and under the observation of a licensed veterinarian; provided, however, if the owner of the dog, cat or other animal presents a current rabies inoculation certificate, issued by a licensed veterinarian, then such animal may be confined on the premises of its owner and away from the public, by a method designated by the Village manager, so as not to repeat the biting incident, for a period of ten days. The period of observation shall consist of an examination by a licensed veterinarian on the first and tenth day from 24 hours after the time of the bite. 
(b)  If, in the opinion of the animal control officer or his authorized representative, a dog, cat or other animal has bitten a person on the face, he shall have such animal confined for a period of ten days in the custody and under the observation of a licensed veterinarian, whether or not such animal has been vaccinated. All expenses in connection with any confinement and veterinary observation as prescribed in this subsection shall be at the expense of the person owning, keeping or harboring the animal. It is unlawful for the owner of such dog, cat or other animal to sell, give away, kill or otherwise dispose of such dog, cat or other animal that is known to have bitten a person until it has been released by the director of development or his authorized representative. 
(c)  If the death of such dog, cat or animal should occur prior to the final inspection of such animal by the animal control officer or a licensed veterinarian, the owner shall deliver the carcass and the brain of such dog, cat or other animal to the police, who shall deliver it to the county health department. 
(Code 1959, § 4.16; Ord. No. 5346, § 7, 5-18-2010)  
Secs. 14-76—14-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - VICIOUS OR DANGEROUS ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 14-101. - Vicious or dangerous dogs. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the term: 
(1)  Vicious dog means any individual dog: 
a.  That, when unprovoked, inflicts bites or attacks a human being either on public or private property. 
b.  With a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of a human being. 
c.  That has as a trait or characteristic and a generally known reputation for viciousness, dangerousness or unprovoked attacks upon human beings, unless handled in a particular manner or with special equipment. Vicious dogs shall not be classified in a manner that is specific as to breed. 
d.  Which attacks a human being without provocation. 
e.  Which has been found to be a dangerous dog, as defined in this section, on at least one prior occasion. 
No dog shall be deemed vicious if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser on the property of its owner, or harms or menaces any person who has tormented or abused such dog or is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard duties and attacks or causes injury to a person while the dog is performing its duties as trained. If a dog is found to be a vicious dog, the dog shall be subject to enclosure, as defined in subsection (3) of this section, or destruction as may be directed in the sole discretion of the animal control officer in accordance with the provisions of subsection (c)(1) of this section, or destruction as may be ordered by a judge of the circuit court of the County. 
(2)  Dangerous dog means any individual dog which, when either unmuzzled, unleashed or unattended by its owner, handler or keeper, in a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person or domestic animal in an apparent attitude of attack upon any street, sidewalk or public grounds or places, or private property of a person other than the owner, handler or keeper of the dog. 
(3)  Enclosure means a fence or structure of a least six feet in height, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner, handler or keeper, such as tethering of a vicious dog within the enclosure. Such enclosure shall be securely fenced and locked, and designed with secure sides, top and bottom, and shall be designed to prevent the dog from escaping from the enclosure. 
(4)  Found to be a vicious dog means that: 
a.  The animal control officer or a law enforcement officer has conducted an investigation and made a finding in writing that the dog is a vicious dog, as defined in subsection (a)(1) of this section, and based on that finding, the animal control officer has declared in writing that the dog is a vicious dog; or 
b.  A judge of the circuit court of the County has found the dog to be a vicious dog, as defined in subsection (a)(1) of this section, and has entered an order based on that finding. 
(5)  Impounded means taken into the custody of the animal control officer or other law enforcement officer. 
(b)  Any dog found to be a vicious dog, which has not been impounded and destroyed, shall be confined to an enclosure. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog unless such dog is at all times kept in an enclosure. The only times that a vicious dog may be allowed out of the enclosure are if it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care for the dog or to comply with the order of a court of competent jurisdiction, provided that the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a tensile strength of 300 pounds and not exceeding three feet in length, and shall be under the direct control and supervision of the owner, handler or keeper of such dog. 
(c)  Any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog that has been directed to be contained in an enclosure rather than being destroyed, which is not confined to an enclosure, shall be impounded by the animal control officer or the Village police department and shall be turned over to a licensed veterinarian for destruction by lethal injection, subject to the provisions of subsection (c)(1) of this section: 
(1)  If the owner, handler or keeper of the dog, after being given written notice of the impoundment order, has not appealed the impoundment order to the circuit court of the County within seven days from the date of impoundment, the dog may be humanely destroyed by lethal injection administered by a licensed veterinarian. 
(2)  A dog found to be a vicious dog that is not destroyed shall not be released to the owner until the animal control officer approves an enclosure, as defined in subsection (a)(3) of this section. 
(3)  No owner, keeper or handler of a vicious dog shall sell or give away such dog. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any vicious dog or dangerous dog to leave the premises of its owner, keeper or handler when not under control by a leash or other recognized control methods as may be otherwise provided under this section. 
(e)  Sentry, guard or police owned dogs that attack or injure a person, while performing duties as trained, are exempt from this section; provided, however, that the owner, handler or keeper of such exempt dog has previously provided the animal control officer with the address of the premises in which such exempt dog is housed and/or maintained. To qualify for exemption under this section, each such dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies in accordance with section 8 of the Illinois Animal Control Act. It shall be the duty of the owner, keeper or handler of such exempt dog to notify the animal control officer of changes of address. In the case of a sentry or guard dog, the owner shall keep the animal control officer advised of the location where such dog will be stationed. The animal control officer shall provide the police and fire departments with a categorized list of such exempt dogs, and shall promptly notify such departments of any address changes reported to him, as the case may be. 
(Code 1959, § 4.20)  
Sec. 14-102. - Vicious and dangerous animals other than dogs. 
(a)  For vicious and dangerous animals other than dogs, see 720 ILCS 585/0.1 et seq. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any poisonous snake or boa constrictor to leave the premises of its owner, keeper or handler when not under control by a recognized control method as may be otherwise provided under section 14-101. 
(Code 1959, § 4.20(d))  
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— At the direction of the city, per email received Mar. 24, 2011, references in this chapter to the "building and zoning director" have been changed to reference the "director of development or his/her designee". See also Ord. Nos. 5430 and 5431, adopted Mar. 1, 2011. 
Cross reference— Director of community development, § 2-412; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 38; buildings with Village water and private water wells, § 38-13; planning, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 58; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; moving buildings, § 62-15; subdivisions, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 82; building sewers, connections and maintenance, § 82-131 et seq.; vegetation, ch. 86; obstruction of building exits or sprinkler system connections, § 90-281 et seq.; zoning, ch. 98; nonconformities, § 98-251 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Scope. 
(a)  The purpose of this chapter is to provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements affecting or relating to the erection, construction, alteration, remodeling, repair, maintenance, removal and demolition of structures, and to regulate the architectural design of buildings or structures erected within the Village limits. 
(b)  This chapter is hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health and welfare, structural strength and stability, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and hazards incidental to the construction, alteration, repair and maintenance of structures, or portions thereof, in the Village, except federal and State buildings and possessions. 
(c)  The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to supplement and otherwise void any existing building ordinances. 
(d)  The existing zoning ordinance set forth in chapter 98, or revisions thereof, are hereby made a part of this chapter. Should a provision in chapter 98 conflict with that of this chapter, the most restrictive provision shall govern. 
(e)  Any existing or future State laws, or revisions thereto, pertaining to the erection, maintenance or occupancy of buildings and structures are hereby made a part of this chapter. Should any provision in the State laws conflict with a similar provision in this chapter, the most restrictive provision shall govern. 
(f)  If any part of this chapter is declared invalid or unconstitutional, it shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity, force or effect of any other part of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 5.1.1)  
Secs. 18-2—18-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-31. - Purpose. 
It is hereby affirmed that the purpose of this chapter is to secure safe and sanitary construction in order to promote public health and safety, and to do equal justice, the director of community development or his/her designee shall have full power to pass upon any question arising under the provisions of this chapter, subject to the conditions, modifications and limitations contained therein. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.1; Ord. No. 5190, § 2, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-32. - Compliance with building code required. 
It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to construct, erect, enlarge, remodel, alter, repair, raise, lower, underpin, move or wreck any building or structure, or portion thereof, within the Village in violation of this chapter or any other laws of the Village. It is further declared unlawful to equip, use or occupy any building or structure, or any portion thereof, in the Village with any device, or for any business or other purpose, in any manner prohibited by this chapter or any other laws of the Village. Violators of any of the provisions or requirements of this section shall be subject to punishment as set forth in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.9; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-33. - Nuisance declared. 
Any building or structure, or any portion thereof, constructed, erected, enlarged, remodeled, altered, repaired, raised, lowered, underpinned or moved within the Village in any manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter or any laws of the Village is hereby declared a nuisance and the person, owner, agent, architect, builder, contractor, house mover or mechanic so constructing, erecting, enlarging, remodeling, altering, repairing, raising, lowering, underpinning or moving such building or structure, or any portion thereof, contrary to any of the provisions of this chapter or laws, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.10; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-34. - Right to complete buildings under outstanding permits. 
Authority is hereby affirmed to complete any building or structure, or portion thereof, either in the process of being, or under contract to be, constructed, erected, enlarged, remodeled, altered, repaired, raised, lowered, underpinned or moved at or prior to the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, provided, a valid and prior permit outstands therefor; the work accords with the building regulations in force at issuance of such a permit; and the building or structure, and various portions thereof, will be safe and sanitary upon completion, and will fully accord with the building and other laws of the Village in force at the time the permit was issued. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.11; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-35. - Compliance of enlarged, remodeled or repaired buildings. 
Any building or structure, or major portion thereof, which is enlarged, remodeled or repaired within the Village shall be made to comply throughout with the provisions of this chapter as if applied to new or original work, provided, the cost of the work proposed to be done exceeds one-half of the estimated fair value of the building or structure, or major portion thereof, proposed to be altered or repaired. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.12; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-36. - Restoration of damaged buildings. 
(a)  Any building or structure, or major portion thereof, that has been damaged by reason of decay, fire or other cause may be restored to its original condition, provided, such condition is then consistent with the provisions of this chapter and the public health and safety, and, provided, the cost of the restoration work does not exceed one-half of the estimated fair value of the building or structure, or major portion thereof, proposed to be restored. 
(b)  Any building or structure, or any major portion thereof, in the Village that has suffered damage by reason of decay, fire or otherwise may be considered and dealt with as an unsafe building unless repairs are promptly made as ordered by the director of community development or his/her designee and as prescribed by this chapter. 
(c)  The value and cost referred to in this section shall be determined or approved by director of community development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.13; Ord. No. 5190, § 2, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-37. - Compliance of moved buildings. 
(a)  Buildings or structures moved from one block to another within the Village, or upon, along or across any street or alley used by and for the public that are worth more than one-third of the cost of duplicating such buildings or structures in their proposed new location with new construction and materials, shall be made to comply throughout with this chapter, and the acceptance of a permit for moving such buildings or structures shall impose the obligation to cause such buildings or structures to be made to comply with this chapter, and failure to cause such buildings or structures to be made to comply with this chapter shall constitute a violation of such code. 
(b)  No building or structure worth less than one-third of the cost of duplicating it in its proposed new location with new construction and materials shall be moved from its present location to another. 
(c)  The costs and values referred to and made necessary to be determined in applying this section shall be furnished by the owner and shall be verified and approved by the director of community development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.14; Ord. No. 5190, § 2, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-38. - Inspection of buildings required. 
(a)  The general contractor shall obtain inspections by the community development department of all buildings and structures, and portions thereof, under his jurisdiction which are in the course of being constructed, erected, enlarged, remodeled, altered, repaired, raised, lowered, underpinned, moved or wrecked under a permit issued by the Village for the work, and in compliance with SUBsection 18-102(c). The inspection shall be made as required in this subsection and in such manner as shall serve the purpose intended, which purpose shall be to ascertain and record whether the work is being undertaken and performed in a safe manner, and complies with the requirements of this chapter and all other ordinances of the Village. 
(b)  The director of community development or his/her designee shall inspect, or cause to be inspected, all buildings or structures, or portions thereof, damaged by fire or other accidents, in order to ascertain, if possible, the cause or origin of the fire or accident, and to make a record of such damage sustained. 
(c)  The director of community development or his/her designee shall inspect, or cause to be inspected, all buildings or structures for which application for a permit to move may be made. Such inspection shall be made for the purpose of ascertaining and recording information as to risks to be incurred, and the strength, size, value and general sanitary and structural features of the building or structure proposed to be moved. The reports shall be placed on file in the develoment department before the permit sought shall be approved for issuance by the director of community development or his/her designee. The inspection required under this subsection shall be recorded on forms prepared and furnished especially for such use by the community development department, and shall be filed by such department. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.15; Ord. No. 5190, § 3, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-39. - Procedure upon deviation or violation. 
The procedure in all cases of unauthorized deviations from, or violations of, the provisions of this chapter found on inspections required by section 18-38 shall be as follows: 
(1)  A verbal notice shall be immediately served by the director of community development or his/her designee at the site and on the person doing or in charge of the work being done, or responsible for or capable of correcting, or of causing to be corrected the deviation observed. If a verbal notice cannot be served on the site, or if served, is disregarded or deemed inadequate by the director of community development or his/her designee for the purpose, then a written notice, on forms prepared for the purpose and designating the deviation observed, shall be posted at the site, in as safe and conspicuous a place as practical, and where, if unmolested, it must come to the notice of any person either employed on the work, or frequenting or occupying the building, structure or premises, and a copy of the notice so posted shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner, agent or person in control of the building or structure involved. 
(2)  If the verbal and/or written notice is respected and steps are promptly taken to correct the deviation observed, and if such deviation is promptly corrected, on notice, to the satisfaction of the director of community development or his/her designee and consistent with the requirements of this chapter, then, and for such case, the deviation observed shall not be deemed a willful violation of this chapter, nor be subject to any penalty therein provided. 
(3)  If a written notice of a deviation observed from the provisions of this chapter has been posted and mailed, as set forth in this section, and the work or condition continues in defiance thereof, or if the deviation, of whatever nature, is not promptly corrected in a manner consistent with the provisions of this chapter and the urgency of the case, then the deviation shall be considered a willful violation, and the director of community development or his/her designee shall promptly stop the work, and, if need be, shall close the building or structure to the public. The facts pertaining to the case and the steps so far taken therein shall forthwith be reported in writing, on forms prepared for such purpose, to the director of community development or his/her designee, who, in turn, shall proceed to enforce the provisions and penalties of this chapter for and in such case provided. 
(4)  The chief of police and Village attorney, pursuant to and consistent with the duties of their respective offices, shall assist in enforcing this chapter against violators who defiantly refuse to comply with notices from the director of community development or his/her designee, and each officer named in this subsection shall act in conjunction with the director of community development in so far as may be necessary and practical. Nothing contained in this subsection is intended, or shall be construed, to disqualify or exempt any officer of the Village not named in this subsection from the duty of assisting in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(5)  The director of community development or his/her designee, and other officers named in subsection (4) of this section who may assist them in case of flagrant or defiant violations of this chapter, are hereby authorized to use the police power of the Village in such manner and to such extent as the character of the violation and the urgency, hazards, rights and interests of public health and safety may justify and demand for the case involved. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.16; Ord. No. 5190, § 2, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-40. - Stop work order. 
(a)  The director of community development or his/her designee is hereby empowered and directed to stop work on any building or structure, or portion thereof, that is being done in a reckless, unsafe or unsanitary manner, or with the use of defective or improper material; and on any building or structure, or portion thereof, proposed for unlawful purposes as regards location, intended use or occupancy; and any work that in any other respect is being done contrary to the provisions of this chapter or to the requirements of any other laws of the Village. Such right and duty shall exist and be performed irrespective of any permit that may or may not have been either required or issued for the work, building or structure, or any portion thereof, involved. The suspension of work shall be for such time as may be necessary to secure a correction of the particular violations and features complained of, or until a satisfactory agreement and arrangement, approved by the director of community development or his/her designee, is reached that such correction will be made, and if a court trial is had, then the work shall be suspended and held in abeyance until the court renders its decision. 
(b)  Any person having charge of, directing, or in any way engaged in work that violates this chapter, who shall refuse or fail to promptly desist from such work on written notice from any director of community development or his/her designee, or who, having desisted on either verbal or written notice, shall resume the work before the violation which occasioned the order is corrected or agreed to be corrected to the satisfaction of the director of community development or his/her designee and consistent with the purposes of this chapter, or who, before having been authorized by the director of community development or his/her designee, resumes work stopped, shall be deemed guilty of violating this chapter and shall be subject to the general penalty provided in section 1-16. Permits for work being done in violation of this chapter may be canceled or revoked on order of the director of community development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.17; Ord. No. 5190, § 2, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-41. - Authority to direct removal of defective and dangerous walls, buildings and structures. 
The director of community development or his/her designee shall have the authority to direct the fire chief to tear down any defective or dangerous wall or structure, or any building or structure, or part thereof, which may be constructed in violation of the terms of this chapter, after written notice has been served upon the owner, lessee, occupant, agent or person in possession, charge or control, directing him to tear down or remove any defective wall, building or structure, or any part thereof, which is in a dangerous condition, or which has been or is being constructed or maintained in violation of the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.18; Ord. No. 5190, § 2, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-42. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5411, § 7, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 18-42, which pertained to certificate of final inspection and derived from Code 1959, § 5.2.19; and Ord. No. 5190, § 2, adopted Jan. 3, 2009.  
Sec. 18-43. - Conflicts between general and specific provisions. 
When a general provision or requirement of this chapter conflicts with specific provisions thereof relating to the construction, equipment, maintenance, use or location of any building or structure, or any portion thereof, in the Village, then and for such case, the specific provision or requirement shall prevail and govern. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.20; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-44. - Hours of construction. 
Construction subject to this chapter shall be conducted only during the following hours: 
(1)  Weekdays, 7:00 a.m.—7:00 p.m. 
(2)  Saturdays, 9:00 a.m.—6:00 p.m. 
(3)  Sundays, 9:00 a.m.—5:00 p.m. 
(4)  Holidays, as designated by the State. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.21; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Sec. 18-45. - Boarded up buildings. 
If the property owner or director of community development or his/her designee requires a building to be boarded up for more than 30 days, it shall be the owner's responsibility to paint the exterior boards a color to be agreed upon between the owner and the director of community development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 5.2.22; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5879, § 3, 12-9-2014)  
Secs. 18-46—18-80. - Reserved.
