ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 82. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-221. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5190, § 7, adopted Jan. 3, 2009, deleted § 18-221 in its entirety. Former § 18-221 pertained to definitions and derived from Code 1959, § 23.1.  
Sec. 18-222. - Compliance required. 
Upon the adoption, by ordinance, of such standards, specifications, rules and regulations, and fees, they shall be operative and, thereafter, no electrical equipment shall be installed or altered except upon permit approved by the development department. The development department shall approve permits for such installations and alterations of electrical equipment in all cases where application shall have been made in accordance with the rules and regulations established as provided in this article. The development department shall inspect all such installed or altered electrical equipment, and shall require that such equipment conform to the standards and specifications applicable thereto, which have been recommended and adopted as provided in this article. The requirements of this article specify minimum acceptable electrical equipment and wiring methods. Other equipment and methods not specified in this article may be approved for use by the director of development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 23.7; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-223. - Liability for damages. 
This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person owning, operating or installing any electrical wires, appliances, apparatus, construction or equipment for damages to any person injured by any defect therein by reason of the inspections authorized in this chapter or the certificate of inspection issued by the development department, nor shall the Village be held liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 23.13; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-224. - Subcontracts. 
When contracts to install electrical work have been obtained by persons that are not registered as electrical contractors, as provided for in this article, and the contract is assigned or sublet to a registered electrician on a subcontract or percentage basis, the name of such registered electrical contractor shall immediately be disclosed by the nonregistered electrical contractor to the other party to the contract and to the development department in writing. 
(Code 1959, § 23.14; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-225. - Alterations, changes, etc., of existing wiring. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, disturb, alter or change any electrical wiring, or to permit such electrical wiring to be cut, disturbed, altered or changed, unless done in conformity with the provisions of this article. Where a building is undergoing remodeling, any changes to be made in the electrical installation must first have the approval of the development department before work is commenced. 
(Code 1959, § 23.17; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-226. - Overfusing conductors, motors or apparatus. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to overfuse any conductor, motor or apparatus in excess of the maximum allowed by this article for such conductor, motor or apparatus, or to install any substitute in lieu of an approved fuse or device so as to remove or reduce the factor of safety thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 23.18)  
Sec. 18-227. - Permit required to repair or alteration wiring and equipment damaged by fire or flood. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to alter or repair any electrical wire or apparatus damaged, directly or indirectly, by fire or flood without first obtaining a permit for such work in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 23.19)  
Sec. 18-228. - Electrical contractor registration and fees. 
(a)  All persons doing work in the Village as an electrical contractor, shall first register as such in the office of the clerk and shall pay an annual registration fee. 
(b)  The term of registration required in accordance with this chapter shall be January 1 through December 31 of the same calendar year. 
(c)  The annual fee for an electrical contractor's registration shall be established by the director of development or his/her designee, and as set forth in section 30-1 of the Code. 
(d)  The term "electrical contractor", as used in this section, means any person engaged in the business of installing or altering, by contract, electrical equipment for the utilization of electrical supplied light, heat or power, not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, and not including apparatus, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers which are under the jurisdiction of the State commerce commission, for use in their operation as public utilities. Such term shall be also not include employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
(e)  Any electrical contractor failing to register and pay the fee as set forth in section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 23.20; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5411, § 4, 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 18-229. - Electrical contractors; additional registration requirements. 
An applicant seeking to register as an electrical contractor, in addition to the registration requirements set out in section 18-228, shall comply with the following provisions: 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Supervising electrician. 
(1)  Before the issuance of a permit to install or alter electrical work to any electrical contractor, the electrical contractor shall appoint or employ a person, who may be himself or some other person, who, for the purposes of this section, shall be known as a "supervising electrician." 
(2)  The supervising electrician shall have had at least three years' experience in the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical wires, equipment and apparatus, or an experience thereto. Proof of such experience shall be furnished to the director of development or his/her designee upon his request. 
(d)  Duties of supervising electrician. The supervising electrician shall perform the work or supervise and direct the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical wires and apparatus authorized by permits issued under the authority of this article. The supervising electrician shall be responsible to see that required electrical inspections are scheduled through and performed by the development department. If requested by the director of development or his/her designee, the supervising electrician or his representative shall be present for inspections. 
(e)  Notice of discharge or resignation of supervising electrician. Whenever a supervising electrician shall leave or be discharged from the employ of any person who is required by this article to appoint or employ a supervising electrician, a notice in writing thereof shall be given to the development department within five business days by both the employer and the supervising electrician, and the permit privileges of such person shall, without further order or action by the development department, stand suspended until the employment or appointment by such person of a supervising electrician as provided for in this section. 
(f)  Homeowners. 
(1)  For the purpose of this section the term "homeowner" means the owner and occupant of a residential dwelling within the corporate limits of the Village. 
(2)  Every homeowner acting as electrical contractor shall, at the time of application of permit, submit proof, to the director of development or his/her designee, that he/her has sufficient knowledge and technical training and experience to perform the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical wiring and equipment of a residential occupancy. The director of development or his/her designee shall approve, or deny, at his discretion, the application of a homeowner acting as an electrical contractor. 
(3)  Permits issued to a homeowner, acting as an electrical contractor, shall be for electrical work on the premises of the said homeowner only. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(Code 1959, § 23.21; Ord. No. 4371, § 3, 2-19-2002; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 6083, § 8, 6-8-2017)  
Sec. 18-230. - Adoption by reference. 
The 2011 edition of the National Electrical Code is adopted by reference. 
(Code 1959, § 23.25; Ord. No. 4385, § 2, 3-19-2002; Ord. No. 4605, § 2, 12-2-2003; Ord. No. 4705, §§ 2, 3, 11-16-2004; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5379, § 2, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 5536, § 2, 1-3-2012)  
Sec. 18-231. - Amendments. 
Any electrical equipment or method of installation not specifically covered by section 18-231 shall be governed by the rules and regulations in the 2011 edition of the National Fire Protection Association, under the auspices of the American National Standards Institute, now on file in the Development Department, and referred to in this article. Any and all references to the National Electrical Code in this article shall mean the edition referred to in this section. 
The 2011 edition of the National Electrical Code is amended as follows: 
(1)  Article 100 Definitions. (Add the following definitions) 
Alter shall mean to make different, modify, or vary. 
Repair shall mean to restore to a good operating condition as in the original state, without alteration. 
(2)  Article 110.24 Identification of the electrical contractor. (Add this section). The name of the electrical contractor performing the work on all new electrical services shall be displayed on the service panel cover. 
(3)  Article 210.50 III Required Outlet. (Amend by adding the following). 
Commercial or industrial office areas shall have receptacles installed within six feet of doorways and every twelve feet on wall spaces two feet or greater in length. 
(4)  Article 210.8 Ground-Fault Circuit-Interrupter Protection for Personnel. (Amend section (A) by adding). When feed through GFCI receptacles are used, they shall feed only receptacles on the same floor. 
(5)  Article 210.8(B). Ground-Fault Circuit-Interrupter Protection for Personnel. (Amend by adding the following). Bathroom switches and receptacles shall not be located within 30 inches measured horizontally, from the outside edge of a bathtub, whirlpool tub, shower or similar fixture. This requirement shall not apply to sink basins. 
Wall mounted lighting fixtures shall not be located within 30 inches measured horizontally, from the outside edge of a bathtub, whirlpool tub, shower or similar fixture unless provided with GFCI protection. 
(6)  Article 210.52(A) General Provisions. (Amend by adding the following). 
(1)  Counter top and work bench areas, other than kitchen counter tops shall be served by at least one receptacle for every six feet of length or fraction thereof. 
(7)  Article 230 Services. (Amend by adding section 230.1(A)). All services shall be installed with an outdoor disconnecting means capable of being secured to prevent tampering. Services that are 200 amps or less shall have a single main disconnect. Multiple disconnects in a common enclosure shall be permitted for services greater than 200 amps. 
(8)  Article 230 Services. (Amend by adding section 230.1(B)). System design drawings shall be submitted for all services greater than 200 amps at the time of permit application. 
(9)  Article 230 Services. (Amend by adding section 230.11 Service Entrance Conductors). 
(A)  Service entrance conductors shall be installed in rigid metal conduit, intermediate metal conduit or rigid nonmetallic conduit. The use of a subpanel shall require the written approval of the Director of inspectional services or his/her designee after submission and approval of complete load calculations. 
(B)  All service conductors shall be installed underground unless special permission is granted by the director of inspectional services. 
(C)  In new residential construction the electrical service shall have a minimum rating of 200 amps and an electrical distribution panel sized for 40 circuits. An interior disconnecting means shall be provided in addition to the exterior disconnect. Fuse box pullouts shall not be used as a service disconnect. 
Exception: Electric service upgrades in existing residences shall have a minimum 100 ampere rating and an electrical distribution panel sized for 30 circuits. Electrical distribution panel replacement and/or riser replacement shall not constitute a service upgrade. 
(D)  In commercial construction an interior disconnecting means shall be provided in addition to the exterior disconnect. Fuse box pullouts shall not be used as a service disconnect. 
(E)  Half-size breakers are not approved for use in new construction. In existing residential dwelling units half-size breakers are limited to manufacturer's specifications. Half-size breakers shall not be permitted in existing commercial or industrial units. 
(F)  Three-phase circuit panels supplied by three-phase, four wire Delta 120/240 volt service shall not be used to directly supply 120 volt single phase loads. 
(G)  Service entrances for underground services shall be governed by the requirements published by Commonwealth Edison entitled "Information and Requirements for the Supply of Electric Service." 
(10)  Article 230.31(B) Minimum Size. (Amend to read as follows). The conductors shall not be smaller than 8 AWG copper or smaller than 2 AWG for aluminum and copper clad aluminum conductors. 
(11)  Article 230.43 Wiring Methods for 600 volts, Nominal, or less. (Amend to read as follows). Service entrance conductors shall be installed in accordance with the applicable requirements of this code covering the type of wiring methods used and shall be limited to the following methods: 
(1)  Rigid metal conduit 
(2)  Intermediate metal conduit 
(3)  Rigid nonmetallic conduit 
(12)  Article 250.50 Grounding Electrode System and Grounding Electrode Conductor. (Amend by adding the following after the first paragraph). 
All grounding conductors shall be: 
(1)  Enclosed in a metal raceway or metal conduit; 
(2)  Connected to the first five (5) feet of the metal water pipe from the point of entrance to the building or structure on the street side of the water meter; 
(3)  Tagged with an approved WARNING tag; and 
(4)  A properly sized bonding jumper shall be installed across the water meter. 
(13)  Article 250.64 Grounding Electrode Conductor Material. (Amend to read as follows). The grounding electrode conductor shall be copper. The use of aluminum or copper clad aluminum for the purpose of grounding is prohibited. 
(14)  Article 310.2(B) Conductor Material. (Amend to read as follows). The use of compact aluminum and copper clad aluminum conductors shall be prohibited if smaller the 2 AWG. 
(15)  Article 314.27(C) Boxes at Ceiling-suspended Paddle Fan Outlets. (Amend to read as follows). Any outlet box which is being installed in an area that can reasonably accommodate a ceiling fan shall be identified for ceiling fan support. 
(16)  Article 320.10 Uses Permitted. (Amend to read as follows). Metal-clad and armored type cable (BX) shall be permitted for remodeling work where the installation of electric metallic tubing and/or intermediate metal conduit presents a hardship and is approved by the Director of Inspectional Services or his/her designee. 
(17)  Article 324 Flat Conductor Cable: Type FCC. (Delete this section) 
(18)  Article 330.10 Uses Permitted. (Amend to read as follows). Type MC cable shall be permitted for remodeling work where the installation of electrical metallic tubing and/or intermediate metal conduit presents a hardship and is approved for use by the Director of Inspectional Services or his/her designee. 
(19)  Article 334 Nonmetallic-sheathed Cable: Types NM, NMC, and NMS. (Delete this section) 
(20)  Article 338 Service-Entrance Cable: Types SE and Use. (Delete this section). This does not apply to USE cable. 
(21)  Article 340 UF Wiring. (Amend to read as follows). UF wiring is permitted in exterior uses when installed underground only. 
(22)  Article 352.10 Rigid Nonmetallic Conduit: Type RNC subsections (A), (C), (D), (E), and (F) Use Permitted. (Delete these sections) 
(23)  Article 348 Flexible Metal Conduit. (Amend by adding the following) 
Flexible metal conduit shall not exceed six feet in length except by written approval by the Director of Inspectional Services or his/her designee. 
(24)  Article 352.12 Uses Not Permitted. (Amend by adding the following section). 
(G)  Where conduits are placed in concrete cast in place on earth, or in direct contact with the earth, only galvanized rigid metal conduit, intermediate conduit or rigid nonmetallic conduit shall be used. Electrical metal conduit, with fittings approved for immersion in concrete, may be placed in concrete above grade, with 2 inches of space below the conduit. 
(25)  Article 362 Electrical Nonmetallic Tubing. (Delete this section) 
(26)  Article 382 Nonmetallic Extensions. (Delete this section) 
(27)  Article 394 Concealed Knob-and-tube Wiring. (Delete this section) 
(28)  Article 398 Open Wiring on Insulators. ..... (Delete this section) 
(29)  Article 410.116 Recessed Light Clearances. (Amend to read as follows). 
Recessed lighting fixtures installed in insulated ceilings are required to be I.C. type. This requirement cannot be obviated through the removal of insulation in the vicinity of the lighting luminar. 
(30)  Article 450.3 Over-Current Protection. (Amend to read as follows). All transformers rated at 150 volts and greater shall have both primary and secondary load break disconnects located within sight of the transformer. 
(31)  Article 450.27 Oil-insulated Transformers Installed Outdoors. (Amend to read as follows). Space separations shall be no less than five (5) feet horizontally from a doorway or window and twenty (20) feet from a fire escape except with written permission of the fire code official or his/her designee. 
(32)  Article 600.6(A) Sign Disconnects. (Amend to read as follows) 
Outdoor disconnects and raceways used in connection with illuminated signage shall be located in accordance with one of the following methods: 
1.  Within an enclosed building within sight of the sign(s), or 
2.  Behind a parapet wall within sight of the sign(s), or 
3.  Completely enclosed within the sign. 
(33)  Article 604 Manufactured Wiring Systems. (Amend to read as follows) 
Manufactured wiring systems shall be permitted for use with furniture systems only. 
(37)  Article 680.23(A) (4) Voltage Limitation. (Amend to read as follows) 
Lighting fixtures installed in swimming pools, fountains, and the like, shall not operate at more than 15 volts, as measured between conductors. 
(38)  Article 720 Low Voltage Wiring. (Amend by adding the following). 
Low voltage wiring shall be installed in conduit in areas made inaccessible by building construction or where subject to damage. 
(Code 1959, § 23.26; Ord. No. 4913, § 2, 9-19-2006; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5379, § 3, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 5536, § 3, 1-3-2012)  
Sec. 18-232. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person who violates any section of this article, or who shall fail or refuse to comply with this article, shall constitute an offense punishable, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 23.28)  
Secs. 18-233—18-250. - Reserved.

Sec. 18-253. - Administration and enforcement of electrical code. 
The director of development or his/her designee shall have general charge and supervision for the regulation of the installation, alteration and use of all electrical equipment as provided in this article within the Village that is required to be inspected by this article, and shall enforce all ordinances related thereto. Any reference in the Glenview Electrical Code or the National Electrical Code to the authority having jurisdiction shall not be construed to mean the Village electrical commission, as a whole. 
(Code 1959, § 23.4; Ord. No. 5079, § 2, 1-22-2008; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 8, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-254. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3656, § 2(f), adopted Feb. 19, 2013, deleted § 18-254, which pertained to Electrical Commission and derived from code 1959, § 23.5; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, adopted Jan. 3, 2009; and Ord. No. 5431, § 2, adopted Mar. 1, 2011.  
Sec. 18-255. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3656, § 2(f), adopted Feb. 19, 2013, deleted § 18-255, which pertained to recommendations of Electrical Commission and derived from Code 1959, § 23.6; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, adopted Jan. 3, 2009; and Ord. No. 5431, § 3, adopted Mar. 1, 2011.  
Sec. 18-256. - Right to entry for inspection. 
The director of development or his/her designee or such other electrical inspectors shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to enter any building in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the installation or alterations of electrical equipment contained therein, or for the purpose of reinspecting present wiring installations to determine whether or not such wiring installations conform to the provisions of this article, and shall have the authority to cause the turning off of all electrical currents and to cut or disconnect, in cases of emergency, any wire where such electrical currents are dangerous to life or property, or may interfere with the work of the fire department. The provisions for inspection of work authorized by the permits issued in accordance with this article shall not be construed as prohibiting the inspection of any electrical equipment installed, whenever the director of development or his/her designee shall determine that the public safety requires such inspection. 
(Code 1959, § 23.8; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-257. - Certificates of inspection. 
(a)  Upon the completion of the wiring or an electrical installation in or on any building or structure, it shall be the duty of the person doing the wiring or electrical installation to notify the development department, which shall cause the wiring or electrical installation to be inspected, and if the wiring or electrical installation conforms to the requirements of this article, the development department shall cause to be issued a written certificate of satisfactory inspection, in triplicate, one copy of which shall be delivered to the person who is to furnish electricity or electrical service and the third copy shall remain for Village files. The certificate of inspection shall contain the date of such inspection, the location or address of the wiring or electrical installation by street number or lot number, the name of the person actually completing the work and the name of the person for whom the work was performed. 
(b)  In no case shall the development department issue a certificate of inspection unless the electrical power or heating installations and all apparatus, wire or appurtenances attached thereto conform with the regulations set forth in this article; and electric current shall not be supplied to any such electrical installation by any person until such certificate of satisfactory inspection shall be issued and delivered to the person contemplated to furnish electrical current. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install electrical energy recording meters on any electrical equipment that has been installed or connect any electric distribution system or circuit to an electricity system previous to the issuance by the chief electrical inspector of a temporary current permit or a certificate of inspection authorizing the use of current on such installation. 
(Code 1959, § 23.9; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-258. - Stop work order. 
No person shall install any electrical conduit, electrical wire, equipment or apparatus in any building or structure for which a permit is required until such permit shall have been secured. If any work is begun on the installation of electrical conduits, raceways of the installation, alterations or repair of electrical wires or apparatus in any building or structure without a permit authorizing such work, the work shall be stopped until the necessary permit is issued. 
(Code 1959, § 23.11)  
Sec. 18-259. - Records. 
The development department shall keep complete records of all permits issued and inspections made, and other official work performed under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 23.12; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-260. - Impersonating an electrical inspector. 
No person who is not a lawful Village electrical inspector shall impersonate an electrical inspector of the development department. 
(Code 1959, § 23.15; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-261. - Official notice and seal. 
The director of development or his/her designee or other electrical inspectors who may be designated are hereby empowered to attach to electrical cabinets and equipment an official notice or seal to prevent use of electricity, and it shall be unlawful for any other person to attach such seal, or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover or otherwise deface or injure any such official notice or seal posted by the development department. 
(Code 1959, § 23.16; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-262. - Suspension or revocation of permits. 
The director of development or his/her designee may suspend any permit for work being executed contrary to the provisions of this article until acted upon by the electrical commission or, at his discretion, he may reinstate the revoked or suspended permit after the violations have been corrected or rectified. 
(Code 1959, § 23.22; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-263. - Suspension or revocation of registration. 
The director of development or his/her designee may suspend any appointment or registration of persons executing electrical installations contrary to the provisions of this article until acted upon by the electrical commission or, at his discretion, he may reinstate the suspended or revoked appointment or registration after the violations have been corrected or rectified. 
(Code 1959, § 23.23; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-264. - Permits, fees and inspections. 
(a)  Permit required. It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to commence or perform any work in connection with the installation or alteration of electrical equipment without first having made application to and secured from the office of the director of development or his/her designee the necessary permit for such work, and any person so doing shall be subjected to the general penalty set forth in section 1-16. Repairs, except repair of wiring or equipment damaged by fire (see section 18-227), wherein the same type of electrical equipment is utilized, may be accomplished without the necessity of obtaining a permit, provided further, that such repair complies in all other respects with the provisions of this article. Repairs shall be performed by a person who is qualified to obtain electrical permits. For associated permit and inspection fees, see section 30-1. 
(b)  Other apparatus. Inspections of temporary installations and all other inspections not specifically provided for in this section shall be charged at not less than the minimum fee. The chief electrical inspector shall determine the fee to be charged in accordance with the schedule set forth in section 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 23.24; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 6140, § 2, 12-5-2017)  
Sec. 18-265. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 6083, § 9, adopted June 8, 2017, repealed § 18-265, in its entirety. Former § 18-265 pertained to "Appeals," and was derived from Code 1959, § 23.27; Ord. No. 5190, § 7, adopted January 3, 2009 and Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, adopted March 1, 2011.

ARTICLE V. - MECHANICAL CODE 
 
Sec. 18-301. - International Code Council (ICC) International Mechanical Code adopted; amendments. 
The 2012 edition of the ICC International Mechanical Code is hereby adopted with the following amendments: 
(1)  Section 101.1. Title. Amend this section to read as follows: "These regulations shall be known as the Mechanical Code of the Village of Glenview, Cook County, Illinois (the "Village"), herein referred to as "this code." 
(2)  Section 102. 8 Referenced codes and standards. Amended to read as follows: "The codes and standards referenced in this code shall be those that are listed in Chapter 15 of this code, and such codes and standards shall be considered part of the requirements of this code to the prescribed extent of each such reference. Where differences occur between the provisions of this code and referenced standards, the provisions of this code shall apply. The following codes and standards are not adopted by reference and thus are not considered part of the requirements of this code: 
IPC 2012 International Plumbing Code 
IPSDC 2012 International Private Sewage Disposal Code 
IZC 2012 International Zoning Code 
IWUIC 2012 International Wildland-Urban Interface Code 
ISPSC 2012 International Swimming Pool and Spa Code" 
(3)  Section 108.4 Violation penalties. Amended to read as follows: "Persons who violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirement thereto or who shall erect, alter, or repair mechanical work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, or certificate issued under the provision of this code shall be subject to penalties as provided in Section 1-16 of the Glenview Municipal Code." 
(Code 1959, § 5.5.4; Ord. No. 4993, § 4, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 5190, § 8, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5879, § 6, 12-9-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5879, § 6, adopted December 9, 2014, amended § 18-301 to read as set out herein. Previously § 18-301 was titled adopted; amendments.  
Secs. 18-302—18-330. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PLUMBING CODE[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 82. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-331. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements affecting or relating to the proper installation of a permanent, efficient system for furnishing a potable water supply and sanitary disposal system for each and every habitable building, and to obtain a serviceable plumbing system for the comfort, convenience, health and safety of the occupants in the Village limits. 
(Code 1959, § 26.1.1)  
Sec. 18-332. - Effect. 
This article is hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health and welfare, through the promulgation of minimum plumbing standards in the Village, except federal and State buildings and possessions. 
(Code 1959, § 26.1.2)  
Sec. 18-333. - Existing plumbing ordinances voided. 
The provisions of this article shall be deemed to supplant and otherwise void any existing plumbing ordinances. 
(Code 1959, § 26.1.3)  
Sec. 18-334. - Conflicting provisions. 
Any State laws or revisions thereto pertaining to plumbing are hereby made a part of this article. Should any provision in the State laws conflict with a similar provision in this article, the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890) shall govern. 
(Code 1959, § 26.1.4; Ord. No. 5928, § 3, 8-18-2015)  
Secs. 18-335—18-350. - Reserved.

Sec. 18-355. - Adoption of standards and specifications and rules and regulations. 
Upon the adoption by ordinance of such standards and specifications and rules and regulations they shall become operative, and thereafter no plumbing fixtures and apparatus shall be installed or altered, except upon a permit approved by the development department. The develop department shall approve permits for such installation and alteration of plumbing fixtures and apparatus in all cases where application shall have been made in accordance with the rules and regulations established. The plumbing inspection department shall inspect such plumbing fixtures and apparatus installed or altered, and shall require that such fixtures and apparatus conform to the standards and specifications applicable thereto, which have been recommended and adopted as provided in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 26.2.5; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5928, § 5, 8-18-2015)

Sec. 18-356. - Right of entry for inspection. 
The director of development or his/her designee or such other plumbing inspectors, after proper identification, shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the installation or alterations of plumbing fixtures or apparatus contained therein, or for the purpose of reinspecting present plumbing installations to determine whether or not such plumbing installations conform to the provisions of this article. The provisions for inspection of work authorized by the permits issued in accordance with this article shall not be construed as prohibiting the inspection of any plumbing installation installed whenever the plumbing inspector shall determine that the public safety requires such inspection. 
(Code 1959, § 26.2.6; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-357. - Inspection upon completion of installation. 
Upon the completion of the plumbing installation in or on any building or structure, it shall be the duty of the person installing such plumbing to notify the development department, which shall cause the plumbing installation to be inspected. 
(Code 1959, § 26.2.7; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)

Sec. 18-364. - Performing work without a permit. 
(a)  Any person who shall install plumbing in any building, except for minor repairs, without having first obtained a written permit for such work from the development department shall be in violation of this article. No unwritten permit will be recognized. 
(b)  No work of plumbing or drainlaying shall be started or continued without the permit being on the premises and in the possession of the person doing such work. 
(c)  Any person who shall install a water softener, or lawn or garden sprinkler system without having first obtained a written permit for such work from the development department shall be in violation of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 26.2.14; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)

All appurtenances to building drains and building sewers, including catchbasins, manholes, cleanouts, backwater valves and fittings, shall be located within the property lines of the premises served by such drains and sewers. 
(Code 1959, § 26.2.17)

Sec. 18-372. - Plans required. 
Plans may be required for all new plumbing installations. Plans shall show the plumbing system completely, including drains, soil, waste, vents, revent pipes, traps and all plumbing fixtures and water supply pipes within the building. Plans are requried for remodeling work unless approved by the director of development or his/her designee. The director of [the] development department or his/her designee shall be notified if plans are to be changed and such change shall be approved before work is installed. 
(Code 1959, § 26.2.22; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)

DIVISION 3. - PERMITS, BONDS AND FEES 
 
Sec. 18-391. - Permit for repairs 
No plumbing work of any kind, except minor repairs, within buildings, shall be done in the Village without a permit first issued therefor by the development department. 
(Code 1959, § 26.3.1; Ord. No. 4371, § 4, 2-19-2002; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 5928, § 6, 8-18-2015)  
Sec. 18-392. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009, deleted § 18-392 in its entirety. Former § 18-392 pertained to permit and inspection fees generally and derived from Code 1959, § 26.3.2; and Ord. No. 5113, § 6, adopted June 17, 2008.  
Sec. 18-393. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009, deleted § 18-393 in its entirety. Former § 18-3932 pertained to sewer permit and inspection fees and derived from Code 1959, § 26.3.3.  
Sec. 18-394. - Duration of permit. 
Any plumbing permit issued by the director of development or his/her designee, and under which no work is commenced within six months from the date of issuance thereof, shall expire by limitation and, unless such permit is surrendered to the director of development or his/her designee within two months (60 days) after its expiration for such cause, all fees paid therefor shall be forfeited to the Village. A cessation of work for more than three continuous months (90 days) shall have the same effect in terminating plumbing permits as a failure to begin work. Any delay to start work or continue work already started caused by a natural disaster commonly referred to as an "act of God," or by insurrection, strike by construction workers or at the source of supply, or by legal delay (judicial or civil authority) will constitute no part of the expiration time limits set forth in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 26.3.4; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-395. - Action on permit application. 
The director of development or his/her designee shall examine applications for permits within a reasonable time after filing of such applications. If, after examination, the director of development or his/her designee finds no objections to the application and it appears that the proposed work will be in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto, and the proposed plumbing or work will be safe, he shall approve such application and issue a permit for the proposed work as soon as practical. If his examination reveals otherwise, he shall reject such application, note his findings in a written report to be attached to the application and deliver a copy thereof to the applicant. 
(Code 1959, § 26.3.5; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-396. - When permit is valid. 
No permit or amendment to a permit issued by the director of development or his/her designee for plumbing work for which a fee is prescribed by Village ordinances shall be in force until the fees prescribed therefor shall have been paid to the Village collector and the Village collector's receipt therefor shall have been stamped on such permit. 
(Code 1959, § 26.3.6; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-397. - Application for plumbing permit. 
When any person shall be desirous to do work for which a permit is required by this article, he shall make written application to the director of development or his/her designee, upon blank forms furnished by the development department, for a permit for such purpose. The application for a plumbing permit shall consist of a complete set of forms for the work to be done, and with properly licensed subcontractors identified thereon. Such forms shall be completely filled out and presented by the general contractor responsible for the proposed work. 
(Code 1959, § 26.3.7; Ord. No. 5190, § 9, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5431, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 6083, § 10, 6-8-2017)  
Secs. 18-398—18-420. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - STATE PLUMBING CODE 
 
Sec. 18-421. - Adopted. 
Pursuant to the authority granted by the general assembly to local government in 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq., to incorporate, by reference, the provisions of nationally recognized technical codes and public records, the Village hereby adopts, by reference, the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890), adopted by the State department of public health, division of sanitary engineering, as certified by the director thereof on December 1, 1998, as authorized by 225 ILCS 320/36, save and except such portions as are deleted, modified or amended and as supplemented and added in this division. 
(Code 1959, § 4.1; Ord. No. 5190, § 10, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5928, § 2, 8-18-2015)  
Sec. 18-422. - Administrative authority. 
Any references in the State of Illinois Plumbing Code [Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890)] to the "administrative authority" shall mean the Village of Glenview. 
(Code 1959, § 4.2; Ord. No. 5190, § 10, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5928, § 2, 8-18-2015)  
Sec. 18-423. - Amendments.

Exceptions:

The winter outdoor design temperature for the locality shall be as indicated in the 2012 International Mechanical Code.
