Note: These heat losses are based on an assumed wind velocity at the water surface of 3½ miles per hour (mph). For a velocity of five mph, multiply these losses by 1.25, and for ten mph, multiply by 2.0. 
The average wind velocity in miles per hour—For spas under 900 square feet, in built-up areas where the spa is sheltered by nearby fences, buildings or shrubs from the prevailing winds, an average velocity of 3½ mph may be assumed. For more exposed locations or higher wind velocities, see above footnote of the heat loss table. For indoor spas where the indoor temperature is a little lower, if any, than the water temperature, a heat loss factor of 100 Btus per hour, per square foot of spa surface may be used. Experience has indicated that when a spa cover is used, heat loss will be reduced by 50 percent or more. If it is desired to raise the temperature in a given time period, the following formula may be used: 
Heater output (Btu/hour) = Spa volumes (gallons) × temperature difference (degrees Fahrenheit) × 8.3 + ½ surface loss. 
(Ord. No. 5383, § 2, 10-5-2010)  
Sec. 18-629. - Regulations. 
The director may promulgate regulations for the construction, alteration, operation and maintenance of pools to carry out the provisions and purposes of this article. The regulations may provide from time to time for the use of materials, devices, structures and appurtenant equipment substantially equivalent to that required in this article as long as the degree of protection afforded is not less than the protection provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 5383, § 2, 10-5-2010)  
Sec. 18-630. - Inspection authority. 
The director and their representatives shall have the right and authority, before or after any permit is issued, to enter upon the real property of the applicant or permittee to inspect any pool and check the operation thereof to assure compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. The owner, lessee, occupant and all persons operating and using a pool shall cooperate fully with such inspections and provide pertinent information, as requested. 
(Ord. No. 5383, § 2, 10-5-2010)  
Sec. 18-631. - Reserved.  
Sec. 18-632. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article, or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair a swimming pool in violation of this article, shall be subject to the general penalty provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 5383, § 2, 10-5-2010)  
Secs. 18-633—18-660. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN 
 
Sec. 18-661. - Findings; requirements. 
It is universally recognized that many neighborhoods in urban areas have deteriorated in the past by reason of poor planning and the erection of inferior and unsuitable buildings in such neighborhoods, and such deterioration has invariably been accompanied by a reduction in property values and a deterioration in conditions and health, sanitation and safety in such neighborhoods, and for the purpose of preventing such deterioration and preserving existing property values unto the owners and residents of property within the Village, and for the purpose of preserving and improving the existing standards of health, sanitation and safety within the Village, the following provisions are required: 
(1)  All new buildings shall be of an architectural design suitable for a good suburban community. No permit shall be issued for any new building or for the improvement of an existing building which is of such architectural design that the building is manifestly inferior or so radically different as to impair the marketability of property values of existing buildings in the immediate vicinity. 
(2)  Freestanding buildings and buildings having a frontage on one or more streets shall have the same architecturally harmonious material used for all exterior walls. Buildings partially freestanding shall have the same or architecturally harmonious materials for all exposed exterior walls. 
(3)  No permit shall be issued for the construction or erection of more than two single-family residential buildings of the same exterior design and style on the same side of the street in any one block. Two single-family residential buildings of the same exterior design and style shall not be erected directly adjacent to each other or directly across the street from each other. 
(4)  When, in the opinion of the director of development or his/her designee, the issuance of a permit would be contrary to any of the provisions stated in this section, the permit will be denied and the matter shall, within two weeks, upon receipt of the permit application, be referred to the appearance commission for consideration and recommendation. After public hearing wherein evidence shall be received from the applicant and such other persons as shall desire to appear and be heard, and after consideration of all evidence, the appearance commission shall forward its recommendation to the board of trustees, indicating whether the proposed construction will or will not detrimentally affect the values of adjoining and neighboring properties. 
(5)  Within 30 days, upon receipt of the recommendation of the appearance commission as set forth in subsection (4) of this section, the board of trustees shall take final action thereon. The action of the board of trustees shall be communicated to the director of development or his/her designee, who shall carry out such decision. 
(Code 1959, § 5.5.1)  
Secs. 18-662—18-690. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - OCCUPATION OF STREETS 
 
Sec. 18-691. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or store on the roadway, parkway or sidewalk space of any street or in alleys, building materials or any fuel or other supplies for any building or structure in the course of erection, repair or alteration, unless a street occupancy permit from the director of development or his/her designee is obtained prior to the act, and any person so doing shall be subject to the general penalty as stated in section 1-16 for such violation. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.1)  
Sec. 18-692. - Street occupancy permit application. 
All applications for street occupancy permits for the purpose of building operations shall be made to the director of development or his/her designee and shall describe the location of the roadway, parkway or sidewalk space of any street or alley proposed to be occupied, the use to be made of such roadway, parkway and sidewalk space, and the length of time of such intended occupation. Should the director of development or his/her designee approve of such application, he shall issue a street occupancy permit to the applicant, provided, the applicant has complied with all the provisions of this chapter as to the payment of fees and all other requisites in connection with such permit. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.2; Ord. No. 6083, § 11, 6-8-2017)  
Sec. 18-693. - Time limitation. 
The permission to occupy roadway, parkway or sidewalk space of any street or in alleys for the purpose of building is intended only for imperative use in connection with the actual erection, repair, alteration, wrecking or removal of buildings, and shall continue only until work can be carried on entirely inside the property. It shall also be unlawful to occupy any of such spaces under the authority of such permit for the storage of articles not intended for immediate use in connection with the operation for which such permit has been issued. Failure to immediately remove building or other material from such occupied space upon notice from the director of development or his/her designee or chief of police shall subject the owner or contractor so notified to the general penalty as provided section 1-16 for such violation. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.3)  
Sec. 18-694. - Space limitation. 
(a)  The occupation of a street or alley for the storage of building materials, including temporary sidewalks for any one building, shall never be extended out beyond the curbline and where no parkway exists not more than one-third of the way across the street or alley as measured from lot line to lot line. 
(b)  It shall not be lawful to occupy with building material any roadway, parkway or sidewalk space of any street or alleys, other than immediately in front of the lot or land upon which the building is being erected, provided that, if the written consent of the owners, tenants or occupants of properties adjoining the site of any proposed building is first obtained and filed with the director of development or his/her designee, the occupation of the roadway, parkway or sidewalk may be extended in front of the property so consenting upon the same terms and conditions as fixed in this article for the occupation of the street front of the building site. 
(c)  During the progress of building operations, a sidewalk not less than four feet in width (or an equal width of a clean, hard paved roadway, available and made safe for a footway, and protected by a substantial hand railing) shall at all times be kept open, clean and unobstructed for the purpose and uses of a passageway in front of such lot. This subsection is not intended to prohibit the maintenance of a driveway for delivery of material across such sidewalk from the curbline to the building site, but such driveway shall be under the supervision of the director of development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.4; Ord. No. 5431, § 2, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-695. - Fences. 
Fences having a minimum height of six feet shall be provided around the entire perimeter of all excavations. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.5)  
Sec. 18-696. - Scaffolds. 
An outside scaffold on a building not more than two stories in height, standing on or within five feet of the street line, shall have a floor of two-inch planks and, at the outer edge thereof, a closed fence of not less than three feet in height, when there is no covering over the sidewalk. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.6)  
Sec. 18-697. - Placement of materials, fences, etc. 
Materials, fences or sheds shall not be placed within two feet of any tree, nor within six feet of the rail of any railway, nor render inaccessible any value chamber, manhole, coal chute, fire hydrant, alarm box or catchbasin. All gutters shall be kept free and clear at all times. Mortar boxes or beds shall be placed and guarded so as to protect the clothing of persons passing, and shall be promptly removed from any street, sidewalk, alley or public way on order of the director of development or his/her designee or the chief of police. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.7)  
Sec. 18-698. - Protection of trees and shrubbery. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bruise, bend, break, cut, saw or in any way mutilate or otherwise injure or damage any tree or shrubbery, or the roots or branches thereof, planted in and along any street, alley, public highway or place in the Village, without first obtaining the consent of the Village forester. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.8)  
Sec. 18-699. - Red lights and warning devices. 
(a)  Sufficient red lights and/or other suitable warning devices shall be displayed and maintained during the whole of every night at each excavation, pile of material, fence or any other obstruction on any public highway, sufficient to ensure that each excavation, pile of material, fence or other obstruction shall be in full view of the public. 
(b)  Any person who maliciously or wantonly, and without legal cause, removes, extinguishes, diminishes or disturbs a light or other warning device so placed shall be liable to a penalty of not less than $25.00, nor more than $50.00 and, in addition thereto, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.9)  
Sec. 18-700. - Restoration of streets, alleys and sidewalks. 
Whenever any street, alley or sidewalk is damaged by the erection or alteration of any building abutting thereon by reason of the construction thereof, the street, alley or sidewalk shall be cleaned and restored by, or at the expense of, the owner of the building involved or his contractor, to a condition as good and serviceable as prior to the beginning of the work. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.10)  
Sec. 18-701. - Awnings. 
Awnings attached to buildings or structures may extend beyond the street line, but not closer than 18 inches to the curbline, provided that such awnings are not less than six feet, six inches from the bottom of a soft flap or drop, or seven feet from the bottom of the awning frame or hard drop above the sidewalk at all points. 
(Code 1959, § 5.4.11)  
Secs. 18-702—18-730. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS FOR DEMOLITION AND CONSTRUCTION WORK IN THE VILLAGE 
 
Sec. 18-731. - Applicability of standards and conditions. 
The standards and conditions of this article shall apply to all work undertaken in the Village in conjunction with a permit issued under this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 30.1)  
Sec. 18-732. - Applicability of requirements. 
The requirements of this article shall apply to all work, whether demolition work or construction work, for which a permit is required under this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 30.2)  
Sec. 18-733. - Conflicts. 
In the event of any inconsistency or conflict in the application or operation of the provisions of this article and other provisions of this Code, the provisions of this article shall apply and control. 
(Code 1959, § 30.3)  
Sec. 18-734. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commencement of construction means the beginning of new work under a permit for the structure being constructed. 
Commencement of demolition means any work done in conjunction with a permit issued pursuant to this chapter, other than the installation of the protective fencing required pursuant to other Code provisions and any approved erosion control. 
Completion of demolition means removal of the walls of the first floor above the foundation of the structure being demolished or removal of all foundation material from the excavation in the case of a foundation removal. 
Construction means all of the on-site work done in building or altering structures, from land clearance to completion, including the excavation, erection, and the assembly and installation of components and equipment. 
Demolition means the razing and removal of all or substantially all of a structure or removal of such portions of a principal structure as to make the structure uninhabitable or unsafe for human occupancy. 
(Code 1959, § 30.4) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-735. - Permit time limit. 
No permit or approval made pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for a period of more than one year after the date of issuance. 
(Code 1959, § 30.5)  
Sec. 18-736. - Permit or approval renewal and reissuance fee. 
The fee for any renewal or reissuance of any permit or approval shall be the same as the original cost of such permit or approval. 
(Code 1959, § 30.6)  
Sec. 18-737. - Required plans and specifications. 
Every application for a permit shall be accompanied by the following plans and specifications: 
(1)  Building plans and specifications. 
a.  If the application includes demolition of a principal structure, the application shall include building plans and specifications, prepared in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, for any structure to be built on the subject property except, when, in the opinion of the Village manager or designee, it is in the public interest to allow the demolition of such structure and site restoration prior to submittal of plans and specifications for any structure to be built on the site, in the event that: 
i.  The structure constitutes a clear safety or health hazard, if not demolished. 
ii.  The condition of the existing structure is determined to be in a condition that it is a detriment to the neighboring community. 
ii.  The demolition of said structure will not adversely impact the structural integrity of an adjacent structure. 
Site restoration, as per subsection (2), includes, without limitation, the backfilling of any excavation, grading, seeding, fencing, or storm water management necessary to render the site clean, and safe, until construction of a new structure has commenced. 
A cash escrow shall be posted with the Village, to guarantee that site restoration is completed within 90 days of the demolition of a structure. Such 90-day period may be extended by the Village manager for good cause shown. The escrow shall be in the amount of 110 percent of the cost of final grading and seeding the site. 
b.  If commencement of construction of such structure is not planned or does not occur within 30 days after completion of demolition, the application also shall include a detailed site restoration plan as provided in subsection (2) of this section. 
(2)  Site restoration plans and specifications. If the application includes demolition of a principal structure and commencement of construction of a new structure is not planned or does not occur within 30 days after completion of demolition, the application shall include a detailed site restoration plan depicting all work required to restore the subject property, within 30 days after completion of demolition, to a safe, clean condition until construction of a new structure has commenced, including, without limitation, backfilling of any excavation, grading, seeding, fencing, stormwater management, etc. 
(Code 1959, § 30.7; Ord. No. 4942, § 2, 1-16-2007)  
Sec. 18-738. - Stormwater management and soil sedimentation and erosion control plans. 
In addition to all other Village departmental regulations, ordinances, plans and specifications, the permit application shall include detailed plans and specifications for stormwater management, soil erosion control and grading on the subject property. Such plans and specifications shall be on a drawing separate from all other plans and specifications, labeled as "stormwater management plans" and/or "soil sedimentation and erosion control plans." Such plans and specifications shall be prepared by a professional engineer, shall be made in conformance with the requirements of the Village's subdivision and engineering guide and shall include a certification by the applicant, in a form provided by the Village, that all requirements of the Village's codes, ordinances and regulations related to stormwater management, soil erosion control and grading shall be satisfied by the applicant at all times. Among other details, the required stormwater management plans shall include: 
(1)  Drainage plans and soil erosion control during demolition, if any. 
(2)  Stormwater management and soil erosion control during any period of time between completion of demolition and commencement of construction. 
(3)  Stormwater management and soil erosion control, commencing with the preparation for foundation pouring and continuing during the entire new construction process until final grading of the subject property. 
(Code 1959, § 30.8; Ord. No. 4942, § 2, 1-16-2007)  
Sec. 18-739. - Accessibility, parking and loading plans. 
The application shall include separate plans and specifications, showing the location of all work affecting, and all parking and loading activities planned to take place on, public streets, sidewalks and other rights-of-way. Such plans and specifications shall include, but not be limited to the: 
(1)  Location of pavement, sidewalks and trees that may be affected by the proposed work; 
(2)  Impact on such pavement, sidewalks and trees; 
(3)  Proposed location for all parking of contractor and worker vehicles; 
(4)  Proposed location of any loading or unloading activities, including concrete to occur within any right-of-way; 
(5)  Proposed location of the gravel mat required by section 18-744(3); 
(6)  Proposed fencing or other protective measures; and 
(7)  Temporary pavement or other temporary accessibility measures. 
(Code 1959, § 30.9)  
Sec. 18-740. - Materials and spoils storage plans. 
The permit application shall include plans depicting the proposed location for storage of materials and spoil on the subject property that are consistent with Village soil and sedimentation and erosion control requirements. 
(Code 1959, § 30.10)  
Sec. 18-741. - Dust and airborne particle control. 
The permit application shall include provisions for controlling dust and other airborne particles from the subject property, including, without limitation, a source of water and spraying equipment, and any other measures to be taken to control airborne particles. 
(Code 1959, § 30.11)  
Sec. 18-742. - Fencing. 
(a)  If a permit issued by the Village authorizes demolition or construction of a new structure, then the applicant shall erect a six-foot chainlink fence to be installed around the perimeter of the structure under construction, around the perimeter of the entire subdivision or site, or around the perimeter of adjacent structures concurrently under construction, and such installation shall be in a location and manner approved by the development department. The fencing shall be installed not more than seven days, nor less than four days before the commencement of any work on the subject property, including mass grading and the installation of site utilities, pursuant to any permit issued by the Village. Such fencing shall remain in place until a certificate of occupancy is issued for the structure. The location of the perimeter fencing may be changed during the construction period with the approval of the development department. "No Trespassing" signs shall be mounted on the fencing in conspicuous locations around the site. If the size of the construction site is too large for fencing alone to be effective, in the judgment of the development department, the permittee must have the construction area patrolled by a licensed State detective agency during the hours specified in this article for the closing and locking of gates. 
(b)  Any gate in a perimeter fence must be closed at all times, except to allow ingress and egress to and from the site. Such gate must be locked at all times, other than permitted hours of construction as specified in section 18-744(11) and at any other time when no work is being performed on the site, for example on Saturday, Sunday or holidays. 
(c)  Fencing, as provided in this section, shall also be required for any construction project of the Village, school or park district, or any other public agency, whether or not a building permit has been or is required to be issued by the Village, when the project is located within the Village. 
(d)  Fencing, as provided in this section, shall also be required around any activity, whether a building permit is required or not, where construction or landscaping materials are stored or stockpiled. 
(e)  In addition to perimeter fencing as required in this section, the permit applicant shall cause safety fencing to be installed around every tree in the parkway abutting the subject property. Such tree fencing shall be located, as far as feasible, at the dripline of the tree, whether on public or private property; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be construed or applied to authorize placement of tree fencing on private property not owned by the applicant, unless proper permission for such tree fencing has been secured from the property owner by the applicant. If placement of tree fencing is not feasible at the dripline of the tree, then such fencing shall be installed in a location approved by the forestry division of the public works department. 
(f)  When a violation of this section is observed, the permittee, general contractor or property owner shall be notified promptly and shall correct the violation within two hours of receiving notice thereof. If the violation is not corrected, the Village shall have the right, but not the obligation, to correct the violation. The costs and fees associated with such corrective action shall be charged to the permittee or property owner, and the Village may place a lien on the property to collect such costs. The Village shall also have the right to issue an immediate stop work order applicable to the site until compliance is achieved and/or the costs, fees or fines are paid. 
(Code 1959, § 30.12)  
Sec. 18-743. - Posted notice of commencement of demolition or construction. 
The permit applicant shall cause notice of demolition or construction to be given by posting the subject property, in a prominent place, with a sign announcing such commencement. The size, shape, color and message of such sign shall be as required by the development department. Such sign shall include notice that the rules and regulations applicable to demolition and construction work are available at the development department. Such sign shall be posted not less than 14 days in advance of such commencement, and shall be maintained on the subject property until all work on the subject property has been completed and approved, or until removal of the sign is approved by the director of development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 30.13; Ord. No. 5431, § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-744. - Site management standards. 
The following site management standards shall apply to all work: 
(1)  Accessibility, parking and loading. No pavement or sidewalk within any public right-of-way shall be unavailable for public use at any time, except when such pavement or sidewalk is removed and replaced. No such pavement or sidewalk that is removed and replaced shall be out of service for more than three days without the prior approval of the engineering department. No parking, loading or storage of demolition debris, spoil or construction materials shall be permitted within any right-of-way, on any public property or within ten feet of any right-of-way adjacent to public or private property, unless specifically approved by the Village and shown on approved accessibility plans as required by section 18-739. The Village may prohibit parking in any particular location on a public right-of-way if the Village determines that such parking has an adverse impact on neighboring property or traffic control. All uses of vehicles shall comply with applicable codes related to parking and time of operation of vehicles. 
(2)  Particulate control. Airborne particles shall be controlled at the subject property at all times during work by means of a water truck and spraying equipment or other water source capable of spraying and thoroughly saturating all portions of the structure and surrounding property affected by the work. Such spraying shall be undertaken at all times as necessary to thoroughly control the creation and migration of airborne particles, including, without limitation, dust, from the subject property. 
(3)  Gravel mat. When determined by the Village engineer to be appropriate and practicable, the applicant shall cause a gravel mat to be installed on the subject property, of a size and in a location sufficient to wash down all vehicles used on the subject property and to cause dirt and mud to be removed from the tires of such vehicles. The gravel mat shall be located so as not to interfere with any use by the public of public rights-of-way and not to cause any nuisance or inconvenience to adjacent public or private property. 
(4)  Sanitation facilities. A portable toilet shall be provided at every site of construction of a new principal structure, or addition thereto, prior to the commencement of construction, unless an existing facility is available on the construction site. The proposed location of any portable toilet shall be depicted on plans submitted at the time of application for the review and approval of the development department, so that the location shall have the least possible impact on adjacent properties. 
(5)  Litter and debris control and cleanup. Litter and debris at the subject property shall be controlled at all times. The applicant shall designate a person regularly present at the subject property as having responsibility to assure that no litter or debris leaves the subject property and that all litter and debris is removed from the subject property before the end of every day, including weekends, and regardless of whether work was conducted that day on the subject property. The permit shall specify the location of the dumpster, as approved by the development department. 
(6)  Street and sidewalk cleaning. The applicant shall cause all dirt, mud, gravel, crushed stone, wood, blocks, bottles, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, and other debris from the subject property or related to any work conducted on the subject property, to be cleaned regularly from all sidewalks and streets adjoining and in the area of the subject property on every day that construction occurs on such property. 
(7)  Entry authorization. No permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall authorize or be construed to authorize any entry onto property adjoining the subject property or any work for which entry onto property adjoining the subject property is or may be necessary, unless a proper right of entry has been secured from the owner of such property. 
(8)  Stormwater management. Stormwater shall be managed during all phases of demolition and new construction so as not to impact adjacent properties and/or public rights-of-way in accordance with the requirements of the subdivision and engineering guide. 
(9)  Wastewater discharge. No person shall undertake any work pursuant to a permit issued under this chapter, from which the discharge of any wastewater will be caused or associated, without prior approval of the director of public works. It shall be the duty of the person undertaking any such work to direct all wastewater flow to the particular location designated by the public works department. No person undertaking such work shall cause or allow any cement truck wash to be discharged onto any public property or into any catchbasin or other Village sewer facility. 
(10)  Limitations of noise. All work undertaken pursuant to a permit issued under this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 98, article VIII, related to limitations on noise. Further, no person shall operate or cause to be operated any radio, phonograph, telecommunications device or other such object at such a volume or in any other manner that would cause a nuisance or disturbance to any person. Every contractor and permittee shall be responsible for all actions of their employees, agents and subcontractors under this subsection, and shall be liable for all violations of the provisions of this subsection committed by such employees, agents or subcontractors. 
(11)  Permissible hours of construction. All work undertaken pursuant to a permit issued under this chapter may occur only between the following hours: 
a.  7:00 a.m.—7:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
b.  9:00 a.m.—6:00 p.m. on Saturdays. 
c.  9:00 a.m.—5:00 p.m. on Sundays. 
(Code 1959, § 30.14; Ord. No. 4921, § 2, 10-17-2006; Ord. No. 5431 § 3, 3-1-2011)  
Sec. 18-745. - Commencement of construction or site restoration. 
Either construction of an approved new structure shall have commenced, or the subject property shall have been fully restored in conformance with the approved site restoration plan, if any, or with such other plans as may be approved by the Village, within 30 days after the completion of demolition. Such 30-day period may be extended by one day for every business day that weather conditions prevent construction or restoration work on the subject property, as determined by the director of development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 30.15)  
Sec. 18-746. - Coal tar sealants prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Coal tar is a byproduct of the process used to refine coal. Coal tar contains high levels of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). 
Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a group of organic chemicals that are present in coal tar and are an environmental concern to human health and watershed life. 
Pavement sealing means the application of sealant or sealcoat product to maintain any surface, including but not limited to, a driveway, driveway approach, on- or off-street parking area, playground, sidewalk, bike trail, patio, sports facility, loading area or facility, street, highway, or roadway. 
(b)  Prohibition on pavement sealing using coal tar products. On public and private property, no coal tar products of any kind, including coal tar derivatives, coal tar mixtures, or any other product containing equivalent levels of PAHs, shall be applied or used for pavement sealing within the Village. Any person engaging in pavement sealing must have a Material Safety Data Sheet available on premises for the product being used for pavement sealing. 
(c)  Prohibition on sale of coal tar products. No person may sell, offer to sell, or display for sale any product used for pavement sealing within the Village that is labeled as containing coal tar products." 
(Ord. No. 6157, § 3, 5-1-2018) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 6157, § 2, adopted May 1, 2018, renumbered § 18-746 as § 18-747; and § 3 enacted a new § 18-746 to read as set out herein.  
Sec. 18-747. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $500.00, nor more than $1,000.00. Each day such violation or failure to comply is permitted to exist after notification thereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any construction undertaken in conjunction with the provisions of this article until such time that all penalties and fines have been resolved to the satisfaction of the director of development or his/her designee. 
(Code 1959, § 30.16; Ord. No. 6157, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 6157, § 2, adopted May 1, 2018, renumbered § 18-746 as § 18-747. See editors note at § 18-746 for more information.  
Secs. 18-748—18-770. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL 
 
Sec. 18-771. - Findings of fact; purpose. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees find that: 
(1)  Excessive quantities of soil are eroding from areas that are undergoing development for certain nonagricultural uses, including, but not limited to, the construction of dwelling units, commercial buildings and industrial plants, the building of roads and highways, and the creation of recreational facilities; 
(2)  The washing, blowing and falling of eroded soil across and upon roadways endangers the health and safety of users thereof by decreasing vision and reducing traction of road vehicles; 
(3)  Such soil erosion necessitates the costly repairing of gullies, washed-out fills and embankments; 
(4)  The sediment from such soil erosion tends to clog sewers and ditches, and pollutes and silts rivers, streams, lakes and reservoirs; 
(5)  Such sediment limits the use of water and waterways for most beneficial purposes, destroying fish and other aquatic life, and that is costly and difficult to remove; and 
(6)  Such sediment reduces the channel capacity of waterways, resulting in greatly increased chances of flooding at grave danger to public health and safety. 
(b)  It is the purpose of this article to provide minimum standards to safeguard persons, protect property and prevent the despoliation of the environment, and promote the public welfare by regulating and controlling the design, construction, quality of materials and use and maintenance of any development or other activity which disturbs or breaks the topsoil or otherwise results in the movement of earth. 
(Code 1959, § 24.12C.1; Ord. No. 4512, 4-15-2003)  
Sec. 18-772. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Architect means a registered architect of the State. 
Building permit means a written authorization issued by the Village for the construction, erection or alteration of a structure or building. 
Excavation means any act by which organic matter, earth, sand, gravel, rock or any other similar material is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed, displaced or relocated and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom. 
Fill means any act by which earth, sand, gravel, rock or any other material suitable for its intended use is deposited, placed, replaced, pushed, dumped, pulled, transported or moved by man to a new location and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom. 
Grading means the use of excavation or fill to bring the ground surface in conformity with the site development plan. 
Land surveyor means a registered surveyor of the State. 
Parcel means all contiguous land in one ownership. 
Permittee means any person to whom a site development permit is issued. 
Person means any person, firm or corporation, public or private, the State and its agencies or political subdivisions, and the United States of America, its agencies and instrumentalities, and any agent, servant, officer or employee thereof. 
Professional engineer means a registered professional engineer of the State. 
Site means a lot or parcel of land, or a contiguous combination thereof, where the site development is performed. 
Site development means altering the terrain on a site and/or providing construction on a site and/or providing landscaping on a site. 
Site development permit means a permit issued by the Village for site development. 
Site development plan means a drawing or other written description, sealed by an architect or professional engineer, which illustrates and/or describes the site development. 
Vacant means land on which there are no structures or only structures which are secondary to the use or maintenance of the land itself. 
(Code 1959, § 24.12C.2; Ord. No. 4512, 4-15-2003) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-773. - General criteria and standards. 
The following general principles shall apply to any movement of earth and any sedimentation and erosion control plan, and the granting of a permit for the execution of such plan as provided in this article: 
(1)  The smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at any given time during development. 
(2)  Such minimum area exposure shall be kept to as short a duration of time as practical. 
(3)  Temporary vegetation or, where appropriate, mulching or other nonviable cover shall be used to protect areas exposed during development. 
(4)  Sediment basins, debris basins, desilting basins or silt traps shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from runoff waters from land undergoing development. 
(5)  Provision shall be made to effectively accommodate the increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions during and after development. 
(6)  Permanent, final plant covering or structures shall be installed as soon as possible. 
(7)  The development plan shall relate to the topography and soils of the site so that the lowest potential for erosion is created. 
(8)  Natural plant covering shall be retained and protected as far as is consistent with developing the site. 
(Code 1959, § 24.12C.3; Ord. No. 4512, 4-15-2003)  
Sec. 18-774. - Site development permit. 
(a)  Required; exemptions. 
(1)  Before site development commences by any person within the Village, a site development permit shall be obtained from the director of development or his/her designee, where development comes under any one or more of the following provisions, unless such development is exempted therefrom by subsection (a)(2) of this section: 
a.  Excavation or fill, or any combination thereof, will exceed 100 cubic yards. 
b.  Fill will exceed three feet in vertical height at its highest point, measured from the natural ground surface. 
c.  Excavation will exceed four feet in vertical depth at its deepest point. 
d.  Excavation or fill, or any combination thereof, will exceed an area of 5,000 square feet. 
e.  Plant cover is to be removed from an area exceeding 5,000 square feet on any vacant parcel or any parcel in excess of ten acres. 
(2)  A site development permit shall not be required in the following cases: 
a.  Excavations below finished grade for septic tanks and drainfields, tanks, vaults, tunnels, basements, swimming pools, cellars or footings of buildings or structures for which a building permit shall have been issued by the Village. 
b.  Excavation or removal of vegetation in public utility easements by public utility companies for the purpose of installing underground utilities. 
c.  Tilling of the soil for fire protection purposes. 
d.  Engaging in the following, only if in connection with a farming or other agricultural or conservation enterprise and upon property zoned solely for farming or agricultural purposes and uses: 
1.  Construction of grassed waterways; 
2.  Construction of terraces; 
3.  Construction of surface water diversions; 
4.  Construction of grade stabilization structures; or 
5.  Tilling of the soil. 
(b)  Application. 
(1)  No site development permit or building permit shall be issued until the developer submits a site development plan, together with other submissions required by this chapter, and certifies that any site development shall be in accordance with such plan and submissions. 
(2)  Each application for a site development permit shall be made by the owner of the property or his authorized agent to the director of development or his/her designee on a form furnished for that purpose. When site development is proposed as a part of a building permit application, it may be combined, and one plot plan, in the number of copies required by the director of development or his/her designee, may be submitted, showing building plans and site development plans. In all instances, a registered land surveyor shall certify as to the accuracy of the existing contour lines. Each application shall be accompanied by the following, unless the director of development or his/her designee finds any item unnecessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article; provided, however, that no exemption from subsection (b)(2)a. of this section shall be granted to any applicant who intends to move in excess of 500 cubic yards of dirt: 
a.  With respect to site development, a site development plan showing the acreage of the site, boundary line survey, zoning, type of proposed sewer and water facilities, location of existing utilities, buildings and drains on and within 100 feet of the site, together with a legend and scale. There shall be included on or with the site development plan: 
1.  A soil map of the subject property, showing the predominant soil types on the site. 
2.  Enough information on the areas abutting or adjacent to the site to show existing drainage patterns and the drainage course that may affect, or be affected by, the development of the site. 
3.  Name and address of the developer or owner. 
4.  Name and address of any architectural or consulting firm retained by the applicant, together with the name of the applicant's principal contact at such firm. 
5.  Limits of natural floodplains, if any. 
6.  Areas to be sodded, seeded, mulched or paved. 
7.  Acreage of area to be vegetatively stabilized, if any. 
8.  Areas to be left undisturbed. 
b.  With respect to site grading, existing topography of the site and a 100-foot adjacent peripheral strip, proposed contours and final grades, and street profiles, and indicating what measures will be employed to protect cut and fill slopes from surface runoff. 
c.  Storm drainage, by means of a plan based upon a competent storm drainage study, including a drainage area map and computations, and indicating what conditions now prevail at proposed and natural outlets, such as: 
1.  Whether the drainage course is bare earth or vegetated. 
2.  Whether the constructed outlet will be in open sun, open shade or dense shade. 
3.  Whether the natural or proposed outlet is subject to longterm or continuous flow. 
4.  Whether the existing outlet is actively eroding. 
5.  Whether there is evidence of a high water table, permanent or seasonal. 
6.  Whether the area is subject to seepage or spring flow. 
7.  Elevation of normal water level in all proposed and natural outlets. 
8.  A profile below the outlet for a sufficient distance to indicate the natural gradient of the accepting natural outlet and/or stream channel. 
9.  A cross section and profile of existing stream channels, where applicable. 
10.  A ditch and computations for all seeded, sodded or bare earth outlets, ditches and similar water conduction facilities. 
d.  An estimate schedule and phasing of development of the site, as follows: 
1.  Phase I, stripping and/or clearing. 
2.  Phase II, rough grading and construction. 
3.  Phase III, final grading and vegetative establishment. 
4.  Phase IV, maintenance. 
e.  All the erosion and sediment control measures needed to provide protection throughout all phases of construction as set forth in subsection (b)(2)d. of this section. Such plans shall also include any off-site borrow and spoil areas, sewer lines, utility lines, and haul and access roads, and shall further indicate: 
1.  Start of clearing date. 
2.  Duration of exposure of disturbed areas. 
3.  Installation of temporary sediment control measures, vegetative and structural, by phase and date. 
4.  Installation of storm drainage, by phase and date. 
5.  Paving of streets and parking areas, if any, by phase and date. 
6.  Establishment of permanent vegetative cover (plans will show what will be done to shorten the duration of exposure of disturbed areas as soon after grading as possible), including seeding mixes and rates, type of sod, seedbed preparation, seeding dates, lime and fertilizer application, temporary seedings, if needed, mulching or similar stabilization procedures. 
7.  Details of all structural sediment control measures. 
8.  Computations for sediment basins, if any. 
f.  The standards and specifications for soil erosion and sediment control, August 1973 edition, as compiled by the North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District, and approved by the president and board of trustees of the Village, are hereby incorporated into this section and made a part of this article by reference, for the purpose of exemplifying the considerations and factors which should enter into the preparation of a site development plan. 
(c)  Bonds. A cash bond, approved by the Village manager, shall be posted which is sufficient to cover all the costs of improvements, landscaping and maintenance of landscaping for such period to be specified as a condition of the issuance of a site development permit. 
(d)  Review. To further the specific purposes of this article, the following review procedures are established: 
(1)  Grading work under 500 cubic yards. Where the aggregate volume of grading on any site or contiguous group of sites is in excess of 100 cubic yards, but not over 500 cubic yards, the director of development or his/her designee shall review the application for the proposed site development permit. If the director of development or his/her designee finds the application for the proposed grading plan in conformance with the provisions of this article, he may issue a permit, with such reasonable conditions as he may deem necessary to substantially secure the objectives of this article, or he may, in the alternative, refer the application to the North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District in the manner provided in subsection (d)(2) of this section. 
(2)  Grading work in excess of 500 cubic yards and/or removal of vegetation. 
a.  Where the aggregate volume of grading on any site or contiguous group of sites is in excess of 500 cubic yards or the proposed cuts and fills exceed five feet at their maximum point, or where approval to remove plant cover is required by this article, the director of development or his/her designee shall refer the application to the North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District for review and recommendation. Such recommendations shall be submitted to the director of development or his/her designee within 30 days. 
b.  Upon receipt of the recommendations of the North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District, and after consideration thereof, the director of development or his/her designee shall approve the application with such reasonable conditions as he may deem necessary to substantially secure the objectives of this article, or disapprove the application for the site development. 
c.  Failure of the director of development or his/her designee to make a determination upon the approval, conditional approval or disapproval of the application for a site development permit within 60 days after receipt of all necessary information for such action will constitute an approval of the application unless such time is extended with the consent of the applicant. 
(3)  Earth removal. No site development permit shall be issued for an intended building site unless: 
a.  Such permit is accompanied by or combined with a valid building permit issued by the Village; or 
b.  The proposed earth moving is coordinated with any overall plan previously approved by the Village for the area in which the site is situated. 
(e)  Appeals. The applicant, as well as any person who has received notice of the filing of the application for a site development permit, or the North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District may appeal the decision of the director of development or his/her designee, including any approval resulting from lack of action by the director of development or his/her designee as provided in subsection (d)(2)c. of this section, to the zoning board of appeals. Upon receipt of an appeal, the zoning board of appeals shall schedule and hold a public hearing, after giving 15 days' notice thereof. The zoning board of appeals shall render a decision within 30 days of the hearing. Factors to be considered on review shall include, but not be limited to, possible saturation of fill and unsupported cuts by water, both natural and domestic; runoff surface waters that produce erosion and silting of drainageways; nature and type of soil or rock that, when disturbed by the proposed grading, may create earth movement and produce slopes that cannot be landscaped; and excessive and unnecessary scarring of the natural landscape through grading or removal of vegetation. 
(f)  Responsibility. Failure of Village officials to observe or recognize hazardous or unsightly conditions or to recommend denial of the site development permit, or of the zoning board of appeals to deny such permit shall not relieve the permittee from responsibility for the condition or damage resulting therefrom and shall not result in the Village, its officers or agent being responsible for any condition or damage resulting therefrom. 
(g)  Retention of plans, specifications and reports. Plans, specifications and reports for all site developments shall be retained in original form or on microfilm by the director of development or his/her designee. 
(h)  Inspections. The director of development or his/her designee shall make inspections as required in this article and shall either approve that portion of the work completed or shall notify the permittee wherein the work fails to comply with the site development plan. Where it is found by inspection that conditions are not substantially as stated or shown in the plan, the director of development or his/her designee may stop further work until approval is obtained for a revised grading plan conforming to the existing conditions. Plans for grading work, bearing the stamp of approval of the director of development or his/her designee, shall be maintained at the site during progress of the grading. Until the final inspection is made, a sign issued by the Village indicating permission to grade has been granted by the Village shall be prominently displayed on the front property line of the property involved so as to be visible from the street on which the property fronts. In order to obtain inspections in accordance with the following schedule, the permittee shall notify the director of development or his/her designee at least two full working days before the inspection is to be made: 
(1)  Rough grading. The rough grading inspection shall be performed when all rough grading has been completed. 
(2)  Final inspection. The final inspection shall be performed when all work indicated on the site development plan has been completed. 
(Code 1959, § 24.12C.4; Ord. No. 4512, 4-15-2003)  
Sec. 18-775. - Operation standards and requirements. 
(a)  Applicability. All earth moving grading and grading operations not specifically exempted by the provisions of this article shall comply with the applicable standards and requirements set forth in this section in addition to the other requirements of this article. 
(b)  Adoption by reference. The Standards and Specifications for Soil Erosion and Sediment Control, August 1973 edition, as compiled by the North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District and approved by the president and board of trustees of the Village, are hereby incorporated into this section and made a part of this article by reference, for the purpose of delineating procedures and methods of operation under development plans approved in section 18-774. In the event of conflict between provisions of the Standards and Specifications for Soil Erosion and Sediment Control and other provisions of this article, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(c)  Special precautions. 
(1)  If, at any stage of the grading, the director of development or his/her designee determines by inspection that the nature of the formation is such that further work as authorized by an existing permit is likely to imperil any property, public way, watercourse or drainage structure, the director of development or his/her designee may require, as a condition to allowing the work to be done, that such reasonable safety precautions be taken as he considers advisable to avoid the likelihood of such peril. Special precautions may include, but shall not be limited to, specifying a more level exposed slope, construction of additional drainage facilities, berms, terracing, compaction or cribbing, installation of plant materials for erosion control and reports of a professional engineer specializing in soils and/or engineering geology, who certifies as to his specialty, whose recommendations may be made requirements for further work. 
(2)  Where it appears that storm damage may result because the grading is not complete, work may be stopped and the permittee required to install temporary planting to control erosion, install temporary structures or take such other measures as may be required to protect adjoining property or the public safety. On large operations or where unusual site conditions prevail, the director of development or his/her designee may specify the time of starting grading and the time of completion or may require that the operations be conducted in specific stages so as to ensure completion of protective measures or devices prior to the advent of seasonal rains. 
(d)  Permit expiration. Every site development permit shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the work authorized by such permit has not been commenced within 180 days, or is not completed within one year from the date of issue of such permit, except that the director of development or his/her designee may, if the permit holder presents satisfactory evidence that unusual difficulties have prevented work being started or completed within the specified time limits, grant a reasonable extension of time, if written application is made before the expiration date of the permit. 
(Code 1959, § 24.12C.5; Ord. No. 4512, 4-15-2003)  
Sec. 18-776. - Exceptions; permit revocation or suspension; charges and fees; nuisances; violations and penalties. 
(a)  Exceptions. The zoning board of appeals may authorize exceptions to any of the requirements and regulations set forth in this article. 
(1)  Application. Application for any exception shall be made by a verified petition of the applicant, stating fully the grounds of the application and the facts relied upon by the petitioner. Such petition shall be filed with the site development permit application. In order for the land referred to in the petition to come within the provisions of this section, it shall be necessary that the zoning board of appeals find all of the following facts with respect thereto: 
a.  The land is of such shape or size or is affected by such physical conditions or is subject to such title limitations or record that it is impossible or impractical for the subdivider to comply with all of the regulations of this article. 
b.  The exception is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner. 
c.  The granting of the exception will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the vicinity of the subject property. 
(2)  Referral of proposed exception. Each proposed exception shall be referred to the officers or agencies involved and such officers or agencies shall transmit their recommendations to the zoning board of appeals, which recommendations shall be reviewed prior to the granting of any exception. 
(3)  Decision of zoning board of appeals. After a public hearing thereon, the zoning board of appeals, by resolution, may approve the site development permit application with the exceptions and conditions it deems necessary or disapprove such site development permit application and exception application or take such other action as is appropriate. 
(b)  Permit revocation or suspension. 
(1)  Authority. If any person holding a site development permit pursuant to this article violates the terms of the permit, or conducts or carries on such site development in such a manner as to materially adversely affect the health, welfare or safety of persons residing or working in the neighborhood of the property of the permittee, or conducts or carries on such site development so that it is materially detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to property or improvements in the neighborhood, the director of development or his/her designee shall revoke or suspend the site development permit. 
(2)  Procedure. 
a.  No site development permit shall be permanently revoked or suspended until a hearing is held by the zoning board of appeals. Written notice of such hearing shall be served upon the permittee, either personally or by registered mail, and shall state the: 
1.  Grounds for complaint or reasons for the revocation or suspension, in clear and concise language. 
2.  Time when and the place where such hearing is to be held. 
b.  Such notice shall be served by registered mail or personal service on the permittee at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. At any such hearing, the permittee shall be given an opportunity to be heard, and he may call witnesses and present evidence on his behalf. Upon conclusion of such hearing, the zoning board of appeals shall determine whether or not the permit shall be suspended or revoked. 
c.  The zoning board of appeals shall hold the hearing to consider recommendations for revocation or suspension of permits which have been temporarily suspended at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the zoning board of appeals, at which all conditions of subsection (b)(2)b. of this section can be fulfilled. 
(c)  Charges and fees. 
(1)  Charges for services shall be computed on the basis of two percent of the estimated cost of site development, including the cost of grading, temporary or permanent soil conservation devices and final landscaping, to cover plan review and site inspection costs. If a contract for site development exists, 100 percent of the contract cost for site development and ten percent for contingencies shall be used in computing the service charge. 
(2)  Filing fees for appeals or exceptions to any of the provisions of this article shall be as specified in the rules of procedure of the Village zoning board of appeals. 
(d)  Nuisances. This article shall not be construed as authorizing any person to maintain a private or public nuisance as caused by the implementation of a site development plan upon their property, and compliance with the provisions of this article shall not be a defense in any action to abate such nuisance. 
(e)  Violations and penalties. No person shall construct, enlarge, alter, repair or maintain any grading, excavation or fill, or cause such to be done, contrary to or in violation of any provisions of this article. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day, or portion thereof, during which any violation of any of the provisions of this article is committed, continued or permitted, and, upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punished by as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 24.12C.6; Ord. No. 4512, 4-15-2003)  
Secs. 18-777—18-800. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS IN EDENS EXPRESSWAY NOISE IMPACT AREA 
 
Sec. 18-801. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this section is to further protect existing and future residential properties from the adverse impact of noise generated by the traffic on the Edens Expressway (Interstate Highway 94), which is a limited-access expressway bordering certain residential properties in the Village of Glenview. This section identifies the geographic boundaries of an Edens Expressway Noise Impact Area, wherein noise from the Edens Expressway adversely impacts the quality of life in residential structures near the Edens Expressway, and prescribes construction standards for that portion of the Village of Glenview which is uniquely and adversely impacted by this noise. This section also sets forth the procedures for the implementation and enforcement of sound transmission control construction requirements. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(200.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-802. - Definitions. 
(a)  For purposes of this section the term "construction" shall mean new construction of principal residential buildings and remodeling and additions to existing principal residential buildings as required by the building codes adopted by incorporation under section 18-191. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "Edens Expressway Noise Impact Area" shall mean those properties legally described below, with common addresses of 905 to 941 Long Road, Glenview, Illinois: 
905 Long Road. Lot 20 in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden's being a subdivision of part of the west 44 acres of the north half of the southeast quarter also part of the east ten acres of the northeast quarter of the southwest quarter and also the vacated east three feet of Long Road all in Section 31, also, a strip of land being a proportionate share of surplus in the north half of the southeast quarter appurtenant to part of the west 44 acres of aforesaid, in Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian, in Cook County, Illinois. 
907 Long Road. Lot 19 in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden's subdivision in the southeast quarter and the southwest quarter of Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian, in Cook County, Illinois also the vacated east three feet of LeClaire Avenue (Long Road) lying west of and adjoining said Lot 19 Block 2 aforesaid, in Cook County, Illinois. 
911 Long Road. Lot 18 in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden's being a subdivision of part of the west 44 acres of the north half of the southeast quarter also part of the east ten acres of the northeast quarter of the southwest quarter and also the vacated east three feet of Long Road, all in Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian; also a strip of land being a proportionate share of the surplus in the north half of the southeast quarter appurtenant to part of the west 44 acres aforesaid in Cook County, Illinois. 
915 Long Road. 921 Long Road. Lot 1 in Patterson's resubdivision of part of Lot 16 and the vacated three feet of street lying west of and adjoining said Lot 16 in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden in the southeast quarter and the southwest quarter of Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian, in Cook County, Illinois. 
925 Long Road. Lot 15 in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden's being a subdivision of part of the west 44 acres of the north half of the southeast quarter also part of the east ten acres of the northeast quarter of the southwest quarter and also the vacated east three feet of Long Road, all in Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian, also a strip of land being proportionate share of the surplus in the north half of the southeast quarter appurtenant to part of the west 44 acres aforesaid, in Cook County, Illinois. 
929 Long Road. Lot 1 in Jerramichaela Resubdivision of part of Lots 13 and 14 and the 3 feet vacated LeClaire Avenue west of and adjoining said Lots in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden's in the southeast quarter and the southwest quarter of Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, East of the Third Principal Meridian, in Cook County, Illinois. 
939 Long Road. That part of Lot 11 lying west of a line drawn from a point in the north line of said Lot 74.5 feet west of the northeast corner to a point in the south line 63.5 feet west of the southeast corner of said lot in Block 2. 
Also 
That part of Lot 12 lying west of a line drawn from a point in the north line of said lot 63.5 feet west of the northeast corner to a point in the south line of south 2.5 feet west of the southeast corner of said Lot in Bock 2; in United Realty Company's Glenayre Gardens subdivision of part of the west 44 acres of the north half of the southeast quarter also part of the east ten acres of the northeast quarter of the southwest quarter all in Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian, in Cook County, Illinois. 
941 Long Road. 
Parcel 1: Lot 10 (except that part thereof lying easterly of a line drawn from a point in the north line of said lot 7.5 feet west of the northeast corner thereof to a point in the easterly line of said Lot 29 feet south of the northeast corner of said lot, taken for highway) in Block 2 in United Realty Company's Glenayre Garden, a subdivision of part of the west 44 acres of the north half of the southeast quarter, also part of the east ten acres of the northeast quarter of the southwest quarter of Section 31, Township 42 North, Range 13, east of the Third Principal Meridian, in Cook County, Illinois. 
Parcel 2: The north half of vacated 20 foot alley lying South of and adjoining said Lot 10 aforesaid; 
Parcel 3: The vacated east three feet of LeClaire Avenue lying west of and adjoining said Lot 10 aforesaid, and the west line of said lot extended south ten feet to center of alley all in Cook County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(300.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-803. - Applicability, and effective date. 
(a)  The sound transmission control construction requirements set forth in this section shall be applicable to building permits for all residential construction in the Edens Expressway Noise Impact Area, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Construction of new principal residential structures, whether detached dwellings or multi-family dwellings. 
(2)  Construction of additions or modifications to existing principal residential structures, whether detached dwellings or multi-family dwellings, including but not limited to first-floor, second-floor, and dormer additions. 
(b)  The sound transmission control construction requirements referenced in subsection (a) of this section shall become effective and apply to applications for building permits filed with the development department on or after the date 14 days after publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village of Glenview of a notice by the Village of Glenview Director of Development certifying the construction of a noise abatement barrier, commonly referred to as a "sound wall," along the Edens Expressway, has commenced. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(400.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-804. - Exemptions. 
Construction projects that, in the reasonable determination of the director of development or his/her designee, are separate from a principal residential structure or wholly contained within a principal residential structure, shall not be subject to the Edens Expressway Noise Impact Area construction requirements set forth in this section. Such construction projects include, but not limited to, the construction of: 
(1)  Detached garages and car ports. 
(2)  Interior remodeling. 
(3)  Patios. 
(4)  Sidewalks. 
(5)  Driveways. 
(6)  Decks. 
(7)  Fences. 
(8)  Sheds. 
(9)  Porches. 
(10)  Swimming pools and spas. 
(11)  Tennis and outdoor courts. 
(12)  Other "accessory structures" as defined in the Glenview Zoning Ordinance, Chapter 98, Glenview Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(500.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-805. - Noise control construction requirements. 
The director of development or his/her designee shall enforce the following regulations the course of reviewing all building permit applications for construction in the Edens Expressway Noise Impact Area identified in section 18-803, and not exempt under section 18-804. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(600.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-806. - Exterior walls. 
(a)  For any new construction, sheathing must be a minimum of one-half inch of plywood, OSB, or a material of similar mass. 
(b)  The interior face of the exterior walls must be a minimum of one-half inch drywall or a material of similar mass. Lightweight paneling and similar low mass surfaces must be backed with drywall. 
(c)  New construction of exterior walls must include batt or blown-in insulation with a rating of R-13 or higher. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(610.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-807. - Windows. 
Windows must include double-glazed insulating glass. Blocking and insulation must be installed around windows to provide a tight seal. Caulking must be provided to effect an air tight seal. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(620.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-808. - Exterior doors. 
All exterior doors must be solid core or insulated. Blocking and insulation must be installed around doors to provide a tight seal. Caulking must be provided to achieve an airtight seal. Doors must be equipped with gasketing at the head and jamb and equipped with a wipe at the base. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(630.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-809. - Wall penetrations. 
Seal or caulk all opening or penetrations through walls, particularly around water and gas pipes, electrical cables, and refrigerant lines. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(640.0), 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 18-810. - Mechanical openings. 
Ductwork for ducted range hoods and bathroom fans must include one 90-degree bend. The opening through the exterior wall must be caulked. The opening around dryer vents must be caulked. All exhaust vents must include a damper. 
(Ord. No. 4762, § 2(650.0), 6-21-2005)  
Secs. 18-811—18-900. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - INTERNATIONAL EXISTING BUILDING CODE 
 
Sec. 18-901. - International Code Council (ICC) International Existing Building Code adopted; amendments. 
The 2012 edition of the ICC International Existing Building Code is hereby adopted with the following amendments: 
(1)  Section 101.1 Title. Amended to read as follows: "These regulations shall be known as the Existing Building Code of the Village of Glenview, Cook County, Illinois (the "Village") herein referred to as 'this code.'" 
(2)  Section 102.4 Referenced codes and standards. Amended to read as follows: "The codes and standards referenced in this code shall be considered part of the requirements of this code to the prescribed extend of each such reference. Where differences occur between provisions of this code and the referenced standards, the provision of this code shall apply. The following codes and standards are not adopted by reference and thus are not considered a part of this code. 
IPC-2012 International Plumbing Code 
IPSDC-2012 International Private Sewage Disposal Code 
IWUIC-2012 International Wildlife-Urban Interface Code 
IZC-2012 International Zoning Code" 
(Ord. No. 5190, § 14, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5879, § 10, 12-9-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5879, § 10, adopted December 9, 2014, amended § 18-901 to read as set out herein. Previously § 18-901 was titled International Existing Building Code; adopted.  
Secs. 18-592—18-1000. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 5190, § 15, 1-3-2009; Ord. No. 5879, § 11, 12-9-2014)
