Further, such a licensing procedure will place a heretofore nonexistent incentive on the holders of sexually oriented business licenses to see that the sexually oriented business is run in a manner consistent with the health, safety, and welfare of its patrons and employees, as well as the citizens of the Village. It is appropriate to require reasonable assurances that the licensee is the actual operator of the sexually oriented business, fully in possession and control of the premises and the activities occurring therein. 
(19)  Removal of doors on video or live-viewing booths and requiring lighting of sufficient intensity to illuminate the video or live-viewing booth to not less than ten foot candles as measured at the floor level, advances a substantial governmental interest in curbing the illegal and unsanitary sexual activity occurring in adult theaters. 
(20)  Requiring licensees of sexually oriented businesses to keep information regarding current employees and certain past employees will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by preventing minors from working in such establishments. 
(21)  The disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the sexually oriented business, where such information is substantially related to the significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses, will aid in preventing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases. 
(22)  It is desirable in the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases to obtain a limited amount of information regarding certain employees who may engage in the conduct which this article XXIII is designed to prevent or who are likely to be witnesses to such activity. 
(23)  The fact that an applicant for a sexually oriented business license or a sexually oriented business employee license has been convicted of a sexually related crime leads to the rational assumption that the applicant may engage in that conduct in contravention of this article XXIII. 
(24)  The general welfare, health, morals, and safety of the citizens of the Village will be promoted by the enactment of this article XXIII. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-828. - Specified prohibited acts at sexually oriented business establishments. 
(a)  No person at any sexually oriented business shall appear, be present, or perform while nude or semi-nude. No sexually oriented business patron shall appear, be present, or perform while nude or semi-nude. 
(b)  No employee of a sexually oriented business or any other person at any sexually oriented business shall perform or conduct any specified sexual activities with or for any patron of a sexually oriented business or any other employee of a sexually oriented business or any other person. No patron of a sexually oriented business or any other person at any sexually oriented business shall perform or conduct any specified sexual activities with or for any employee or any other patron of a sexually oriented business or any other person. No employee of a sexually oriented business or any other person at any sexually oriented business shall perform or conduct any role-playing interaction in any way related to any specified sexual activities with or for any patron of a sexually oriented business or any other employee of a sexually oriented business or any other person. 
(c)  Straddle dances shall be prohibited at all sexually oriented businesses. 
(d)  No massage, as defined in section 22-601, shall be provided at any sexually oriented business. 
(e)  No alcoholic liquor shall be delivered, received, sold, purchased, provided or consumed by any person at any sexually oriented business. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-829. - Exterior display prohibited; sign limitations; exterior lighting limitations. 
(a)  No sexually oriented business shall be maintained or operated in any manner that causes, creates or allows public viewing of any explicit sexual material, or any entertainment depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, from any area outside of the licensed premises of the sexually oriented business, or from any sidewalk, public or private right-of-way, or any property adjacent to any sexually oriented business. 
(b)  All signs for sexually oriented businesses shall comply with section 98-331, et seq. 
(c)  All exterior lighting shall comply with applicable Village codes and ordinances. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provisions in this article XXIII or the Municipal Code, Village of Glenview, Illinois to the contrary, other than a numerical address sign, a sexually oriented business is prohibited from (i) placing, installing, erecting or otherwise constructing any sign on the exterior facade of a sexually oriented business, or (ii) displaying any window sign, or (iii) a display of any kind on the facade of, or in a window of, a sexually oriented business, which is (1) visible from a pedestrian route via sidewalks located in a public or private right-of-way or ingress/egress easement, whichever shall be applicable, or (2) visible from a vehicle route via streets located in a public or private right-of-way or ingress/egress easement, whichever shall be applicable, or (3) adjacent to a residential district or a public lands district, as defined in Glenview's Zoning Code. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-830. - Noise amplification outdoors. 
No loudspeakers or sound equipment audible beyond the licensed premises shall be used at any time. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-831. - Gambling and related devices prohibited. 
No sexually oriented business shall contain any internet access, video pinball, slot, bagatelle, pigeonhole, pool or any other games, machines or implements of chance. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-832. - Lighting. 
Unless otherwise required under this ordinance, all areas of a sexually oriented business shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access at a minimum illumination level of not less than 50 foot candles as measured at the floor level. It shall be the duty of the licensee, the licensee's employees and agents to insure that the minimum illumination level required by this section 22-832 is maintained at all times the sexually oriented business is open for business. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-833. - Manager's station. 
Each sexually oriented business shall have one or more manager's stations. The interior of each sexually oriented business shall be configured in such a manner that there is either a direct or unobstructed view from at least one manager's station to every part of the entire premises (except restrooms) of such establishment to which any patron of a sexually oriented business is permitted access for any purpose. Where the manager's station will not have a clear view of the entire premises, the use of wide-angle mirrors or video systems shall be required to provide continuous monitoring of blind spots or remote parts of the premises (except restrooms). 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-834. - License required. 
(a)  It is unlawful: 
(1)  For any person to operate a sexually oriented business without a valid sexually oriented business license issued by the Village pursuant to this article; or 
(2)  For any person who operates a sexually oriented business to employ a person to work for the sexually oriented business who is not licensed as a sexually oriented business employee by the Village pursuant to this article; or 
(3)  For any person to obtain employment with a sexually oriented business without having secured a sexually oriented business employee license pursuant to this article. 
(b)  An application for a license must be made on a form provided by the Village. 
(c)  All applicants who seek to either operate or work in a sexually oriented business must be qualified according to the provisions of this article. The application may request and the applicant shall provide such information (including fingerprints) as necessary to enable the Village to determine whether the applicant meets the qualifications established in this article. 
(d)  If a person who wishes to operate a sexually oriented business is an individual, the person must sign the application for a license as applicant. If a person who wishes to operate a sexually oriented business is other than an individual, each individual who has a seven percent or greater interest in the sexually oriented business must sign the application for a license as applicant. Each applicant must be qualified as set forth below and each applicant shall be considered a licensee if a license is granted. 
(e)  The completed application for a sexually oriented business license shall contain the information and shall be accompanied by the documents set forth in subsections (e)(1) through (e)(12). For individual applicants, the information and documents shall relate to the individual. For applicants other than individuals, the information and documents shall relate to each individual controlling a seven percent or greater interest in the sexually oriented business. 
(1)  If the applicant is: 
a.  An individual—The individual shall (i) state his/her legal name (including any stage name) and any aliases; (ii) submit proof (two forms of identification (e.g., driver's license, passport, etc.) reasonably satisfactory to the Village that he/she is at least 18 years of age; and (iii) the current address (post office boxes are not acceptable), current land line telephone number, and current cell phone number. 
b.  A partnership (general or limited)—The partnership, through its duly authorized representative, shall (i) state its complete name, and the names of all partners; (ii) indicate whether the partnership is general or limited; (iii) submit a copy of the partnership agreement, if any; and (iv) provide the names, current addresses (post office boxes are not acceptable), current land line and cell phone numbers of all partners (general or limited). 
c.  A corporation, limited liability company or other entity—The corporation, limited liability company or other entity, through its duly authorized representative, shall (i) state its complete name, (ii) provide the date of its incorporation or organization, as applicable, (iii) provide certified copies of evidence from the state organizing authority that the corporation, limited liability company or other entity is in good standing under the laws of its state of incorporation or organization, as applicable, (iv) if a foreign corporation, foreign limited liability company, or other foreign entity, provide certified copies from the Secretary of State of Illinois that the foreign corporation, foreign limited liability company, or other foreign entity has authority to transact business and is in good standing in the State of Illinois, and (v) provide the names, current addresses (post office boxes are not acceptable), current land line and cell phone numbers, and capacity of all officers, directors, principal stockholders, and members, and the name and current address (post office boxes are not acceptable) of the registered agent and the current address (post office boxes are not acceptable) and telephone numbers of the registered office for service of process. 
d.  A land trust—Include (i) the land trust's complete name; (ii) the legal name and the business address (post office boxes are not acceptable) of the trustee of the land trust; (iii) the legal name, birth date and business address (post office boxes are not acceptable) of each holder of a power of direction or each beneficiary of the land trust and the specific interest of each such holder of a power of direction or beneficiary in the land trust; and (iv) the interest, if any, that the land trust holds in the licensed premises, as required by Chapter 765 ILCS 405 (Illinois Compiled Statutes). All such applications shall be verified by the applicant in his/her capacity as trustee, or by the beneficiary as a beneficial owner of interest in such land trust. 
(2)  If the applicant intends to operate the sexually oriented business under a name other than that of the applicant, he, she or it must (i) state the sexually oriented business's fictitious name and (ii) submit the required registration documents for such name. 
(3)  Whether the applicant, the applicant's officers or employees or a person residing with the applicant holds any other licenses under this article or other similar sexually oriented business ordinance from another governmental entity and, if so, the names and locations of such other licensed businesses. 
(4)  Whether the applicant, the applicant's officers or employees or a person residing with the applicant has had a previous license under this article or other similar adult or sexually oriented business ordinances from another governmental entity denied, suspended, or revoked, including the name and location of the adult or sexually oriented business for which the permit was denied, suspended, or revoked, as well as the date of the denial, suspension, or revocation, and whether the applicant, the applicant's officers or employees or a person residing with the applicant has been a partner in a partnership or an officer, director, or principal stockholder of a corporation that is licensed under this article whose license has previously been denied, suspended, or revoked, including the name and location of the sexually oriented business for which the permit was denied, suspended, or revoked as well as the date of denial, suspension, or revocation. 
(5)  Intentionally omitted. 
(6)  The single classification of license for which the applicant is filing. 
(7)  The location of the proposed sexually oriented business, including a legal description of the property, common street address, and: 
a.  If the property within which the sexually oriented business is to be located is owned by the applicant, then a copy of the ownership documents shall be provided with the application; or 
b.  If the property within which the sexually oriented business is to be located is to be leased, then a copy of the lease agreement, and the name, address and land line telephone number of the landlord. 
(8)  The applicant's current mailing address and residential address (post office boxes are not acceptable). 
(9)  Two color photographs of the applicant, measuring two inches by two inches, clearly showing the applicant's face, in addition to the applicant's fingerprints on a form provided by the Glenview Police Department. Any fees for the photographs and fingerprints shall be paid by the applicant. 
(10)  The applicant's driver's license number, Social Security number, and/or his/her state or federally issued tax identification number. 
(11)  A sketch or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of gross public floor area occupied by the business. The sketch or diagram need not be professionally prepared, but it must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with marked dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. 
(12)  A drawing, prepared and certified by a registered land surveyor within 30 days prior to the date the application, depicting: 
a.  Property lines and structures thereon for the location of the proposed sexually oriented business. 
b.  Unless otherwise provided herein, all of the following uses, existing or established, within 500 feet (as measured on a pedestrian route via sidewalks which shall be located in a public or private right-of-way or ingress/egress easement, whichever shall be applicable or on a vehicle route via streets which shall be located in a public or private right-of-way or ingress/egress easement, whichever shall be applicable) from the main public entrance of the proposed sexually oriented business to the property line of the following protected uses and/or zoning districts: (i) a church, synagogue, mosque, temple, or building which is used primarily for religious worship and related religious activities, (ii) a public or private educational facility including, but not limited to child day care facilities, nursery schools, preschools, kindergartens, elementary schools, private schools, intermediate schools, junior high schools, middle schools, high schools, vocational schools, secondary schools, continuation schools, special education schools, junior colleges, and universities; school includes the school grounds, but does not include facilities used primarily for another purpose and only incidentally as a school, (iii) a boundary of a residential district as defined in this article, (iv) a public library, a public park or recreational area which has been designated for park or recreational activities including, but not limited to, a park, playground, nature trail, swimming pool, reservoir, athletic field, basketball or tennis court, pedestrian/bicycle path, wilderness area, or other similar public land within the Village which is under the control, operation or management of the Village or other governmental entity, (v) an entertainment, youth activity, or sports-related business that is oriented primarily towards minors or family entertainment, (vi) premises licensed pursuant to the alcoholic beverage control regulations of the State of Illinois or the Village, or (vii) other sexually oriented businesses within 1,000 feet measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects or political boundaries, from the closest exterior wall of the structure in which each business is located. For the purposes of this subsection (e)(12)b, a use shall be considered existing or established if it is in existence at the time an application is submitted. 
(f)  Before any applicant may be issued a sexually oriented business employee license, the applicant shall submit, on a form to be provided by the Village, the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's name or any other name (including any stage name) or aliases used by the individual; 
(2)  Age, date and place of birth; 
(3)  Height, weight, hair and eye color; 
(4)  Current residence address (post office boxes are not acceptable), land line telephone number and cell phone number; 
(5)  Present business address (post office boxes are not acceptable), land line telephone number and cell phone number; 
(6)  Date, issuing state and number of driver's license or other identification card information; 
(7)  Social Security number; and 
(8)  Proof (two forms of identification, e.g., valid driver's license, passport, etc.) reasonably satisfactory to the Village that he/she is at least 18 years of age. 
(g)  Attached to the application form for a sexually oriented business employee license, as provided above, shall be the following: 
(1)  Two color photographs of the applicant, measuring two inches by two inches, clearly showing the applicant's face, in addition to the applicant's fingerprints on a form provided by the Glenview Police Department. Any fees for the photographs and fingerprints shall be paid by the applicant. 
(2)  A statement detailing the license history of the applicant for the five-year period immediately preceding the date of filing of the application, including whether such applicant previously operated or is seeking to operate, in this or any other county, city, state, or country has ever had a license, permit, or authorization to do business denied, revoked, or suspended, or had any professional or vocational license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended. In the event of any such denial, revocation or suspension, state the name, the name of the issuing or denying jurisdiction, and describe in full the reason for the denial, revocation, or suspension. A copy of any order of denial, revocation, or suspension shall be attached to the application. 
(3)  A statement whether the applicant has been convicted of a specified criminal activity and, if so, the specified criminal activity involved, the date, place and jurisdiction of each. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-835. - Issuance of license—Sexually oriented business and sexually oriented business employee. 
(a)  Sexually oriented business license. 
(1)  For a sexually oriented business licensee, within 30 days after receipt of a completed sexually oriented business application, the Village shall approve or deny the issuance of a license to an applicant. The Village shall approve the issuance of a license to an applicant unless it is determined by a preponderance of the evidence that one or more of the following is true (i) with respect to the individual applicant or (ii) if the applicant is an entity other than an individual, with respect to any person controlling a seven percent or greater interest in the applicant entity: 
a.  An applicant is under 18 years of age; 
b.  An applicant or a person with whom applicant is residing is overdue in payment to the Village of taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against or imposed upon him/her in relation to any business; 
c.  An applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form; 
d.  An applicant or a person with whom the applicant is residing has been denied a license by the Village to operate a sexually oriented business within the preceding 12 months or whose license to operate a sexually oriented business has been revoked within the preceding 12 months; 
e.  An applicant or a person with whom the applicant is residing has been convicted of specified criminal activity; 
f.  The premises to be used for the sexually oriented business have not been approved by the Village Health Department, the Glenview Fire Department and the Village Development Department as being in compliance with applicable laws and ordinances; 
g.  The license fee required by section 22-836 has not been paid; or 
h.  An applicant of the proposed establishment is in violation of or is not in compliance with any of the provisions of this article or with any other licensing provisions or regulations of the Village as contained in the Municipal Code, Village of Glenview, Illinois. 
(2)  A sexually oriented business license granted pursuant to this section shall state on its face the name of the person or persons to whom it is granted, the expiration date, the common street address of the sexually oriented business, and the classification for which the license is issued pursuant to section 22-826. All licenses shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the sexually oriented business so that they may be easily read at any time. 
(3)  The Village Health Department, the Glenview Fire Department, and the Village Development Department shall complete their certification that the premises are in compliance or not in compliance within 20 days of receipt of the application by the Village. 
(4)  A sexually oriented business license shall not be issued to an applicant for more than one classification as found in section 22-826. 
(b)  Sexually oriented business employee license. For a sexually oriented business employee license, upon the filing of an application for a sexually oriented business employee license, the Village shall issue a temporary license to the applicant. The application shall then be referred to the appropriate Village departments for an investigation to be made on such information as is contained in the application. The application process shall be completed within 30 days from the date the completed application is filed. After the investigation, the Village shall issue a license, unless it is determined by a preponderance of the evidence that one or more of the following findings is true: 
(1)  The applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form; 
(2)  The applicant is under the age of 18 years; 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of specified criminal activity; 
(4)  The sexually oriented business employee license is to be used for employment in a business prohibited by local or state law, statute, rule or regulation, or prohibited by a particular provision of this ordinance; or 
(5)  The applicant has had a sexually oriented business employee license or sexually oriented business license revoked by the Village within two years of the date of the current application. If the sexually oriented business employee license is denied, the temporary license previously issued is immediately deemed null and void. Denial, suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this section shall be subject to appeal as set forth in section 22-841 below. 
(c)  Renewal of sexually oriented business license and sexually oriented business employee license. A license granted pursuant to this section 22-836 shall be subject to annual renewal on December 31 each year. Renewal shall be conditioned upon the written application of the applicant and a finding by the Village that the applicant has not been convicted of any specified criminal activity or committed any act during the term of the previous license which would have been grounds to deny the initial license application. The renewal of the license shall be subject to the payment of the fee as set forth in section 22-836. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-836. - Fees. 
(a)  Every application for a sexually oriented business license or a sexually oriented business employee license (whether for a new license or for renewal of an existing license) shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application, investigation and license issuance fee as outlined in Chapter 30-1 under general business, and will be assessed an additional fee as determined by the police department for background check processing. 
(b)  The license fee shall be paid at the time of issuance of a new license and not less than 30 days prior to expiration of a current license in the case of an application for a renewal license. 
(c)  All fees shall be submitted to the Village Finance Department. The completed application, including a receipt showing payment of the required fee, shall be submitted to the Village Clerk. Processing of any application hereunder, whether for a new application or the renewal of an existing license, shall not commence until all fees are paid. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005; Ord. No. 5113, § 7, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 22-837. - Inspection. 
(a)  An applicant or licensee shall permit representatives of the Glenview Police Department, the Village Health Department, the Glenview Fire Department, the Village Development Department, or other Village departments or agencies, as applicable, to inspect the premises of a sexually oriented business at any time it is occupied or open for business for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the law. 
(b)  A person who operates a sexually oriented business or his/her agent or employee commits a petty offense and is in violation of the provisions of this article if he/she refuses to permit such lawful inspection of the premises at any time it is open for business. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-838. - Expiration of license. 
(a)  Each license shall expire on December 31 of each year and may be renewed only by making application as provided in section 22-834. Application for renewal shall be made not less than 30 days before the expiration date of the license. If an application for renewal is made less than 30 days before the expiration date, the expiration date of the license will not be effected and the applicant shall not operate under the terms of the license or continue to work as an employee at a sexually oriented business during any period of time between the expiration of the license and the issuance of a renewal license. 
(b)  In the event the Village denies renewal of a license, the applicant shall not be issued a license for one year from the date of denial. If, subsequent to denial, the Village finds that the basis for denial of the renewal license has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the denial became final. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-839. - Suspension. 
The Village shall suspend a license for a period not to exceed 30 days if it determines that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with any section of this article; or 
(2)  Refused to allow an inspection of the sexually oriented business premises as authorized by section 22-837. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-840. - Revocation. 
(a)  The Village shall revoke a license if a cause for suspension in section 22-839 occurs during the 12-month period after the same license has been suspended. 
(b)  The Village shall revoke a license if it determines that: 
(1)  A licensee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted during the application process; 
(2)  A licensee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the sexually oriented business premises; 
(3)  A licensee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the sexually oriented business premises; 
(4)  A licensee knowingly operated the sexually oriented business or worked as an employee at a sexually oriented business during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended or expired; 
(5)  A licensee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation, or other sex act to occur in or on the sexually oriented business premises; or 
(6)  A licensee is delinquent in payment of any taxes or fees owned to the Village, county or state. 
(c)  In the event the Village revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for not less than three years from the effective date of the revocation, and the Village shall not accept an application from a license whose license has been revoked for three years from the date the revocation became effective. However, if subsequent to revocation pursuant to subsection (b)(6), the Village finds that the basis for the revocation has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation became effective. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-841. - Due process hearing regarding denial of an application for a sexually oriented business license, suspension of license, or revocation of license—Licensee or employee. 
(a)  Any license issued for a sexually oriented business or a sexually oriented business employee may be suspended for not more than 30 days or revoked by the Village Manager or his designee upon written notice to the licensee, which notice shall state a basis for the suspension or revocation. The licensee may request in writing a hearing within ten days of receipt of the notice from the Village Manager or his designee. Within ten days from receipt of a demand for hearing, the Village Manager or his designee shall conduct the hearing in any case where any provision of this article XXIII or any state law, or any Village ordinance or regulation is violated, or any employee of the licensee is engaged in any conduct at licensee's place of business which violates any provision of this article XXIII or any state law, or any Village ordinance or regulation. Such license may also be suspended or revoked by the Village Manager, upon the recommendation of the Village Health Administrator that such business is being managed, conducted or maintained without regard for the public health or health of patrons or without due regard to proper sanitation or hygiene. The burden is on the licensee to show cause why the suspension or revocation, as the case may be, should not remain in effect. The licensee shall be permitted to present any relevant evidence bearing on the violation. The decision of the Village Manager shall be in writing and shall be final subject to review pursuant to a writ of certiorari. The decision of the Village Manager shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the licensee as it appears on the application for a license within 15 days after the date of the final hearing. 
(b)  Any violation of this article XXIII by any employee of the licensee shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the sexually oriented business license. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-842. - Transfer of license. 
A licensee shall not transfer a license to another, nor shall a licensee operate a sexually oriented business under the authority of a license at any place other than the common street address designated in the application. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-843. - Location of sexually oriented businesses. 
(a)  A person is in violation of this article and commits a petty offense if that person operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business in any zoning district other than the I-2 Light Industrial District, as defined and described in the section 98-162. 
(b)  A person is in violation of this article and commits a petty offense if the person operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business within 500 feet (as measured pursuant to subsection 22-834(e)(12)b. of: 
(1)  A church, synagogue, mosque, temple or building which is used primarily for religious worship and related religious activities; 
(2)  A public or private educational facility including, but not limited to, child day care facilities, nursery schools, preschools, kindergartens, elementary schools, private schools, intermediate schools, junior high schools, middle schools, high schools, vocational schools, secondary schools, continuation schools, special education schools, junior colleges, and universities; school includes the school grounds, but does not include facilities used primarily for another purpose and only incidentally as a school; 
(3)  A boundary of a residential district; 
(4)  A public library, a public park or recreational area which has been designated for park or recreational activities including, but not limited to, a park, playground, nature trail, swimming pool, reservoir, athletic field, basketball or tennis court, pedestrian/bicycle path, wilderness area, or other similar public land within the Village which is under the control, operation or management of the Village or other governmental entity; 
(5)  An entertainment, youth activity or sports-related business that is oriented primarily towards minors or family entertainment; or 
(6)  Premises licensed pursuant to the alcoholic beverage control regulations of the State of Illinois or the Village. 
(c)  A person is in violation of this article and commits a petty offense if that person causes or permits the operation, establishment, substantial enlargement, or transfer of ownership or control of a sexually oriented business within 1,000 feet of another sexually oriented business (measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects or political boundaries, from the closest exterior wall of the structure in which each business is located). 
(d)  A person is in violation of this article and commits a petty offense if that person causes or permits the operation, establishment, or maintenance of more than one sexually oriented business in the same building, structure, or portion thereof, or the increase of floor area of any sexually oriented business in any building, structure, or portion thereof containing another sexually oriented business, unless otherwise provided in this article. 
(e)  A person is in violation of this article and commits a petty offense if that person places, installs, erects or otherwise constructs a sign in violation of subsection 22-829(d). 
(f)  For the purposes of this section, except measurement consistent with subsection (c) above, measurement on a pedestrian route via sidewalks shall be located in a public or private right-of-way or ingress/egress easement, whichever shall be applicable or measurement on a vehicle route via streets shall be located in a public or private right-of-way or ingress/egress easement, whichever shall be applicable, from the main public entrance of the proposed sexually oriented business to the property line of the uses listed in section 22-834(e)(12)b, unless otherwise provided therein. Presence of a village, city, county or other political subdivision boundary shall be irrelevant for purposes of calculating and applying the distance requirements of section 22-843(c) or this subsection. 
(g)  Any sexually oriented business lawfully operating on the effective date of this article XXIII that is in violation of subsections (a) through (f) above shall be deemed a legal nonconforming use. The legal nonconforming use will be permitted to continue for a period not to exceed one year, unless sooner terminated for any reason or voluntarily discontinued for a period of 30 days or more. Such legal nonconforming uses shall not be increased, enlarged, extended or altered, except the use may be changed to a conforming use in the event all conditions of this article, after application being made, are satisfied. If two or more sexually oriented businesses are within 1,000 feet of one another (measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects or political boundaries, from the closest exterior wall of the structure in which each business is located) and otherwise in a permissible location, the sexually oriented business which was first established and continually legally operating at a particular location is the conforming use and the later established business(es) is/are nonconforming and subject to subsection (c) above. 
(h)  A sexually oriented business lawfully operating as a conforming use is not rendered a nonconforming use by the location, subsequent to the grant or renewal of the sexually oriented business license, of a use listed in subsection (b) above. This provision applies only to the renewal of a valid license, and does not apply when an application for a license is submitted after a license has expired or been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-844. - Regulations pertaining to exhibition of sexually explicit films, videos or live entertainment in viewing rooms. 
(a)  A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, which exhibits on the premises in a viewing room of less than 150 square feet of floor space, a film, DVD, video cassette, live entertainment, or other video reproduction which depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Upon application for a sexually oriented business license, the application shall be accompanied by a diagram of the premises showing a plan thereof specifying the location of one or more manager's stations and the location of all overhead lighting fixtures and designating any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. A manager's station may not exceed 32 square feet of floor area. The diagram shall also designate the place at which the permit will be conspicuously posted, if granted. A professionally prepared diagram in the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint shall not be required; however, each diagram should be oriented to the north or to some designated street or object and should be drawn to a designated scale or with marked dimensions sufficient to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. The Village may waive the foregoing diagram for renewal applications if the applicant adopts a diagram that was previously submitted and certifies that the configuration of the premises has not been altered since it was prepared. 
(2)  The application shall be sworn to be true and correct by the applicant. 
(3)  No alteration in the configuration or location of a manager's station may be made without the prior approval of the Village. 
(4)  It is the duty of the licensee of the premises to ensure that at least one licensed employee is on duty and situated in each manager's station at all times that any patron is present inside the premises. 
(5)  The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from a manager's station of every area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose, excluding restrooms. Restrooms may not contain video reproduction equipment. If the premises has two or more manager's stations designated, then the interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view of each area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose from at least one of the manager's stations. The view required in this subsection (a)(5) must be by direct line of sight from the manager's station. 
(6)  It shall be the duty of the licensee to ensure that the view area specified in subsection (a)(5) above remains unobstructed by any doors, curtains, partitions, walls, merchandise, display racks, or other materials and, at all times, to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the premises which has been designated as an area in which patrons will not be permitted in the application filed pursuant to this article XXIII. 
(7)  No viewing room may be occupied by more than one person at any time. 
(8)  The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access at an illumination of not less than ten foot candles as measured at the floor level. 
(9)  It shall be the duty of the licensee to ensure that the illumination described above is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(10)  No licensee shall allow openings of any kind to exist between viewing rooms or booths. 
(11)  No person shall make or attempt to make an opening of any kind between viewing booths or rooms. 
(12)  The licensee shall, during each business day, regularly inspect the walls between the viewing booths to determine if any openings or holes exist. 
(13)  The licensee shall cause all floor coverings in viewing booths to be nonporous, easily cleanable surfaces, with no rugs or carpeting. And, 
(14)  The licensee shall cause all wall surfaces and ceiling surfaces in viewing booths to be constructed of, or permanently covered by, nonporous, easily cleanable material. No wood, plywood, composition board, or other porous material shall be used within 48 inches of the floor. 
(b)  A person having a duty under subsections (a)(1) through (a)(14) above commits a violation of this article if he/she fails to fulfill that duty. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-845. - Additional regulations for nude model studios. 
(a)  A nude model studio shall not employ any person under the age of 18 years. The license holder of a nude model studio commits a violation of this article if the nude model studio employs a person under 18 years of age. 
(b)  A person under the age of 18 years commits a violation of this article if the person appears semi-nude or in a state of nudity in or on the premises of a nude model studio. It is a defense to prosecution under this section if the person under 18 years was in a restroom not open to public view or visible to any other person. 
(c)  A person commits a violation of this article if the person appears in a state of nudity, or knowingly allows another to appear in a state of nudity in an area of a nude model studio premises which can be viewed from the public right-of-way. 
(d)  A nude model studio shall not place or permit a bed, sofa, or mattress in any room on the premises; except that a sofa may be placed in a reception room open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-846. - Additional regulations concerning public nudity. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this article for a person who, in a sexually oriented business, appears in a state of nudity or depicts specified sexual activities. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article for a person who, in a sexually oriented business, appears in a semi-nude condition unless the person is an employee who, while semi-nude, shall be at least ten feet from any patron and on a stage at least two feet from the floor. 
(c)  It shall be a violation of this article for an employee, while semi-nude in a sexually oriented business, to solicit any pay or gratuity from any patron, or for any patron to pay or give any gratuity to any employee, while such employee is semi-nude in a sexually oriented business. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this article for an employee, while semi-nude, to touch a patron or the clothing of a patron. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-847. - Prohibition against minors in a sexually oriented business. 
A person commits a violation of this article if the person allows a person under the age of 18 years on the premises of a sexually oriented business. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-848. - Hours of operation. 
No sexually oriented business may remain open at any time between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturdays, and 1:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. (noon) on Sundays. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-849. - Exemptions. 
It is a defense to prosecution under section 22-845 above that a person appearing in a state of nudity did so in a modeling class operated: 
(1)  By a proprietary school, licensed by the State of Illinois, a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
(2)  By a private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or 
(3)  In a structure: 
a.  Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; 
b.  Where, in order to participate in a class, a student must enroll at least three days in advance of the class; and 
c.  Where no more than one nude model is (i) appearing semi-nude, (ii) in a state of nudity, or (iii) displaying specified anatomical areas on the premises at any one time. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Sec. 22-850. - Injunction and penalties. 
(a)  A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business without a valid license in violation of this article XXIII is subject to a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for violation of this article. 
(b)  Each day a sexually oriented business operates in violation of this article XXIII is a separate violation for which a fine may be assessed by a court of competent jurisdiction in the sum of $1,000 per day for each day the violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-6-2005)  
Chapter 26 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34, law enforcement, ch. 42. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 26-1—26-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5020, § 2, adopted Aug. 21, 2007, deleted Art. II in its entirety and supplied provisions for a new Art. II to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, §§ 26-31—26-43, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1959, §§ 27.1—27.13; and Ord. No. 4587, adopted Nov. 4, 2003. 
 
Sec. 26-31. - Establishment. 
(a)  Pursuant to the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1, et seq.) (the "IEMA Act") there is hereby created a local emergency management agency (the "EMA") to coordinate the emergency management program within the Village and with private organizations, other political subdivisions, and the State and federal governments. 
(b)  The Village president shall be the executive in charge of the EMA. 
(c)  The Village president shall appoint, subject to the advice and consent of the Village Board, a coordinator, who shall be the assistant to the Village president with the duty of coordinating the emergency management program for the Village consistent with the applicable provisions of the IEMA Act. 
(d)  All other members of the EMA shall be appointed or designated by the coordinator, and shall serve at the pleasure of the coordinator. 
(e)  The term of the coordinator shall be one year, from August 1 to July 31, or until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-32. - Service as a mobile support team. 
(a)  Members of the EMA may be designated by the governor or the director of the Illinois Emergency Management Agency (the "IEMA") as members of a mobile support team to aid and to reinforce the IEMA and emergency services and disaster agencies in areas stricken by disaster. 
(b)  Any member of a mobile support team who is a municipal employee or officer while on duty pursuant to a call to duty or while engaged in a regularly scheduled training exercise shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the Village, while so serving, may receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-33. - Agreements with other political subdivisions. 
The coordinator may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipal corporations or political subdivisions of the State for reciprocal aid and assistance, pursuant to law, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the Village Board. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-34. - Emergency action. 
If the governor declares that an emergency exists in the event of a disaster, as defined in the IEMA Act, then it shall be the duty of the EMA to cooperate fully with the IEMA in the provision of emergency services as provided in the IEMA Act. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-35. - Compensation. 
(a)  Neither the Village president, the coordinator, nor members of the EMA shall receive compensation from the Village for their services in the EMA, but this provision shall not affect their compensation authorized by the Village for other services to the Village or their compensation for activities related to the EMA as otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  If members of the EMA who are paid employees or officers of the Village are called for training by the director of the IEMA, then they shall receive for time spent in such training the same rate of pay as they may receive from the Village while performing their regular duties and obligations for the Village. 
(c)  Members of the EMA who are neither employees nor officers of the Village shall receive for such training time only such compensation as may be provided by law. 
(d)  Members of the EMA who are also members of a Village mobile support team, and who, while engaged in a disaster or disaster training exercise, suffer disease, injury or death, shall be deemed to be employees of the State for the purposes of benefits under the Worker's Compensation Act or Worker's Occupational Diseases Act only, if (1) the claimant is a duly qualified and enrolled (sworn in) volunteer of the EMA, and (2) the claimant was participating in an actual disaster as defined in the IEMA Act or engaged in a regularly scheduled training or exercise pursuant to a call for duty by the IEMA. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-36. - Powers and duties of the organization. 
(a)  The Village president shall be the chairperson of the EMA. The EMA shall meet at the call of the Village president who shall be advised on all matters pertaining to emergency services. 
(b)  The EMA shall, from time to time, recommend to the Village Board action or procedures necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the Village as it may deem necessary or advisable in order to carry out the purposes of this ordinance and of the IEMA Act, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The creation of separate departments for the performance of the several functions of the EMA. 
(2)  The specification of the duties and functions of each department, particularly with respect to preparation for any emergency which may require the active interposition of the EMA in order to protect the community, and with respect to action to be taken upon occurrence of any such emergency. 
(3)  The formulation of a plan of action, to be coordinated with the Illinois Emergency Preparedness Plan and program, and to serve particularly the residents of the Village and of any surrounding area. 
(c)  Any regulations of the EMA shall not become effective until approved by the Village Board. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-37. - Reimbursement by State. 
The Village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement received from the state for expenses incident to training members of the EMA as prescribed by the director of the IEMA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the Village in response to a call by the governor or the director of the IEMA, and any other reimbursement made by the State incident to the EMA's activities as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-38. - Purchases and expenditures. 
(a)  The Village Board may, on recommendation of the coordinator, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the Village in a position to combat effectively any disaster in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the Village and its residents. 
(b)  In the event of any disaster, the coordinator is authorized, on behalf of the Village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for emergency purposes, in light of the exigencies of the disaster and, excepting mandatory constitutional requirements, without regard to the procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase of supplies and materials, and the appropriation, expenditure, and disposition of public funds and property as authorized by the IEMA Act, until the Village Board is able to act effectively, whereupon the coordinator shall then act in accordance with the direction of the Village president, pursuant to law. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-39. - Oath. 
Every member of the EMA, and every person who is appointed to serve in any capacity in connection therewith, shall take the following oath in writing before the coordinator or other person authorized to administer oaths in this state: 
"I, _______________ do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the constitution of the United States and the constitution of the state of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear ( or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of Glenview, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence." 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-40. - Office. 
The Village manager is authorized to designate space in the Village hall for the office of the EMA, or such other location as may be provided by the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Sec. 26-41. - Village president—Emergency powers. 
(a)  Emergency powers. Pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Police Protection and Public Order provisions contained in the Illinois Municipal Code under 65 ILCS 5/11-1-6, during a state of emergency, the Village president shall have the extraordinary power and authority to exercise, by executive order, such of the powers of the corporate authorities as may be reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Civil disturbance means a riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting in concert without authority of law. 
(2)  Natural disaster or manmade calamity includes flood, railroad or vehicle wrecks, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake, explosion, drought, aircraft crashes, or any other occurrence of such magnitude, within the corporate limits of the Village, that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(3)  Curfew means a prohibition against any person or persons walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any sidewalk, alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the Village, excepting officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to such civil emergency. 
(c)  Emergency powers—Duration. Whenever any civil disturbance, natural disaster or manmade calamity shall occur within the corporate limits which are sufficiently extensive and reach such proportions that law and order cannot be maintained by available methods, the Village president, by this section and as may be otherwise provided in 65 ILCS 5/11-1-6, is empowered to: 
(1)  Suspend the sale and/or provision of liquor and alcoholic beverages by establishments licensed under the ordinances of the Village; 
(2)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products; 
(3)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever; 
(4)  Set curfew hours for all persons within the corporate limits of the Village — this curfew to be during such hours of the day or night as deemed necessary; 
(5)  Order the evacuation of all residences, businesses and other buildings as may be deemed necessary; 
(6)  Call on the National Guard through the Office of the Governor in accordance with the Illinois Internal Security Plan as outlined by the Adjutant General of the State of Illinois when the local law enforcement authorities are unable to cope with a dangerous or disastrous situation; and 
(7)  Issue any other order as is imminently necessary for the protection of life, property, health, safety, and the public welfare. 
The orders authorized in this subsection may be issued singly or together. 
(d)  Justification. Whenever the Village president shall deem it necessary to invoke the emergency powers set forth in this section, the Village president shall, as soon as practical, but in no case longer than 12 hours from the time of the invocation of the powers, notify the Village clerk and the board of trustees, in writing, under oath, of his reasons for invoking such emergency powers and giving his justification for his actions. 
(e)  Time limit. The emergency powers given to the Village president by this article shall not, without Village Board approval, extend beyond any seven-day period (Sundays and holidays included) for any one occurrence of a civil disturbance, natural disaster or manmade calamity, nor later than the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the board of trustees after the State of emergency is declared. 
(f)  Public notification. Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the Village clerk shall notify one of the news media publications whose papers are of general circulation in the Village and shall cause two copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the following places within the Village: the Village hall and the main Glenview post office. 
(g)  Emergency powers—Order of succession. Should the Village president be unavailable, the emergency powers of the Village president shall be carried according to the following order of succession: Village manager, the coordinator, chief of police. 
(h)  Violations. Any person violating the provisions of this article or executive order issued pursuant thereto shall be guilty of an offense against the Village, and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to undermine the powers granted to the Glenview Police Department, the Glenview Fire Department, or any other operating department of the Village, but shall be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5020, § 2, 8-21-2007)  
Secs. 26-42—26-59. - Reserved.

Sec. 30-2. - Improved land fair market value. 
Fair market value of improved land in the Village is $500,000.00 per acre. 
(Code 1959, ch. 2, art. XVII, § 2; Ord. No. 4146, § 2, 3-21-2000)  
Sec. 30-3. - Fee discount for certain single-family building permits. 
For building permit applications filed between December 1 and February 28 each year, the Village of Glenview will extend a twenty-five (25) percent discount on associated building and plan review permit fees for single-family home improvement projects including room additions, interior remodeling, and accessory uses to single-family dwellings including but not limited to detached garages, sheds, decks, fences, swimming pools, gazebos, and concrete and asphalt flatwork. 
(Ord. No. 6230, § 3, 12-4-2018)  
Sec. 30-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5411, § 5, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 30-4, which pertained to electrical contractor registration fee and derived from Code 1959, § 10.14; and Ord. No. 5190, § 17, adopted Jan. 3, 2009.  
Sec. 30-5. - Overweight and oversize vehicle permit fee schedule. 
(a)  The Village with respect to highways under its jurisdiction shall collect a fee as shown herein from applicants for the issuance of a permit to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicle(s), and/or loads, which fit the categories shown. 
(b)  Limited continuous use permits are not available for overweight vehicles. Limited continuous use permits are available only for over-dimension (oversized vehicles) and for a period of not more than three months from the date of issue. 
(c)  Fee schedule. All fee schedules will be included in chapter 30, section 1 (30-1) the Fees and Charges Ordinance. 
(1)  Weights which exceed those prescribed in categories 7B, 8B and 9B or larger will require an escort. The number of police escort vehicles shall be determined by the Village, based upon route and safety concerns. Fees for said escort shall be time and a half, top patrol officer pay, per officer assigned and shall provide for a minimum of two hours of service. 
(2)  Any axle or gross weight greater than the maximum weights set forth in this ordinance are subject to special assessment and investigation to determine appropriate fees for the above table. 
(3)  When a permit is requested for an overweight and over-dimension (oversized) vehicle, the higher fee schedule will be assessed. 
(4)  The number of police escort vehicles shall be determined by the police department for dimension categories 3C through 5C and shall be based on the route and safety concerns. Fees for said escort shall be time and a half, top patrol officer pay, per officer assigned and shall provide for a minimum of two hours of service. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 3, 3-18-2008; Ord. No. 5411, § 6, 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 30-6. - Emergency medical service (EMS) fees. 
The following EMS fee schedule is hereby created and shall be applicable to all EMS transports including Basic Life Support (BLS) and Advanced Life Support (ALS) transports provided by the Village of Glenview Fire Department. Ambulance responses not resulting in patient transports will not be subject to these fees. 
(1)  Resident Rate (applies to Village of Glenview residents, Glenbrook Fire Protection District residents, and Village employees): Shall be as provided in chapter 30, section 1. The Village hereby establishes an "Insurance-Only" collection policy for residents, which means that the Village will accept the amount allowed by insurance companies, Medicare, Medicaid, etc. as payment-in-full for the service; residents will not incur any out-of-pocket expenses such as insurance co-pay or deductible fees. The rate will automatically increase by 3% on each calendar year commencing January 1, 2010 unless otherwise modified by the Village Board of Trustees. 
(2)  Non-Resident Rate: Shall be as provided in chapter 30, section 1. The Village hereby establishes a "Full-Billing" collection policy for non-residents, which means the Village will bill patients for amounts not covered by insurance, with the exception of Medicare and Medicaid payments, which by law, must be accepted as payment for these services. The rate will automatically increase by 3% on each calendar year commencing January 1, 2010 unless otherwise modified by the Village Board of Trustees. 
(3)  Mileage Rate: a per mile fee will be charged from the point of patient pick up to the hospital; the resident and non-resident collection policies apply. Such fee shall be as provided in chapter 30, section 1. The rate will automatically increase by 3% on each calendar year commencing January 1, 2010 unless otherwise modified by the Village Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 5086, § 2, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 5113, § 8, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 5802, § 3, 6-17-2014)  
Sec. 30-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5411, § 3, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, deleted § 30-7, which pertained to engineering fees and derived from Ord. No. 5159, § 3, adopted Nov. 18, 2008.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 34-31. - Established; composition; oath of office. 
There is hereby established an executive department of the Village which shall be known as the fire department. The fire department shall be a full-time paid department and shall consist of a fire marshal and such officers and members of the fire department and such other employees as the corporate authorities may provide from time to time. Each sworn member of the fire department shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe the oaths of office required of the sworn officers of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 7.1)  
Sec. 34-32. - Service outside corporate limits. 
Members of the fire department are authorized to go outside the corporate limits of the Village for the purpose of rendering aid to other fire departments, extinguishing fires or rendering aid in the case of accidents; provided, however, that the fire department shall not render such service outside the corporate limits of the Village, except upon order of the fire marshal, Village manager or Village president, and except where the Village has undertaken, by contract, to render service to property outside the corporate limits of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 7.11)  
Sec. 34-33. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The fire marshal shall promulgate administrative rules and regulations to govern the operation of the fire department, and such rules and regulations are to be effective upon their approval by the Village manager. 
(b)  Members of the fire department, other than the fire marshal and other exempt ranks, shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the board of fire and police commissioners, pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code. Examination for all applicants for a position as a sworn firefighter in the fire department shall be conducted by the board of fire and police commissioners. The board of fire and police commissioners shall, according to its rules and regulations, establish an eligible list of all candidates for a position in the fire department, make all appointments thereto, provide for non-exempt promotions within the fire department, as well as provide for the suspension or removal of any member of the fire department. 
(Code 1959, § 7.12)  
Sec. 34-34. - Civil service exempt command positions. 
The fire chief, with the concurrence and the approval of the Village manager, shall have the authority to recruit and appoint individuals to civil service exempt command positions within the fire department. Civil service exempt command positions will not have certified status and rights. Individuals appointed to civil service exempt command positions shall serve at the pleasure of the fire chief and may be removed by the fire chief at any time with the concurrence of the Village manager. If an individual who holds certified status within the fire department in another position is appointed to a civil service exempt command position, the individual shall retain a guaranteed right to return to the former position with the certified status upon termination from the exempt command position. 
(Code 1959, § 7.14)  
Sec. 34-35. - Fire lieutenant. 
There is hereby created the office of fire lieutenant for the Village. The duties of a fire lieutenant shall be such as are prescribed by the fire marshal and board of fire and police commissioners. The compensation of the fire lieutenant shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 7.15)  
Sec. 34-36. - Firefighters and firefighter paramedic. 
There are hereby created the positions of firefighter and firefighter paramedic for the Village. The duties of a firefighter shall be such as are prescribed by the fire marshal and board of fire and police commissioners. The compensation of a firefighter shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 7.16)  
Sec. 34-37. - Residency requirements. 
Members of the Village fire department are not required to live within the corporate limits of the Village, either at the time of their appointment as firefighters or while serving as firefighters with the fire department. No geographical restrictions with respect to residency are applicable to members of the fire department. 
(Code 1959, § 7.17)  
Secs. 34-38—34-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FIRE MARSHAL 
 
Sec. 34-61. - Office created; appointment. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of fire marshal, who shall be the chief of the fire department. The fire marshal shall be appointed by and shall serve at the pleasure of the Village manager. The office of fire marshal is specifically exempt from the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4 and 5/10.2-1-17. 
(b)  No person shall be eligible to hold the office of fire marshal unless he shall possess technical training and knowledge, and experience in the matters of fire suppression, rescue and fire prevention. The fire marshal may be appointed from within or without the fire department. 
(Code 1959, § 7.2)  
Sec. 34-62. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and every member thereof to extinguish fires and prevent the occurrence or spread thereof. The fire department and its members shall have such additional municipal duties as may be assigned by the Village manager. The fire department is authorized to cooperate with other municipal firefighting organizations in the performance of its duties. 
(b)  The duties of the fire marshal are as follows: 
(1)  The fire marshal shall have direct charge and control of the fire department, subject to the supervision and direction of the Village manager, and shall be responsible to the Village manager for the faithful and efficient conduct and operation of the fire department. The fire marshal shall be responsible for the proper care and maintenance of all fire equipment and apparatus belonging to the Village. 
(2)  The fire marshal shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of all fire department activities and shall report such activities to the Village manager. He shall investigate the cause of all fires which may occur in the Village and keep a record of the circumstances of each case, reporting such findings to the Village manager as soon as possible. He shall have the right to enter upon the premises wherein any fire has occurred, if necessary, in order to investigate the origin of the fire. 
(3)  The fire marshal shall inspect, or cause to be inspected, all buildings and premises, except the interiors of private dwellings, as often as may be necessary for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire or any violations of the provisions of this chapter and of any other ordinances affecting the fire hazard, and to ensure compliance, in all places of assembly, with all laws, ordinances, regulations and orders dealing with overcrowding, use of decorative materials, maintenance of exitways, maintenance of fire alarm and fire detecting systems, and fire extinguishing systems and appliances, and all other similar laws, ordinances, regulations and orders. It shall further be the duty of the fire marshal to perform all duties which are set forth in this chapter. 
(4)  The fire marshal shall attend all fires occurring in the Village, and, in case of his absence, it shall be the duty of the next ranking member of the fire department in command to take charge of the fire department, and, during the absence of the fire marshal, such person in command shall have and exercise all the powers of the fire marshal. 
(5)  The fire marshal shall examine all buildings reported dangerous or damaged by fire or accident, and shall, when requested by the Village manager or director of building and zoning, also examine all buildings under application to raise, enlarge, alter or rebuild and make a report of the condition to the director of building and zoning. 
(Code 1959, § 7.3)  
Sec. 34-63. - Power to remove or destroy property. 
The fire marshal shall have the power to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire, to prevent the spreading of fire or to protect adjoining property. 
(Code 1959, § 7.4)  
Sec. 34-64. - Reports. 
(a)  The fire marshal shall cause records to be kept for the Village manager of all transactions in the fire department for the preceding year. Such report shall also set forth, as nearly as can be ascertained, the number of fires, the causes thereof, the number of persons injured, a description of the buildings destroyed and injured, the amount of property destroyed by fire and insurance thereon, and all other relevant statistics. He shall make such interim reports as may be requested by the Village manager. 
(Code 1959, § 7.5)  
Sec. 34-65. - Command at fires. 
In case of fire, the fire marshal and his assistants shall rank in the order named, and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire department and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire, in the best manner possible. 
(Code 1959, § 7.6)  
Secs. 34-66—34-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RESERVED[3]
