After February 20, 1999, a food service establishment must apply for and be granted a conditional use in accordance with the provisions of section 98-50 in order to extend its hours of operation beyond the terms of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Secs. 38-32—38-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE FOOD VENDORS 
 
Sec. 38-41. - License and inspection required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a mobile food unit within the Village without first having obtained a license for that purpose. Business license requirements are as listed in chapter 22. 
(1)  Business License fees are as listed in section 30-1. 
(2)  All licenses provided for in this section shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to transfer such license from one licensee to another. 
(4)  The mobile food unit shall be inspected and approved prior to issuance of a business license and shall be subject to inspection by the Village at any time while in operation. 
(5)  Licenses issued may be suspended, revoked or refused to be issued upon good cause shown in accordance with section 22-8. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-42. - Sanitation requirements. 
All food delivery vehicles shall comply with the following: 
(1)  The exterior of the vehicle shall be kept in good repair to prevent the entrance of dirt, dust, insects or other vermin. 
(2)  The floors, walls and ceilings of the food storage compartment of the vehicle shall be smooth and easily cleanable, and shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(3)  The use of ice as a refrigeration method shall be allowed if such use is approved by the development department. Such ice shall be self-draining and the melted ice shall be contained in a permanently installed retention tank. The liquid waste from the retention tank shall be disposed of as sewage. 
(4)  Adequate mechanical refrigeration equipment or its equivalent shall be provided for all meat, milk, dairy products, fish, poultry and any other perishable products, including meat sandwiches and cream filled pies. Food items shall be stored in the vehicle at a temperature not to exceed 41 degrees Fahrenheit, except that perishable food products commonly served as a hot food shall be stored in a heating appliance or oven equipped with a thermometer showing an internal temperature of 135 degrees or higher. 
(5)  All milk and milk products shall be served only in the individual containers or approved dispensers. 
(6)  Only single service food utensils shall be used. Single service items are to be individually wrapped and kept in a clean and sanitary fashion protected from contamination by the customers, dirt, dust and flies. 
(7)  All perishable food products shall be stored as provided in this chapter or as provided by the rules and regulations established by the Village manager until served to the customer. 
(8)  All individually wrapped portions of perishable food products including sandwiches, pies and other similar portions shall be plainly marked by the manufacturer on the wrapper or container in such a manner as to plainly identify the day and month of which each portion was prepared and wrapped at an approved and licensed establishment. The name and address of the establishment or manufacturing and wrapping portions of perishable food products shall appear on each individual portion. No food product shall be offered for sale as individual portions of a perishable food product which have been rewrapped or repackaged or portions of which the identifying wrapper has been altered. 
(9)  No sale of such food or food products shall be made from mobile food units on the public rights-of-way, streets or other publically controlled property that may create congestion or inconvenience the public. All sales of food or food products from mobile food units conducted upon private property shall have the permission of the owner of such private property to make sales from such location. Vendors shall obey any lawful order of a police officer to move to a different location to avoid congestion or obstruction of a public way or remove the mobile food unit entirely from the public way if necessary to avoid such congestion or obstruction. 
(10)  Mobile food units shall comply with all provisions of this section, section 38-30 and all applicable State, County and local rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-43. - Restrictions on use. 
(a)  Any signage should be attached to the mobile food unit. 
(b)  There shall be no bollards, seating, or any other equipment not contained in the mobile food unit. 
(c)  The mobile food unit shall display the name, phone number and address of the owner. Vendors and peddlers are required to show their license at the request of any citizen. 
(d)  Any power required for the mobile food unit shall be self-contained. 
(e)  All off-site food preparation and food storage must be done at a licensed food facility. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Secs. 38-44—38-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - NUISANCES 
 
Sec. 38-61. - Enumeration. 
In addition to the actions which are elsewhere in this Code that are declared to be and constitute a nuisance, it is hereby declared to be a nuisance and unlawful for: 
(1)  Any person within the territorial jurisdiction of the Village to: 
a.  So negligently conduct any business, or use any premises to create such an offensive smell as may taint the air and render it unwholesome or disagreeable to other persons. 
b.  Cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected, deposited or remain in any place to the prejudice of other persons. 
c.  Throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter or the carcass of any animal in any watercourse, pond, spring, well or sewer. 
d.  Deposit any night soil, dead animal or other filthy, offensive or noisome substance upon any lot, street, alley, highway, park or other place. 
e.  Corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring, stream, pond or well to the injury or prejudice of others. 
f.  Obstruct or impede, without legal authority, the passage of any gutter, conduit, sewer or the natural drainage of any public or private property. 
g.  Construct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys or commons. 
h.  Establish, maintain and carry on any offensive or unwholesome business within the limits of the Village or within one mile of the limits thereof. 
i.  Establish a cemetery within the corporate limits of the Village or within one mile of the limits thereof without first having obtained permission to do so under an ordinance of the president and board of trustees. 
j.  Permit or suffer any offal, filth, refuse, animal or vegetable matter which is liable to become putrid or offensive, or injurious to health to remain on any premises used or occupied by him for a period of time longer than of four hours at any one time. 
k.  Keep or suffer to be kept in a foul, offensive, nauseous or filthy condition any building, yard, cellar, barn, sewer, pig sty or privy. 
l.  Own, keep or use any railroad car, yard, pen, place or premises, in or upon which cattle or swine shall be confined, or kept so as to be offensive to persons residing in the vicinity thereof. 
m.  Erect, continue or use any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture which, by occasioning noxious exhalations or offensive smells, or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or the public. 
n.  Boil or render tainted lard or other animal substance so as to taint the air or render it unwholesome or offensive. 
o.  Keep, own or raise any chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys or other fowl. 
p.  Own, manage or operate for hire or compensation an outdoor amusement park, outdoor theater, outdoor motion picture theater, outdoor dancehall, racecourse, slaughterhouse, sports arena or enclosure, garbage or refuse dump or incinerator, rendering plant or outdoor shooting gallery; provided, however, that nothing in this subsection shall be applicable to outdoor amusements, bazaars, fairs, etc., operated by or for the benefit of charitable, religious, civic or educational groups or organizations. 
q.  Cause, maintain or permit to remain on any premises abutting on any public highway or public place any open cistern, excavation, catch basin, cesspool or vault, unless it is provided with, and completely enclosed by, an adequate wall, fence or other barrier; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to excavations made for the purpose of, and during the progress of, building construction while being carried on under a permit duly issued by Village authorities. 
r.  Permit or have any offensive water, or other liquid or substance on his premises or grounds to the prejudice of life or health, whether for use in any trade or otherwise. 
s.  Throw, run, allow to seep, drain or otherwise permit or cause to be disposed into any river, stream, lake, pond or other surface and underground water within, or which flows within, the Village, any organic or inorganic matter that may prevent, interfere with, delay or stop the flow of water in any river or stream, or which shall cause pollution of such waters, more particularly, but not limited to, sewage, industrial waste or other wastes which shall cause pollution as set forth in this subsection. In this connection, the definition of the terms "pollution," "sewage," "industrial waste," "other wastes" and "any other act which may cause pollution as set forth in this subsection" shall be the definitions as set forth in 415 ILCS 5/3.105 et seq., in effect as of the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this subsection is derived, and any amendments which may subsequently be made applicable thereto, all of which definitions are incorporated in, and made a part of, this subsection by reference. 
t.  The emission of dense smoke within the Village from the smokestack of any machine or contrivance, or from the smokestack or chimney of any building or premises, except for a period aggregating not to exceed six minutes in any one hour, whether consecutive or not, during which the firebox is being cleaned out or a new fire is being built therein, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be summarily abated by the Village manager or any person whom he/she may duly authorize for such purpose. 
u.  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect sanitary sewerage or industrial waste to any storm sewer system in the Village. 
v.  It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any lot or premises to suffer to stand, or remain thereon, water which is or may become stagnant, foul or offensive, as well as detrimental to the health and comfort of persons residing in the neighborhood thereof. 
(2)  The conduct, operation, maintenance or sufferance of any of the nuisances declared in subsection (1) of this section within the territorial jurisdiction of the Village, or within one mile of the corporate limits of the Village, shall be unlawful and is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-62. - Duty to maintain landscaping. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant and any agent, servant, representative or employee of any such owner, lessee or occupant, having control of any real estate and improvement thereon, if any, to allow or maintain on such real estate any rubbish, garbage, construction debris, or landscape waste including but not limited to trimmings, leaves and grass clippings, to stand and accumulate thereon. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to have any growth of grass, weeds or plant growth to the height of over eight inches. The violator under this section may be punished as provided in section 1-16. Grass or weeds allowed to grow contrary to this section and any rubbish on such real estate, including but not limited to vacant lots, commercial properties, parkways, ditches, and cul-de-sacs, are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(c)  Natural landscaping on private lots shall be mowed or cut to 18 inches or less at least once prior to June 1 of each calendar year. 
(d)  Natural landscaping on private lots shall not be located within three feet of the front property line or at corner side property lines of lots having a public sidewalk, or within four feet of any other property line; provided, however, no rear or side yard setback shall be required where the natural landscaping material abuts permitted natural landscaping material on an adjacent lot. No natural landscaping shall infringe upon any public right-of-way or obstruct vision at any street, alley or driveway. 
(e)  Properly maintained composting is exempt from the requirements of section 38-62. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-63. - Failure of owner, etc., to cut. 
(a)  In all cases where the owner and the person who controls the real estate on which there are such growths of weeds or rubbish as set forth in this chapter shall fail to cut or remove such weeds or rubbish, or cause such weeds or rubbish to be cut or removed, owner shall be subject to the penalties and punishment set forth in section 1-16 of the municipal code. 
(b)  Weeds, when cut down, and rubbish, when collected, must be removed from the lot or disposed of in such a manner as not to create a nuisance or hazard. 
(c)  Properly maintained composting is exempt from the requirements of section 38-63. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-64. - Abatement of common law and statutory nuisances. 
In all cases where no provision is made in this chapter defining what nuisances are and how the nuisances may be removed, abated or prevented, in addition to what may be declared as such in this chapter, such offenses which are known to the common law of the land and the statutes of the State as nuisances may, in case such nuisances exist within the Village limits, be treated as such and proceeded against as provided in this chapter, or in accordance with any other law which shall give the officer trying the nuisances jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-65. - Power of abatement. 
Except as otherwise provided, it shall be the duty of the Village manager to serve notice upon the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession or control of any lot, building or premises in or upon which any nuisance may be found or who may be the owner or cause of any such nuisance requiring him to abate the nuisance in such manner as the Village manager shall prescribe, within a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Sec. 38-66. - Responsibility of expense of nuisance abatement. 
The expense of abatement of the nuisances as set forth in this Code shall be collected from the person who may have created, continued and suffered such nuisance to exist. 
(Ord. No. 5547, § 2, 4-3-2012)  
Secs. 38-67—38-90. - Reserved.  
Chapter 42 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 26; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 46; vehicles and traffic, ch. 90; powers and duties of chief of police generally, § 94-3. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 42-1—42-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Departments, § 2-391 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 42-31. - Chief of police—Office created; appointment; term; exemption. 
There is hereby created the office of chief of police for the Village. The chief of police shall be appointed by the Village manager and shall serve at the pleasure of the Village manager. The office of chief of police is specifically exempt from the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2-17. 
(Code 1959, § 14.2)  
Sec. 42-32. - Same—Salary. 
The salary of the chief of police shall be fixed by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 14.3)  
Sec. 42-33. - Same—Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The chief of police shall, subject to the supervision and direction of the Village manager, have direct charge and control of the police department and shall be responsible to the Village manager for the faithful and efficient conduct and operation of the police department. He shall be the keeper of the Village jail and have custody of all persons incarcerated therein. He shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required of him by the Village manager. All records and reports, or accurate copies thereof, shall be promptly filed by the chief of police with the Village manager and kept on file in the office of the Village manager. 
(b)  The chief of police, with the concurrence and the approval of the Village manager, shall have the authority to recruit and appoint individuals to exempt command positions within the police department. 
(Code 1959, §§ 14.4, 14.7(2))  
Sec. 42-34. - Sergeant of police. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of sergeant of police for the Village. The duties of the sergeant of police shall be such as are prescribed by the chief of police and board of fire and police commissioners. The compensation of sergeant of police shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 14.7; Ord. No. 5974, § 2, 1-5-2016)  
Sec. 42-35. - Police patrol officer. 
There is hereby created the office of police patrol officer for the Village. The duties of the police patrol officer shall be such as are prescribed by the chief of police, the board of fire and police commissioners and the ordinances of the Village. The compensation of the police patrol officer shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 14.8)  
Sec. 42-36. - Police department members. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the terms "police officer" and "member of the police department" shall mean the following members of the regularly constituted police department of the Village, sworn and commissioned to perform police duties: 
(1)  Chief of police; 
(2)  Deputy chief of police; 
(3)  Commanders; 
(4)  Sergeants of police; and 
(5)  Police patrol officers. 
(b)  Members of the police department shall be subject to the rules and regulations prescribed from time to time by the board of fire and police commissioners pursuant to the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1. Examination for all applicants for a position in the police department shall be conducted by the board of fire and police commissioners. The board of fire and police commissioners shall, according to its rules and regulations, establish an eligible list of all candidates for a position in the police department, make all appointments thereto, provide for promotions within the department, as well as provide for the suspension or removal of any member of the police department. 
(c)  The chief of police is specifically exempt from the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. In addition, the police chief, with the concurrence and the approval of the Village manager, shall have the authority to recruit and appoint individuals to exempt command positions such as deputy police chief and commander within the department. Exempt command positions are not subject to the board of fire and police commissioners. Individuals appointed to exempt command positions shall serve at the pleasure of the police chief and may be removed by the chief at any time with the concurrence of the Village manager. If an individual is appointed to such an exempt position and holds a certificate of appointment within the department in another position, the individual shall retain a guaranteed right to return to the certified position upon removal from the exempt command position. 
(d)  Members of the Village police department are not required to live within the corporate limits of the Village, either at the time of their appointment as police officers or while serving as police officers with the police department. No geographical restrictions with respect to residency are applicable to members of the police department. 
(Code 1959, § 14.9)  
Sec. 42-37. - Authority and duties of police officers generally. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to: 
(1)  Enforce all ordinances of the Village and all statutes and laws effective in the Village; 
(2)  Preserve order; 
(3)  Prevent infractions of law; and 
(4)  Arrest violators thereof. 
(b)  The police officers of the Village shall be conservators of the peace, and are hereby severally empowered and authorized to: 
(1)  Arrest, or cause to be arrested, with or without process, or on view, all persons who shall break the peace or are found violating any ordinance of the Village or the statutes of the State; 
(2)  Commit arrested persons for examination; 
(3)  Detain, if necessary, arrested persons in custody overnight or on Sunday in the Village jail, or any other safe place, until such persons can be brought before the circuit court of the County; and 
(4)  Exercise all other powers as conservators of the peace that the corporate authorities of the Village may from time to time prescribe. 
(c)  The Village police officers shall have all the common law and statutory power of constables. 
(Code 1959, § 14.10)  
Sec. 42-38. - Service and execution of legal process. 
Each member of the police department is hereby authorized, and it shall be their duty, within the corporate limits of the Village, to serve and execute warrants, writs, summons and other legal process for the apprehension and commitment of persons charged with a violation of the Village ordinances or any crime, misdemeanor or offense against the people of the State, and, while serving or executing any such process, such police officers shall be vested with and have all the power and authority of constables by common law and the statutes of the State. 
(Code 1959, § 14.11)  
Sec. 42-39. - Service as witnesses, etc. 
Each officer of the police department making an arrest shall attend before the court as a witness at the time of the trial of the person arrested, and shall use his best efforts to secure the attendance of material witnesses for the prosecution, and at the direction of the court or Village attorney, furnish a list of names of material witnesses within his knowledge. No member of the police department shall receive from or have taxed against the Village any witness fee in any action for a violation of an ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 14.12)  
Sec. 42-40. - Accident reports. 
The police department shall document and report vehicle crashes in the manner prescribed by the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-406 
(Code 1959, § 14.13)  
Sec. 42-41. - Original reports. 
The chief of police shall be responsible for the safe and secure storage of all police reports. Public access and inspections of police reports shall comply with all applicable State statutes. 
(Code 1959, § 14.14)  
Sec. 42-42. - Oath of office. 
Each member of the police department shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe the oath required of the officers of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 14.15)  
Sec. 42-43. - Resisting or interfering with police officers. 
No person shall resist any member of the police department in the discharge of his duty, or in any way interfere with, hinder or prevent such discharge, or offer or endeavor so to do. 
(Code 1959, § 14.16)  
Sec. 42-44. - Impersonating police officers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be a member of the police department or maliciously, or with the intent to deceive, or use, or imitate any of the signs of the police department, or wear the uniform accepted as a police uniform. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or wear a star or other similar device like that of a police officer, except as otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 14.17)  
Sec. 42-45. - Traffic control aides. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Traffic control aide means any unsworn person employed by the police department who may be selected and cross trained by the police department for the purpose of directing vehicular traffic, with the prior approval of the chief of police. 
(b)  Direction of vehicular traffic. Traffic control aides may direct vehicular traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with the traffic laws of the State and the applicable ordinances of the Village. In the event of a fire or other emergency, or in order to expedite vehicular traffic or safeguard pedestrians, traffic control aides may direct traffic contrary to traffic control devices as conditions may require, in the discretion of the police department. 
(c)  Requirements. Prior to acting as a traffic control aide, a person must: 
(1)  Be employed by and submit to training by the police department and demonstrate proficiency in traffic control procedures as determined by the police department; 
(2)  While performing traffic control duties, wear uniforms as directed by the police department, which clearly indicate their affiliation with the police department; and 
(3)  While performing traffic control duties, comply with all police department policies and procedures regarding traffic direction and control. 
(Ord. No. 4375, § 2(14.20), 3-5-2002)  
Secs. 42-46—42-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - POLICE PENSION FUND 
 
Sec. 42-71. - Operation under State law. 
The police pension fund shall operate under the provisions of 40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1959, § 14.18)  
Chapter 43 - MANUFACTURED HOME COMMUNITIES  
ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL. 
 
Sec. 43-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements affecting or relating to the erection, construction, alteration, remodeling, repair, maintenance, removal and demolition of mobile home structures, and to regulate said structures within the Village limits. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-2. - Scope and applicability. 
(a)  This chapter is remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health and welfare, structural strength and stability, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and hazards incidental to the construction, alteration, repair and maintenance of mobile home structures, or portions thereof, in the Village, except federal and State buildings and possessions. 
[(b)  Reserved.] 
(c)  This chapter shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations prescribing standards other than are provided herein, including, but not limited to, building codes, fire codes, property maintenance codes or water and other utility codes, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(d)  The existing zoning ordinance set forth in chapter 98, the existing subdivision ordinance set forth in chapter 66, and the existing site plan ordinance set forth in chapter 54, and the appearance code ordinance set forth in chapter 54, and all revisions to the foregoing, are hereby made a part of this chapter. Should a provision in these chapters or any provision in the State laws pertaining to the erection, maintenance or occupancy of mobile home structures conflict with a similar provision in this chapter, the most restrictive provision shall govern. 
(e)  This chapter applies to all mobile homes and mobile home parks located within the corporate boundaries of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-3. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
County means Cook County, Illinois. 
Department means the Village's development department, unless otherwise indicated. 
Dependent mobile home means a mobile home which does not have toilet and bath or shower facilities. 
Director means director of development. 
Front means the end of the mobile or manufactured home to which the hitch is or was attached and used for towing or for delivery to the site. When a mobile home is placed in a mobile home park and the hitch is removed, the department shall make a determination as to what constitutes the front. 
Immobilized manufactured home means a manufactured home served by individual utilities, resting on a permanent perimeter foundation that extends below the established frost depth, and with the wheels, tongue and hitch removed and the home secured in compliance with the Mobile Home Tiedown Act, 210 ILCS 120/1, et seq. 
Independent mobile home means a mobile home which has self-contained toilet and bath or shower facilities. 
Individual utilities means the provision for each mobile home of a separate metered connection to electrical service; separately tapped water service from an approved public water supply or a separate private water supply; and a separately tapped connection to an approved public sewer system or a separate private sewage disposal system. 
License means a mobile home park operator's license. 
Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 feet or more in length, or when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, including plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. Any structure defined in this chapter as a "mobile home" shall also be considered a manufactured home. For purposes of this chapter, the terms "mobile home" and "manufactured home" are used interchangeably. This term shall not include "manufactured building" which shall mean any building that is of closed construction and is made or assembled in manufacturing facilities on or off the building site for installation, or for assembly and installation of the building site. 
Manufactured home accessory buildings or structures is an assembly of materials forming a construction for use which contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of the principal building or structure served, including, among other things, awnings, cabanas, garages, storage structures, sheds, decks, carports, fences, windbreaks, porches or other like appurtenances. 
Manufactured home community means a tract of land or two or more contiguous tracts of land that contain sites with the necessary utilities for five or more independent manufactured homes for permanent habitation either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, vehicle, or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such manufactured home community. Separate ownership of contiguous tracts of land shall not preclude the tracts of land from common licensure as a manufactured home community if they are maintained and operated jointly. Neither an immobilized manufactured home nor a motorized recreational vehicle shall be construed as being part of a manufactured home community. Any community defined in this chapter as a "mobile home park" shall also be considered a manufactured home community. For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "mobile home park," and "manufactured home community," are used interchangeably. 
Mobile home means a structure designed for permanent habitation for use as a single family dwelling unit suitable for year-round occupancy and containing water supply, sanitary waste disposal and electrical facilities. It is so constructed as to permit its transport on wheels, temporarily or permanently attached to its frame, from the place of its construction to the location, or subsequent locations, provided that any such structure resting on a permanent foundation, with wheels, tongue, lug bolts and hitch permanently removed, shall not be construed as a "mobile home." 
Mobile home park means an area of land or lands upon which one or more independent mobile homes are harbored either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle, or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park. 
Park operator means an owner or manager of a mobile home park, their officers, agents or employees. 
Permanent habitation means a period of one or more months. 
Site means the lot on which the mobile home is located for permanent habitation. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Secs. 43-4—43-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 43-21. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The development department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. Each mobile home park shall be inspected annually by the department pursuant to the codes and regulations of the Village. Such officials or officers are hereby granted the power and authority to enter upon the premises of all mobile home parks at any time for inspection. The department shall promptly bring such action as is necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and to prosecute any person or persons who fail to comply with same. 
(b)  Notices. The department shall serve or cause to be served upon the licensee a written notice which shall specify the way or ways in which a licensee has failed to comply with this chapter. Said notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate such nuisance, insanitary or objectionable condition, or to otherwise bring the mobile home park into compliance with the provisions of this chapter. If the licensee fails to comply with the terms and conditions of said notice, within the time specified or such extended period of time, the director may initiate enforcement actions. 
(c)  Any person found to have violated any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine as set out in section 1-16 of the Municipal Code, in addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to the Village. 
(1)  A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which such person or persons shall violate the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  The Village may enforce this article in a system of administrative adjudication or through the Circuit Court of Cook County. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Secs. 43-22—43-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 43-41. - License. 
No person, firm or corporation shall maintain, conduct, or operate a mobile home park without first obtaining an annual license from the department. The term "conduct or operate a mobile home park" as used in this chapter shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, supplying or maintaining common water, sewer or other utility supply or service, or the collection of rents directly or indirectly from five or more independent mobile homes. The license year or period shall begin on January 1 of each year and expire on December 31 of that year. A new license may be issued upon proper application and payment of the annual license fee provided the applicant is in substantial compliance with the rules and regulations of the department. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-42. - License fee; rate. 
(a)  The annual license fee for the manufactured home community shall be as set out in section 30-1. In addition, there shall be an amount as set out in section 30-1 for each mobile home space in the park. 
(b)  The licensee shall pay to the Village an amount as set out in section 30-1 for each additional mobile home space added to a park under the authority of a written permit to alter the park as provided in this chapter. All requisite permits and payment of fees must be secured before any mobile homes are located on the additional mobile home sites. The department shall issue an amended license to cover such additional mobile home sites, when they are to be occupied before the end of the license year, for which an annual license has been previously issued. 
(1)  Additional mobile homes may be installed pursuant to an approved plot plan by completing a license application and complying with all applicable codes and regulations specified herein or otherwise in the Municipal Code. 
(2)  If site plan approval to construct or alter a park has been granted by ordinance, the department shall then inspect the park and if completed in accordance with the approved site plan, the department shall issue a license. 
(c)  Each license fee shall be paid to the Village and, once accepted by the Village, no license fee or portion thereof shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-43. - Registration of mobile homes with park. 
Each mobile home park shall maintain a register which shall include the name and address of the owner of each mobile home [in the] park, the square feet of floor space contained in each mobile home, and the date of entry of each mobile home into the park. The register shall be signed by the owner of the mobile home. The registration records shall be neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records shall be destroyed until six years have elapsed after the departure of any tenant from the park. The register shall be available for inspection upon request by all law enforcement officers and by the department. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-44. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ZONING/MANUFACTURED HOME DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 43-45. - Zoning. 
Mobile home developments are regulated as a conditional use in the R-1 district within the Village of Glenview. All mobile home developments shall comply with the conditions set forth in subsection 98-50(a)(20). 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-46. - Existing mobile home developments. 
Mobile home developments operating as of the effective date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be considered existing nonconforming under section 98-256. 
Sunset Village Mobile Home Community, an existing mobile home community as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, shall be governed by Alternate Site Plan "C", consisting of four pages, prepared by Christian-Roge and Assoc., Inc, for Capital First Realty, dated June 18, 2008, attached to and made part of this chapter, which shall be deemed the existing site plan as of the effective date of this chapter for the purpose of approving changes or alterations to the site plan. Applications for such changes or alterations shall be subject to the provisions of the site plan review ordinance, chapter 54 of the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Sec. 43-47. - Application. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall establish or construct a mobile home park without first obtaining a permit from the department. In order to obtain a permit to construct a mobile home park, the applicant shall file with the department a written application and submit plan documents, that shall be prepared by a registered engineer or architect licensed to practice in the State of Illinois, with registration seal affixed, setting forth: 
(1)  The full name and address of the applicant or applicants or names and addresses of the partners if the applicant is a partnership, or names and addresses of the officers if the applicant is a corporation, and the present or last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the application; 
(2)  The address, location and legal description of the tract of land upon which it is proposed to operate and maintain a mobile home park; 
(3)  The proposed facilities in the mobile home park for water supply, sewage, garbage and waste disposal, fire protection, and any proposed alterations therein and the maintenance thereof; 
(4)  The proposed method of lighting the structures and land upon which the mobile home park is to be located; 
(5)  The plot plans of the mobile home park as may be required by the rules and regulations of the department under the provisions of this chapter; 
(6)  The building plans and specifications for existing buildings and facilities; and 
(7)  A statement of the firefighting facilities, public or private, which are available to the mobile home park. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by an application fee in the amount set out in section 30-1. The application fee, once paid to the Village, shall not be refunded. 
(c)  Applications for new mobile home parks shall be subject to the provisions of the site plan review ordinance, chapter 54 of the Municipal Code. 
(d)  No change in any sanitary facilities, methods of water supply, sewer, drainage, garbage or waste disposal, and no change in the plot plan shall be made without first making a written application to the department and receiving a written permit therefore. Such application shall be made in accordance with the provisions contained in chapter 54, site plan review, and shall be accompanied by an application fee as set out in section 30-1. 
(e)  No application fee or site plan approval shall be required to accompany an application for a permit to alter a mobile home park where such alteration involves only a reduction in the number of mobile home spaces to a number less than that for which such park is currently licensed. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Secs. 43-48—43-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OPERATING REQUIREMENTS AND STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 43-101. - Operating requirements. 
Each mobile home park licensed or to be constructed under the provisions of this chapter shall be operated and maintained in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(1)  Every mobile home park shall be in the charge of a responsible attendant or caretaker ("manager") whose name, address and telephone number shall be on file at all times with the department, who shall maintain an office within the park, and whose duty it shall be to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition. The manager, along with the licensee, shall be responsible for any violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  All licenses and permits to construct, alter and operate the mobile home park shall be prominently displayed in the mobile home park office. 
(3)  Setbacks and pad locations; accessory structures; parking; Except as provided in section 43-46 herein: 
a.  Each site on which a mobile home is located shall have a minimum area of 2,500 square feet, except that sites existing in parks or approved by the County or the State of Illinois for construction prior to August 21, 1967, shall contain an area of not less than 1,000 square feet. 
b.  No mobile home shall be located closer than five feet to the side lot lines of a mobile home park, or closer than ten feet to a public street, alley or building. Each individual site shall abut or face on a private or public driveway or roadway of not less than 24 feet in width, which driveway or roadway shall have unobstructed access to a public highway or alley. There shall be an open space of at least ten feet adjacent to the sides of every mobile home and at least five feet adjacent to the ends of every mobile home for mobile homes placed on a site prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
c.  For mobile homes placed on a site after the effective date of this chapter, no portion of a mobile home, excluding the tongue, shall be closer than ten feet side to side, eight feet end to side, and six feet end to end horizontally from any other mobile home or community building. All manufactured home accessory buildings or structures, including, but not limited to, garages (attached and detached), carports, canopies, porches, decks or storage sheds, shall be considered as part of the mobile home for the purpose of computing distances for the setback requirement. Parking spaces shall not, however, be considered part of the mobile home for the setback requirements. 
d.  Compliance with the setback and separation requirements shall be adhered to whenever an owner of a mobile home community enlarges or expands a concrete pad used to support a mobile home, installs a new mobile home, or replaces an existing mobile home on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
e.  For new mobile home parks constructed and licensed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, no mobile home shall be located closer than ten feet to a private street. 
f.  In the instance where an owner of a mobile home community enlarges or expands a concrete pad in an existing community used to support a mobile home, installs a new mobile home in an existing community, or replaces an existing mobile home in an existing community, on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the mobile home shall be no closer than five feet to a public or private street. The licensee may apply to the department for a variance from this setback requirement. 
(4)  Utilities; drainage. 
a.  All sewage and other water-carried wastes shall be disposed of into a municipal sewerage system. 
b.  When a water carriage system of sewage is used, each site shall be provided with a sewer connection for the combined liquid waste outlet or outlets of each mobile home. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of said park to provide an approved type of water and odor tight connection from the mobile home water drainage to the sewer connection, and it shall be the duty of said owner or operator to make such connection and keep all occupied mobile homes connected to said sewer while located in the park. Sewer connections in unoccupied sites shall be closed such that they will emit no odors or cause a breeding place for flies. No water or waste shall be allowed to fall on the ground from a mobile home. 
c.  No mobile home park shall be located such that the drainage of the park area will endanger any water supply. All mobile home parks shall be well drained and shall be maintained such that the area is kept free from ponds, swamps and similar places in which mosquitoes may breed. No wastewater shall be deposited on the surface of the ground within the mobile home park. 
d.  Water supply system. 
1.  All private water supply systems and hydrants for fire safety purposes in existence prior to the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be maintained in operable condition and good repair, and it shall be the duty of the owner or operator to connect such water supply system to all occupied mobile homes while located in the park. A mobile home park that does not have a private water supply and hydrants shall have an agreement, approved by the Village to provide an adequate and reliable water supply for fire mitigation and suppression needs. This agreement shall be signed by the licensee, and by the Glenview Village Manager. A copy of this agreement shall be on file at the Village and posted in public view at the mobile home park site by the manager. 
2.  A manufactured home community existing on the effective date of this chapter must provide an operating water supply system that meets the following requirements: 
3.  A manufactured home community based water system, with fire hydrants within at least every 500 feet of any structure. At a minimum, the hydrants within the mobile home park must be connected to a six-inch water main that generates 1,000 to 1,500 gallons per minute, with a static pressure of 35 psi; or 
4.  An adequate and reliable water supply system that meets fire mitigation needs, if approved by the department in consultation with the Glenview Fire Department. Examples include, but are not limited to, the following: 
i.  A mobile home park based system, connected to the Village of Glenview water distribution system, with fire hydrants strategically placed. At a minimum, the hydrants within the system must be connected to a six-inch water main that generates 1,000 to 1,500 gallons per minute, with a static pressure of 35 psi; 
ii.  An on-site water reservoir; and 
iii.  Fire prevention authority that has capable mobile sources, such as a water tanker or fire apparatus designed with larger water tanks. 
e.  An adequate supply of potable water of safe, sanitary quality, approved by the department and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency shall be furnished at each mobile home park. Each site shall be provided with a cold water tap located in accordance with ordinances of the Village. 
f.  A manufactured home community constructed or developed after the effective date of this chapter must provide a mobile home park based system connected to the Village of Glenview water distribution system for both potable water and fire mitigation requirements. 
(5)  Nuisances; garbage. 
a.  A sufficient number of adequate vermin, pest-resistant and watertight containers in accordance with the ordinances of the Village shall be supplied for the storage of garbage. 
b.  Grass, trees and shrubbery shall be maintained in a safe, sanitary and attractive condition, which creates neither a nuisance nor menace to public health. 
c.  Garbage containers shall be emptied at least once a week and shall not be filled to overflowing, or allowed to become foul-smelling or a breeding place for insects. Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to health and which is approved by the department. 
d.  Adequate insect and rodent control measures shall be employed. All buildings shall be vermin and pest-resistant and rodent harborages shall not be permitted to exist in the mobile home community or pathways. 
e.  No person owning, keeping or harboring a dog or cat, or other animal shall permit any offal, fecal matter or noisome substance from such animal to remain on any public or private property in any place in the Village, other than the property of such owner or keeper. 
(6)  Fire protection. 
a.  A smoke detector and a carbon monoxide detector, in working order, shall be installed in every dwelling unit shall be equipped with at least one approved carbon monoxide alarm in operating condition within 15 feet of every room used for sleeping in accordance with adopted codes of the Village. 
b.  All areas and individual sites within the manufactured home community shall be maintained so as to be free of dry brush, leaves and other debris that could contribute to the spread of fire within the site or community. 
c.  The space under manufactured homes and accessory buildings and structures shall not be used for the storage of combustible materials or for the storage or placement therein of flammable liquids, gases, or liquid or gas fuel-powered equipment. 
d.  Maintenance of fire hydrants. 
1.  The licensee shall test all fire hydrants annually to establish that they are in good working order. Testing requirements include turning the hydrant stem so a positive water flow is established, static and residual pressure readings documented, and the hydrant checked to ensure that it drains. Such testing documentation shall be provided to the fire department and meet the criteria established in subsection (4)d.1 herein. During the annual test other maintenance items to be addressed shall include lubrication of the steamer and/or threads, and verification that each hydrant is clear and free of debris and obstructions, and the b-box is clear and accessible. 
2.  The licensee shall notify the fire department whenever a hydrant(s) is not operable or in working condition and shall identify the nonworking hydrant in a manner acceptable to the fire department. The location of these fire hydrant(s) shall be specified in writing along with a plan to either replace the defective hydrant(s) or restore them to working order, and an anticipated date for completion. A copy of such notification shall be provided to the department. No more than one consecutive hydrant shall be out of service at any time. 
(7)  Temporary or accessory structures. 
a.  Except as provided in section 43-46 herein: Temporary porches, canvas-roofed canopies and skirts may be permitted for mobile homes and auxiliary rooms if in compliance with applicable local fire safety and building codes. Manufactured home accessory buildings or structures constructed after the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may be located immediately adjacent to a site's lot line when constructed entirely of non-combustible materials, provided that such buildings or structures are at least three feet from an accessory building or structure on an adjacent site and do not obstruct required exit doors or windows. Accessory buildings and structures constructed before the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived and which do not obstruct required exit doors or windows shall be permitted, such structures to be permitted as nonconforming. 
b.  Fences are not permitted on any mobile home site. 
(8)  All streets and driveways in every mobile home park must be maintained in a passable and reasonably dustproof condition at all times. 
a.  The management of every mobile home park shall assume full responsibility for maintaining in good repair and condition all sanitary and electrical appliances in the park. 
(9)  Electrical hookup devices for each individual site shall be provided and the installation shall be in accordance with all State or local codes and ordinances. 
(10)  In no event shall a dependent mobile home, or nonpermanent shelter or other vehicle designed or used for sleeping purposes, other than an independent mobile home, be permitted for occupancy at any time in a mobile park. 
(11)  Community kitchens, plumbing and electrical installations. 
When mobile home community kitchens, dining rooms, laundries or other facilities are provided, such facilities and equipment as are supplied must be maintained in a sanitary condition and kept in good repair, and subject to the ordinances of the Village. 
(12)  All buildings constructed or altered, and all plumbing, electrical and heating installations shall be in accordance with existing Village ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 5367, § 2, 7-20-2010)  
Chapter 46 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 42; vehicles and traffic, ch. 90. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 46-1—46-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST MORALS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-31. - Keeping a place of prostitution. 
Any person who has or exercises control over the use of any place which could offer seclusion or shelter for the practice of prostitution and performs any of the following acts keeps a place of prostitution: 
(1)  Knowingly grants or permits the use of such place for the purpose of prostitution; 
(2)  Grants or permits the use of such place under circumstances from which he could reasonably know that the place is used, or is to be used, for purposes of prostitution; or 
(3)  Permits the continued use of a place after becoming aware of facts or circumstances from which he should reasonably know that the place is being used for purposes of prostitution. 
(Code 1959, § 13.9) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/11-17.  
Sec. 46-32. - Possession of less than ten grams of cannabis. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cannabis includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the Cannabis Sativa plant, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis, or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis, but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination. 
(b)  Possession. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to knowingly possess any quantity of any substance containing less than ten grams of cannabis. 
(c)  Violations; penalties. All persons convicted of a violation of the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 13.63)  
Sec. 46-33. - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Drug paraphernalia means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are peculiar to and marketed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance. 
(b)  Possession. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to knowingly possess an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance in the human body, or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use. 
(c)  Violations; penalties. All persons convicted of a violation of the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-16.  
Secs. 46-34—46-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OBSCENITY 
 
Sec. 46-51. - Definition; commission; interpretation of evidence. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Obscene means any material or performance that: 
(1)  The average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest; 
(2)  The average person, applying contemporary adult community standards, would find it depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way, ultimate sexual acts or sadomasochistic sexual acts, whether normal or perverted, actual or simulated, or masturbation, excretory functions or lewd exhibition of the genitals; and 
(3)  Taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(b)  Commission. A person commits an obscenity, which is hereby prohibited, when, for the first time, with knowledge of the nature or content thereof, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable inspection which would have disclosed the nature or content thereof, he: 
(1)  Sells, delivers or provides, or offers or agrees to sell, deliver or provide, any obscene writing, picture, record or other representation or embodiment of the obscene; 
(2)  Presents or directs an obscene play, dance or other performance or participates directly in that portion thereof which makes it obscene; 
(3)  Publishes, exhibits or otherwise makes available anything obscene; 
(4)  Performs an obscene act or otherwise presents an obscene exhibition of his body for gain; 
(5)  Creates, buys, procures or possesses obscene matter or material with the intent to disseminate it in violation of this section or of the penal laws or regulations of any other jurisdiction; or 
(6)  Advertises or otherwise promotes the sale of material represented or held out by him to be obscene, whether or not it is obscene. 
(c)  Interpretation of evidence. Obscenity shall be judged with reference to ordinary adults, except that it shall be judged with reference to children or other specifically susceptible audiences if it appears from the character of the material or the circumstances of its dissemination to be specifically designed for or directed to such an audience. Where circumstances of production, presentation, sale, dissemination, distribution or publicity indicate that material is being commercially exploited for the sake of its prurient appeal, such evidence is probative with respect to the nature of the matter and can justify the conclusion that the matter is lacking in serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. In any prosecution for an offense under this section, evidence shall be admissible to show: 
(1)  The character of the audience for which the material was designed or to which it was directed; 
(2)  What the predominant appeal of the material would be for ordinary adults or a special audience, and what effect, if any, it would probably have on the behavior of such people; 
(3)  The artistic, literary, scientific, educational or other merits of the material, or absence thereof; 
(4)  The degree, if any, of public acceptance of the material in the State; 
(5)  Appeal to prurient interest, or absence thereof, in advertising or other promotion of the material; 
(6)  Purpose of the author, creator, publisher or disseminator. 
(Code 1959, § 13.15) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/11-20.  
Sec. 46-52. - Writings, printing and painting on buildings, walls, etc. 
No person shall write, print or paint, with chalk, ink, paint or other material, any obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), words, language or expression upon any building, tenement, fence, wall or other place. 
(Code 1959, § 13.17)  
Secs. 46-53—46-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - GAMBLING 
 
Sec. 46-71. - Nuisance declared. 
Every house, room, yard or other premises, kept for the purpose of permitting persons to gamble for any valuable thing, within the limits of the Village, is hereby declared to be a common nuisance. All persons who keep, own, maintain, manage or conduct, or who are interested in any such place, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 13.36)  
Sec. 46-72. - Suppression and prevention. 
It shall be the duty of all members of the police department to give information to the chief of police of each house, room or other place within the Village wherein games, devices, tables or other instruments or things for the purpose of gaming are, or may be, set up, kept or maintained; and such police officers shall take all lawful means to suppress and prevent the playing at such tables, games or devices, and, for such purpose, when and as often as any one of them shall have reasonable cause to suspect that any such table, game or device is set up, kept or maintained as set forth in this section, he shall forthwith make complaint thereof before a judge or magistrate, and obtain a warrant authorizing him to enter such house or place, or any room therein, and such police officer shall thereupon have authority to demand entry therein, and any person who shall refuse or neglect to open the door or entrance to such house, yard, place or any room therein, upon the application of any police officer having such warrant, shall forfeit and pay a fine of not less than $25.00, nor more than $500.00 for each and every offense. 
(Code 1959, § 13.37)  
Sec. 46-73. - Commission; exemptions. 
(a)  A person commits gambling when he: 
(1)  Plays a game of chance or skill for money or other thing of value, unless excepted in subsection (b) of this section; 
(2)  Makes a wager upon the result of any game or contest, or any political nomination, appointment or election; 
(3)  Operates, keeps, owns, uses, purchases, exhibits, rents, sells, bargains for the sale or lease of, manufactures or distributes any gambling device; 
(4)  Contracts to have or give himself or another the option to buy or sell, or contracts to buy or sell, at a future time, any grain or other commodity whatsoever, or any stock or security of any company, where it is, at the time of making such contract, intended by both parties thereto that the contract to buy or sell, or the option, whenever exercised, or the contract resulting therefrom, shall be settled, not by the receipt or delivery of such property, but by the payment only of differences in prices thereof; however, the issuance, purchase, sale, exercise, endorsement or guarantee, by or through a person registered with the secretary of State pursuant to section 8 of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953 (815 ILCS 5/8), or by or through a person exempt from such registration under section 8 of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953 (815 ILCS 5/8), of a put, call or other option to buy or sell securities which have been registered with the secretary of State or which are exempt from such registration under section 3 of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953 (815 ILCS 5/3) is not gambling within the meaning of this subsection; 
(5)  Knowingly owns or possesses any book, instrument or apparatus by means of which bets or wagers have been, or are, recorded or registered, or knowingly possesses any money which he has received in the course of a bet or wager; 
(6)  Sells pools upon the result of any game, contest of skill or chance, political nomination, appointment or election; 
(7)  Sets up or promotes any lottery or sells, offers to sell or transfers any ticket or share for any lottery; 
(8)  Sets up or promotes any policy game or sells, offers to sell or knowingly possesses or transfers any policy ticket, slip, record, document or other similar device; 
(9)  Knowingly drafts, prints or publishes any lottery ticket or share, or any policy ticket, slip, record, document or similar device, except for such activity related to lotteries, bingo games and raffles authorized by and conducted in accordance with the laws of the State or any other state or foreign government; 
(10)  Knowingly advertises any lottery or policy game, except for such activity related to lotteries, bingo games and raffles authorized by and conducted in accordance with the laws of the State or any other state; 
(11)  Knowingly transmits information as to wagers, betting odds or changes in betting odds by telephone, telegraph, radio, semaphore or similar means, or knowingly installs or maintains equipment for the transmission or receipt of such information, except that nothing in this subsection prohibits transmission or receipt of such information for use in news reporting of sporting events or contests; or 
(12)  Knowingly establishes, maintains or operates an internet site that permits a person to play a game of chance or skill for money or other thing of value by means of the internet or to make a wager upon the result of any game, contest, political nomination, appointment or election by means of the internet. 
(b)  Participants in any of the following activities shall not be convicted of gambling therefor: 
(1)  Agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance, including, without limitation, contracts of indemnity or guaranty, and life, health or accident insurance; 
(2)  Offers of prizes, awards or compensation to the actual contestants in any bona fide contest for the determination of skill, speed, strength or endurance or to the owners of animals or vehicles entered in such contest; 
(3)  Pari-mutuel betting as authorized by the law of the State; 
(4)  Manufacture of gambling devices, including the acquisition of essential parts therefor and the assembly thereof, for transportation in interstate or foreign commerce to any place outside the State when such transportation is not prohibited by any applicable federal law; 
(5)  The game commonly known as bingo, when conducted in accordance with the Bingo License and Tax Act (230 ILCS 25/1 et seq.); 
(6)  Lotteries, when conducted by the State in accordance with the Illinois Lottery Law (20 ILCS 1605/1 et seq.); 
(7)  Possession of an antique slot machine that is neither used, nor intended to be used, in the operation or promotion of any unlawful gambling activity or enterprise. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "antique slot machine" means a slot machine manufactured 25 or more years ago; 
(8)  Raffles, when conducted in accordance with the Raffles Act (230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq); 
(9)  Charitable games, when conducted in accordance with the Charitable Games Act (230 ILCS 30/1 et seq.); 
(10)  Pull tabs and jar games, when conducted under the Illinois Pull Tabs and Jar Games Act (230 ILCS 20/1 et seq.). 
(Code 1959, §§ 13.38, 13.40, 13.42)  
Sec. 46-74. - Possession of gaming tables, things and devices. 
No person shall bring into the Village, or have in his possession in the Village, for the purpose of gaming, any table, thing or device of any kind or nature, whereon or with which money or any other thing of value may in any manner be played for. 
(Code 1959, § 13.39)  
Sec. 46-75. - Duty to seize and destroy. 
It is hereby made the duty of every member of the police department to seize any table, instrument, device or thing used for the purpose of gaming, and all such tables, instruments, devices or things shall be destroyed. Any person obstructing or resisting any member of the police department in the performance of any act authorized by this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00, nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1959, § 13.41)  
Secs. 46-76—46-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE AND SAFETY  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-101. - Disorderly conduct. 
A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly: 
(1)  Does any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and provokes a breach of the peace; 
(2)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, in any manner, to the fire department of any city, town, village or fire protection district, a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such fire exists; 
(3)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, in any manner, to another, a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature or a container holding poison gas, a deadly biological or chemical contaminant, or radioactive substance is concealed in such place that its explosion or release would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such bomb, explosive or a container holding poison gas, a deadly biological or chemical contaminant, or radioactive substance is concealed in such place; 
(4)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, in any manner, to any peace officer, public officer or public employee, a report to the effect that an offense will be committed, is being committed or has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such an offense will be committed, is being committed or has been committed; 
(5)  Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other opening therein; 
(6)  While acting as a collection agency, as defined in the Collection Agency Act (225 ILCS 425/1 et seq.), or as an employee of such collection agency, and while attempting to collect an alleged debt, makes a telephone call to the alleged debtor which is designed to harass, annoy or intimidate the alleged debtor; 
(7)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, a false report to the department of children and family services under section 4 of the Abused and Neglected Child Reporting Act (325 ILCS 5/4 et seq.); 
(8)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, a false report to the department of public health under the Nursing Home Care Act (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.); 
(9)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, in any manner, to the police department or fire department of any municipality or fire protection district, or any privately owned and operated ambulance service, a false request for an ambulance, emergency medical technician-ambulance or emergency medical technician-paramedic, knowing at the time there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such assistance is required; 
(10)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, a false report under article II of an act in relation to victims of violence and abuse, approved September 16, 1984, as amended (320 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq.); 
(11)  Transmits, or causes to be transmitted, a false report to any public safety agency without the reasonable grounds necessary to believe that transmitting such a report is necessary for the safety and welfare of the public; or 
(12)  Calls the number 911 for the purpose of making or transmitting a false alarm or complaint and reporting information when, at the time the call or transmission is made, the person knows there is no reasonable grounds for making the call or transmission and further knows that the call or transmission could result in the emergency response of any public safety agency. 
(13)  No person shall make any other false alarm of any kind calculated to disturb the peace of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 13.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/26-1.  
Sec. 46-102. - Congregating unlawfully. 
No person shall, with other persons, congregate about or upon any stairway, doorway, window or in front of any business or dwelling, house, theater, lecture room, church or elsewhere, and, by so doing, obstruct or interfere with free passage of persons entering or occupying any such buildings or premises. 
(Code 1959, § 13.4)  
Sec. 46-103. - False alarms. 
No person shall make any false alarm of any kind, excluding alarms of fires, bombs and crimes, calculated to disturb the peace of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 13.12)  
Sec. 46-104. - Noises generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the Village to make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, convenience, health, peace or safety of others within the limits of the Village. 
(b)  The following acts are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this section, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Horns and signaling devices. 
a.  The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place of the Village, except as a danger warning; 
b.  The creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; 
c.  The sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time; 
d.  The use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and 
e.  The use of any such signaling device when traffic is held up for any reason. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, etc. The playing, using or operating, or permitting to be played, used or operated, of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, television receiving set or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or with louder volume than is necessary for the convenient hearing of the persons who are in the room, chamber, vehicle or outdoor area, within the Village limits, in which or where such machine or device is played, used or operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., in such manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the location of such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device, shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(3)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers, etc., for advertising or attracting the attention of the public. The playing, using or operating, or permitting to be played, used or operated, of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets of the Village for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure, except when a permit has been first procured from the Village manager as required by other ordinances. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets of the Village, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of persons in the vicinity, within the limits of the Village. 
(5)  Animals and birds. The keeping of any animal or bird, shut up or tied up in any yard, enclosure, stable, house or other place within the Village, which, by barking, howling, crying, singing or causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort or repose of persons in the vicinity. 
(6)  Engine exhausts. The discharge into the open air within the Village of the exhaust of any steam engine, gasoline engine, stationary internal combustion engine or other kind or type of engine, motor boat or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(7)  Defect in vehicles or loads. The use within the Village of any wagon, cart, automobile, truck, motorcycle or other vehicle, so out of repair or loaded in such a manner or with material of such nature as to create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises. 
(8)  Loading and unloading vehicles, and opening boxes, etc. The creation within the Village of loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading of any vehicle, or the opening or destruction of bales, boxes, crates, containers, etc., without exercising reasonable care to limit and confine such noise. 
(9)  Building construction, repair, etc., and street excavation.
