The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building within the Village, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on Monday—Friday, 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on Saturday, and 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Sunday, except in case of urgent necessity, in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit from the building commissioner, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three days or less while the emergency continues and which permit may be renewed for periods of three days or less while the emergency continues. If the building commissioner should determine that the public health and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building, or the excavation of streets and highways between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday—Thursday, 7:00 p.m. on Friday and 9:00 a.m. on Saturday, 6:00 p.m. on Saturday and 9:00 a.m. on Sunday, and after 5:00 p.m. on Sunday, and if he shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest if the work was not undertaken, he may grant permission for such work to be done within such hours only upon prior written application from the person requesting to do the work. 
(10)  Schools, institutions of learning, courts, churches and hospitals. The creation within the Village of any excessive noise in the vicinity of any school, institution of learning, church, court or hospital, while such school, institution of learning, church, court or hospital is in use, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided, conspicuous signs are displayed in the vicinity of any such building indicating that the building is a school, institution of learning, hospital, court or church. 
(11)  Drums and other instruments or devices. The use within the Village of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention, by the creation of noise, to any place of business, entertainment or public assembly. 
(Code 1959, § 13.22; Ord. No. 5748, § 2, 12-10-2013) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5748, § 2, adopted December 10, 2013, set out provisions noting this section of the Code shall not be applicable to automotive sales and leasing dealership uses; provided, however, that all other standards and regulations set forth in this Code relating to automotive sales and leasing uses shall remain in full force and effect.  
Sec. 46-105. - Obedience to police officers in public places. 
All persons when at or about any public place in the Village shall obey the commands and directions of any police officer who may be stationed or on duty on or about such public place for the preservation of order and enforcing the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the Village. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to obey the commands and directions of a police officer as set forth in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 13.23)  
Sec. 46-106. - Obstructing view at intersections. 
The owner or occupant of every lot or parcel of land adjoining a street or alley intersection in the Village, upon which any tree, shrub, bush or plant is growing, shall trim, prune or cut the tree, shrub, bush or plant or cause it to be trimmed, pruned or cut so as not to obstruct the passage of light from any streetlight or traffic signal light and so that it shall not interfere with, nor obstruct the passage or vision of persons using the sidewalks, alleys, streets, highways or driveways on or adjacent thereto. The existence of any tree, shrub, bush or plant on the premises of any owner or occupant adjoining a street, alley or driveway intersection, which shall obstruct the passage of light from any street light or traffic signal light, or which shall interfere with or obstruct the vision at street intersections or the intersection of a street with a public alley or driveway, is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance. No bushes, shrubs or plants, other than trees, that are more than 36 inches above the crown of the adjacent alley, street or highway, shall be planted or maintained in the public right-of-way. No bushes, shrubs or plants, other than trees, that are more than 36 inches above the crown of the adjacent alley, street or highway, shall be planted or maintained on private property within 100 feet from the intersecting centerlines of the public rights-of-way at the intersection of any streets or highways. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of such premises to fail, neglect or refuse to abate any violation of this section by removing, trimming, cutting or pruning such tree, shrub, bush or plant within ten days after being notified, in writing, to do so by the Village. Such ten-day period shall commence with the date that a written notice shall have been deposited in the U.S. mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the owner or occupant of such premises. 
(Code 1959, § 13.24)  
Sec. 46-107. - Abandonment of refrigerators and deep freezes. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or discard, in any place accessible to children, any refrigerator, icebox or ice chest, of a capacity of 1½ cubic feet or more, which has an attached lid or door which may be opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch, or who, being the owner, lessee or manager of such place, knowingly permits such abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox or ice chest to remain in such place in such condition. 
(Code 1959, § 13.27)  
Sec. 46-108. - Bungee jumping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, operate, construct, utilize or make available any apparatus, crane, building or other structure from which a person may jump and/or be suspended by any cords, parachutes, ropes and/or other devices (such activity is commonly referred to as "bungee jumping"). 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in the activity of bungee jumping and/or being suspended by any means from any apparatus, crane, building or other structure; provided, however, that this subsection does not apply to a scaffold, body harness or similar apparatus, while being used in the construction, maintenance or cleaning of a building or structure. 
(Code 1959, §§ 13.34, 13.35)  
Sec. 46-109. - Windshields must be unobstructed; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person licensed to do business under the provisions of this article to sell, equip, apply or manufacture, or cause to be sold, equipped, applied or manufactured, a motor vehicle which is not in compliance with 625 ILCS 5/12-503. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to motor vehicles manufactured prior to January 1, 1982. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Secs. 46-110—46-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FALSE BURGLAR ALARMS 
 
Sec. 46-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Burglar alarm means any security device installed and directly or indirectly connected to the police department for the purpose of alerting others to an unauthorized entry onto the premises or to vehicles, or the commission of an unlawful act, or any audible security device installed for the purpose of alerting others to the unauthorized entry onto the premises or to vehicles, or the commission of an unlawful act. 
False alarm means a burglar alarm system activated by any one or more of the following causes: 
(1)  Mechanical failure; 
(2)  Malfunction of the burglar alarm system; 
(3)  Improper installation or maintenance of the burglar alarm system; 
(4)  Willful or negligent act of a person under the control or direction of a burglar alarm system; 
(5)  Any other cause not related to an actual or attempted unauthorized entry onto the premises or to vehicles, or the commission of an unlawful act or a fire emergency; provided, however, that any burglar alarm activated by natural causes, including, but not limited to, tornadoes and severe windstorms, or by malicious acts of persons not under the direction or control of the alarm system's owner/lessee or any other cause clearly beyond the control of the owner/lessee of the alarm system shall not be considered a false alarm. 
(Code 1959, § 13.55) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-132. - Activation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly activate a burglar alarm system for the purpose of summoning the police, except if such person knows or suspects that there is an actual or attempted unauthorized entry onto the premises or to vehicles, or the commission of an unlawful act. 
(Code 1959, § 13.56)  
Sec. 46-133. - Automatic reset or disconnection. 
It shall be unlawful for any exterior audible alarm not to automatically reset or be disconnected within ten minutes of activation. 
(Code 1959, § 13.57)  
Sec. 46-134. - Response charges; reconsideration. 
(a)  If the Village police department responds to more than three residential false burglar alarms per residential system at the same premises within any 12-month period, the owner/lessee of such residential burglar alarm system shall pay the Village $50.00 for four—eight alarms, and $100.00 for each subsequent alarm. Commercial premises shall be charged a flat charge of $25.00 per false burglar alarm after the third false burglar alarm. 
(b)  If a residential property is cited for a violation of section 46-133, each such violation shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00, nor more than $100.00 for each such violation. 
(c)  Within seven days after notice of a false burglar alarm, the burglar alarm system owner/lessee may file a written request with the chief of police of the Village to reconsider whether such burglar alarm was false. Such request shall state the owner/lessee opinion with respect to the cause of the burglar alarm and shall indicate the facts upon which the owner/lessee bases his opinion. 
(d)  Within five days after the receipt of a request for reconsideration from an owner/lessee, the chief of police or his agent shall determine whether or not the burglar alarm was false and shall notify the owner/lessee of his decision, in writing, by personal delivery or mail. 
(e)  If the owner/lessee fails to contest the validity of a finding by the chief of police of the Village, as provided in subsection (c) of this section, that a burglar alarm was a false alarm, it shall be conclusively presumed that the alarm was a false burglar alarm. 
(Code 1959, § 13.59)  
Sec. 46-135. - Over ten responses within a six-month period. 
If the police department responds to more than ten false burglar alarms per system at the same premises in a six-month period of time, the chief of police or his agent may initiate burglar alarm system revocation proceedings. 
(Code 1959, § 13.60)  
Sec. 46-136. - Grace period. 
Whenever a new burglar alarm system is installed, the owner/lessee shall be given 30 days from the date of the installation of such burglar alarm system within which no alarm from the premises shall be deemed to be a false burglar alarm, except where such system operates in violation of sections 46-132 and 46-133. 
(Code 1959, § 13.61)  
Sec. 46-137. - Final approval. 
Final approval of a burglar alarm system shall be obtained from the Village or its agents before such system is connected to the police department. 
(Code 1959, § 13.62)  
Sec. 46-138. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16, and each day that such a violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 13.58)  
Secs. 46-139—46-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 
 
Sec. 46-171. - Assault and battery. 
(a)  A person commits an assault, which is hereby prohibited, when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. 
(b)  A person commits battery, which is hereby prohibited, if he intentionally or knowingly, without legal justification, and by any means: 
(1)  Causes bodily harm to an individual; or 
(2)  Makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual. 
(Code 1959, § 13.1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/12-1, 5/12-3.  
Secs. 46-172—46-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-201. - Damage to public property. 
No person shall damage, remove, destroy, break, cut, injure, mutilate, mark or deface in any way any public building, sewer, water pipe, hydrant, lamppost, curbstone, fence, wall, bridge, pavement or any motor vehicle of the Village, or any other public property, including, but not limited to, the posting of any and all notices, papers and posters of any and all types on trees, utility posts or any posts of any type on public rights-of-way or public property; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the use of posters, notices, papers which may be used for religious decorations, if permission for such usage is first had and obtained from the board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 13.5) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.  
Sec. 46-202. - Defacing notices, handbills and posters. 
No person shall willfully and maliciously tear down, mutilate or deface or render illegible any notice, handbill or poster lawfully posted upon any street, avenue, alley or other place in the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 13.6)  
Sec. 46-203. - Damage to property. 
Within the corporate limits of the Village, no person shall knowingly or recklessly damage any property of another person without such person's consent. 
(Code 1959, § 13.51)  
Sec. 46-204. - Theft of property. 
(a)  "Petit theft" is hereby defined as a theft when the property taken is of a value of less than $150.00. 
(b)  Within the corporate limits of the Village, it shall be unlawful for any person to commit petit theft. 
(Code 1959, § 13.51; Ord. No. 5141, § 2, 9-16-2008)  
Sec. 46-205. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person issued a citation for such violation may settle and compromise the violation claim in respect of such ordinance by paying the Village the amount of $100.00 within a period to be specified in the citation. If payment has not been received during this specified period of time, payment of $200.00 may be accepted as settlement. 
(b)  Every person found guilty of an offense set forth in this division shall be subject to one or all of the following penalties: 
(1)  Punishment as provided in section 1-16; 
(2)  Make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed the actual loss or damage to property and pecuniary loss. 
(Ord. No. 5141, § 3, 9-16-2008)  
Secs. 46-206—46-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TRESPASS 
 
Sec. 46-221. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Legal guardian includes a person appointed as guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of the State, but does not include a person appointed as guardian or given custody of a minor under the Illinois Juvenile Court Act, 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq. 
Minor means a person who has attained 11 years of age, but who has not yet reached 18 years of age. 
Person includes any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Property includes any real estate, including improvements thereon, and tangible personalty. 
(Code 1959, § 13.50) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-222. - Real property. 
(a)  A person commits a violation of this division if such person: 
(1)  Knowingly and without lawful authority enters or remains within or on a building; 
(2)  Enters upon the land of another after receiving, prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden; 
(3)  Remains upon the land of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart; or 
(4)  Enters upon one of the following areas while in or on a motor vehicle, including an off-road vehicle, motorcycle, moped or any other powered two-wheel vehicle, after receiving, prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that the entry is forbidden, or remains upon or in the area after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart: 
a.  Any field that is used for growing crops or which is capable of being used for growing crops; 
b.  An enclosed area containing livestock; 
c.  An orchard; or 
d.  A barn or other agricultural building containing livestock. 
(b)  For purposes of subsection (a)(1) of this section, this section shall not apply to being in a building which is open to the public while the building is open to the public during its normal hours of operation; nor shall this section apply to a person who enters a public building under the reasonable belief that the building is still open to the public. 
(c)  A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning of subsection (a) of this section if he has been notified personally, either orally or in writing, including a valid court order as defined by section 112A-3(7) of the Code of Criminal Procedure of 1963 (725 ILCS 5/112A-3), granting remedy (2) of section 112A-14(b) of the Code of Criminal Procedure of 1963 (625 ILCS 5/112A-14), or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land, or the forbidden part thereof. 
(d)  This section does not apply to any person, whether a migrant worker or otherwise, living on the land with permission of the owner or his agent having apparent authority to hire workers on such land and assigns them living quarters or a place of accommodations for living thereon, nor to any person living on such land at the request of, or by occupancy, leasing or other agreement or arrangement with, the owner or his agent, nor to any person invited by such migrant worker or other person so living on such land to visit him at the place he is so living upon the land. 
(e)  A person shall be exempt from prosecution under this section if he beautifies unoccupied and abandoned residential and industrial properties located within any municipality. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "unoccupied and abandoned residential and industrial property" means any real estate for which the taxes have not been paid for a period of at least two years, and which has been left unoccupied and abandoned for a period of at least one year; and the term "beautifies" means to landscape, clean up litter, repair dilapidated conditions or board up windows and doors. 
(f)  This section does not prohibit a person from entering a building or upon the land of another for emergency purposes. For purposes of this subsection, the term "emergency" means a condition or circumstance in which an individual is, or is reasonably believed by the person to be, in imminent danger of serious bodily harm or in which property is, or is reasonably believed to be, in imminent danger of damage or destruction. 
(Code 1959, § 13.31)  
Sec. 46-223. - Liability of parent or legal guardian of minor offender. 
The parent or legal guardian of a minor defendant who resides with such parent or legal guardian shall be liable for any fine or condition of restitution or reparation imposed by a court upon a minor for a violation of this division, provided that such minor has not paid the fine or made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court, and, further provided, that such parent or legal guardian has been served with a summons or notice to appear in the original cause and all proceedings thereafter as provided by law. 
(Code 1959, § 13.53)  
Sec. 46-224. - Violations; penalties. 
Every person found guilty of an offense shall be subject to one or all of the following penalties: 
(1)  Punishment as provided in section 1-16; 
(2)  Undergo medical or psychiatric treatment, or treatment for drug addiction or alcoholism; 
(3)  Make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed the actual loss or damage to property and pecuniary loss; and 
(4)  If a minor: 
a.  Reside with his parent or in a foster home; 
b.  Attend school; 
c.  Attend a nonresidential program for youth; or 
d.  Contribute to his own support at home or in a foster home. 
(Code 1959, § 13.52)  
Secs. 46-225—46-260. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - MINORS 
 
Sec. 46-261. - Curfew. 
(a)  By the adoption of a curfew ordinance, the Village is attempting to provide for the protection of minors from each other and from other persons, for the reduction of juvenile criminal activity, and for the protection of the public. 
(b)  The Village Board has determined that because minors under the age of 17 years possess a particular vulnerability to crime and harmful influence under certain circumstances or when not supervised or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian at night, and because minors under the age of 17 years often lack the ability to make critical decisions in an informed and mature manner when exposed to nighttime influences, a critical need exists for a minor curfew ordinance in the Village. 
(c)  A curfew for those under the age of 17 years will be in the interest of the public health, safety, and general welfare and will assist in the protection of minors as described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1959, § 13.64; Ord. No. 4630, § 2(A), 4-20-2004)  
Sec. 46-262. - Curfew hours. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicated a different meaning: 
Curfew hours means: 
(1)  11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and 
(2)  11:59 p.m. on any Friday or Saturday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term "emergency" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
"Guardian means: 
(1)  A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  An authorized person of a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
Minor means any person under 17 years of age. 
Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation managing, conducting or operating any establishment. The term "operator" includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural parent, adoptive parent or stepparent of a minor; or 
(ii)  At least 18 years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of the minor in question. 
Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities and shops. 
Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay; or 
(2)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer, or the owner, operator or other person in control of the premises. 
(b)  Offenses The following are committed offenses of curfew violation: 
(1)  A minor commits the offense of curfew violation in the event he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the Village during curfew hours. 
(2)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the Village during curfew hours. 
(3)  The owner, operator or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(c)  Defenses. 
(1)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (b)(1) and (2) of this section that the minor was: 
a.  Accompanied by the minor's parent, or a person who is named as guardian of the minor under court order or who is an authorized person of a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court; 
b.  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
c.  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
d.  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
e.  Involved in an emergency; 
f.  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if a neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
g.  Attending a school, religious or other recreational activity supervised by adults or sponsored by the Village, a civic organization or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, a school, religious or other recreational activity supervised by adults or sponsored by the Village, a civic organization or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
h.  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right to peaceably assemble; or 
i.  Married or had been married or is an emancipated minor under the Emancipation of Mature Minors Act, 750 ILCS 30/1 et seq. 
(2)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (b)(3) of this section that the owner, operator or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(Code 1959, § 13.64; Ord. No. 4630, § 2(B)1—3, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 4666, § 2(A),(B), 6-15-2004)  
Sec. 46-263. - Enforcement. 
Before taking any enforcement action under this article, a police officer shall ask the alleged offender's age and reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this article unless, after a reasonable preliminary investigation, appropriate under the circumstances, including, but not limited to, questioning of the alleged offender, the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and no defense under subsection 46-262(c) is available. 
(Code 1959, § 13.64; Ord. No. 4630, § 2(B)4, 4-20-2004)  
Sec. 46-264. - Penalties. 
A person who violates a provision of this article is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine in an amount not less than $75.00 nor more than $500.00. In addition, the court, upon its exercise of discretion, may sentence any person found in violation of this article to community service work, in lieu of or in addition to the above referenced fine. 
(Code 1959, § 13.64; Ord. No. 4630, § 2(B)5, 4-20-2004)  
Sec. 46-265. - License—Tobacco. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give away, deliver or keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or delivering tobacco products within the Village without having first obtained a tobacco dealer's license pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Application. Application for a license under this article shall be made in writing to the Village manager and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of article V of this chapter. 
(c)  Fee. The license fee for a tobacco dealer's license shall be as set forth in section 30-3. 
(d)  Sales to persons under 21 years of age. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products to any person under the age of 21 years. 
(2)  Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for in this subsection (d) shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products and upon every vending machine which offers tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state the following: 
The sale of tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products to persons under 21 years of age is prohibited by law. 
The text of such signs shall be in red letters, on a white background, and such letters shall be at least one inch high. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 6279, § 2, 9-3-2019)  
Sec. 46-266. - Minors. 
(a)  Sales by minors. It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to engage, employ or permit any person under 21 years of age to sell tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products in any licensed premises. 
(b)  Purchase by minors. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to purchase tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products, misrepresent their identity or age, or use any false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products. 
(c)  Possession by minors. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess any tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products, provided that the possession by a person under the age of 18 years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. 
(d)  Proximity to certain institutions. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products within 1,000 feet of any pre-existing public or private preschool or elementary or secondary school or junior college or university, or day care center or day care home, or group day care home or part day child care facility, or playground, or public library, or other building used for educational or recreational programs for persons under the age of 21 years. 
(e)  Certain free distribution. It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person engaged in the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products, or any employee or agent of any such licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products free of charge to any person on any right-of-way, park, playground or other property owned by the Village, any school district, park district or public library. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 6279, § 3, 9-3-2019)  
Sec. 46-267. - Vending machines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give away, deliver or keep with the intention of selling, giving away or delivering tobacco, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products by use of a vending machine, unless such vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the age of 21 years. 
(b)  Any premises where access by persons under the age of 21 years is prohibited, or premises where the public is generally not permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of the business located at such premises, shall be exempt from the requirements of subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 6279, § 4, 9-3-2019)  
Sec. 46-268. - Responsibility for agents and employees. 
Every act or omission of any nature, constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this article by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 46-269. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The president shall be charged with the administration of this article. The president may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provision of this article if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this article. In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, the president may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The imposed fine shall not exceed that provided in section 1-16 for each violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. However, no such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined, except after a public hearing by the president, with a seven-day written notice to the licensee affording the opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The seven-day notice provisions shall begin the day following delivery of such notice by certified mail or personal service. 
(b)  The president shall, within seven days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine, the period of suspension or that the license has been revoked and serve a copy of such order upon the licensee within such seven-day period. 
(c)  Any licensee determined by the president to have violated any of the provisions of this article shall pay to the Village the costs of the hearing before the president on such violation. The president shall determine the costs incurred by the Village for such hearing, including, but not limited to, court reporter's fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the Village or such lesser sum as the president may allow. 
(d)  The licensee shall pay such costs to the Village within 30 days of notification of the costs by the president. Failure to pay such costs within 30 days of notification is a violation of this article and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of a fine. 
(e)  Any minor under the age of 18 years, violating this article, in possession of tobacco products as defined by this article, shall be fined $50.00 for the first offense, and an additional $50.00 for each additional offense within a one-year period of time. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 46-270. - Granting license after revocation. 
When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to the licensee for a period of six months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling tobacco products as defined in section 22-151. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 46-271. - Secondhand, pawn shops: dealing with minors under 18 years of age; stolen goods. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person having a license from the Village under the provisions of this article to purchase or receive from minors who are under 18 years of age, without the written consent of their parents or guardians, any article of property whatsoever. 
(b)  Every licensee who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or other property of value which may have been lost or stolen shall report to the police department, and shall, upon demand, produce such goods, articles or other property to any Village official for examination. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 46-272. - Transaction restrictions. 
(a)  No pawnbroker shall take or receive in pawn or pledge for money loaned, any property from any minor under 18 years of age, or the ownership of which is in or claimed by any minor under 18 years of age, or which may be in the possession or under the control of any minor under 18 years of age, or otherwise have any business dealings with any minor under 18 years of age. 
(b)  No pawnbroker shall receive, as purchased, pawned or pledged, any gun, blackjack, knife or other weapon of any kind. No pawnbroker shall display any such weapon for sale. 
(c)  No pawnbroker shall conduct the business of a secondhand dealer without having obtained a license therefore in addition to the pawnbroker's license. 
(Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Secs. 46-273—46-290. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PICKETING 
 
Sec. 46-291. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Employee includes any employees, except employees of persons who are not employers under the definition of that term in this section, but shall not include any individual having authority, in the interests of an employer, to hire, transfer, suspend, lay off, recall, promote, discharge, assign, reward or discipline other employees or responsibly direct them, or to adjust their grievances, or effectively to recommend such action, if in connection with the exercise of such authority is not of a merely routine or clerical nature, but requires the use of independent judgment. 
Employer includes any person acting as an agent of an employer, directly or indirectly, but does not include any person subject to the Federal Railway Labor Act, as amended from time to time, nor within the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board, as announced from time to time by the board. 
Labor organization means any organization of any kind or any agency or employee representation committee or plan in which employees participate and which exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, of dealing with employers concerning grievances, labor disputes, wages, rates of pay, hours of employment or conditions of work. 
Person includes one or more individuals, labor organizations, partnerships, associations, corporations, legal representatives, trustees in bankruptcy or receivers. 
Picket and picketing mean the patrolling or stationing of one or more persons about the premises being picketed, upon the sidewalks and streets thereabouts, to convey, in oral or written form, by means of banners, signs, placards, advertisement or handbills, the message of the persons picketing. 
(Code 1959, § 6.65) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-292. - Secondary boycotts or activities. 
It shall be unlawful for any labor organization, or any officer, member or agent thereof, by picketing or otherwise, to directly induce, encourage, force or require any person to reduce or cut off the transportation or delivery of any goods, articles, materials or commodities to an employer with which the labor organization has a primary dispute, or to refuse to perform any services within the scope of his employment with an employer other than one with which the labor organization has a primary dispute. 
(Code 1959, § 6.66)  
Sec. 46-293. - Interference with transportation or delivery of goods, performance of services and free access to premises of employer by threats and intimidation. 
It shall be unlawful for any labor organization, or any officer, member or agent thereof, by force, threat or intimidation, whether oral, written or by gesture, to interfere with the transportation or delivery of any goods, articles, materials or commodities to, or the performance of any services for, an employer, or to restrict or curtail free access to an employer's premises. 
(Code 1959, § 6.67)  
Sec. 46-294. - Harassment, coercion or intimidation of employers and employees, etc., when no labor dispute exists between the employer and employees. 
It shall be unlawful for any labor organization, or any officer, member or agent thereof, by harassment, coercion or intimidation, including threats of violence, or loss of business or employment, or following or trailing by automobile or truck, of any employer or his employees, or any other person, to interfere in any way with the normal business operation of any employer or the employment or work of his employees when no labor dispute exists between such employer and his employees. 
(Code 1959, § 6.68)  
Sec. 46-295. - Reducing or cutting off deliveries to self-employed persons for purpose of requiring membership in labor organization by picketing. 
It shall be unlawful for any labor organization, or any officer, members or agency thereof, to cause deliveries to or from the premises of any self-employed person to be reduced or cut off by means of picketing for the purpose of requiring such self-employed person to join or pay any dues, fees or other sums of money to such labor organization or to any officer, member or agent thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 6.69)  
Sec. 46-296. - Threats, gestures or intimidations causing deliveries to self-employed persons to be reduced or cut off for purpose of requiring membership in labor organization. 
It shall be unlawful for any labor organization, or any officer, member or agent thereof, by oral or written statement, gesture, threat, intimidation or force, to cause deliveries to or from any premises of a self-employed person to be reduced or cut off, or free access to or from such premises to be interfered with, for the purpose of requiring such self-employed person to join or pay any dues, fees or other sums of money to such labor organization or to any officer, member or agent thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 6.70)  
Sec. 46-297. - Harassment, coercion or intimidation of self-employed persons for purpose of requiring membership in labor organization. 
It shall be unlawful for any labor organization, or any officer, member or agent thereof, by harassment, coercion or intimidation, including threats of violence or loss of business or employment, or following or trailing by automobile or truck, of any self-employed person or any other person, to interfere in any way with the normal business operation of any self-employed person for the purpose of requiring such self-employed person to join or pay any dues, fees or other sums of money to such labor organization or to any officer, member or agent thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 6.71)  
Sec. 46-298. - Representation of majority of employees required for labor dispute between employer and employees. 
No labor dispute between an employer and his employees shall be deemed to exist for the purposes of this article where the labor organization participating or sponsoring the activity prohibited by this article does not in fact represent a majority of the employees of such employer and an objective of such activity is to obtain recognition or designation as the exclusive collective bargaining representative of such employees. 
(Code 1959, § 6.72)  
Sec. 46-299. - Circumstances under which labor organization does not represent a majority of employees. 
It shall be presumed, for the purposes of this article, that a labor organization does not represent a majority of the employees of an employer under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where such labor organization refuses to join with the employer in requesting the department of labor of the State to administer a secret ballot election for such employees after the employer has, in writing, so requested of the labor organization; 
(2)  During the period of time pending such election where the labor organization and employer have jointly requested the department of labor of the State to administer a secret ballot election; and 
(3)  For a period of 12 months after such an election is conducted, if the labor organization fails to procure a majority of the votes of the employees voting in such election. 
(Code 1959, § 6.73)  
Sec. 46-300. - Circumstances under which labor organization does represent a majority of employees. 
It shall be presumed, for the purposes of this article, that a labor organization does represent a majority of the employees of an employer under the following circumstances: 
(1)  For a period of 12 months after a secret ballot election has been administered by the department of labor of the State in which the labor organization has procured a majority of the votes of the employees voting in the election; or 
(2)  Where an employer refuses to join with such labor organization in requesting the department of labor of the State to administer a secret ballot election for such employees after the labor organization has, in writing, so requested of the employer. 
(Code 1959, § 6.74)  
Sec. 46-301. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00, nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and each day that such violation continues shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1959, § 6.77)  
Secs. 46-302—46-330. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - WEAPONS 
 
Sec. 46-331. - Discharge. 
No person shall fire or discharge any cannon, gun, fowling piece, pistol or firearm of any kind or description, explode or set off any cracker or anything containing powder or other explosive substance in the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 13.7)  
Secs. 46-332—46-360. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - TELEPHONE DEVICES ACTIVATING POLICE AND FIRE EMERGENCY NUMBERS 
 
Sec. 46-361. - Installation and use. 
No person shall install or use, or cause to be installed or used, any telephone device or attachment which automatically selects a public telephone line of the Village fire or police department and which reproduces any prerecorded message to report any burglary, robbery, fire or other emergency. 
(Code 1959, § 13.45)  
Sec. 46-362. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 13.46)  
Secs. 46-363—46-390. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - LAKE GLENVIEW REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes:
