Editor's note— Ord. No. 5675, § 2, adopted May 7, 2013, amended the title of ch. 46, art. X, to read as set out herein. Formerly ch. 46, art. X, pertained to Fishing Regulations for Lake Glenview. 
 
Sec. 46-391. - Fishing regulations on Lake Glenview. 
(a)  A State fishing license is required. 
(b)  Catch and release fishing is strictly enforced. Common Carp (Cyprinus carpio) is the exception to catch and release, and its removal from the lake is encouraged. 
(c)  Fishing is permitted in designated areas only, and fishing and is only permitted from the shore. 
(d)  Emptying of bait buckets in or near the lake is prohibited. 
(e)  Spear, gig, and bow and arrow fishing are prohibited. 
(f)  One-pole limit per person. 
(g)  Personal floatation devices or waders are prohibited. 
(h)  Fishing is permitted from April 15 to November 15 from sunrise to sunset. 
(Ord. No. 4686, § 2, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 5382, § 2, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 5675, § 3, 5-7-2013) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5675, § 3, adopted May 7, 2013, amended the title of § 46-391 to read as set out herein. Formerly § 46-391 pertained to generally.  
Sec. 46-392. - Signs showing fishing regulations. 
The director of public works shall post or erect signs indicating the above regulations relating to Lake Glenview. 
(Ord. No. 4686, § 3, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 5675, § 4, 5-7-2013)  
Sec. 46-393. - Swimming and boating and ice skating. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, float or enter the water, or use a boat or other watercraft, or ice skate on Lake Glenview. 
(Ord. No. 5675, § 5, 5-7-2013)  
Secs. 46-394—46-410. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - FILM PRODUCTION 
 
Sec. 46-411. - Statement of policy and purpose. 
It is the policy of the Village to allow interior or exterior locations on public or private property to be used in film production, as hereinafter defined, only if the personal and property rights of affected residents and businesses can be adequately protected, unreasonable and unnecessary disruptions to the community can be avoided, the rights of the public to the safe and normal use of the public streets, rights-of-way and property can be protected, the rights of the public to the orderly functioning of government and the provision of public services can be protected and hazards to the public health, safety, and welfare can be prevented. It is the purpose of this section to establish standards for evaluating requests for the use of public or private property as a location for film production be evaluated on a case-by-case basis, recognizing that the nature of the film, the type of production, the location desired to be used, the length of time of production activities, and the impact of such activities on Village operations and services makes each request unique. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(a), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-412. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings and be constructed in accordance with the definitions set forth below: 
Film production: The process of recording live action on film, magnetic tape, or any other medium, for later sale or distribution as a movie, commercial, training film, or educational program, and any activities relating thereto including set-up and site restoration. 
Film production equipment: Any object used in film production, including but not limited to: lighting equipment, sound equipment, cameras, dressing rooms, trailers, props, furnishings, and vehicles. 
Film production permit: A permit issued in accordance with the procedures and provisions of this section. 
Village manager: The manager of the Village of Glenview, Illinois, or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(b), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-413. - Permit required. 
No person, group of persons, or entities shall use any interior or exterior public or private location or property in the Village of Glenview for film production, or place any film production equipment on any public street or right-of-way, on any public property, or on the exterior of any private property without first having obtained a film production permit from the Village in accordance with the procedures established in the section. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(c), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-414. - Application and permit fees. 
All applications for film production permits shall be accompanied by a fee as outlined by chapter 30-1 and determined by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(d), 9-15-1998; Ord. No. 5113, § 9, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 46-415. - Submission for application for a permit. 
All applications for a film production permit shall be submitted on a standard form prescribed by the Village and to be made available in the Village manager's office. The completed application shall be filed with the Village manager no less than 30 days prior to the proposed commencement of film production. The application shall be accompanied by all documentation and statements required under sections 46-416 through 46-424. In addition, the application shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The name, permanent address, local address, and local telephone number of the applicant. If the applicant is an entity, the nature of the entity shall be described and proof of its current, lawful existence provided. 
(2)  The name, permanent address, local business address, permanent phone number, and local phone number of the individual or individuals responsible for the day-to-day operations of the film production. 
(3)  A statement that the person signing the application is authorized to do so. 
(4)  A description of the type of film production and type of film production equipment to be used. 
(5)  The proposed dates for the film production. 
(6)  The proposed hours for the film production. 
(7)  A letter or statement signed by the owner or owners and occupants of each property which the applicant proposes to use as a location for film production in the format provided in section 46-417. 
(8)  The identification of the location of all public streets, public ways, and public property which the applicant proposes to use for the film production or for the location and/or storage of film production equipment. 
(9)  A description of all public streets and public rights-of-way for which the applicant requests the imposition of restrictions on or the alteration of normal parking or vehicular pedestrian traffic patterns, and the nature of such restriction or alteration. 
(10)  A description of the personnel and equipment the applicant proposes to have on the film production location to provide emergency medical treatment for persons involved in the film production. 
(11)  A description of the methods and procedures to be used for food service and health and sanitation on the film production location. 
(12)  A description of the methods and procedures for the removal of garbage and other waste from the film production location. 
(13)  Such other and further information as the Village manager may deem necessary in order to evaluate and process the application. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(e), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-416. - Notification of neighbors. 
Once the application for permit has been approved by the Village manager, the applicant must notify all owners of record and occupants of all property situated within two blocks in every direction of each separate film production location of the proposed film production within three days of approval. The notice must be delivered personally or sent by certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice shall contain a written description of the proposed film production, including the proposed production schedule and the type of film production activities and film production equipment the applicant proposes to use. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(f), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-417. - Property owner letter of approval. 
The letter or statement required by subsection 46-415(7) above shall state the approval and consent of the owner or owners and, where applicable, the lessee or lessees of the property to its use as a location for film production. The signatures on the letter shall be notarized. The letter of approval shall contain the following statement: "I hereby certify that I am the owner of record (or, where applicable, the occupant) of the property located at (street address) which will be used for film production. I hereby waive any claim against the Village of Glenview arising out of or in connection with the issuance of the film production permit and will indemnify and hold harmless the Village of Glenview for and from any loss, damage, expense, claims, and costs of every nature and kind arising out of or in connection with the film production pursuant to said permit." 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(g), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-418. - Certificate of insurance. 
The film production permit application shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance, issued by a company acceptable to the Village and authorized to do business in the State of Illinois. The certificate of insurance shall be in an amount of not less than $5,000,000.00 general liability, including bodily injury, property damages, and automobile liability. The certificate of insurance shall name the Village as an additional insured, using the following language: "The Village of Glenview, its corporate authorities, officers, officials, boards, commissions, employees, attorneys, agents, and representatives are made additional insured with respect to any and all claims which arise out of, or in any way related to, the operations of (insert name of film maker) while present in the Village of Glenview." The certificate of insurance shall be accompanied by a letter from the insurer stating that there are no outstanding claims against the policy. The Village also requires a copy of the policy in order to satisfy that no exclusions exist which would defeat the anticipated coverage. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(h), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-419. - Worker's compensation and employer's liability insurance. 
The application for film production permit shall be accompanied by proof acceptable to the Village manager that the applicant has provided worker's compensation insurance, employer's liability insurance, and all other insurance required by law to be provided for the employees of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(i), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-420. - Indemnification and hold harmless agreement. 
The application for a film production permit shall be accompanied by an indemnification agreement in a form acceptable to the Village wherein the applicant agrees to defend and hold the Village of Glenview, its officers, employees and agents, harmless from any loss, damage, expense, claim and cost of every nature and kind whatsoever, including attorney's fees, arising out of or in connection with applicant's use of the public property, public right-of-way, public equipment, or public personnel specified in the film production permit or arising out of or in connection with the film production authorized under the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(j), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-421. - Restoration and repair of property. 
The application for film production permit shall contain a statement of the applicant agreeing to pay in full, promptly upon receipt of an invoice, the cost of repair for any and all damage to public property, resulting from or in connection with, the film production, and to restore the property to its condition prior to the film production. Any permit issued pursuant to this section shall be conditioned upon such agreement. The applicant shall deposit funds with the Village in the amount of $1,000.00 in order to secure such restoration. At the discretion of the Village manager, the applicant may be required to deposit additional funds based upon the circumstances of the film production and its impact upon public property, in order to secure such restoration. 
Such funds shall be placed in escrow by the Village. The Village may draw against said escrow to pay any portion of an invoice for the repair or restoration of public property that is not paid within 14 days of its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(k), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-422. - Use of Village personnel. 
The applicant shall agree to pay in full, before film production, the costs of any police, fire, public works, or other Village personnel resulting from the film production. Such costs shall include costs of services specifically requested by the applicant and costs of services which, in the judgment of the Village manager, is directly related to the film production. The costs billed for such direct Village labor shall be equal to one and half times the hourly rate of pay for each individual Village employee so assigned, including any applicable overtime, plus an administrative charge equal to ten percent of such costs. The Village reserves the right to assign additional fire and/or police personnel to the film production or film production location, where in the opinion of the chief of police or fire chief, such protection is warranted by the nature of the film production. Any expenses not incurred will be reimbursed to the applicant after the film production by the Village. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(l), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-423. - Use of Village equipment. 
The use of Village equipment as film production equipment is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(m), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-424. - Use of Village property. 
The applicant shall agree to pay in full, before film production, the costs for the use of all Village property and public ways. The costs billed for such use of Village property shall be at the rates hereinafter set forth, based on the extent of interference with or disruption of the normal use and operation of Village property or public way. The rates for such costs shall be as follows: 
(1)  For any use of any public building, the cost shall be $1,000.00 per day. Any building occupied by the Glenview Police or Fire Departments cannot be used for film production. 
(2)  For the partial closure or obstruction of any public street or right-of-way within any block, the cost shall be $250.00 per day. Total closure of any public street or right-of-way is prohibited. 
Any expenses not incurred will be reimbursed to the applicant after the film production by the Village. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(n), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-425. - Processing of application. 
The Village manager shall distribute copies of the completed application for film production permit to the chief of police, fire chief, and public works director. The chief of police, fire chief, and public works director shall evaluate the application to determine its impact on the functions of their respective departments and the extent of need to provide additional personnel and/or services in the event the permit is issued. In addition, the chief of police, fire chief, and public works director shall evaluate the application on the basis of the impact of use on the public streets, the impact on traffic safety, and potential fire hazards. The reports of the chief of police, fire chief, and public works director shall be forwarded to the Village manager, who shall determine as to whether the permit should be granted. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(o), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-426. - Authority of Village manager. 
The Village manager shall review the report and recommendation of the chief of police, fire chief, and public works director and, based on all of the circumstances surrounding the film production permit application and the assessed impact of the film production, shall: 
(1)  If the film production is for five days or less, the Village manager shall determine whether the film production permit shall be issued or be denied. 
(2)  If the film production is for more than five days, the applicant must appear before the Village Board to seek approval. The Village manager shall recommend to the Village Board of Trustees whether to issue or deny the film production permit for an extended period. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(p), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-427. - Reservation of rights. 
The Village hereby reserves the following rights: 
(1)  To prohibit the issuance of the film production permit in the event that the applicant does not meet the conditions of the permit; 
(2)  To order the cessation of the film production in the event the Village manager determines either that any of the terms and conditions upon which the film production permit was issued have been violated or that the operation of the film production has otherwise caused a detriment to the public health, safety, and welfare; 
(3)  To inspect all structures, devices and/or film production equipment to be used in connection with the film production at any time the film production is in process; 
(4)  To impose such regulations, conditions or restrictions other than or in addition to those provided in this section as the Village, acting through the Village manager, may deem necessary to protect the public health, safety, or welfare, which regulations, conditions, or restrictions shall be stated in the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(q), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-428. - Number of permits limited. 
No more than one film production shall be authorized in the Village on any given day. Specific locations will be granted one film production permit every 12 months. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(r), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-429. - Time limitation for permit. 
Any film production permit issued under this section shall be valid only for the time period specified within the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(s), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-430. - Hours of production. 
Film production, including time for set-up and restoration, shall be limited to the hours of between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(t), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-431. - Specific location for permit. 
Film production must have a specific location. Random filming from Village streets is prohibited. The use of film production equipment is not to be mobile on Village streets. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(u), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-432. - Compliance with applicable ordinances, regulations, conditions, and restrictions. 
All film production permits issued pursuant to this section shall be conditioned upon the applicant's compliance with all applicable ordinances of the Village of Glenview and with any additional regulations, conditions, or restrictions set forth in the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(v), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-433. - Compliance with police orders. 
The Village hereby reserves the right of the chief of police to order any holder of a permit under this section to immediately vacate the public ways and/or public property if, in his determination, such action is necessary to protect the public health, safety, or welfare. All film production permits issued pursuant to this section shall be conditioned upon the applicant's immediate compliance with any such order. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(w), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-434. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  General penalty. Any person who violates a provision of this article, who makes a false statement in obtaining a permit under this article, or who violates a condition of any permit issued under this article, shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00. 
(b)  Revocation of permit. Any permit issued pursuant to this section may be revoked by the Village manager upon any violation of the terms or conditions upon which it was issued, or upon the violation of this section or any other applicable Village ordinance or State law. Such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed for any such violation. 
(c)  Separate offenses. Each act of violation and each day on which a violation of this section or a permit issued pursuant to this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Liability of permit holder. Every permit holder shall be subject to penalties or violations of this section or a permit issued pursuant to this section by an officer, director, manager, employee, agent or representative of the permit holder as if such violation had been committed by the permit holder personally. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 2(x), 9-15-1998)  
Sec. 46-435. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to the Village of Glenview. 
(Ord. No. 3990, § 3, 9-15-1998)  
Chapter 50 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 50-1—50-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS 
 
Sec. 50-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Handbill distributor means any person who travels either by foot or by some means of conveyance, to or from any residence, and hangs, affixes or otherwise distributes any book, handbill, flyer, circular, poster or other form of writing that contains advertisements for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, on any premises or residence, either for or on behalf of himself or any other person; or any person who travels either by foot or by some means of conveyance, to or from any residence, or upon any highway, street, byway or sidewalk, distributing, delivering and/or handing out any handbill, flyer, circular, poster or other form of advertisement for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, either for or on behalf of himself or any other person. 
Peddler means any person who takes orders for, offers to sell, sells, or seeks to obtain orders or sales from persons within the Village, including, but not limited to, any person within any residence or apartment, or from any person upon any street, highway, byway, alley or sidewalk within the Village, for any goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever. 
Residence means every separate living unit occupied for dwelling purposes by one or more persons, and contained within any type of building or structure. 
(Code 1959, § 6.43) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 50-32. - License—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any individual to engage in business as a peddler within the Village without first having obtained a license for such purpose as provided in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 6.44)  
Sec. 50-33. - Same—Application; fee. 
(a)  Any individual who desires to peddle or distribute handbills within the Village shall make an application, in writing, in duplicate, to the Village manager, on a form to be furnished by the Village manager, in which the following information shall be given, under oath: 
(1)  Applicant's name and address, together with his places of residence during the preceding 12 months; 
(2)  Name and address of the employer of the applicant, if any, together with written evidence of the employment relationship; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the property to be sold in the Village; 
(4)  Length of time for which the privilege to do business as a peddler is desired, the hours of the day that such function will be performed and the approximate area within the Village where the peddling will take place; 
(5)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the vehicle, together with the vehicle's current license number issued by the secretary of State, or such other identification as will serve to identify the vehicle and its owner; 
(6)  If a vehicle is used, a certificate of insurance of a responsible company, in sufficient amounts to protect the public; 
(7)  Two photographs of the applicant, taken within 30 days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the peddler in a clear and distinguishing manner, together with a personal description of such individual; 
(8)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor under the laws of the State or any other State or federal law of the United States; 
(9)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or any ordinance of any state municipality regulating peddling. 
(b)  At the time of filing the application, a fee as outlined in chapter 30-1 shall be paid to the village manager to help defray the cost of investigation. 
(Code 1959, § 6.45; Ord. No. 5113, § 10, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 50-34. - Same—investigation; issuance; record; display; transferability. 
(a)  The Village manager shall cause an investigation to be made by the police department, director of development and other officers and employees of the Village as to the applicant's character, record and compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, and such other matters as the Village manager may deem necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. The applicant shall cooperate with such investigation and furnish such additional information as may be requested by the Village manager or corporate authorities. 
(b)  If the investigation shows proper character, record and compliance, the Village manager shall issue a peddler's license to the applicant upon payment of the license fee as set forth in section 50-35. 
(c)  The Village manager shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(d)  Each peddler shall carry with him, as evidence of his licensing, the license form issued to him, evidencing the license issued under this article, and he shall exhibit the license upon demand by any resident, police officer or other public official of the Village. The license issued under this article shall not be transferable and it shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit any other person to use or display the license issued to him. 
(Code 1959, § 6.46)  
Sec. 50-35. - Same—Fee. 
Every peddler shall pay an annual license fee for each year, or part thereof, in which the peddler conducts business in the Village. Such license fee shall be as provided in chapter 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 6.47; Ord. No. 5113, § 10, 6-17-2008)  
Sec. 50-36. - Display vehicles. 
No vehicle used by a peddler shall be permitted to be utilized by such peddler as a showcase, sample case or display area for the sale, or offering for sale, of foods, goods, wares, merchandise or any article of any kind whatsoever. 
(Code 1959, § 6.48.1)  
Sec. 50-37. - Fraud, cheating or misrepresentation. 
Any peddler who shall, in the Village, be guilty of any fraud, cheating or misrepresentation with respect to peddling, or who shall neglect or refuse to comply with any of the provisions of this article, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 6.49)  
Sec. 50-38. - Regulations. 
(a)  No person shall be a peddler who has been convicted of the commission of a felony or misdemeanor under the laws of the State or any other state, or federal law of the United States, within five years of the date of application, or who has been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or any ordinance of any other state municipality regulating peddling, within five years of the date of application. 
(b)  No peddler shall make, or cause to be made, any loud or obnoxious noise of such volume that is sufficient to disturb the peace of the residents of this Village. 
(c)  No peddler shall have the exclusive right to any location in the public streets, sidewalks, alleys or ways, nor shall any peddler be permitted a stationary location, nor shall he be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations might impede or inconvenience the public or the public safety or contribute to the creation of traffic obstructions, hazards or congestion. For the purposes of this subsection, the judgment of a Village police officer, exercised in good faith in the course of his employment, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced, or the public safety impaired or placed in jeopardy or a traffic obstruction, hazard or congestion is created. 
(Code 1959, § 6.50)  
Sec. 50-39. - Hours regulated. 
In order to preserve and protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens and the residents of the Village, it is hereby declared unlawful and constitutes a nuisance for any person to peddle within the Village before the hour of 9:00 a.m. and after the hour of 9:00 p.m. 
(Code 1959, § 6.50.1)  
Sec. 50-40. - Duty of peddlers, handbill distributors. 
It shall be the duty of each peddler or handbill distributor, upon going onto any premises in the Village, to first examine the premises for the notice provided for in section 50-41. If a "NO SOLICITORS OR PEDDLERS INVITED" notice is posted, then the peddler or handbill distributor, whether registered under the provisions of this article or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(Code 1959, § 6.50.2)  
Sec. 50-41. - Uninvited peddling. 
No person, whether or not registered under this article, shall hang, affix or distribute any book, handbill, flyer, circular, poster or other form of writing that contains an advertisement for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, on any premises or residence, either for or on behalf of himself or any other person, whether or not registered under this article, or peddle goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications or subscriptions on any premises within the Village, if the premises are posted against solicitation or peddling by means of a notice, prominently displayed, on which the following is printed: "NO SOLICITORS OR PEDDLERS INVITED." The premises shall be deemed to be posted against solicitation or peddling if there is exhibited on or near the main entrance to the property, or on or near the main door, a sign, at least three inches by four inches, which bears such notice in letters at least one-third inch in height. For the benefit of the public health, safety and welfare, the Village and public utilities are specifically exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1959, § 6.50.3)  
Sec. 50-42. - Charitable peddling. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charitable peddling includes the selling of any foods, goods, wares and merchandise upon or along the streets, highways or public places of the Village, or at the doors of residences or apartments, where the proceeds from the sale of such foods, goods, wares and merchandise are received by a charitable, religious, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic or eleemosynary organization. 
(b)  Regulation. Charitable peddling shall be regulated by the provisions set forth in article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 6.50.4)  
Sec. 50-43. - Compliance with other Code provisions required; license revocation; appeals. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this article shall relieve any person from the necessity of obtaining a license or paying the required fee for such license, when otherwise required by this Code. 
(b)  Any license issued under this article shall be revoked by the chief of police or his authorized representative if the holder of the license is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false statement in the representation in the course of peddling or distribution activities contrary to the conditions of the licensing requirements, or conducts peddling or distribution activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or so as to constitute a danger to the public health, safety or welfare, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a license under the terms of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police or his authorized representative to the holder of the license, in person or by certified U.S. mail, addressed to the license holder's residence address set forth in the application, stating the action taken and the reasons supporting such action. Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the license shall become null and void. 
(c)  Persons who are denied a peddling license or who have had licenses suspended or revoked may appeal by filing a written notice of appeal with the office of the Village manager, addressed to the attention of the Village manager. The appeal must be filed within five working days after receipt of the notice of denial, suspension or revocation. The Village manager or his designee shall hear and determine the appeal and the decision of the Village manager or his designee shall be final. 
(Code 1959, § 6.50.5)  
Secs. 50-44—50-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOLICITORS AND DISTRIBUTORS 
 
Sec. 50-71. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Peddler means any person who takes orders for or offers to sell or sells or seeks to obtain orders or sales from persons within the Village, including but not limited to any person within any residence or apartment or from any person upon any street, highway, byway, alley or sidewalk within the Village for any goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions, or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever; or any person who travels either by foot or by some means of conveyance, to or from any residence, and hangs, affixes, or otherwise distributes any book, handbill, flyer, circular, poster, or other form of writing that contains advertisement(s) for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, on any premises or residence, either for or on behalf of himself or any other person; or any person who travels either by foot or by some means of conveyance, to or from any residence, or upon any highway, street byway, or sidewalk distributing, delivering and/or handing out any handbill, flyer, circular, poster, or other form of advertisement for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, insurance, publications, subscriptions or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, either for or on behalf of himself or any other person. 
Person means any individual, organization, group, association, partnership, joint venture, corporation or trust, or any combination thereof. 
Residence means every separate living unit occupied for dwelling purposes by one or more persons contained within any type of building or structure. 
Solicitor means any person requesting or seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other thing of value or the pledge of any type of future donation for the support or benefit of any charitable, political, religious or nonprofit association, organization, project, corporation, partnership, trust or joint venture, or any combination thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 6.7; Ord. No. 4426, § 2, 8-6-2002; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.7), 12-6-2004) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 50-72. - Registration required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a solicitor or peddler unless such person is registered as provided in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 6.7.1; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.7.1), 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 50-73. - Registration application. 
Any person who desires to act as a solicitor or peddler as defined hereinabove, within the Village shall make application in writing to the chief of police, on a form to be furnished by the chief of police or his authorized representative(s), with the following information to be given under oath or affirmation, as the case may be, as to its truth and veracity: 
(1)  Applicant's name and address, together with the applicant's place of residence during the preceding 12 months. 
(2)  Name and address of the employer of the applicant, if any, together with written evidence of the employment relationship. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature and subject matter of the solicitation or distribution that the applicant seeks to undertake or a brief description of the nature of the peddler's business and the property to be sold in the Village. 
(4)  If a vehicle is to be used: 
a.  A description of the vehicle, together with the current license place number issued by the Secretary of State of such vehicle, or such other identification as will serve to identify the vehicle; and 
b.  A certificate of insurance of a responsible company in sufficient amounts as required by Illinois law. 
(5)  The length of time for which the solicitation, distribution or peddling is desired, the hours of the day that such function will be performed, and the approximate area within the Village where the solicitation, distribution or peddling will take place. 
(6)  Two photographs of the applicant taken within 30 days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the solicitor in a clear and distinguishing manner, together with a personal description of such individual. If the applicant is a corporation or firm, such photographs and such description shall be of the employee or employees who are conducting the solicitation, distribution or peddling. 
(7)  A statement by applicant as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or has been convicted of a felony under the federal laws of the United States. 
(8)  A statement by the applicant as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or of any ordinance of any State municipality or of any other State regulating solicitation or peddling as defined herein. 
(Code 1959, § 6.8; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.8), 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 50-74. - Investigation of applicant; issuance of registration. 
(a)  The chief of police or his authorized representative(s) shall cause an investigation to be made by the police department of the Village as to the applicant's criminal record, if any, and compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the State, the Village, other states and federal law. The applicant shall cooperate with such investigation and furnish such additional information as may be reasonably requested by the chief of police or his authorized representative(s) in furtherance of such investigation. 
(b)  If the investigation indicates that the applicant is in compliance with the regulations contained in section 50-75, depending on the type of solicitation applied for, the chief of police or his authorized representative shall notify the applicant within 24 hours from the time the application is made, and shall cause a registration badge to be issued directly to the applicant. 
(c)  All registration badges issued under this section shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance and must be thereafter renewed in the same manner as the original registration as provided in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 6.9; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.9), 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 50-75. - Regulations. 
(a)  In general. 
(1)  Each solicitor or peddler registered hereunder shall wear a registration badge as evidence of registration. The registration badge shall be worn by the solicitor or peddler on the left front chest of the solicitor's outer clothing in such a way that the badge may be easily read while in the course of solicitation, or distribution or peddling activities. If a badge becomes damaged or obscured, the solicitor or peddler shall return it to the chief of police or his authorized representative(s) and receive another badge at a cost of $5.00 for each replacement badge. The registration badge issued hereunder shall not be transferable, and it shall be unlawful for any solicitor or peddler to permit any other person to use or display the registration badge issued to such solicitor or peddler. 
(2)  Denial of a registration badge. The chief of police or his authorized representative(s) shall not issue a registration badge: 
a.  To any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony (excluding those felonies which relate to political protest) under the laws of the State of Illinois, the laws of any other State or the federal laws of the United States, within five years of the date of application; 
b.  Nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or of an ordinance of any other Illinois municipality or in any other State regulating soliciting or peddling, within five years of the date of application; 
c.  Nor to any person whose registration badge issued hereunder has been previously revoked as provided under Section 50-76. 
(3)  No solicitor or peddler shall have the exclusive right to any location in the street, sidewalks, alleys, byways or highways, nor shall any solicitor or peddler be permitted a permanent stationary location, nor shall he be permitted to operate in any area where his solicitation, distribution or peddling impedes the public safety or contributes to the creation of traffic obstructions, hazards, or congestion. 
(4)  Only persons registered with the Attorney General of the State of Illinois as a charitable organization as provided by "An Act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefore," approved July 26, 1963, as amended, shall be permitted to solicit or peddle for charitable purposes within the Village of Glenview. 
(5)  No person, whether registered or not under this article, shall solicit, distribute or peddle within the Village or on any premises if the same are posted against solicitation, distribution or peddling by means of a notice, prominently displayed, on which is printed: "No Solicitors or Peddlers Invited." Premises shall be deemed to be posted against solicitation, distribution or peddling if there is exhibited on or near the main entrance to the property, or on or near the main door, a sign at least three inches by four inches which bears the above legend in letters at least one-third inch in height. 
(6)  No person, whether registered or not under this article, shall hang, affix, or distribute any book, handbill, flyer, circular, poster, or other writing requesting or seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing, or any other thing of value, or the pledge of any type of future donation for the support or benefit of any charitable, political, religious or non-profit association, organization, project, corporation, partnership, trust, joint venture, or any combination of the foregoing, or espouse any political, religious, atheistic, philosophical, thought or idea, or any combination thereof if the same are posted against solicitation or peddling as described above. For the benefit of the public health, safety and welfare, the Village and public utilities are specifically exempted from the provisions of this subsection. 
(7)  It shall be the duty of each solicitor or peddler upon going onto any premise in the Village upon which a residence as herein defined is located to first examine for the notice provided for in subsection (a)(5) above. If a "No Solicitors or Peddlers Invited" notice is posted, then the solicitor or peddler, whether registered under the provisions of this article or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(8)  Any solicitor or peddler who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(9)  It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any solicitor or peddler, whether registered under this article or not, to go upon any residential property and ring the door bell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and/or engage in soliciting or peddling as herein defined, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. 
(10)  No vehicle used by a solicitor or peddler shall be permitted to be utilized by that solicitor or peddler as a showcase, sample case, or display area for the sale or offering for sale of foods, goods, wares, merchandise or any article of any kind whatsoever. 
(b)  Soliciting on streets and sidewalks. 
(1)  Permitted intersections. Solicitation or peddling on streets, sidewalks, alleys, highways or byways within the Village of Glenview shall be allowed only at the following intersections: Glenview Road and Harlem Avenue; Glenview Road and Waukegan Road; and East Lake Avenue and Waukegan Road. 
(2)  Any solicitor seeking to engage in solicitation for charitable purposes at permitted intersections will be allowed to do so once per calendar year, for a period of two consecutive days. Only one soliciting organization may engage in intersection solicitation on a single date. Intersection solicitation will be permitted during daylight hours. Solicitors seeking to solicit at approved intersections must obtain prior approval from the Village Chief of Police, or his designee, as set forth below in subsection (b)(3). 
(3)  Application. Solicitors seeking to engage in solicitation for charitable purposes at permitted intersections must make written request for authorization for same to the Village Chief of Police, or his designee, no later than 30 days prior to the requested date(s) for solicitation. The request must include the requested date(s), times, and location(s) for the solicitation; the solicitor's name and contact information; the name and contact information for the person(s) designated by the solicitor the coordinate the solicitation; proof of approved status as set forth in subsection (a)(4) above; and proof of insurance at limits approved by the Village. 
(4)  Solicitors may designate rain dates, subject to approval by the Village Chief of Police, or his designee. If a rain date is required, the Village may, at its sole discretion, exempt the solicitor from the requirement of soliciting on consecutive days as set forth in subsection (b)(2). 
(5)  Any person engaged in solicitation, distribution or peddling on any public street or highway shall be at least 16 years of age or more and shall wear a high-visibility vest and the registration badge required hereunder along with an emblem, insignia, sign, or button that clearly informs the public of the identity of the organization for which the solicitation or peddling is being undertaken. 
(Code 1959, § 6.10; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.10), 12-6-2004; Ord. No. 5099, § 2, 5-20-2008; Ord. No. 5425, § 2, 2-15-2011)  
Sec. 50-76. - Effect of noncompliance; revocation. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this article shall relieve any person from the necessity of obtaining a license, permit, registration card or other authority or from paying the required fee therefor, when the same is otherwise required by this Code. 
(b)  Revocation of a registration badge. The chief of police shall revoke the registration badge of any solicitor or peddler who: 
(1)  Is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article; or 
(2)  Has made a false statement in the application for registration; or 
(3)  Perpetrates a fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting solicitation, distribution or peddling activities; or 
(4)  Conducts solicitation, distribution or peddling activities contrary to the conditions of the registration requirements; or 
(5)  Conducts solicitation, distribution or peddling activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance; or 
(6)  Otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a registration badge under the terms of this article. 
Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police, or his authorized representative(s), to the holder of the registration badge in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his residence address set forth in the application stating the action taken and the reasons supporting such action. Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the registration badge shall become null and void. 
(c)  Persons who are denied registration or whose registration has been revoked may appeal by filing a written notice of appeal with the office of the Village manager addressed to the attention of the Village manager. The appeal must be filed within five working days after receipt of the notice of denial or revocation. The Village manager or his designee shall hear and determine the appeal. 
(d)  The Village manager's determination as to the denial or revocation of a registration badge shall be a final administrative decision, and may be appealed to the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois, in accordance with the procedures specified in the Administrative Review Law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101, et seq. Such an action must be filed and summons issued within 35 days of service of the Village manager's decision. 
(Code 1959, § 6.11; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.11), 12-6-2004; Ord. No. 5099, § 2, 5-20-2008)  
Sec. 50-77. - Penalty for noncompliance. 
Any person charged with violation of this article for solicitation, distribution or peddling contrary to the terms hereof who shall be found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined therefor not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each such offense. 
(Code 1959, § 6.11.1; Ord. No. 4729, § 2(6.11.1), 12-6-2004)
