ARTICLE III. - APPEARANCE CODE 
 
Sec. 54-61. - Purposes. 
This article is adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To promote the public health, safety, morals, comfort and general welfare of the citizens of the Village. 
(2)  To enhance the values of property throughout the Village. 
(3)  To protect and stabilize the general appearance of buildings, structures, landscaping and open area, in the multiple dwelling, business, commercial, planned development, public lands, hospital and industrial zoning districts of the Village. These regulations shall also apply to nonresidential uses which are located in any single-family residential district, except churches, schools and parks, and buildings and grounds associated therewith. 
(4)  To ensure adequate light, air and privacy for property in the multiple dwelling, business, commercial, planned development, public lands, hospital and industrial zoning districts of the Village. These regulations shall also apply to nonresidential uses which are located in any single-family residential district, except churches, schools and parks, and buildings and grounds associated therewith. 
(5)  To encourage and promote acceptability, attractiveness, cohesiveness and compatibility of new buildings, developments, remodeling and additions so as to maintain and improve the established standards of property values within the multiple dwelling, business, commercial, planned development, public lands, hospital and industrial zoning districts of the Village. These regulations shall also apply to nonresidential uses which are located in any single-family residential district, except churches, schools and parks, and buildings and grounds associated therewith. 
(Code 1959, § 25.2)  
Sec. 54-62. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
External architectural feature means the architectural style and general arrangement of such portion of a building or structure as is designed to be open to view from a public street, place or way, including the kind, color and texture of the building material, or a portion thereof, and the types of windows, doors, lights, attached or ground signs and other fixtures appurtenant to such portion. 
(Code 1959, § 25.9) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 54-63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5636, § 2(d), adopted February 19, 2013, repealed § 54-63, which pertained to appearance commission and was derived from Code 1959, §§ 25.3—25.5; and Ord. No. 4811, § 1, adopted Nov. 1, 2005.  
Sec. 54-64. - Appearance plan adopted. 
The Glenview Appearance Plan adopted and approved by the corporate authorities on September 15, 1968, by Ordinance No. 1688, is hereby ratified, approved and confirmed, is made a part of this article as though specifically set forth in this section and is incorporated in this article by reference. Awnings shall be governed by the Awning Design Guidelines, attached hereto and incorporated into this section [as if fully set out herein], which may be amended from time to time. Parking lot landscaping shall be governed by the Parking Lot Landscaping Design Guidelines, attached hereto and incorporated into this article, which may be amended from time to time. Signs in downtown Glenview shall be governed by the signs in the downtown design guidelines, attached hereto and incorporated into this section, which may be amended from time to time. Multi-Tenant Ground Signs shall be governed by the signs in the Multi-Tenant Ground Sign Design Guidelines, attached hereto and incorporated into this section, which may be amended from time to time. Real estate signs shall be governed by the real estate signs design guidelines, attached hereto and incorporated into this section, which may be amended from time to time. Lighting shall be governed by the lighting design guidelines, attached hereto and incorporated into this section, which may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1959, § 25.6; Ord. No. 4925, § 2, 11-21-2006; Ord. No. 4965, § 2, 3-20-2007; Ord. No. 5069, § 2, 1-8-2008; Ord. No. 5309, § 3, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 5394, § 3, 11-16-2010)  
Sec. 54-65. - Regulatory powers of appearance commission over external architectural features of buildings and structures. 
(a)  Scope of powers. No building or other permit otherwise required under any ordinance of the Village for the erection, construction, alteration or repair of any building or structure in multiple dwelling, business, commercial, planned development, public lands, hospital and industrial zoning districts shall be issued by the building and zoning director, and no work shall be started on any elements in any of the jurisdictional areas of the appearance commission as outlined in section III of the appearance plan as adopted by Ordinance No. 1688, passed and approved September 15, 1969, except upon the granting of a certificate of appropriateness by the appearance commission. Such requirement shall not preclude the issuance of a building permit without such certificate if the building and zoning director shall determine that no external architectural feature, as defined in section 54-62, is involved in the work for which the building permit is sought. These regulations shall also apply to nonresidential uses which are located in any single-family residential district, except churches, schools and parks, and buildings and grounds associated therewith. 
(b)  Preliminary consideration. The appearance commission shall, at the written request of a prospective applicant for a certificate of appropriateness, give consideration to preliminary exterior drawings, sketches, landscape and site plans, and materials on a specific project before a formal application is filed, and shall provide such advice, counsel, suggestions and recommendations on matters pertaining to aesthetics as they may deem necessary to guide the prospective applicant in the development of a plan which would comply with the requirements and purposes of the appearance plan, except that the appearance commission shall act in an advisory capacity only with regard to preliminary plans, and shall provide consultation only on projects for which preliminary drawings and materials are furnished by the prospective applicant, and shall not participate in the development of the basic concept, plans or drawings. All hearings on preliminary plans are to be public, and are to be held in accordance with the provisions and requirements provided for in subsection (c) of this section. Upon finding the preliminary exterior drawings, sketches, landscape and site plans, and materials are appropriate to, or compatible with, the character of the immediate neighborhood and will tend to affect the general purposes of the appearance plan, the appearance commission will issue a preliminary approval. The approval will be irrevocable, and makes the issuance of the certificate of appropriateness mandatory upon application, unless the final presentation does not comply in all respects with the preliminary presentation upon which the preliminary approval was based. 
(c)  Hearing. Coincidental with the filing of an application for a building permit or for permission to work on any elements in any of the jurisdictional areas of the appearance commission for which a certificate of appropriateness is required under subsection (a) of this section, the applicant shall file a written application for such certificate of appropriateness, on forms provided for such purpose, with the office of the building and zoning director not later than seven days prior to any regularly scheduled hearing of the appearance commission for consideration by them. Upon such hearing, the appearance commission shall consider the application for a certificate of appropriateness and, if necessary, receive additional evidence (such as exterior elevation renderings) and statements from the applicant, his agent or attorney, and from Village personnel or other persons as to whether the external architectural features of the proposed building or structure, or other improvement, comply with the appearance plan. At the request of any member of the appearance commission, testimony given at such hearing shall be under oath. 
(d)  Action of appearance commission. If preliminary consideration has not been requested under the terms and provisions of subsection (b) of this section, prior to making its decision, the appearance commission may make recommendations to the applicant as to changes in the exterior drawings, sketches, landscaping, site plans and materials which, in the judgment of the appearance commission, would tend to effect the general purposes of the appearance plan. The appearance commission shall make its decision within 15 days after the hearing is closed and shall issue to the building and zoning director a certificate of appropriateness, unless the appearance commission finds that the plan does not conform to the appearance plan and that the proposed building or structure will be inappropriate to, or incompatible with, the character of the immediate neighborhood and cause substantial depreciation in property values. If preliminary hearings have been held on the project for which application is being made, and preliminary approval has been issued by the appearance commission as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the appearance commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness immediately, provided that the final drawings, plans and materials as presented comply in all respects with the preliminary presentation upon which the preliminary approval was based. 
(e)  Denial by appearance commission. The appearance commission shall not deny a certificate of appropriateness, except upon the concurring vote of three members. 
(f)  Appeals. All final decisions of the appearance commission under this section shall be subject to judicial review pursuant to the provisions of the Administrative Review Law, and all amendments and modifications thereof, 735 ILCS.5/3-101 et seq.). 
(g)  Administrative approvals. Requests for approval regarding the elements identified in this subsection may be administratively approved by the director of community development and a certificate of appropriateness issued without appearing before the appearance commission. In lieu of the provisions of this subsection, the director of community development reserves the right but not the obligation to forward any request for approval of elements described by this subsection to the appearance commission for formal consideration. 
(1)  Minor architectural changes to buildings and/or tenant spaces including replacement and/or modification of doors, windows, storefront systems, and/or hardware if such replacement and/or modification is comprised of materials, finishes, and colors which match the existing architectural features and approximate rough openings of the building and/or tenant space. 
(2)  Landscape substitutions for diseased, dead, dying, and infested plant materials subject to review and approval of the director of public works or other village manager designee. 
(3)  Extensions to or replacement of fencing comprised of materials, finishes, and colors which match the previously installed fencing in locations permitted by section 98-213. 
(4)  Awnings without signage and comprised of a single color, when designed in compliance with the awning design guidelines and with the structural requirements of section 18-192. 
(5)  Signage for any tenant space within a shopping center with shopping center sign design guidelines previously approved by the appearance commission which is designed in compliance with said shopping center sign design guidelines and the requirements of chapter 98, article VII, signs, the wall sign design guidelines, single-tenant ground sign design guidelines, multi-tenant ground sign design guidelines, downtown sign design guidelines, and glen town center tenant design criteria, as applicable. 
(Code 1959, § 25.7; Ord. No. 6091, § 2, 8-1-2017)  
Sec. 54-66. - Followup by building and zoning director. 
(a)  Upon the granting of a certificate of appropriateness, the exterior drawings, sketches, landscape and site plans, renderings and materials upon which the certificate was granted shall be turned over to the building and zoning director, whose responsibility it shall be to determine, from time to time as the project is in progress and finally upon its completion, that there have been no unauthorized deviations from the evidence upon which the granting of the certificate of appropriateness was originally based. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the person to whom a certificate of appropriateness has been granted to comply with the requirements of the certificate of appropriateness and to obtain such inspections as may be necessary in order to assure such compliance. The building and zoning director will notify such person of any deficiencies found to exist. Failure to correct any deficiency within ten days after notification of such deficiency will constitute a violation of this article. 
(c)  When, by reason of nonavailability of planting materials or any other valid circumstance, it becomes necessary to vary any of the provisions under which a certificate of appropriateness has been granted and, in the opinion of the building and zoning director, such variation will be aesthetically equal to or be better than the original provisions and will not conflict with the intent of the appearance plan, the building and zoning director shall have the power to grant such variation. To the extent that the building and zoning director exercises such power, within 30 days thereafter, he shall submit a written report of the circumstances to the appearance commission. 
(d)  Before any use may be made of improvements constructed under the provisions of this article, a final inspection of the premises must be obtained from the building and zoning director, who will consider his findings in matters under the jurisdiction of the appearance commission, together with other codes, in the issuance of an occupancy certificate. An occupancy certificate will not be issued unless such an inspection has been made and the completed work found to be in compliance with plans approved by the appearance commission and under which the certificate of appropriateness was issued, except as provided in subsection (e) of this section. 
(e)  If it should become impossible, by reason of weather, strike or any other circumstance beyond the control of the person to whom the certificate of appropriateness has been granted, to complete all work required before occupancy or start of use, a temporary occupancy permit may be granted upon either the depositing with the Village of a sufficient cash escrow to guarantee completion of the work or upon the execution of an agreement, in a form satisfactory to the Village manager, in which the applicant shall be firmly bound to comply with the terms, provisions and conditions of the certificate of appropriateness as soon as the circumstances causing such impossibility shall have been abated. Refunds of such cash escrow may be made progressively as work is completed or in a lump sum upon final inspection and approval by the building and zoning director. 
(f)  If the person to whom the certificate of appropriateness has been granted fails to complete the work required in accordance with provisions under which the cash escrow amount set forth in subsection (e) of this section has been deposited within nine months of the date of such escrow deposit, the cash deposit shall be forfeited and the Village shall use all or part of such deposit as may be required to complete work in accordance with drawings submitted and approved by the appearance commission, and under which a certificate of appropriateness and certain permits have been granted. The nine-month time limit may be extended by the building and zoning director if, in his opinion, it is in the public interest to do so. In the event of such forfeiture, the person to whom the certificate of appropriateness has been granted shall only be entitled to the refund of that portion, if any, of the cash deposit that remains in escrow after completion of the work entailed. 
(Code 1959, § 25.8)  
Sec. 54-67. - Amendments. 
(a)  Proposal. Amendments to this article and the appearance plan may be proposed by the board of trustees, the appearance commission or any resident or owner of property in the Village. 
(b)  Application; notice of hearing. An application for an amendment to this article or the appearance plan shall be filed with the office of the building and zoning director, who shall forward a copy thereof to the appearance commission, without delay. The application shall contain such information as the appearance commission may, from time to time, by rules, provide, and the application shall be accompanied by a fee of $75.00 in the case of any applicant other than the board of trustees or the appearance commission. Not more than 60 days after the filing of such application, a hearing shall be held by the appearance commission on the application. Such hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the rules of the appearance commission. Notice of such hearing shall be published at least once, not more than 30 days, nor less than 15 days before the hearing, in a newspaper with a general circulation within the Village. The published notice may be supplemented by such additional form of notice as the appearance commission, by rules, may provide. 
(c)  Report by appearance commission. Following such hearing, and within 180 days after the filing with the building and zoning director of the application for amendment, the appearance commission shall transmit to the board of trustees a written report giving its findings and recommendations for action to be taken by the board of trustees in regard to the application. If no such report is transmitted within 180 days of the filing of the application, the appearance commission shall be deemed to have recommended that the application be denied, unless the petitioner has, prior to the expiration of such 180 days, requested and has been granted a stipulated extension of time by the appearance commission. 
(d)  Action by board of trustees. After receiving the report of the appearance commission, the board of trustees may enact the amendment with or without change, or may reject it, or may refer it back to the appearance commission for further consideration. If no action is taken by the board of trustees within six months of the date of the filing of the application with the building and zoning director, the application shall be deemed to have been denied. 
(Code 1959, § 25.11)  
Sec. 54-68. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 25.10)  
Secs. 54-69—54-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SITE PLAN REVIEW 
 
Sec. 54-81. - Statement of purpose. 
(a)  Site plan review is a procedure for the review of proposed developments or redevelopments to ensure they are compatible with adjacent development by taking into account the relationship of the new development to its surroundings. The purpose of site plan review is to go beyond the basic zoning, subdivision, design and building requirements in order to address site details which the other codes adopted in this chapter may not regulate. It should be noted that site plan review is in addition to, and not an exception from, other required procedures under Village ordinances, including, but not limited to, those established by article III of chapter 18 pertaining to the building code, article III of this chapter pertaining to the appearance plan, chapter 66 pertaining to subdivisions and chapter 98 pertaining to zoning. Instead, it augments these regulations in order to promote more orderly and harmonious development. It is also intended to ensure, generally, that all codes and ordinances have been met and to provide a logical and coordinated review of proposed developments. 
(b)  In conducting a site plan review of a proposed development, the following elements of the development are examined: 
(1)  Parking arrangement and location. 
(2)  Site circulation, pedestrian and vehicular. 
(3)  Traffic and driveway access. 
(4)  Building location on the site. 
(5)  Transitions to adjacent properties. 
(6)  Drainage and stormwater detention. 
(7)  Environmental impact and open space, including existing vegetation. 
(8)  Intensity of use. 
(9)  Building massing, scale and relationship to surrounding development. 
(10)  Impact on provision of Village services, including public safety and infrastructure demands. 
(c)  Specific building and landscaping design and materials are not examined, for such details are addressed as part of the required appearance commission review. Instead, the focus is on the aspects of site planning as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  In addition to upgrading site planning through the site plan review, the Village hopes to create a process, which will expedite the review of development proposals, by addressing the fundamental details of site planning early in the review process. By providing a forum for the communication of Village requirements and applicable policy documents and plans, it is hoped that costly delays may be avoided. During the site plan review, there is an opportunity for direct communication between the developer, Village staff, the plan commission and the Village Board prior to the preparation of final plans. 
(e)  Finally, given the essentially developed nature of the Village, it is intended that site plan review should help minimize adverse impact on, protect and enhance property values of and promote compatibility with adjacent development and surroundings. 
(Code 1959, § 25.13)  
Sec. 54-82. - Developments requiring approval; exemptions. 
(a)  The following developments require final site plan approval prior to the issuance of building permits for the development: 
(1)  Any use in the business, limited commercial, light industrial, public land or hospital district that results in the construction of a new building or structure, major modifications to the exterior dimensions of an existing building or structure (including building additions), alteration in area to a paved parking lot or the addition of or change to a curb cut. 
(2)  All new multifamily dwellings or conversions of existing buildings to create new multifamily units, including attached single-family residences and townhomes. 
(3)  All nonresidential uses in residential districts that result in construction of a new building or structure, major modifications to the exterior dimensions of an existing building or structure (including building additions), alterations in area to a paved parking lot or the addition of or change to a curb cut. 
(4)  All planned developments. 
(5)  Single-family subdivisions which will result in more than two lots. 
(b)  Uses determined by the director of community development as having no land use impact and which are consistent with the intent of this article as set forth in section 54-81(a) shall be exempt from the requirements of this article. Additionally, the following site plan changes shall be eligible for administrative approval by the director of community development: 
(1)  Parking lot improvements comprised of 25 or fewer parking stalls which comprise fewer than five-percent of the quantity of existing parking stalls upon any property which would include a sufficient quantity of parking stalls onsite for the existing and/or proposed uses on the property as required by code upon completion of the improvements, would include no impacts to the land use or site circulation, and otherwise have no outstanding staff review comments. 
(2)  Building additions comprised of up to 3,000 square feet which comprise less than five-percent of the total existing building square footage upon any property provided the building additions would include no impacts to the land use or site circulation, and otherwise have no outstanding staff review comments. 
(3)  The director of planning can require appearance before the plan commission for any project which he/she does not feel meets the intent of the above requirements. 
(4)  Once quarterly, the director of community development shall forward a list of all administrative approvals granted in accordance with this section to the plan commission for their information. 
(c)  Uses in the P-1 district which are subject to a conditional use public hearing conducted by the Village Board of trustees shall be exempt from the requirements of this article. 
(d)  Uses specified in section 98-135(a)(2), not otherwise authorized on the ground floor of an existing building, or addition or expansion thereto, located in a D-1 downtown district, may be permitted to occupy such ground floor space by approval of the plan commission and Village Board under the site plan approval process established in this article, but only in accordance with the permitted use requirements established in section 98-135(a)(1). 
(Code 1959, § 25.14; Ord. No. 6091, § 3, 8-1-2017)  
Sec. 54-83. - Procedures. 
(a)  Preliminary conference (development meeting). Prior to filing an application for site plan review with the director of development, an applicant shall request and attend a development meeting with the Village staff to obtain all necessary filing information and have the procedures for review explained. 
(b)  Preliminary review. Within 21 days of filing a complete application, including all information as shall be required from time to time by the Village, for site plan review with the director of development, the applicant shall attend a preliminary site plan review conference with the Village staff. The purpose of the conference is to acquaint the Village staff with the proposal and convey the concerns of those participating early in the process, when designs are still flexible and refinements and adjustments are possible. The preliminary site plan review is also intended to assist the applicant in bringing the site plan into conformance with the requirements of this article and other applicable regulations. The staff will also review the application for completeness and apply the evaluation criteria set forth in subsection (c) of this section. The review will form the basis of the staff report, which will be considered by the plan commission and board of trustees as part of final site plan review. 
(c)  Final review. 
(1)  Final site plan review approval by the plan commission is required for all developments specified in section 54-82. The final site plan review shall be scheduled by filing with the director of development the necessary number of site plans as may be established by departmental procedure. Such submittal shall accompany the necessary applications and other required documents for rezoning, subdivision, conditional use, variation and/or annexation, if applicable. If the applicant elects, final site plan approval may be considered in conjunction with preliminary subdivision approval. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the information required in subsection (c)(1) of this section, the director of development shall circulate the application for staff review and cause a staff report to be prepared for transmittal to the plan commission. The director of development shall also schedule the matter for consideration by the plan commission at the next available meeting, taking into account procedural requirements for other related approvals, if applicable. 
(3)  Within 60 days of the submission to the director of development of a completed application for final site plan review approval, the proposed development shall appear on a plan commission agenda to determine compliance with the evaluation criteria as established in section 54-85. The plan commission shall consider the application at one or more meetings and then forward its recommendation to the board of trustees for final action. The plan commission and board of trustees shall make one of the following decisions on the matter: 
a.  The proposed site plan satisfies the evaluation criteria established in section 54-85 and is therefore approved. 
b.  The proposed site plan, with specific modifications, could satisfy the evaluation criteria and is therefore approved, conditionally. 
c.  The proposed site plan does not satisfy the evaluation criteria and is therefore disapproved. 
(4)  One copy of the site plan will be marked with the final decision of the Village Board and returned to the applicant and one copy will be placed in the Village case file on the matter. Upon approval of the final site plan, the applicant may seek and the Village may issue a building permit for the proposed development, provided all other Village requirements are satisfied. 
(Code 1959, § 25.15; Ord. No. 5352, § 4, 6-15-2010)  
Sec. 54-84. - Submission requirements. 
(a)  Preliminary review. Submission of the following documents shall be deemed a complete application for preliminary site plan review: 
(1)  A current plat of the survey for the proposed property, depicting existing structures, top of foundation elevation, site improvements, utilities and legal description. 
(2)  A preliminary site plan, drawn to scale, which includes the following information: 
a.  The number and location of proposed buildings and/or all proposed structures. 
b.  Dimensional setbacks from all property lines for all structures and accessory uses. 
c.  Project density, including: 
1.  Gross building area. 
2.  Percentage of impervious surface coverage. 
3.  Floor area by use, bedroom count and dwelling units per acre. 
4.  Gross floor area ratio (FAR), excluding interior parking. 
d.  Signage location, height and area. 
e.  Lighting location and type. 
f.  Fence locations, types and heights. 
g.  Parking lots, including: 
1.  Number of stalls, including those designated for handicapped uses. 
2.  Dimensions. 
3.  Aisles. 
4.  Drives. 
5.  Location of all curbing. 
h.  Loading areas. 
i.  Roadways, public and private. 
j.  Trash areas. 
k.  Preliminary building elevations and floor plans. 
l.  Surrounding land use, location and zoning. 
m.  Preliminary landscaping. 
n.  Utility locations and stormwater detention improvements. 
o.  Any additional information requested by staff during the course of preliminary site plan review. 
(b)  Final approval. 
(1)  Submission of the required number of the following documents to the director of development shall be deemed a complete application for final site plan review: 
a.  All information required in connection with the preliminary site plan review, including any revisions thereto. 
b.  All information required in connection with an application for rezoning, conditional use, variation and/or annexation. 
(2)  At the applicant's option, the applicant may submit all information required in connection with preliminary subdivision approval to be considered in conjunction with the final site plan review. 
(Code 1959, § 25.16)  
Sec. 54-85. - Evaluation criteria. 
The goals and objectives of the Village comprehensive general plan and other applicable Village planning and policy documents shall be utilized in the review of proposed site plans. In addition, the following criteria shall also be used to determine whether a proposed site plan fulfills the requirements of this article: 
(1)  Building and structure locations. The arrangements of the structures on the site shall allow for the effective and efficient use of the proposed development. Such arrangement shall be compatible and harmonious with development on adjacent property. The arrangement of structures on the site shall be evaluated to ensure effective and efficient provision of municipal services. In the downtown and downtown frame area, the site plan shall embody a pedestrian orientation, generally represented by a building location at or near the street, with parking at the rear. 
(2)  Building scale. The scale of the proposed building must be appropriate to the site, location and function of the site. The building scale must promote harmonious transitions to adjacent developments and land uses. 
(3)  Open space. The proposed development should be designed to maximize the preservation of natural site features, including vegetation, drainage and topography. The landscape treatment of exterior open spaces should enhance the quality of the project and create a desirable and functional environment for patrons, visitors and occupants. Stormwater detention facilities should be integrated into the proposed site design to provide functional and attractive open space. The amount of open space provided shall be appropriate to the proposed use and compatible with surrounding development. Excessive lot coverage shall be prohibited, notwithstanding the amount of such coverage permitted by chapter 98 pertaining to zoning. 
(4)  Landscaping:. Landscape design shall provide an aesthetically pleasing design, create a logical transition to adjoining development, screen incompatible uses, screen unsightly activities from public view and break up large expanses of asphalt with plant materials. Existing mature trees and shrubs should be maintained to the maximum extent practicable. Plant materials shall be selected so as to withstand the Village's climatic conditions and the specific constraints imposed by adjacent functions. 
(5)  Graphics and signage. Signs and other site graphics shall be minimized in size and number to promote their effectiveness. Such signs and site graphics shall be integrated with architectural and site landscape features. 
(6)  Circulation. All site circulation systems, vehicular and pedestrian, shall provide adequate and safe access to the site. Dangerous traffic movements will be prohibited and curb cuts shall be minimized. Disruption of traffic flows on adjacent streets and undue congestion shall be minimized or avoided. Connections and linkages with adjacent developments are encouraged to promote logical circulation patterns and minimize curb cuts. 
(7)  Parking lots. Proposed parking lots shall be designed, located and screened to minimize visual impact on adjacent properties. Such parking shall also be designed and located to minimize the number of curb cuts. Shared parking lot access shall be promoted, where practical. Perimeter screening is encouraged and interior lot landscaping shall be provided to break up large expanses of asphalt with plant and other landscape materials. 
(8)  Site illumination. Site illumination shall be designed, located and installed in such a manner that will minimize adverse impact on adjacent properties. 
(9)  Preservation. Preservation of unique architectural, cultural, environmental or historical resources is encouraged. Development designs and treatments that respect such desirable resources on adjacent properties are also encouraged. 
(10)  Completeness. The application for the site plan review must contain all the information required in section 54-84. 
(Code 1959, § 25.17)  
Sec. 54-86. - Amendments. 
Amendments to an approved site plan shall require approval in the same manner as required for the original site plan. 
(Code 1959, § 25.18)  
Sec. 54-87. - Approval time limit. 
Final site plan review approval granted by the board of trustees shall be established in accordance with the period set forth in section 54-2, unless a longer period of time is expressly authorized by the board of trustees or by further board of trustees action. Time extensions may be authorized by the board of trustees, as provided in section 54-2, if the applicant demonstrates that there are circumstances, difficulties or practical hardships which make compliance with the original time period unreasonable. 
(Code 1959, § 25.19; Ord. No. 5352, § 5, 6-15-2010)  
Sec. 54-88. - Exceptions and waivers. 
Consistent with the intent and purpose of this article, the plan commission and Village Board may, in any particular case where such action is in the public interest and not inconsistent with the Village comprehensive plan, chapter 66 pertaining to subdivisions, chapter 98 pertaining to zoning or other applicable codes and ordinances of the Village, waive strict compliance with the regulations of this article. Any waivers granted shall be specifically listed on the face of the site plan submitted for approval and include the date of such grant. Any waivers granted shall be included in the official records and minutes of the meeting. 
(Code 1959, § 25.20)  
Chapter 58 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Dead animals, § 14-4; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; health and sanitation, ch. 38; weeds and rubbish, § 38-311 et seq.; utilities, ch. 82. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 58-1—58-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REFUSE 
 
Sec. 58-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Household means any single-family property or any unit of a multi-family property. 
Landscape waste sticker means the official sticker purchased through the Village or its designees, to be placed on each bag or bundle of landscape waste, unless the person has landscape waste subscription service. 
Multi-family property means a residential building consisting of three or more attached units, and capable of being serviced by one or more waste containers, as such are defined herein. 
Person includes the owner, occupant or lessee of any premises, and firm, corporation or organization of any kind. 
Premises means any house, residence building, flat, apartment, dwelling place or place of abode, commercial or industrial establishment, office building, hotel, church, school, hospital, club building or meeting hall. 
Waste means any or all of the following: garbage, refuse, ashes, tin cans, bottles, cartons, books, newspapers, boxes and other household rubbish, discarded household furniture, furnishings, fixtures and appliances of all kinds, manure, dead animals or parts thereof, trees, tree branches, tree roots, tree trunks, brush, shrubs, grass clippings, plant stalks, leaves and all other rubbish of any kind, and shall be further classified as follows: 
Bulky items means any and all of the following: stoves, refrigerators and other large appliances, large furniture, bedding, large crates, trees and dead tree branches more than four feet in length and four inches in diameter. 
Construction and demolition wastes means any or all of the following: lumber, roofing, rubble, plaster, pipe, wire, insulation, earth, sod, sand, gravel, stone, brick, concrete and other building materials. 
Garbage means any rejected waste or waste household food, offal, swill or carrion and every accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking and dealing in or storage of meats, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables and any other matter of any nature, which are subject to decay, putrefaction and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding material for flies or other germ-carrying pests; discarded household fixtures, manure, dead animals or parts thereof, tree branches, roots and trunks four inches or greater in diameter; building materials from home remodeling and repairs; and small amounts of bricks, sod, earth, concrete and rocks. 
Landscape waste means all accumulations of grass, shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs or trunks less than four inches in diameter and less than four feet in length, other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees. 
Recyclable material means aluminum cans, tin/steel/bimetal cans, newspapers, clear and colored glass bottles/containers, HDPE and PET plastic beverage containers, liquid laundry detergent containers, plastic bleach bottles, fabric softener containers and windshield washer solvent bottles for automobile windshield washers. 
Special wastes means any or all of the following: hazardous wastes, paint sludges, chemical wastes, metal scraps and metal shavings. 
Waste container means a container made of nonabsorbent, durable, noncorrodible metal or plastic, with a tightfitting cover, rodentproof and insectproof, of a capacity of not less than ten gallons, nor more than 32 gallons, unless 90-gallon toter carts are used, and with suitable handles on the can and lid. Landscape waste containers shall be 30-gallon, two-ply, 50-pound wet strength per ply kraft paper bags or 90-gallon toter carts. Light hedge clippings and tree branches not more than four feet, may also be tied in bundles not more than 24 inches in diameter and not more than 60 pounds in weight. 
Waste disposal firm means any licensed person engaged in the business of removal and disposal of waste as defined in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 9.26; Ord. No. 5436, § 2, 3-15-2011) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-32. - Administration. 
(a)  Whenever directed by the provisions of sections 58-31—58-37, the health administrator shall carry out such directions and perform such duties as provided thereby, unless the Village manager shall designate some other officer to perform such duties. The term "health administrator," as used in this article shall refer to such officer or other officer as designated from time to time by the Village manager. 
(b)  All matters relating to or affecting the accumulation, collection, removal or disposal of waste, unless specifically otherwise assigned, shall be subject to and under the supervision of the health administrator. 
(c)  The occupancy of any premises for residential purposes shall be prima facie evidence that waste is being produced and accumulated on such premises. 
(Code 1959, § 9.27)  
Sec. 58-33. - Storage. 
(a)  Accumulations. 
(1)  Waste, garbage and rubbish. Waste shall be promptly removed from the premises and every person shall keep his premises free and clean from waste accumulation at all times. All waste must be disposed of at least once weekly. No person shall permit any garbage or rubbish to accumulate within the Village unless the garbage or rubbish shall be suitably enclosed in waste containers, and filled to a weight no greater than 60 pounds, unless a 90-gallon toter cart is used. 
(b)  Yard refuse. No person shall permit any yard refuse to accumulate within the Village unless it is suitably placed in official bags or bundles, with official stickers attached, and disposed of at least weekly. 
(c)  Containers required. 
(1)  A sufficient number of waste containers for a weekly accumulation of normal waste shall be provided and at all times maintained in good order and repair by the owner, lessee or head of household of any premises in the Village. 
(2)  All waste containers shall be as defined in section 58-31 and no other type of container shall be acceptable. Filthy, leaking or defective receptacles shall be cleaned, repaired or replaced by the owner, lessee or head of household of the premises served, and at his expense, as directed by the health administrator. All containers shall be kept clean and disinfected with an antiseptic solution as often as necessary to maintain the containers in a sanitary condition. Evidence of neglect of these requirements or unsafe containers shall be determined by the health administrator. 
(3)  Institutional, commercial and industrial waste containers not mounted on wheels shall be stored on durable racks or placed on an easily cleanable, impervious surface. The racks shall raise the waste containers at least 12 inches off the storage surface. Containers mounted on wheels shall be specifically designed for use with collection vehicles. The container's wheels must elevate the base of the container a distance of at least six inches off the storage surface. 
(d)  Container contents. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the owner, lessee or head of household of any premises to cause all garbage produced on the premises to be thoroughly drained of all surplus liquid, securely wrapped or bagged in paper or packed in a covered box or carton of such dimensions as will permit its free passage into and out of the waste container, and finally deposited, after such wrapping or bagging, in such waste container as soon as practicable after the garbage is produced thereon. 
(2)  Garbage and rubbish shall be securely wrapped or bound in such a manner as may be necessary to prevent the scattering thereof, and shall be deposited in a waste container as prescribed in subsection (c)(1) of this section. It shall further be the duty of every owner, lessee or head of household of any premises to cause all yard refuse to be properly placed in containers or bundled. 
(e)  Container placement and use. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or head of the household of any premises to place any such waste containers within any alley, street or walkway of the Village. 
(2)  Waste containers shall be stored at an accessible outdoor location for backdoor service. Curb service customers shall place containers at the curb, between the lot lines of their property as if such lot lines were continued to the street, not closer than two feet nor more than five feet from the street no earlier than 7:00 p.m. the night before pickup and remove the containers, including the recycling bin, no later than 7:00 p.m. on the service day. 
(3)  Waste containers shall be maintained and used in a rodentproof and sanitary condition, and in accordance with standards prescribed by the health department. Underground waste containers are prohibited unless they presently exist on the date of passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived. Household waste containers, landscape waste, bulky items and recycling bins shall be placed on the parkway, between the lot lines of the customer requesting service as if such lot lines were continued to the street, for service no earlier than 7:00 p.m. the day before collection. 
(f)  Container inspection and approval. All waste containers shall be subject to inspection and approval by the health department. 
(Code 1959, § 9.28; Ord. No. 4268, § 1(9.28(d)), 2-6-2001)  
Sec. 58-34. - Collection and disposal. 
(a)  Garbage, rubbish and landscape waste refuse. 
(1)  All garbage, rubbish and landscape waste refuse shall be called for and disposed of at least once per week by a waste disposal firm duly appointed by the Village. The waste disposal firm will not call for waste at the residence of any person before 7:00 a.m. or after 5:00 p.m. on Monday—Friday, and before 8:30 a.m. or after 12:00 noon on Saturday and before 9:00 a.m. or after 12:00 noon on Sundays. These hours shall also apply for refuse pickup within 100 feet of residential areas as defined by Chapter 98, Article III, Division 2. 
(2)  Every household having once a week collection shall be permitted to use a 35, 65, or 95-gallon toter cart. 
(3)  Landscape waste will be collected once weekly from April 1—November 30, and must be placed at the curb, between the lot lines of the customer requesting service as if such lot lines were continued to the street, with the official stickers, properly bagged or bundled. If the subscription program is used, no stickers are required. 
(4)  A multi-family property may apply to the Village to receive collection and disposal services from the waste disposal firm duly appointed by the Village, which application shall be approved by the Village at its sole discretion. In order to receive these waste disposal services, a multi-family property must: 
a.  Be capable of receiving service using waste containers, as defined herein; 
b.  Have participation from all households within the multi-family property; and 
c.  Pay the Village for Village-provided waste containers. 
(5)  Any multi-family property that chooses to receive collection and disposal services from the waste disposal firm duly appointed by the Village may not revoke that decision, and is henceforth bound to receive collection and disposal services from the waste disposal firm duly appointed by the Village. A multi-family property electing to receive collection and disposal services from the waste disposal firm duly appointed by the Village voluntarily relinquishes its right to contract for collection and disposal services with an entity other than that with which the Village has appointed to provide such services. 
(b)  Construction, demolition and special wastes. All construction and demolition wastes, and special wastes not resulting from the performance of work within the Village by a building or other construction contractor shall require a special collection within one week of the time the waste is produced on the premises. Building and other construction contractors shall remove construction and demolition wastes, and special wastes resulting from the performance of work within the Village as frequently as necessary to maintain sanitary conditions, but at least once per week, employing either their own equipment and employees or a waste disposal firm which either is duly licensed by the Village or conforms to the standards set forth in this article. 
(c)  Dumping, scattering and burying waste. No waste shall be dumped, scattered or buried within the Village limits. 
(d)  Open burning. The open burning of leaves, branches, trunks and roots of trees, bushes and shrubs, rubbish, waste, garbage, paper, carbonaceous materials or any other combustible materials on any public or private property within the Village is unlawful and prohibited; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to the noncommercial cooking of food in outdoor fireplaces or grills. 
(e)  Garbage and combustible wastes. Garbage and other combustible wastes may be disposed of by grinding or shredding such waste finely and disposing of it through pipes leading to a public sanitary sewer, provided that all garbage or combustible matter so disposed of in such pipes shall have been ground or shredded to such a degree that all particles are carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in the sewers into which such garbage or combustible matter is deposited. 
(f)  Frequency of collections. Any person contracting for residential waste collection may specify either one or two collections per week. The frequency of residential waste collection may be changed by arrangement between the individual resident and the waste disposal firm; however, a $10.00 service fee will be charged for each service change after the first change in the contract year (July 1—June 30). 
(g)  Bulky waste. All bulky waste removal shall require a special collection as curb service at an extra charge. It shall be the duty of the owner, lessee or head of household of any premises to contact the hauler to make special arrangements to have bulky wastes removed. Bulky items shall be placed at the street, between the lot lines of the customer requesting service as if such lot lines were continued to the street, not closer than two feet nor more than five feet from the street after 7:00 p.m. the night before service and a pickup request by telephone to the waste service company shall be made prior to the scheduled service day. 
(Code 1959, § 9.29; Ord. No. 4268, § 1(9.29((a),(g)), 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 4860, § 2, 4-18-2006; Ord. No. 5436, § 3, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 6007, § 2, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 58-35. - Sanitation requirement. 
No person shall transport waste, or cause waste to be transported, over the streets or other public ways in the Village unless such waste being transported is entirely and securely covered. Garbage shall not be transported over or along the streets of the Village or other public property thereof, except in a leakproof, compaction type body, commonly referred to as a "packer type" refuse body, approved by the health department. Such equipment shall be cleaned frequently enough to prevent nuisances and insect breeding, shall be maintained in good condition, repair and appearance, and may be stored or kept, when not in use, in a tightly constructed and closed building or shed within the Village, provided, such building or structure shall conform with the requirement of chapter 98, zoning, or in open storage areas, subject to the approval of the health department. The waste disposal firm shall immediately clean up any waste that he may have caused to spill on private premises, parkways, streets, alleys or other public places, in a neat and workmanlike manner, and shall replace, at his expense, containers or other property which may be seriously damaged by carelessness of his employees. 
(Code 1959, § 9.30)  
Sec. 58-36. - Waste disposal firm requirements. 
(a)  The Village shall contract with waste disposal firms for the collection of waste materials within the Village from single-family residences, as specified in the contract. It shall be the purpose of the Village in issuing such contracts to seek the highest quality of service at the lowest economic cost to each category of customer. 
(b)  The Village shall license waste disposal firms for the collection of waste materials from other than single-family residences. Either party thereto may, upon 90 days' written notice, sooner if mutually agreeable, cancel such license. 
(c)  The waste disposal firm shall be required to dump or dispose of the waste collected under the license of the Village in a sanitary landfill which is being operated in compliance with all applicable statutes, rules and regulations. 
(d)  The Village reserves the right to receive, and/or have prepared, annual audits of the licensee's books of account, at the licensee's expense, for the purpose of establishing fair rates for each category of customer and to provide for adequate and sanitary collection, provided that such audit may be performed by a certified public accountant of the licensee's choosing, who shall apply usual and normal accounting techniques to the audit of the licensee's books. 
(e)  The Village shall establish rate ceilings and service standards. Such rate schedule shall include rate ceilings for special collections, referred to in section 58-34(b), but shall not include commercial, institutional and industrial collection rate ceilings. The contracted waste disposal firm shall adhere to such standards and shall not exceed such rate ceilings. 
(f)  Each waste disposal firm shall be required to post a performance bond with adequate surety to carry out the purposes of the license. 
(g)  The waste disposal firm shall be required to serve premises serviced by a licensed waste disposal firm no less than once per week; provided, however, that all institutional, commercial and industrial garbage shall be collected as frequently as necessary to maintain sanitary conditions, but at least once per week. 
(h)  All trucks operating within the Village shall carry in the cab the rules of collection as provided by the Village. The disposal firm shall display its name and telephone number on both sides of the compactor unit, in letters and numerals no less than six inches in height. Every licensee shall have a local telephone number listed in a telephone directory of general circulation in the Village, and an answering service shall be provided between 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Monday—Friday, except legal holidays. 
(i)  No person, except as provided in this article, shall remove waste from any premises in the Village or transport waste through the streets, alleys or public ways of the Village, or in any other manner dispose of waste originating in the limits of the Village, or contract for or permit himself to be employed or engaged for any such removal, transportation or disposal without first having secured a license from the Village for performing such waste disposal service. Any new license shall be approved by the board of trustees. 
(j)  Application for and issuance of such license shall be made in accordance with the general licensing provisions of chapter 30, and the annual license fee for operating a waste disposal firm within the Village shall be as provided in section 30-3. Evidence of such license shall be provided by the Village and displayed on each motor vehicle of the license used in the Village, in accordance with the regulations promulgated by the Village manager. 
(k)  Every applicant must submit adequate assurances as to his character, morals and business reputation for himself and his employees. 
(l)  Every applicant must submit complete financial statements and references as to his financial responsibility. 
(m)  Every applicant must demonstrate that he has adequate and sufficient equipment, personnel and financial responsibility to render service to any customer requesting such service and in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(n)  Every licensee shall carry comprehensive general public liability and automobile insurance in basic limits of not less than $200,000.00/$400,000.00, plus $50,000.00 property damage insurance, plus an amount of liability umbrella coverage which, together with the basic amounts and any coverage now carried in excess thereof, will total not less than $2,000,000.00 of such comprehensive general public liability and automobile coverage. In addition thereto, such licensees shall carry workmen's compensation for his employees. Certificates of insurance for all of such coverages shall be furnished to the Village within 30 days after the passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(o)  No licensee shall dump or otherwise place or dispose of waste in violation of the laws of the State or the ordinances of any municipality. 
(p)  The president and board of trustees of the Village reserve the right to deny the applicant a license if any reasonable doubt exists as to the applicant's compliance with the provisions of this article or any other ordinance provisions of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 9.31)  
Sec. 58-37. - Rate ceilings. 
In accordance with section 58-36(e), the rates are established through the Village manager. 
(Code 1959, § 9.33)  
Sec. 58-38. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(b)  If a waste disposal firm violates any provision of any ordinance of the Village, the Village shall have the right, in addition to enforcing the penalties otherwise provided, to revoke or suspend the license of such waste disposal firm. 
(c)  If it becomes necessary for the Village or a property owner or person in possession and/or control of property to have a survey prepared to determine the location of lot lines as referenced in sections 58-33 and 58-34 because of a dispute between or among affected persons or entities, the person or entity determined by a court to have violated the provisions of section 58-33(e) or section 58-34(a) and (g) shall be liable for payment or reimbursement of all survey costs and expenses to the survey company or the person or entity having advanced the cost for payment of the survey. 
(Code 1959, § 9.32; Ord. No. 4268, § 2, 2-6-2001)  
Chapter 62 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; moving buildings, § 18-155; occupation of streets, § 18-691 et seq.; sanitary requirement of public places, § 38-9; damage to public property, § 46-201; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 50; planning, ch. 54; subdivisions, ch. 66; design standards for street arrangement, extent, width grade and location in subdivisions, § 66-16; design standards for street plan in subdivisions, § 66-163; location and layout of streets, blocks, depth of lots, parks and other public grounds, § 66-192; design standards for streets in floodplains, § 66-193; required improvements for street paving in subdivisions, § 66-235; telecommunications (other than wireless), ch. 74; telecommunications (wireless services), ch. 78; vehicles and traffic, ch. 90; one-way streets and alleys, § 90-81 et seq.; vehicles for hire, ch. 94; zoning, ch. 98. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Construction permit required; escrow. 
No street, public or private, nor any sidewalk, water main, storm sewer, sanitary sewer, street lighting system, gas and electric service or other public improvement shall be constructed in the Village unless a permit for such construction shall be obtained, and such permit shall be issued by the superintendent of public works. At the time application is made for the permit, the applicant shall deposit in escrow in a bank designated by the Village manager a sum of money equal to the cost of construction and improvement covered by the permit, and such amount is to be determined by the superintendent of public works. Such escrow shall provide that if the applicant fails to complete the construction in accordance with the requirements of all pertinent Village ordinances within a time fixed in the escrow, the Village shall be permitted to use all or such portion of the escrowed money as may be required to enable the Village to complete the construction of the improvements involved. 
(Code 1959, § 17.1)  
Sec. 62-2. - Installation or extension of public utilities. 
Whenever any public utility is installed or extended, pursuant to the provisions of section 62-1, to serve any lot or subdivision, then, in such event, the person making such installation or extension shall extend such utility along the frontage to the most distant limit of the lot or subdivision involved. No permits for any house service connections to such public utilities shall be granted unless and until such utilities are extended the full frontage of the lots involved. For the purpose of this section, the term "public utility" shall include streets, sidewalks, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, water mains, street lighting systems and gas, electric and telephone services. 
(Code 1959, § 17.2)  
Sec. 62-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 6083, § 16, adopted June 8, 2017, repealed § 62-3, in its entirety. Former § 62-3 pertained to "Bond," and was derived from Code 1959, § 17.4.  
Sec. 62-4. - Construction of streets required as prerequisite for building permit. 
No permit shall be issued for the erection or construction of any building or structure, or for the excavation for any building or structure, on any lot or parcel of land within the Village unless a highway, road, street or way for public service facilities improved with water mains, sanitary sewers and storm sewers has been provided to serve the lot or parcel of land, or the applicant shall have deposited in escrow a sum of money equal to the cost of constructing the highway, road, street or way for public service facilities improved with water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers and curb and gutter, pursuant to all of the provisions of section 62-1, except in such cases where a paved highway, paved road, paved street or paved way for public service facilities has already been provided prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(Code 1959, § 17.5)  
Sec. 62-5. - Injury to new pavement. 
It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the pavement is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft or newly laid pavement. 
(Code 1959, § 17.6)  
Sec. 62-6. - Street obstructions. 
A person shall not erect, construct, place or maintain any bump, fence, gate, chain, bar, pipe, wood or metal horse, or any other type of obstruction in or on any street within the boundaries of the municipality, without the expressed written permission of the Village Board. The Village Board shall, prior to issuing such approval, obtain an opinion from the chiefs of the fire and police departments and the public works director regarding the impact any obstruction might have on public safety. The term "street," as used in this section, shall mean any roadway accessible to the public for vehicular traffic, including, but not limited to, private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets and highways within the boundaries of the municipality. 
(Code 1959, §§ 7.66, 17.7)  
Sec. 62-7. - Barricading excavations and defects. 
(a)  Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place, or making any excavation in any such place shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work. Such barricades shall be protected by a light at nighttime. 
(b)  Any defects in any pavement shall be barricaded to prevent any injury, and any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any such place shall guard such opening or excavation while it remains open by proper barricades and lights. 
(Code 1959, § 17.8)  
Sec. 62-8. - Disturbing or interfering with barricades and lights. 
It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or light lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement, or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1959, § 17.9)  
Sec. 62-9. - Deposits on sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass or other article which might cause injury to persons, animals or property. 
(b)  Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery, provided that the usable width of the sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet and, provided that no such article shall remain on such sidewalk for more than a period of one-half hour. 
(Code 1959, § 17.10)  
Sec. 62-10. - Snow and ice removal. 
(a)  Every owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or other person having charge of any building or lot of ground in the Village abutting upon any public way or public place shall remove the snow and ice from the sidewalk in front of such building or lot of ground. 
(b)  If the sidewalk is of greater width than five feet, it shall not be necessary for such person to remove snow and ice from the sidewalk for a space wider than five feet. 
(c)  If the snow and ice on the sidewalk shall be frozen so hard that it cannot be removed without injury to the pavement, the person having charge of any building or lot of ground as set forth in this section shall, within the time specified, cause the sidewalk abutting on the premises to be strewn with ashes, sand, sawdust or some similar suitable material, and thoroughly clean the sidewalk as soon thereafter as the weather shall permit. 
(d)  The snow which falls or accumulates during the day before 4:00 p.m. shall be removed within three hours after the snow has fallen or accumulated. The snow which falls or accumulates after 4:00 p.m. and during the night shall be removed before the following 10:00 a.m. 
(Code 1959, § 17.11; Ord. No. 5032, §§ 5, 6, 10-2-2007)  
Sec. 62-11. - Manner of removal and deposit of snow or ice. 
(a)  No person engaged in removing snow or ice from any building, private property, driveway, driveway approach or public sidewalk shall sweep, plow, shovel, scrape, drag or in any other manner move or deposit snow or ice in such a way as to narrow the traveled portion of any street or alley, block the vision of motorists at intersections, prevent parking at the curb, cover or interfere with the use of fire hydrants, block sidewalks or driveways, damage parkway trees, sod or curbing, or otherwise create any traffic hazard. Every owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or other person that contracts for the removal of snow or ice shall bear responsibility for actions by their agents. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16 for each and every offense. 
(Code 1959, §§ 17.11.1, 17.11.2)  
Sec. 62-12. - Duty of to keep streets, alleys and sidewalks in good repair. 
All public streets, alleys and sidewalk pavements shall be kept in good repair. All sidewalks shall at all times be kept in good repair by the abutting owners, at their own expense. If the Village shall sustain damages because of the failure of the abutting owner to keep the sidewalks in good repair, such owner shall be liable to the Village to the extent of all damages sustained by the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 17.12)  
Sec. 62-13. - Removal of dirt from public way. 
No person shall plow, dig up or remove any dirt from any dedicated public way in the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 17.13)  
Sec. 62-14. - Moving buildings. 
(a)  No person shall move, or cause to be moved, or aid in moving any building into, along or across any street, alley or public ground in the Village without having first obtained the written permission to do so from the director of public works and director of development, which permit shall state the street, alley or public ground to be traversed in the moving of such building and the length of time the moving of such building shall be permitted thereon. 
(b)  Any owner of any building and/or any contractor for its removal who shall move any building contrary to the provisions of this section, shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 17.14) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18.  
Sec. 62-15. - Poles and wires. 
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any poles or wires on or over any public street, alley or other public way without having first secured permission from the board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 17.15)  
Sec. 62-16. - Objects in public rights-of-way and/or public easements. 
The Village shall bear no responsibility to maintain, replace and/or repair any objects or plantings in any public right-of-way or public easement. Any party who places such objects or plantings in public rights-of-way or public easement does so at its own risk. The Village shall, at its sole discretion, retain the right to remove any plantings or objects placed in the public right-of-way or public easement at any time, for any reason, without any liability to the party who placed such planting and/or object in the public right-of-way or public easement. 
(Ord. No. 5393, § 2, 11-16-2010)  
Secs. 62-17—62-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION OF STREETS AND DRIVEWAYS 
 
Sec. 62-51. - Street construction minimum requirements. 
No street shall be constructed which does not conform to the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Pavement quality. The pavement of such street must be of a material which, in quality, equals or exceeds water-bound macadam. For the purpose of this subsection, pit gravel is to be considered inferior to such macadam and may not be used in street construction within the Village. 
(2)  Thickness, etc., of materials. A water-bound macadam base, not less than eight inches in thickness, surfaced with not less than 2¼-inch thickness of asphaltic concrete, type I—II or equal, of which the upper one inch shall be of fine aggregate, dense graded asphaltic concrete, all manufactured and laid in accordance with the current specifications of the State division of highways, shall be used. 
(3)  Specifications of State division of highways. The material or construction requirements with respect to streets constructed, whether macadam or a superior construction is used, shall meet all specifications of the State division of highways for the particular type of pavement used. 
(4)  Curb and gutter. All streets constructed must be provided with concrete curb and gutter which shall meet all specifications of the State division of highways for the particular type of curb and gutter used. 
(5)  Drainage. Proper drainage shall in all cases be provided at the time such street is constructed. 
(6)  Driving widths. No pavement shall be constructed that will afford less than a driving width of 25 feet, except that the minimum driving width afforded shall not be less than 20 feet in cases where the minimum lot area on both sides of the street proposed to be paved is not less than one-half acre, and where the average frontage of each such lot fronting on the street proposed to be paved is not less than 90 feet. 
(7)  Half streets. Where half streets are dedicated on any plat of a subdivision, no pavement shall be constructed on such half streets that will afford less than a driving width of 20 feet. 
(8)  Identical pavement in same block. Where a portion of a street in any block is already improved with a paving of a type which is superior to the minimum requirements set forth in this section, the pavement of the balance of the street within the same block shall be of identical construction with the existing pavement. 
(9)  Commercial and industrial streets. Where any pavement is to be constructed in any public right-of-way within the Village limits to serve commercial or industrial property, and where any concrete pavement is to be widened, altered or repaired, such new pavement shall be of concrete not less than eight inches in thickness and constructed in accordance with the current specifications of the State division of highways. 
(10)  Permit fee. The charge for a permit as required by section 62-1 shall be one percent of the estimated cost of the improvement. 
(Code 1959, § 17.28)  
Sec. 62-52. - Driveway construction rules, regulations and specifications; permit required; fee. 
The board of trustees shall adopt, from time to time, reasonable and necessary rules, regulations and specifications pertaining to entrance and exit driveways to serve residential or commercial establishments and other uses of property abutting upon streets, including specifications for drainage and structures appurtenant to such driveways. All such rules, regulations and specifications adopted by the board of trustees shall be on file in the office of the superintendent of public works. No permit shall be issued by the superintendent of public works for the construction of any such driveway which does not conform to the rules, regulations and specifications prescribed by the Village. The charge for a permit as required by this section shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1959, § 17.29)  
Secs. 62-53—62-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 62-81. - Cost to be deposited in escrow. 
At the time application is made for a permit, the applicant shall deposit in escrow, in a bank designated by the Village manager, a sum of money equal to the cost of excavation and restoration covered by the permit, and such amount is to be determined by the superintendent of public works. The provisions of section 62-1 shall apply fully if the applicant shall fail to complete all or any part of the work covered by the permit. 
(Code 1959, § 17.19)  
Sec. 62-82. - Manner. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to make any excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. 
(b)  Proper bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground, and in excavations, the excavation shall not have any place below the surface, any portion which extends beyond the opening at the surface. 
(c)  No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits in the making of such excavations or tunnels, and notice shall be given to the persons maintaining any such pipes, cables or conduits, or to the Village department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel, before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed. Proper care shall be taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub, wherever possible. 
(Code 1959, § 17.20)  
Sec. 62-83. - Availability of street during work; temporary sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful to render more than one-half the width of any street unavailable for travel in connection with any excavation or tunnel. If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(Code 1959, § 17.21)  
Sec. 62-84. - Time limit; extension. 
Each application for a permit shall state the length of time it is estimated will elapse from the commencement of the work until the restoration of the surface of the ground, or until the refill is made ready for the restoration of the pavement. It shall be unlawful to fail to comply with such time limitation unless the permission for an extension of time is granted by the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1959, § 17.22)  
Sec. 62-85. - Surface restoration. 
(a)  Any person making any excavation or tunnel in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the Village shall restore the surface thereof to its original condition if there is no pavement thereon. Refills shall be of suitable materials, placed under the supervision of the superintendent of public works and properly tamped down, and any bracing in such tunnel or excavation shall be left in the ground. 
(b)  If the excavation or opening has necessitated an opening in a pavement or sidewalk, the refill and restoration of the pavement or sidewalk shall be made in accordance with all applicable provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the Village pertinent thereto, under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1959, § 17.23)  
Sec. 62-86. - Inspections; notice of commencement of work. 
The superintendent of public works shall from time to time inspect all excavations or tunnels being made in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the Village to ensure the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Notice shall be given to the superintendent of public works at least ten hours before the work or refilling of any such excavation or tunnel commences. 
(Code 1959, § 17.24)  
Sec. 62-87. - Railings and fences. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person engaged in digging into any street, alley or other public highway, in paving any street or alley, or building any sewer or drain, or trench for water pipes, in any of the public streets, avenues or other public places, under contract with the Village, or by virtue of any permission which may have been granted by the Village to them or their principals, where such work, if left exposed, would be dangerous to passersby, to erect a fence or railing at such excavations or work, in such a manner as to prevent danger to passersby who may be traveling on such streets, roads or avenues, and to continue and uphold the railing or fence until the work shall be completed or the obstruction or danger removed. It also shall be the duty of such persons to place upon such railing or fence, at twilight in the evening, suitable and sufficient red lights as danger signals and such persons shall keep such lights burning through the night until dawn, during the performance of the work.
