When notified of an excavation or when requested by the Village or by J.U.L.I.E., a utility shall locate and physically mark its underground facilities within 48 hours, excluding weekends and holidays, in accordance with the Illinois Underground Facilities Damage Prevention Act (220 ILCS 50/1 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-517. - Vegetation control. 
(a)  Electric utilities — Compliance with state laws and regulations. An electric utility shall conduct all tree-trimming and vegetation control activities in the ROW in accordance with applicable Illinois laws and regulations, and additionally, with such local franchise or other agreement with the Village as permitted by law. 
(b)  Other utilities — Tree trimming permit required. Tree trimming must be done in accordance with applicable Illinois laws and regulations specifically governing same, and the Village Tree Preservation Ordinance. 
(1)  Application for tree trimming permit. Applications for tree trimming permits shall include assurance that the work will be accomplished by a certified arborist, and competent workers with supervision who are experienced in accepted tree pruning practices. Tree trimming permits shall designate an expiration date in the interest of assuring that the work will be expeditiously accomplished. 
(2)  Damage to trees. Poor pruning practices resulting in damaged or misshapen trees will not be tolerated and shall be grounds for cancellation of the tree trimming permit and for assessment of damages. The Village will require compensation for trees extensively damaged and for trees removed without authorization. The formula developed by the International Society of Arboriculture will be used as a basis for determining the compensation for damaged trees or unauthorized removal of trees. The Village may require the removal and replacement of trees if trimming or radical pruning would leave them in an unacceptable condition. 
(c)  Specimen trees or trees of special significance. The Village may require that special measures be taken to preserve specimen trees or trees of special significance. The required measures may consist of higher poles, side arm extensions, covered wire or other means. 
(d)  Chemical use. 
(1)  Except as provided in the following subsection (2), no utility shall spray, inject or pour any chemicals on or near any trees, shrubs or vegetation in the Village for any purpose, including the control of growth, insects or disease. 
(2)  Spraying of any type of brush-killing chemicals will not be permitted on rights-of-way unless the utility demonstrates to the satisfaction of the director of public works that such spraying is the only practicable method of vegetation control. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-518. - Removal, relocation, or modifications of utility facilities. 
(a)  Notice. Within 90 days following written notice from the Village, a utility shall, at its own expense, protect, support, temporarily or permanently disconnect, remove, relocate, change or alter the position of any utility facilities within the rights-of-way whenever the corporate authorities have determined that such removal, relocation, change or alteration, is reasonably necessary for the construction, repair, maintenance, or installation of any Village improvement in or upon, or the operations of the Village in or upon, the rights-of-way. 
(b)  Removal of unauthorized facilities. Within 30 days following written notice from the Village, any utility that owns, controls, or maintains any unauthorized facility or related appurtenances within the rights-of-way shall, at its own expense, remove all or any part of such facilities or appurtenances from the rights-of-way. A facility is unauthorized and subject to removal in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Upon expiration or termination of the permittee's license or franchise, unless otherwise permitted by applicable law; 
(2)  If the facility was constructed or installed without the prior grant of a license or franchise, if required; 
(3)  If the facility was constructed or installed without prior issuance of a required permit in violation of this article; or 
(4)  If the facility was constructed or installed at a location not permitted by the permittee's license or franchise. 
(c)  Emergency removal or relocation of facilities. The Village retains the right and privilege to cut or move any facilities located within the rights-of-way of the Village, as the Village may determine to be necessary, appropriate or useful in response to any public health or safety emergency. If circumstances permit, the municipality shall attempt to notify the utility, if known, prior to cutting or removing a facility and shall notify the utility, if known, after cutting or removing a facility. 
(d)  Abandonment of facilities. Upon abandonment of a facility within the rights-of-way of the Village, the utility shall notify the Village within 90 days. Following receipt of such notice the Village may direct the utility to remove all or any portion of the facility if the director of public works determines that such removal will be in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare. In the event that the Village does not direct the utility that abandoned the facility to remove it, by giving notice of abandonment to the Village, the abandoning utility shall be deemed to consent to the alteration or removal of all or any portion of the facility by another utility or person. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-519. - Clean-up and restoration. 
The utility shall remove all excess material and restore all turf and terrain and other property within ten days after any portion of the rights-of-way are disturbed, damaged or destroyed due to construction or maintenance by the utility, all to the satisfaction of the Village. This includes restoration of entrances and side roads. Restoration of roadway surfaces shall be made using materials and methods approved by the Village engineer. Such cleanup and repair may be required to consist of backfilling, regrading, reseeding, resodding, or any other requirement to restore the ROW to a condition substantially equivalent to that which existed prior to the commencement of the project. The time period provided in this section may be extended by the Village engineer for good cause shown. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-520. - Maintenance and emergency maintenance. 
(a)  General. Facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within rights-of-way are to be maintained by or for the utility in a manner satisfactory to the Village and at the utility's expense. 
(b)  Emergency maintenance procedures. Emergencies may justify non-compliance with normal procedures for securing a permit: 
(1)  If an emergency creates a hazard on the traveled portion of the right-of-way, the utility shall take immediate steps to provide all necessary protection for traffic on the highway or the public on the right-of-way including the use of signs, lights, barricades or flaggers. If a hazard does not exist on the traveled way, but the nature of the emergency is such as to require the parking on the shoulder of equipment required in repair operations, adequate signs and lights shall be provided. Parking on the shoulder in such an emergency will only be permitted when no other means of access to the facility is available. 
(2)  In an emergency, the utility shall, as soon as possible, notify the director of public works or his or her duly authorized agent of the emergency, informing him or her as to what steps have been taken for protection of the traveling public and what will be required to make the necessary repairs. If the nature of the emergency is such as to interfere with the free movement of traffic, the Village police shall be notified immediately. 
(3)  In an emergency, the utility shall use all means at hand to complete repairs as rapidly as practicable and with the least inconvenience to the traveling public. 
(c)  Emergency repairs. The utility must file in writing with the Village a description of the repairs undertaken in the right-of-way within 48 hours after an emergency repair. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-521. - Variances. 
(a)  Request for variance. A utility requesting a variance from one or more of the provisions of this article must do so in writing to the director of development as a part of the permit application. The request shall identify each provision of this article from which a variance is requested and the reasons why a variance should be granted. 
(b)  Authority to grant variances. The director of development shall decide whether a variance is authorized for each provision of this article identified in the variance request on an individual basis. 
(c)  Conditions for granting of variance. The director of development may authorize a variance only if the utility requesting the variance has demonstrated that: 
(1)  One or more conditions not under the control of the utility (such as terrain features or an irregular right-of-way line) create a special hardship that would make enforcement of the provision unreasonable, given the public purposes to be achieved by the provision; and 
(2)  All other designs, methods, materials, locations or facilities that would conform to the provision from which a variance is requested are impracticable in relation to the requested approach. 
(d)  Additional conditions for granting of a variance. As a condition for authorizing a variance, the director of development director of development may require the utility requesting the variance to meet reasonable standards and conditions that may or may not be expressly contained within this article but which carry out the purposes of this article. 
(e)  Right to appeal. Any utility aggrieved by any order, requirement, decision or determination, including denial of a variance, made by the director of development under the provisions of this article shall have the right to appeal to the Village board, or such other board or commission as it may designate. The application for appeal shall be submitted in writing to the Village clerk within 30 days after the date of such order, requirement, decision or determination. The Village board shall commence its consideration of the appeal at the board's next regularly scheduled meeting occurring at least seven days after the filing of the appeal. The Village board shall timely decide the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-522. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to fine in accordance with the penalty provisions of this Code. There may be times when the Village will incur delay or other costs, including third party claims, because the utility will not or cannot perform its duties under its permit and this article. Unless the utility shows that another allocation of the cost of undertaking the requested action is appropriate, the utility shall bear the Village's costs of damages and its costs of installing, maintaining, modifying, relocating, or removing the facility that is the subject of the permit. No other administrative agency or commission may review or overrule a permit related cost apportionment of the Village. Sanctions may be imposed upon a utility that does not pay the costs apportioned to it. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-523. - Enforcement. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as limiting any additional or further remedies that the Village may have for enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Sec. 62-524. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 5039, § 2, 10-16-2007)  
Chapter 66 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; planning, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 82; vegetation, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Plat Act, 765 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Intent. 
The intent of this chapter is to protect the interests of the land owner or subdivider, the investor in land, the homeowner and the Village by providing reasonable rules and regulations in conformity with accepted engineering and public health standards and practices, to govern the location, width and course of streets, and control of floodwater runoff, with respect to any map, plat or subdivision of any block, lot or sublot, or any part thereof, or any piece or parcel of land within the corporate limits of the Village and within its jurisdictional area, which rules and regulations include reasonable requirements with respect to any map, plat or subdivision of any block, lot or sublot, or any part thereof, or any piece or parcel of land within the corporate limits of the Village and within its jurisdictional area, which rules and regulations include reasonable requirements with respect to water supply, sewerage collection, street drainage and other public improvements. The requirements for all new or existing public improvements shall extend and relate to off-site as well as on-site improvements, when deemed necessary by the plan commission and board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 18.2)  
Sec. 66-2. - Minimum requirements. 
In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals and welfare. 
(Code 1959, § 18.10.3A)  
Sec. 66-3. - Overlapping or contradictory regulations. 
Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this chapter upon the use of land or buildings are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provision of this chapter or any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive shall govern. 
(Code 1959, § 18.10.3B)  
Sec. 66-4. - Private agreements and legal relationships. 
This chapter is not intended to abrogate, annul or otherwise interfere with any easement, covenant or any other private agreement or legal relationship; provided, however, that where the regulations of this chapter are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than such easements, covenants or other private agreements or legal relationships, the regulations of this chapter shall govern. 
(Code 1959, § 18.10.3C)  
Sec. 66-5. - Construction and definitions. 
(a)  Construction. In the construction of this chapter, the following provisions and rules shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly requires otherwise: 
(1)  Terms used in the present tense shall include the future. 
(2)  Terms in the singular number include the plural number, and terms in the plural number include the singular number. 
(3)  The term "used for" shall include the terms "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for" and "occupied for." 
(4)  The term "shall" is mandatory. 
(5)  The term "may" is permissive. 
(6)  The term "Village" means the Village of Glenview, Illinois. 
(7)  The term "commission" means the plan commission. 
(8)  Unless otherwise specified, all distances shall be measured horizontally. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alley means a dedicated public right-of-way, other than a street, that affords a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
Block means a tract of land bounded by streets or combinations of streets and public parks, forest preserves, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, bulkhead lines, shorelines or waterways. 
Board of trustees means the president and board of trustees of the Village. 
Building means any covered structure built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind, and which is permanently affixed to the land. 
Cul-de-sac means a local street with only one outlet and having an appropriate terminal for the safe and convenient reversal of traffic movement. 
Ditch means a long, narrow channel with side slopes steeper than 2.5 to one, dug into the earth as a trough for drainage. 
Easement means a plat of dedication by the property owner of the use of land for a specific purpose. 
Floodplain and areas subject to flooding mean the area which would be inundated by stormwater runoff equivalent to that which would occur with a rainfall of five-year frequency after total development of the watershed. 
Improvement, public, means any sanitary sewer, storm sewer, drainage ditch, water main, street planting strip, sidewalk, pedestrian way, off-street parking area or other facility for which the Village may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation. 
Jurisdictional area means the area extending 1½ miles from the Village in the unincorporated County, except where the Village and other villages have mutually agreed to a division of overlapping jurisdictions, in which case the area of jurisdiction shall be shown by a line on the duly recorded comprehensive plan. 
Lots, double frontage, means lots, other than corner lots, platted on two streets, one of which is a thoroughfare. 
Lot of record means a lot which is a part of a subdivision, the plat of which has been recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of the County. 
Lot width means the distance on a horizontal plane between the side lot lines measured at right angles to the lot depth at the established front building line. 
Multiple-family dwelling means a residential building containing two or more dwelling units. 
Official map means parts of the official plan implemented by regulatory ordinance, including, but not necessarily limited to, chapter 98, zoning, this chapter and major street, sewer and water maps. 
Official plan means a comprehensive plan, not regulatory, for the present and future development and/or redevelopment of the Village and the jurisdictional area adjacent to the Village. 
Pavement width means the measurement perpendicular to the pavement centerline, extending from the back of curb to back of curb. 
Plan commission means a commission created under the authority of the Illinois Municipal Code, and by Ordinance No. 1267 of the Village. 
Professional engineer means a person licensed in the State as a professional engineer. 
Record plat means the map or plan of record of a subdivision, filed for public record in the office of the recorder of deeds of the County. 
Regulations means the subdivision regulations of the Village. 
Retention basin means a pond, lagoon, lake, depression in the earth's surface, underground structure or pipe that has been designed to provide storage for storm water runoff and a controlled release of such impounded water into water channels or pipes. 
Screening means structures, or evergreen or shrub vegetation maintained for the purpose of concealing from view the area behind such structure or plantings. 
Single-family dwelling means a residential building containing one dwelling unit. 
Street means a public right-of-way which affords a primary means of access to abutting properties, whether designated as a street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, lane or thoroughfare, or however designated, except driveways to buildings. 
Streets marginal access, means a minor street parallel and adjacent to a thoroughfare street, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
Street, section line, means a street which follows, or closely follows, section lines. 
Street, thoroughfare, means a street serving as an arterial trafficway with a high degree of continuity. 
Subdivider means a person, corporation or duly authorized agent who undertakes the subdivision of land as defined in this subsection (b). 
Subdivision means: 
(1)  The division or redivision of a parcel of land into two or more parts or parcels; 
(2)  The platting of a parcel or tract of land into a single numbered lot, without alteration of its boundaries; 
(3)  A planned development or planned unit development as defined in this chapter, chapter 98, zoning, or the zoning ordinance of the County; or 
(4)  The widening, extension, alteration, dedication or variation of a street, alley, public ground, railroad or waterway for the purpose of transfer of ownership, correction of a survey or building development. 
Such term includes resubdividing and, when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. 
Subdivision design standards means the basic land planning principles established as guides for the preparation of plans or plats, or plans for public improvement. 
Surveyor means any person licensed in the State as a land surveyor. 
Swale means a long, wide, shallow depression in the earth for drainage, with side slopes flatter than three to one. 
Thoroughfare means a street with a high degree of continuity and serving as an arterial trafficway. 
Village engineer means a licensed professional engineer employed or retained by the Village and designated as the Village engineer. 
Working drawings means an engineer's or architect's plans, details, sections and profiles, prepared for building or constructing a public improvement. 
(Code 1959, §§ 18.10.1, 18.10.2, 18.11) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 66-6. - Jurisdiction. 
This chapter shall apply to all subdivisions of land within the corporate limits of the Village and within its jurisdictional area. 
(Code 1959, § 18.3)  
Sec. 66-7. - Amendments; hearings. 
For the purpose of promoting the public health, safety, morals, comfort and general welfare, the board of trustees may from time to time amend the regulations imposed by this chapter. The plan commission, at the direction of the board of trustees, shall hold public hearings on proposed amendments. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.3)  
Sec. 66-8. - Procedure. 
Any owner of land desiring to subdivide property within the corporate limits of the Village, or within the jurisdictional area, shall submit the following: 
(1)  Application and preliminary plan. 
(2)  Final plan. 
(3)  Working drawings. 
(Code 1959, § 18.5.1)  
Sec. 66-9. - Application fee schedule. 
Every application to appear before the plan commission shall be accompanied by a fee in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Each application for a one lot subdivision ..... $ 50.00 
Plus, per lot ..... 5.00 
(2)  Each application for a subdivision in excess of one lot ..... 100.00 
Plus, per lot ..... 5.00 
(3)  Recording fees for each plat of a subdivision, annexation, vacation or other plat ..... 103.00 
Plus, per lot, tract or parcel therein ..... 2.00 
(4)  Recording fees for annexation agreements and any other agreements, documents or instruments regarding property requiring development approval by the plan commission and/or Village Board, first two pages ..... 23.00 
Plus, for each additional page ..... 2.00 
provided, however, that the fee for any pages or exhibits which exceed 120 square inches in area shall be $2.00 for each 120 square inches thereof, but shall not exceed a maximum of $9.00 per page or exhibit. 
(5)  Each amendment to chapter 98, zoning ..... 200.00 
(6)  Each amendment to the zoning map (under five acres) ..... 250.00 
(7)  Each amendment to the zoning map (over five acres) ..... 250.00 
Plus, per acre ..... 100.00 
(8)  Each petition for annexation ..... 100.00 
(9)  Each application for a planned development of five acres or less ..... 500.00 
(10)  Each application for a planned development in excess of five acres ..... 500.00 
Plus, per acre ..... 100.00 
(11)  Each amendment to a planned development involving an accessory use as defined by section 98-4 ..... 250.00 
(12)  Each amendment to a planned development, other than an accessory use ..... 500.00 
(13)  Each application for a plat of vacation for a public street or alley ..... 200.00 
(14)  Each application for variation of chapter 98, zoning, in conjunction with a planned development or annexation agreement ..... 100.00 
(15)  Each official map application ..... 250.00 
(Code 1959, § 18.5.1A)  
Sec. 66-10. - Time limit for construction completion. 
If the subdivider fails to complete the construction in accordance with the requirements of this chapter within two years of the date of the cash deposit agreement, the cash deposit shall be forfeited and the Village shall use all or such part of such deposit as may be required to complete the project in accordance with the approved working drawings. The two-year time limit may be extended by the Village when such extension is in the public interest. In the event of such forfeiture, the subdivider shall only be entitled to the refund of that portion, if any, of the cash deposit that remains in escrow after completion of the project. 
(Code 1959, § 18.5.2D)  
Sec. 66-11. - Permit and approval required. 
No street pavement, sidewalk, sanitary sewer, storm sewer or water line shall be constructed until a permit has been obtained. No improvements shall be constructed in any area which is to be subdivided until the final plan and working drawings have been approved by the board of trustees of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.9)  
Sec. 66-12. - Disconnection of territory. 
(a)  The provisions of this section shall supersede the disconnection provisions of section 7-3-6 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/7-3-6). 
(b)  The provisions of section 7-3-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/7-3-6) shall be the exclusive disconnection provisions in the Village under article 7, division 3 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Code 1959, § 18.14)  
Sec. 66-13. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.4)  
Secs. 66-14—66-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 66-41. - Organization. 
The offices concerned with administration of this chapter are as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.1)  
Sec. 66-42. - Plan commission. 
The plan commission is vested with the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Subject to the approval of the board of trustees, prepare and adopt such procedural rules and regulations as are required for the orderly and efficient conduct of its business, provided, such rules and regulations shall not be in conflict with any provision of this chapter; and 
(2)  Review all preliminary and final subdivision plans and plats, making determinations and recommendations in the areas of design standards and engineering specifications, as specified and referred to in this chapter, and hold public hearings pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.1A)  
Sec. 66-43. - State department of public health. 
Plans and specifications for water supply shall be submitted to the State department of public health for approval after such plans and specifications have been approved by the plan commission. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.1B)  
Sec. 66-44. - Metropolitan sanitary district. 
Plans and specifications for sanitary sewers shall be submitted to the metropolitan sanitary district for approval after such plans and specifications have been approved by the plan commission. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.1C)  
Sec. 66-45. - Board of trustees. 
(a)  The board of trustees shall, in addition to its authority and powers as a home rule municipality, also exercise the authority granted by the Illinois Revised Statutes in regard to subdivision control, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Approval or disapproval of final plats and working drawings referred to the board of trustees by the plan commission. 
(2)  Approval or disapproval of all variations and exceptions recommended by the plan commission. 
(3)  Amendment of this chapter, when found necessary and desirable, as provided in this chapter. 
(4)  Enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Approval or disapproval of intended dedication of land for public use. 
(6)  Vacation of a street, alley or other public place and fix compensation to the Village therefor. 
(b)  Requirements for new or existing public improvements shall extend and relate to off-site, as well as on-site, public improvements, when deemed necessary by the board of trustees to carry out the intent of this chapter, and enhance and preserve the public health, welfare and safety of the general public. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.1D)  
Sec. 66-46. - Exceptions and waivers. 
(a)  Consistent with the intent and purpose of this chapter, the plan commission may recommend, and the board of trustees may grant exceptions or waivers to this chapter, in any particular case where such action is in the public interest, because of special circumstances applicable to the property, and not inconsistent with the Village comprehensive plan, chapter 54 pertaining to site plan review, chapter 98 pertaining to zoning or other applicable codes and ordinances of the Village, provided, however, that the granting of the exception or waiver will not be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare, or injurious to other property or improvements or to the neighborhood in which the property is located, and will not be in conflict with the objectives and requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  Criteria for granting waivers of required improvements. The following criteria may be considered by the plan commission and the board of trustees in evaluating a request for waiver of the installation of required improvements listed in article V, division 1 of this chapter: 
(1)  The required improvement is not identified as a future public improvement in an adopted planning document of the Village, including, but not limited to, the Village comprehensive plan, bike and sidewalk master plan, the Milwaukee Avenue or the Waukegan Road Corridor Plan. 
(2)  The required improvement is not located within a Village right-of-way, but is in a right-of-way governed by a jurisdictional authority which does not require the improvement. 
(3)  The required sidewalk improvement does not lead to a school or park in the immediate neighborhood. 
(c)  The plan commission may recommend, and the board of trustees may grant, a waiver from the requirement to immediately install the required public improvement (temporary waiver) if any of the following circumstances apply: 
(1)  Installation of the required improvement is proposed as part of a Village project within one year from the date of final subdivision approval. 
(2)  The required improvement is identified as a future public improvement in an adopted planning document of the Village, including but not limited to the Village comprehensive plan, bike and sidewalk master plan, the Milwaukee Avenue or the Waukegan Road Corridor Plan. 
Where a temporary waiver is granted, the owner shall be required to execute an escrow agreement or a covenant agreement which: 
(1)  Shall obligate the current or future property owner to be responsible for installation of said required improvement in compliance with all Municipal Code requirements, when and if so, requested by the Village at the owner's sole expense; and 
(2)  Shall include language stating that the current or any future property owner will support a special service area created for the purpose of installing the improvements described in the covenant agreement, in which the undersigned owners shall be required to vote in favor of said special service area and shall not object to same. 
(Code 1959, § 18.4.2; Ord. No. 5372, § 2, 8-17-2010)  
Secs. 66-47—66-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PLANS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 66-81—66-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY 
 
Sec. 66-101. - In general. 
(a)  A topographic and boundary survey, signed and sealed by a surveyor, shall be prepared before the preliminary plan is submitted. Such survey shall accurately show contours, at no more than one-foot intervals, and shall include the same contour information for surrounding property sufficient to establish the existing pattern of surface drainage. The survey shall be referenced to a Village datum benchmark, accurately located and described on the plan. 
(b)  The required number of copies of the completed application form and preliminary plan shall be filed with the secretary of the plan commission in accordance with the rules and procedures of the plan commission. 
(c)  The preliminary plan shall show pertinent information required by the subdivision design standards as approved by the Village Board as set forth in this Code or on file with the Village clerk, and the comprehensive plan of the Village. 
(d)  The plan commission, in the examination of the preliminary plan, will consider the requirements of the ordinances of the Village and the best use of the land proposed for subdivision. Consideration will be given to lot sizes and arrangement; width and location of streets; location of sanitary sewer and water systems as they relate to existing and future systems; locations of surface and underground stormwater drainage systems, retention basins, schools and parks, public utilities, existing easements and covenants; and other information pertinent to the property to be subdivided. The preliminary plan need not contain specifications for proposed improvements. 
(e)  The subdivider shall submit to the plan commission a preliminary plan for the entire tract; however, the subdivider may be permitted to submit a final plan for a portion of such tract and subsequently submit final plans for additional portions of the tract. The preliminary plan shall show provisions made for the satisfactory extension of storm and sanitary sewers, water systems, roadways and sidewalks. The plan commission shall request evidence from school district and park district authorities regarding future needs for schools and parks in the tract before recommending approval of a final plan or part of a tract. 
(f)  Evidence of ownership of the property, in the form of either a copy of a current guaranty policy issued by Chicago Title and Trust Company or a Torrens Certificate, shall be submitted. If the preliminary plan is filed by a person other than the owner of land to be subdivided, a letter of authorization from the owner also must be placed on file with the plan commission before the plan will be considered. 
(g)  The plan commission may require the preliminary plan to be modified and resubmitted before approval. 
(h)  Two copies of the preliminary plan shall be approved and signed by the chairman of the plan commission. If the preliminary plan is rejected, the reasons for rejection shall be stated on the plan and shall be signed by the chairman of the plan commission. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider and the other copy shall be retained by the secretary of the plan commission. 
(i)  The plan commission shall approve or disapprove the application for preliminary approval within 90 days from the date of the application or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent. 
(Code 1959, § 18.5.2A)  
Sec. 66-102. - Floodplain regulation required information and data. 
Accompanying the preliminary plans of each proposed subdivision which involves any portion of a base flood area as described by the official maps of the Village, the following information and data shall be furnished: 
(1)  Contour map. A topographic map, with two-foot interval contours, of the land to be subdivided and such adjoining land whose topography may affect the layout or drainage of the subdivision. On such a map, the following shall be shown: 
a.  The location of streams and other floodwater runoff channels, the extent of their floodplains at the established high water elevations and the limits of the floodway, all properly identified. 
b.  The normal shoreline of lakes, ponds, swamps and detention basins, and the floodplains and lines of inflow and outflow thereof, if any. 
c.  The location of farm drains and the inlets and outlets thereof. 
d.  Storm, sanitary and combined sewers and any sewer outfalls. 
e.  Septic tank systems and outlets, if any. 
f.  Seeps, springs, and flowing and other wells. 
g.  Location of existing structures that will remain. 
h.  One hundred-year flood elevation and limits, including floodway data for that portion of a subdivision or development which is in the base flood area. 
(2)  Channel profiles. Profile drawings of each stream, channel, pond and basin, showing elevations of the following: 
a.  Streambed. 
b.  Channel banks, if any. 
c.  Waterway openings of existing culverts and bridges within and near the tract. 
d.  Size and elevation of sewer and drain outlets into the stream, channel or basin. 
e.  Base flood elevations established by this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.1)  
Secs. 66-103—66-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FINAL 
 
Sec. 66-121. - In general. 
(a)  The final plan to be recorded shall be prepared by a surveyor and shall conform to the requirements of record plats. Final plans shall be submitted to the plan commission for approval not more than one year after the approval of the preliminary plan, and only after the preliminary plan has been approved. If the final plan is not presented within the one-year period, the owner shall present the approved preliminary plan for review, correction and approval by the plan commission before the final plan is presented. 
(b)  The required number of copies of the final plan, the original tracing and the working drawings shall be submitted to the plan commission. 
(c)  The final plan will not be approved until the property has been staked, and field measurements agree with final plan measurements certified to on the final plan by the surveyor. 
(d)  The final plan will be approved only when working drawings acceptable to the plan commission have received approval from all agencies having jurisdiction, including, but not limited to, the metropolitan sanitary district, County or State highway departments, Environmental Protection Agency and North Cook County Soil and Water Conservation District. 
(e)  Working drawings shall be prepared under the supervision of and certified by a registered professional engineer. The working drawings shall be to an appropriate scale, legible and clear, and shall conform with the final plan and requirements for working drawings as described in section 66-232. 
(Code 1959, § 18.5.2B)  
Sec. 66-122. - Approval procedure. 
(a)  When all requirements of this chapter have been met, and the subdivider has deposited, for review of plans and specifications, a cash review fee of one percent of the estimated construction cost of required public improvements and of the estimated cost of rough and final grading as indicated in subsection (e) of this section, the secretary of the plan commission shall submit the final plan and working drawings to the Village engineer for examination. 
(b)  After review, the plan commission may refer the final plan and working drawings back to the subdivider for corrections, additions and changes. When recommended for approval, the secretary of the plan commission will deliver to the board of trustees the subdivider's application, documents and plans, signed by the chairman of the plan commission and Village engineer. When the subdivider has supplied all drawings, maps and other documents required by this chapter, and if all such material meets all of the requirements of this chapter, the corporate authorities shall approve the proposed plat within 60 days from the date of filing the last required document or other papers or within 60 days from the date of filing the first plat, whichever date is later. The subdivider and the corporate authorities may mutually agree to extend the 60-day period. 
(c)  After approval of the board of trustees, the secretary of the plan commission shall cause the final plan to be recorded in the recorder's office of the County; however, in the case of a subdivision in the jurisdictional area, the final plan will be transmitted to the plat officer of the County. 
(d)  If the plan commission recommends disapproval of a subdivision plat or working drawings, the subdivider, within 60 days after recommendation for disapproval, may request the board of trustees, in writing, to review the action of the plan commission. The board of trustees may uphold or reverse the recommendations of the plan commission or it may refer the request back to the plan commission for review. 
(e)  A performance bond, approved by the Village manager, shall be posted only in cash, sufficient to cover estimated construction expenditures of required public improvements and the estimated cost of rough and final grading in accordance with plans submitted to and approved by the Village engineer. The basis for calculating such performance bond shall be as follows: 
(1)  Public improvements. If a contract exists, the amount shall be 100 percent of the contract and ten percent for contingencies. In absence of a contract, the estimate of the subdivider's engineer shall be used, which shall include ten percent for contingencies. 
(2)  Rough and final grading. 
a.  A minimum amount of $500.00 for each 10,000 square feet, or fraction thereof, up to a maximum of $10,000.00 for any one subdivision, to cover the cost of rough and final grading in accordance with plans submitted to and approved by the Village engineer, except that in the case of one lot subdivisions where such subdivisions are surrounded by improved lots or properties and, in the opinion of the plan commission, no useful purpose would be served in the imposition of this requirement, the provisions of all or part of this subsection (e) may be waived. In addition to such amounts, the following percentage of estimated construction, including the amount posted for rough and final grading, to cover the cost of inspection services shall be included: 
1.  All sanitary sewer construction, shall be as provided in section 30-1. 
2.  All other construction costs up to $500,000.00, shall be as provided in Chapter 30-1.3. All other construction costs above $500,000.00, shall be as provided in Chapter 30-1. 
(f)  All public improvement plans, costs and estimates shall be checked and approved by the Village engineer, and all improvements shall be inspected by the Village engineer during and after completion of all construction. The subdivider's engineer, with the approval of the Village engineer, may make alterations and corrections, where required, to conform to existing field conditions. Changes from original plans shall only be approved when accompanied by an adjustment in the cash deposit. Changes, where made, shall be shown on the original working drawings as revisions, and noted "as-built," and signed and sealed by the subdivider's engineer. Before the completed improvements are accepted by the board of trustees, the subdivider shall file one copy of as-built working drawings, together with a duly executed bill of sale, in satisfactory form, granting, transferring and conveying to the Village, with a proper warranty free of any claims or encumbrances, good title to all public improvements, including utilities, street signs and street trees installed by or on behalf of the subdivider in such subdivisions. 
(g)  Payments from the cash escrow account shall be made periodically, upon the certification of the subdivider's engineer, to the contractor constructing the improvement. Upon final payment to the contractor, any remaining balance shall be refunded to the subdivider. 
(Code 1959, § 18.5.2C; Ord. No. 5159, § 2, 11-18-2008)  
Sec. 66-123. - Specifications. 
The final plan to be recorded should be clearly and legibly drawn upon tracing cloth, in black India ink. The final plan and accompanying application for approval shall contain the graphic and descriptive items enumerated in this division. The lack of information under any item specified in this article, or improper information supplied by the applicant, may be cited by the plan commission as cause for disapproval of a final plan. 
(Code 1959, § 18.8.1)  
Sec. 66-124. - Scale. 
The final plan of the subdivision which is to be recorded shall be accurately drawn to an engineering scale approved by the plan commission as being large enough to clearly show the necessary details, and shall include the items set forth in sections 66-125 and 66-126. 
(Code 1959, § 18.8.2A)  
Sec. 66-125. - Title. 
The title shall be neatly and conspicuously drafted, in the lower righthand corner of the sheet, when possible, and shall include the following information, as applicable in each case, in the following order: 
(1)  A list of all blocks, lots, parcels, etc., on the plat. 
(2)  Approved name of the subdivision, and section thereof. 
(3)  Scale and north point of the drawing, and date of completion. 
(4)  Name of the land surveyor who prepared the final plan for record. 
(Code 1959, § 18.8.2B)  
Sec. 66-126. - Required data. 
All boundaries, street lines and lot lines, plus any other lines pertinent to the plan, shall be neatly and clearly shown, together with sufficient data, accurately calculated, so that each line and property corner may be located and reproduced upon the ground. The plan shall show the following items, as applicable in each case: 
(1)  All property boundary lines necessary to identify the subdivision, with the conveyance, or part thereof, by which the owner acquired the property. Where a subdivision includes all or parts of two or more conveyances, the boundaries of such separate deed descriptions shall be indicated by light lines running through the subdivision, together with deed reference to each original tract or parcel. 
(2)  Exact locations, widths and names of all streets within the subdivision, and widths of alleys and walk easements, if any. 
(3)  All easements established or rights-of-way provided for public services or utilities in the subdivision, and any limitations on such easements. 
(4)  Accurate outlines of any areas to be reserved for common use by residents of the subdivision, or dedicated for general public use, or proposed to be acquired by a public body, with the purposes indicated thereon. 
(5)  Accurate bearings and lengths of all blocks and lot lines, together with the length of radii, arcs, tangents and chords, with chord bearings and central angles for all curves in the layout. A curve table containing such data and references to the curves shown on the drawing is required. 
(6)  Accurate location of all monuments, as required by law. 
(7)  Lots, numbered in numerical order. In tracts containing more than one block, the blocks shall be lettered in alphabetical order. If there is a resubdivision of lots in any block, such resubdivided lots shall be numbered consecutively, beginning with the number following the highest lot number in the original block subdivision and the original lot lines shall be dashed and the original lot numbers shall be dotted. 
(8)  Areas of each lot or parcel, shown on a copy of the plat. 
(9)  Front building lines, shown graphically with dimensions, and any other building restriction lines which may apply in a particular case. 
(10)  Tie connections as needed between the adjacent blocks and other subdivisions. 
(11)  Names and locations of adjoining subdivisions, with lot and block numbers immediately adjoining, together with plat references. 
(12)  Location of adjoining unsubdivided property. 
(13)  Key map, showing the location of the subdivision. In case of a large subdivision requiring multiple plats, the key map shall show the location of previously recorded plats within the subdivision, by section number. 
(14)  Surveyor's verification that field and plat measurements are not in conflict. 
(15)  The following signatures and stamps or seals, affixed to the tracing: 
a.  Surveyor's certificate and seal, indicating that plan and field measurements are in agreement. 
b.  Surveyor's certificate and seal regarding the distance from a watercourse serving 640 acres or more. 
c.  Owner, trustee or sponsor. 
d.  Notary. 
e.  County tax seal. 
f.  Recorder of deeds. 
g.  Chairman of the plan commission. 
h.  Village collector. 
i.  Village clerk. 
j.  Village president. 
(Code 1959, § 18.8.2C)  
Secs. 66-127—66-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN STANDARDS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 66-161. - Conformance. 
The subdivision design shall conform to criteria set forth in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(intro. ¶))  
Sec. 66-162. - Street arrangement, extent, width grade and location. 
The arrangement, extent, width, grade and location of streets shall conform to the official plan of the Village, as amended, and shall relate to existing and proposed streets, topography, public convenience and safety, and the appropriate relation to the proposed use of the land to be served by such streets. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(1)) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.  
Sec. 66-163. - Street plan. 
(a)  Streets shall be carried to the boundaries of the subdivision, and connected to existing streets in adjoining subdivisions, or to points where it is proposed to extend the street at a later date. 
(b)  Nonconnecting streets shall end in a cul-de-sac with a maximum length of 500 feet and a minimum turnaround radius as follows: 
(1)  Single-family residential districts. Fifty-five feet, with an inner pavement radius of 23 feet, an outer pavement radius of 49 feet and a pavement width of 26 feet. 
(2)  Multiple-family residential districts. Sixty feet, with an inner pavement radius of 15 feet, an outer pavement radius of 51 feet and a pavement width of 36 feet. 
(3)  Business and industrial districts. Sixty-six feet, with an inner pavement radius of 15 feet, an outer pavement radius of 57 feet and a pavement width of 42 feet. 
(c)  For subdivisions bordering on railroads, a street parallel or approximately parallel to the railroad shall be laid out so that the intersection of its centerline with the centerline of a street which crosses the railroad shall not be less than 150 from the nearest railroad right-of-way line. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(2)) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.  
Sec. 66-164. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Provisions formerly found in § 66-164 have been moved and incorporated into § 34-312. Former § 66-164 pertained to street names and signs and derived from Code 1959, §§ 18.6.1A(3).  
Sec. 66-165. - Right-of-way dedication. 
Each lot in any subdivision shall front upon a public street. Where no such street right-of-way exists or where an existing right-of-way does not conform to the width required by this section, the subdivider shall dedicate right of way in accordance with the following table except for cul-de-sacs which shall be designed in accordance with section 66-163(b): 
Right-of-Way Location 	Required 
Dedication 
Village of Glenview rights-of-way, except as otherwise specified in this section. 	30.0 feet from the centerline. 
Jurisdictional rights-of-way, except as otherwise specified in this section. 	33.0 feet from the centerline. 
Property fronting upon: 
• Wagner Road north of Glenview Road 
• Washington Street south of Central Road 	40.0 feet from the centerline. 
Property fronting upon: 
• Central Road west of Harlem Avenue 
• Chestnut Avenue 
• Dearlove Road 
• East Lake Avenue 
• Glenview Road 
• Golf Road 
• Greenwood Avenue 
• Harlem Avenue 
• Harms Road 
• Landwehr Road 
• Lehigh Avenue 
• Milwaukee Avenue 
• Pfingsten Road north of East Lake Avenue 
• Sanders Road 
• Shermer Avenue 
• Sunset Ridge Road 
• Waukegan Road 
• West Lake Avenue west of Patriot Boulevard 
• Willow Road 
• Willow Road 
• Winnetka Road 	50.0 feet from the centerline. 
 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(4); Ord. No. 4542, §§ 2,3, 7-15-2003; Ord. No. 5773, § 2, 3-4-2014)  
Sec. 66-166. - Marginal access streets. 
Where a residential or neighborhood business area abuts a major street, the plan commission may require marginal access streets, or double frontage lots with screen planting or screen fencing. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(5))  
Sec. 66-167. - Private streets. 
Private streets shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(7))  
Sec. 66-168. - Half streets. 
Half streets shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(7))  
Sec. 66-169. - Alleys. 
Alleys shall only be provided in commercial, multiple-family and industrial districts for service access, off-street loading and unloading, and access to parking. The minimum width of the alley shall be 20 feet. Dead-end alleys shall be avoided, but if unavoidable, shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities at the end. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(8))  
Sec. 66-170. - Easements. 
Easements not less than six feet wide in the Village and ten feet wide within the jurisdictional area shall be provided on all lots for any or all public utilities, and sewer and water lines. The easements shall be laid out to provide proper continuity for such utilities or surface water flow from block to block. If lands are dedicated or easements given for private use, the plat shall designate the beneficiaries of such use and the nature thereof. Pedestrian easements shall have a minimum width of ten feet and have a concrete sidewalk installed in compliance with the requirements of the Village specification standards for public improvements. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(9))  
Sec. 66-171. - Blocks. 
Maximum residential block length shall be 1,320 feet. Blocks in commercial and industrial areas shall bear a reasonable relation to the use of the land as determined by the plan commission. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(10))  
Sec. 66-172. - Lots. 
(a)  All lot lines shall be shown on the plat. All lots and blocks shall be numbered. Lots shall be designed so that the side lines of all lots are approximately perpendicular to the street line. No lot shall be platted with frontage on two parallel or converging streets, except corner lots, which shall be platted so required side yard provisions of chapter 98, zoning, may be observed. 
(b)  All lots shall have frontage on a public street, or private street if such private street is approved as a waiver to this chapter, and be oriented so as to be provided frontage on such street. The creation of lots oriented in a front to rear, front to side or rear to rear pattern (generally described as a flag lot or a lot with no street frontage) shall be prohibited. Lots which shall have access to a street solely across another property or through any portion of such property by means of an easement shall also be prohibited. However, the formal subdivision of parcels configured in the patterns otherwise prohibited by the requirements of this subsection shall be permitted if the ownership of such parcel has been held separately by another unrelated person or entity from that of any adjoining parcel at all times since the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(c)  Double frontage lots may be permitted where one such frontage would be on a major street or County thoroughfare. In such a development, access to the double frontage lot shall be by an interior street and shall not be permitted from the major thoroughfare. The subdivider of such a lot shall provide screening or fencing to prevent automobile access to the lot from the major thoroughfare. The screening or fencing shall consist of a fence of one color or a densely planted compact hedge, not less than four feet in height. 
(d)  All lots shall be rough and final graded to provide side lot line and rear lot line surface drainage with detrimental effect to property proposed for subdivision or property adjacent thereto. It shall be the subdivider's responsibility to establish and conform to such grades as shown and approved on the working drawings. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(11))  
Sec. 66-173. - Lot areas. 
(a)  The plan commission will not consider a plat of a subdivision unless the lot areas conform to the requirements of the zoning district in which the development is located and to the area requirements of this section. 
(b)  The subdivider shall show the area of all lots in the development in square feet on one print of the final plat. Any existing building in the subdivision shall be shown on one copy of the plat, dimensioned as to size and location from lot lines and certified as to accuracy by a surveyor. 
(c)  Lots on curved streets of a radius of 200 or less shall have a minimum width at the street line of 40 feet. Lot areas, widths and frontages within the Village shall conform to chapter 98, zoning, as well as to the provisions of this section. Lot areas, widths and frontages in the jurisdictional area shall conform to the minimum requirements of the County zoning ordinance. 
(d)  Subdivisions in a multiple-family district shall have lots with a minimum area of 6,250 square feet and a maximum area of two acres. Each lot must abut a public right-of-way. 
(e)  Subdivisions in an industrial district shall have a minimum lot area of one acre and each lot shall abut a public right-of-way. 
(f)  Subdivisions in a commercial district shall have lots with a minimum width of 60 feet and a minimum depth of 100 feet. 
(Code 1959, § 18.6.1A(12))  
Secs. 66-174—66-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FLOODPLAINS 
 
Sec. 66-191. - In general. 
(a)  The rules set forth in this division shall govern the design of land improvements with respect to floods. 
(b)  All proposed subdivision and other developments within the base flood area shall be reviewed to assure that: 
(1)  The proposed developments are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; 
(2)  All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, are located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage; and 
(3)  Adequate drainage is provided. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(intro. ¶, (a))  
Sec. 66-192. - Location and layout of streets, blocks, depths of lots, parks and other public grounds. 
Streets, blocks, depths of lots, parks and other public grounds shall be located and laid out in such a manner as to preserve and utilize natural streams, channels and detention basins. Wherever possible, the larger streams and floodplains shall be included within parks or other public grounds. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(b)) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.  
Sec. 66-193. - Streets. 
Streets shall be designed so that the elevation of the finished surface at any point on the centerline of any new street constructed within a floodplain shall not be less than the flood base elevation for such floodplain. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(c)) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.  
Sec. 66-194. - Utilities. 
Underground utilities, such as stormwater sewers, sanitary sewers and water mains, shall be constructed in solid, compacted earth and located so as to minimize damage from a potential flood in the floodplain. The design and construction of such utilities are subject to the approval of the Village engineer in accordance with sound engineering practice. Sanitary manholes constructed within floodplain areas shall have rim elevations 12 inches above the flood base elevation or must be provided with watertight, lock-type covers. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(d)) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 82.  
Sec. 66-195. - Channel straightening. 
Sharply meandering streams or channels may be partially straightened and minor changes made in other channels, subject to the approval of the plan commission, provided that: 
(1)  The hydraulic capacity of the floodway is maintained; 
(2)  The volume of floodwater storage outside the floodway is not reduced; 
(3)  Provision is made to stabilize the banks of the modified channel to control erosion; and 
(4)  Any additional permits for the work that are required by the State department of transportation and the Corps of Engineers are obtained. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(e))  
Sec. 66-196. - Lots in base flood area. 
Land lying wholly or partially in the base flood area may be laid out and platted as building lots or parcels, provided, a building site not lower than the base flood elevation, plus one foot: 
(1)  Exists on the high part of the lot or parcel; 
(2)  Will be built up during execution of the subdivision improvement plan through general excavation or filling; or 
(3)  Can be provided with excavation taken from within the area of the lot or parcel. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(f))  
Sec. 66-197. - Compensatory filling. 
Such filling as may be required or permitted by this chapter for a building site or as may otherwise be done in a floodplain shall be compensated for and balanced by at least an equal volume of excavation taken from below the high water elevation. In the case of streams and channels, such excavation shall be made opposite or immediately adjacent to the areas so filled or occupied and shall be constructed to drain freely and openly to the watercourse. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(g))  
Sec. 66-198. - Drainageways. 
Whenever the plans call for the passage and/or storage of surface runoff or excess stormwater on lots, the grading of all such lots shall be prescribed and established as part of the subdivision plat. The areas designated for the passage and/or storage of such waters shall not be obstructed. The limits of the high water levels resulting from the passage and/or storage of surface runoff or excess stormwater on lots shall be recorded on the plat of record and shall be covered by an easement. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.2(h))  
Secs. 66-199—66-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 66-231. - Water supply and sanitary sewer systems located in the floodplain. 
The design of water supply and sanitary sewer systems to be located in the floodplain shall minimize or eliminate the discharges from the system into the floodwaters and infiltration of floodwaters into the system. On-site waste disposal systems shall be located so as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from them during or subsequent to flooding. 
(Code 1959, § 18.7.3) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 82.  
Sec. 66-232. - Working drawings. 
The working drawing submission, conforming to specification standards adopted by the board of trustees in the Village engineering standards, shall include the items listed and described in sections 66-233—66-239. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.14735, § 2, 1-4-2005)  
Sec. 66-233. - Sanitary sewer system. 
(a)  A sanitary sewer system shall be constructed throughout the entire subdivision in a manner to provide each lot with a separate connection and extended to the ends of platted streets, alleys or utility easements that contain sanitary sewers. All plans must be approved and a permit issued by the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago after approval of the plans by the plan commission. 
(b)  Working drawings shall show surface and flow line grades of all new sewer lines, and an invert grade and size of the line to which connection is to be made. 
(c)  Sanitary sewer plans will not be approved unless it is shown that the existing sewer system has the capacity to meet the demands of the proposed increased flow to a point of discharge into a metropolitan sanitary district interceptor and it is sized and graded to serve areas beyond the subdivision that could be served by extension of the proposed system. A lift station must be provided by the subdivider if minimum flow velocity in the new sewer cannot be maintained. 
(d)  A stormwater sewer system shall be constructed for each development which is separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system. The specifics of the design of the stormwater sewer system are to be in accordance with the requirements set forth in the Village engineering standards. 
(e)  Drainage ditches used as an integral part of a development's stormwater conveyance system shall not be permitted in any subdivision. 
(f)  A stormwater retention basin, which has been sized in accordance with the metropolitan sanitary district (MSD) design requirements for stormwater retention, must be provided for all developments, redevelopments or improvements to existing facilities, regardless of the development's acreage. The metropolitan sanitary district design requirements are to be modified by specific basin design criteria as set forth in the Village engineering standards. 
(g)  Working drawings shall show final grades, including rear and side yard grades, designed to facilitate the flow of surface water toward a collector without detrimental effect to property proposed for subdivision or property adjacent thereto. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.2; Ord. No. 4735, § 3, 1-4-2005) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 82.  
Sec. 66-234. - Water distribution system. 
A water distribution system shall be constructed throughout the subdivision in such a manner as to provide each lot with a separate connection. Water mains shall extend to the extremities of streets, alleys or easements which are served by water mains. The system shall be designed and constructed in conformance with the requirements of the State department of public health and its regulations. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.3)  
Sec. 66-235. - Street paving. 
(a)  Generally. All street paving, including concrete curbs, gutters and sidewalks, shall be constructed throughout the subdivision. All public sidewalks shall be located on public rights-of-way not more than one foot from the abutting property line. Paved vehicular surfaces in streets may be bituminous or concrete. Curbs, alley surfaces and sidewalks shall be concrete. 
(b)  New paving. If a portion of a street in any block or an adjoining area is already improved with a type of paving superior to or of greater width than the minimum standards adopted by the board of trustees, the new paving shall be constructed in the same manner and to the same width as the portions already improved. 
(c)  Widths. 
(1)  Paving in residential streets shall have a minimum width of 26 feet. 
(2)  Paving in the multifamily districts shall have a paving width of not less than 42 feet. 
(3)  Paving in business or industrial districts shall have a paving width of not less than 42 feet. 
(d)  Concrete walks. Concrete walks shall have a width of five feet. 
(e)  Plans. Plans for all paving shall be shown on a separate sheet, with elevations indicated for the tops of the curb. The plans shall show the proposed top of foundation elevations of all main buildings. 
(f)  Alleys. When alleys are approved, they shall have a paving width of 18 feet. 
(g)  Driveways. 
(1)  Driveways shall be permitted to be constructed in accordance with specifications adopted by the development department. The maximum allowable width of a driveway shall be as follows: 
a.  Commercial. Forty-one feet at the curb line. 
b.  Residential. Thirty feet at the curb line. 
(2)  If the driveway is constructed with impermeable materials, the area of the driveway shall be included in any lot coverage calculations which are required by code. 
(3)  In single-family residential zoning districts, one driveway curb cut per lot shall be permitted; provided, however, that a second curb cut may be permitted under the following circumstances: 
a.  A minimum of a 75-foot lot line. 
b.  A minimum setback of 45 feet for the principal structure on the lot. 
c.  No second curb cut may be located within 20 feet of an intersection. 
(4)  Where a property owner requests a second curb cut, but does not meet the criteria listed in subsection (f)(3) of this section, a written appeal shall be filed with the plan commission. Within 30 days of the filing of such an appeal, the plan commission shall consider the request and may, with the concurring vote of four members, approve the request for a second curb cut. In so doing, the plan commission shall consider the impact of the proposed additional driveway on the impermeable surface area of the lot, the availability of off-site parking on the street, the proximity of other driveways on the street, the hardship, if any, necessitating the request for the driveway and other applicable safety factors or special circumstances. 
(5)  Where the plan commission denies the request for a second curb cut, the decision may be appealed to the board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.4) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.  
Sec. 66-236. - Planting trees. 
(a)  Trees are required to be planted in the public parkways. Each subdivider shall deposit, in cash, only an amount sufficient to cover the estimated cost of planting trees in the public parkways. 
(b)  A minimum of one tree per lot shall be planted in the parkway strips along both sides of all streets where a public parkway exists. Trees shall be planted not less than 30 feet apart, but not in excess of 60 feet apart. Trees shall be indicated on construction drawings by an appropriate note. 
(c)  The Director of Public Works shall annually establish a tree planting cost, which shall include a ten percent surcharge over the actual tree price for overhead costs. The actual tree price shall be calculated based on the anticipated cost in the year the trees are expected to be planted. The Director of Public Works shall be responsible for determining the species to be planted, the size and diameter of the trees and the spacing of the trees. The acquisition and planting of the trees shall be the responsibility of the public works department, and shall be paid by the cash deposit of the subdivider and shall occur within one year from the date on which a certificate of occupancy is issued. Funds in excess of the tree planting cost shall be returned to the subdivider following the planting of the trees. 
(d)  Application of this section may be waived by the Director of Public Works upon a showing by the subdivider that he plans to plant parkway trees which exceed the quality and number of trees which would be planted by the public works department. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.5; Ord. No. 5883, § 2, 1-6-2015) 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 86.  
Sec. 66-237. - Profiles. 
Profiles shall be clearly drawn for all sewer lines, water lines and paving, and pertinent elevations from such profiles shall be shown on the respective plans. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.6)  
Sec. 66-238. - Specifications. 
Specifications for all work shall be the specifications adopted by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.7)  
Sec. 66-239. - Electric service and telephone lines. 
Electric service and telephone lines shall be provided in all subdivisions. The subdivider shall provide for proper easements for such services and shall obtain approval, in writing, from the proper authorities. Where feasible, electric and telephone utilities shall be constructed belowground. 
(Code 1959, § 18.9.8)  
Secs. 66-240—66-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[2]

Secs. 66-273—66-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DEDICATION OF LAND FOR PARKS AND SCHOOLS 
 
Sec. 66-291. - Land dedication required. 
(a)  Condition of approval of a final plat of a subdivision or final plat of a planned development. As a condition of approval of a final plat of a subdivision of one or more lots or a final plat of a planned development or any other subdivision development of one or more lots or units, intended to be used entirely or in part for residential purposes, the applicant, as subdivider and/or developer thereof, shall be required to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes and land for school sites to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the subdivision, or to provide payment of a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or to provide a combination of both land and cash contributions, at the option of the Village Board of trustees in accordance with the criteria of this division. 
(b)  Timing. The actual dedication of lands for park and/or school purposes shall be made by the applicant as subdivider and/or developer to the Village upon final subdivision plat approval and recordation via a title transfer to the appropriate bodies and prior to any construction permit application or permit approvals for such subdivision in accordance with sections 66-303 and 66-304. In no case shall an occupancy permit be issued by the Village for the affected subdivision unless and until the land dedication is made. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.1; Ord. No. 4364, § 2, 2-5-2002) 
_____

The table of estimated ultimate population per dwelling unit, as set forth in the following table, shall be used as provided in this section to calculate the amount of required dedication of land acreage for park and recreational, and school site purposes and/or for cash contributions in lieu thereof, unless a written objection thereto is filed by the applicant with the Village manager or his designate pursuant to subsection (c) of this section.
