(b)  Provision of site data. The applicant shall provide consistent data on the number of residential units and bedrooms for the proposed subdivision during the final subdivision approval and permit application process. The applicant shall also submit as part of the subdivision application process, population projections, together with the resulting calculations for land dedication and/or cash contributions for the proposed subdivision. 
(c)  Objections. If the applicant files a written objection with the Village manager or his designate to the use of the population density formula in the table set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the applicant shall submit, at the applicant's sole expense, a comprehensive demographic study showing the estimated population to be generated by the proposed subdivision to the Village manager or his designate. The board of trustees shall make the final determination as to the density formula and estimated population that shall apply to the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.2)  
Sec. 66-293. - Park and recreational site land dedication requirements. 
(a)  Calculation of amount. The amount of land required to be dedicated for park and recreational purposes for a proposed subdivision shall be a direct function of the ultimate population density of the subdivision. The requirement shall be based on a standard of five acres of land per 1,000 ultimate population, computed in accordance with section 66-292. 
(b)  Location. The location of land to be dedicated for park and recreational purposes for the proposed subdivision shall be determined by the board of trustees, in cooperation with the Village park district board, and shall be located within the Village corporate limits. The Village comprehensive plan and the park district comprehensive plan shall both be used as guidelines for locating the park sites, the acreage of the park sites, as well as the type or classification of the park. Additional factors utilized to determine the suitability of park locations shall include, but not be limited to, the: 
(1)  Availability of land; 
(2)  Suitability of the land for park and recreational purposes; 
(3)  Location of the land relative to population concentrations; and 
(4)  Proximity of the land to other parks and recreational land. 
(c)  Minimum size. The minimum size of any land to be dedicated for park and recreational purposes shall be two acres (87,120 square feet), and no dimension shall be less than 100 feet; provided, however, that the board of trustees may approve dedications of a smaller size or dimension when required by the specific plans of the proposed subdivision and when the usefulness of the smaller area for park and recreational purposes is clearly demonstrated. 
(d)  Stormwater detention and retention areas. No stormwater detention or retention area shall qualify as land suitable for dedication for park and recreational purposes, unless the suitability of such land for park and recreational purposes as a secondary use is clearly demonstrated to the satisfaction of the board of trustees and the Village park district board. 
(e)  Private open space and recreational area credit. 
(1)  When applicants, as subdividers or developers, provide their own open space for recreation areas and facilities, it may have the effect of reducing the demand for local public recreational services. 
(2)  Depending on the size of the development, a portion of the park and recreation area in subdivisions or planned unit developments may, at the option of the Village Board, be provided in the form of private open space in lieu of dedicated public open space. The extent thereof shall be determined by the Village Board, based upon the needs of the projected residents and in conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area. 
(3)  In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of recreational facilities, including equipment, by the developer as part of his obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of facilities to be installed, must be approved by the Village, and, before any credit is given for private recreation areas, the subdivider or developer must guarantee that the private recreation areas will be permanently maintained for such use by the execution of the appropriate legal documents. Private swimming clubs are included in this provision. When an adjustment for private recreation areas is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total park land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be given. 
(Code 1959, § 18.3.3)  
Sec. 66-294. - School site land dedication. 
(a)  Calculation of amount. 
(1)  The amount of land required to be dedicated for school sites for a proposed subdivision shall be a direct function of the ultimate number of students to be generated by the subdivision. The school site land dedication requirement shall be determined in accordance with the following equation: 
The number of children from the proposed subdivision to be served in each school classification (computed in accordance with the table set forth in section 66-292. 
Divided by: 
The maximum number of students to be served in each such school classification (as stated in subsection (b) of this section) 
Multiplied by: 
The minimum number of acres for each school site for each such school classification (as stated in subsection (b) of this section) 
(2)  The product of such calculation shall be the minimum acreage of land necessary for school sites to serve the children in the proposed subdivision. 
_____
(b)  School classifications and required minimum size. School classifications and the required minimum size of new school sites within the Village shall be determined in accordance with the following criteria: 
School Classification by Grades 	Maximum Number of Students For Each School Classification 	Minimum Number of Acres of Land Per Site For Each Classification

Junior high schools 
Grades 7—8 	  900 	29 
High schools 
Grades 9—12 	2,300 	55 
 
(c)  Location. The location of each school site shall be determined by the board of trustees, in cooperation with the affected school district board, and shall be located within the Village corporate limits. The Village comprehensive plan and the standards adopted by the affected school district shall be used as guidelines in locating school sites. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.4) 
_____ 
Sec. 66-295. - Cash contribution in lieu of park and school land dedication. 
(a)  General qualification. If a proposed subdivision is small and the resulting required land dedication is too small, in the determination of the board of trustees, or when the board of trustees finds that the available land is inappropriate for park and recreational purposes or for a school site, then the Village shall have the authority to require the applicant to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the otherwise required land dedications, in accordance with the standards of this section. 
(b)  Fair market value determination. The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land in the proposed subdivision, as determined by the board of trustees based on the value of improved land in and surrounding the Village. The fair market value figure shall be set forth in the Village's annual fee ordinance and shall be used in making any calculation required by this section, unless the applicant or other affected party files an objection pursuant to subsection (c) of this section. The Village manager or his designate shall periodically, but no less frequently than annually, survey surrounding communities, conduct discussions with the applicable township assessor's office, affected school districts and other interested parties, and shall report findings of such surveys and communications to the board of trustees with respect to the continued adequacy and reasonableness of the Village's determination of fair market value as set forth in the annual fee ordinance. 
(c)  Improved land. For the purposes of this section, the term "improved land" means a parcel or lot which has prepared for development by grading, draining or installing public utilities or improvements, such as a sanitary sewer, drainage conveyance system, stormwater detention/retention or compensatory storage area, water main, street, parkway, parkway trees, sidewalk or other facility. Such improvements may be on-site or off-site. 
(d)  Objection to fair market value determination. If the applicant or any other affected person files a written objection with the Village manager or his designate to the fair market value as established pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, and as set forth in the annual fee ordinance, the applicant or other affected person shall submit, at their sole cost and expense, a certified appraisal, professionally prepared by a member of the Appraisal Institute of America (MAI). The appraisal shall show the fair market value of improved land in the area of the proposed subdivision. Upon receipt of such objection, the Village manager or his designate shall cause the objection to be delivered to the Village park district and/or the applicable school district, and the affected district shall have the right, but not the obligation, within 30 days after receipt of the objection by the Village manager or his designate, to make a recommendation regarding the disposition of such objection. The board of trustees shall make the final determination as to the fair market value of such improved land, which final determination shall be based on the appraisal or other information submitted by the applicant, the recommendations, if any, received from the Village park district and the applicable school district, and all other facts and circumstances relevant to the issue as determined and required by the board of trustees. All costs incurred by the Village in the consideration of the objection to the fair market value determination shall be paid by the applicant prior to the issuance of the first building permit of the subdivision. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as limiting or preventing the board of trustees from utilizing the fair market value as established in subsection (b) of this section for any proposed subdivision. 
(e)  Disposition. 
(1)  Cash contributions to benefit parks and schools in lieu of land dedication shall be made to the appropriate school district and/or the Village park district by the applicant at the time of the permit application for residential construction. In no case shall any occupancy permits be issued for the affected subdivision/planned development plat unless or until the cash contribution is made and proof thereof is provided to the Village. 
(2)  Cash contributions in lieu of park land dedication shall be used by the Village park district solely for use in the acquisition, expansion or development of park and recreational land and facilities in the Village park district neighborhood, community or urban parks, to serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of the proposed subdivision, and shall not be used for general capital improvements to such district. 
(3)  Cash contributions in lieu of school site land dedications shall be used by the applicable school district solely for use in the acquisition of land for a school site to serve the immediate or future needs of students from the proposed subdivision or the improvement or expansion to any existing school site already serving such needs and shall not be used for general capital improvements to such district. 
(f)  Refunds. If any portion of a cash contribution in lieu of a park land dedication or a cash contribution in lieu of a school site land dedication, as the case may be, is not expended for the purposes set forth in this section within ten years after the date of receipt of such contribution by the appropriate school or park district, then the cash contribution shall be refunded to the applicant who made such contribution, or the applicant's successor or assign. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.5)  
Sec. 66-296. - Combination of land dedication and cash contribution in lieu of land dedication. 
A combination of land dedication and cash contribution in lieu of land dedication may be required, when appropriate, as determined by the board of trustees, including, without limitation, when: 
(1)  Inadequate land. The proposed subdivision has some, but not enough, adequate land to meet the dedication requirements of this division. The portion of the land within the proposed subdivision that is adequate for park land or a school site shall be dedicated as provided in this division, and a cash contribution shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be dedicated pursuant to this division. 
(2)  Previous acquisition. A major part of the local park or recreational site, or school site already has been acquired and only a small parcel of land is needed from the proposed subdivision to complete the site. Such parcel shall be acquired by dedication, and a cash contribution shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be dedicated pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.6)  
Sec. 66-297. - Reservation of additional land. 
When the Village comprehensive plan or other applicable standard of the Village requires a larger amount of park and recreational land or a larger school site in a particular subdivision than the applicant is otherwise required to dedicate pursuant to the terms of this division, the land needed in excess of the otherwise required dedication shall then be reserved by the applicant for subsequent purchase by the Village or applicable other public body, provided that such acquisition is started within one year after the date of approval of the final plat for the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.7)  
Sec. 66-298. - Combining with adjoining subdivisions. 
For proposed subdivisions of 40 acres or less, the otherwise applicable park and recreational land dedication or school site land dedication may be combined, where practical, as determined by the board of trustees, with dedications for the same purposes from adjoining subdivisions or developments to produce usable parks or recreational areas, or school sites. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.8)  
Sec. 66-299. - Topography and grading. 
The slope, topography and geology of a site to be dedicated pursuant to the requirements of this division, as well as its surroundings, shall be suitable for the intended purpose of the site. Grading on dedicated land shall not differ greatly from surrounding land. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.9)  
Sec. 66-300. - Improved sites. 
All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of electrical, telecommunications, gas, water, sewer and streets, including curb and gutter, and enclosed drainage, as applicable to the location of the site, or acceptable provisions shall be made therefor. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.10)  
Sec. 66-301. - Condition of annexation. 
Unless waived by the board of trustees, in its sole and absolute discretion, the dedication of land or cash contributions in lieu thereof, required by this division, also shall be required as a condition of the annexation of any land to the Village for residential purposes. However, such dedications or payments shall not be required as a condition of an amendment to an annexation agreement unless the board of trustees finds, from a consideration of the purposes of this division, that such dedications or payments should be required because of increased burdens to be placed on schools and the park system over and above those covered by the dedications and cash contributions made or provided for in connection with the original annexation agreement. If the board of trustees makes such finding, then additional dedications or cash contributions shall be required, but only to the extent necessary to cover the shortage resulting from such increased burdens. Dedications of land or cash contributions in lieu thereof as specified in any annexation agreement that substantially complies with the requirements of this division shall be deemed to have fulfilled the dedication requirements of this division. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.11)  
Sec. 66-302. - Dedication as condition of approval of final plat. 
Approval of any final plat of a subdivision or planned development plat shall be conditioned on the dedication of land or cash contribution in lieu thereof, as required by this division. When a subdivision is to be developed over a period of years, dedication of required land may be made after completion of a portion of the subdivision, provided that an escrow fund, satisfactory to the Village, has been established to guarantee the conveyance of land after completion of such portion of the subdivision. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.12)  
Sec. 66-303. - Title to dedicated park land and school sites. 
(a)  General requirement. All sites to be dedicated pursuant to this division shall be conveyed to the Village either by warranty or trustee's deed, or such form of conveyance as the Village shall require. The applicant shall be responsible for payment of all real estate taxes to the date of conveyance, including any agricultural rollback taxes that might be extended or levied against such sites. In the discretion of the Village, a commitment for title insurance, issued by a company authorized to do business in the State, will be required as evidence of clear title. 
(b)  Park land. Conveyance of park land dedications shall occur only after or simultaneously with the passage of an ordinance or resolution by the Village park district, or by the Village if the subdivision is not located within the Village park district, in which it indicates that the land will be accepted by the park district or the Village, as the case may be, for park purposes. If the land is in the park district, then immediately after the adoption of the park district resolution or ordinance, the Village shall convey the land to the park district. 
(c)  School sites. Conveyance of school sites shall occur only after or simultaneously with the passage of an ordinance or resolution by the school district in which the subdivision is located, in which the district indicates that the site will be accepted by the district for school purposes. Immediately thereafter, the Village shall convey the site to the district. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.13)  
Sec. 66-304. - Intergovernmental agreement. 
The Village park district and the affected school districts shall be required, as a condition of receiving the dedications or donations under this division, to enter into a binding, written intergovernmental agreement with the Village, acceptable in form and content by the Village attorney, providing for the indemnification and holding harmless of the Village from any loss, claim and cause of action of every kind that may be incurred by the Village as a result, either directly or indirectly, of the enactment of the ordinance from which this division is derived, or the administration or enforcement thereof, including any loss, claim or cause of action incurred as a result of a lawsuit brought or threatened against the Village park district or the affected school district. The intergovernmental agreement shall provide that if the Village is sued by any applicant, subdivider or developer as a result, directly or indirectly, of the enactment of the ordinance from which this division is derived, the Village may, at its option, undertake the defense, and the Village's costs and expenses related thereto, including attorneys' fees, shall be immediately reimbursed by the Village park district and/or affected school district, as the case may be. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.14)  
Sec. 66-305. - Waiver of requirement. 
The dedication of land or cash contribution in lieu thereof as required by this division shall be applicable unless the board of trustees determines either that such new subdivision will not in itself have an impact upon or create a need for new school and/or park facilities and that any such need is not uniquely attributable to such new subdivision. The determination by the Village Board shall be binding upon all of the parties involved. 
(Code 1959, § 18.13.15)  
DIVISION 4. - RESIDENTIAL INFILL CONSTRUCTION 
 
Sec. 66-306. - Purpose and scope; definitions. 
(a)  The purpose of these Infill Construction regulations is to provide minimum standards to insure the public health, safety, and welfare in so far as they are affected by Infill Construction projects and shall be in addition to, and not a substitute for, any and all other applicable regulations contained in The Building Code. These Infill Construction regulations shall control all matters concerning construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, and excavation activities on Infill Construction Sites. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Infill Construction shall mean shall mean any construction that will cause, or result in, a change in the grade, or an increase in the impervious surface coverage, of an area that is either (i) located within a Residential Zoning District or (ii) located adjacent to a lot or parcel of land that is either (a) within a Residential Zoning District or (b) lawfully used for residential purposes. 
(2)  Infill Construction Site shall mean any lot or parcel of land, or portion thereof, upon which Infill Construction is to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 5094, § 2, 4-15-2008)  
Sec. 66-307. - Drainage and grading of lots; earth moving. 
(a)  No person shall, by changing the natural or existing grade of any lot, tract or parcel of land, alter or obstruct, partially or otherwise, the flow of natural drainage in a manner which wholly or partially obstructs the natural or usual flow of surface or subsurface waters, or which causes or contributes, or tends to contribute to temporary or permanent pooling, ponding or collection of waters upon the property of another, or which concentrates or intensifies the discharge of surface water upon the property of another; provided, however, that changes in the natural grade which would otherwise have the effect prohibited hereinabove, may be permitted if the person making such change shall drain said waters by drain pipe to a connection with a Village storm sewer or in any other manner as may be approved by the Village engineer or their designee. 
(1)  Existing drainage nuisance: Any surface or roof drainage which creates a structural or health hazard, or any other nuisance, to the owners or occupants of adjoining premises, or to the public thoroughfare, shall be abated by the owner of the improperly drained area. Drainage shall be disposed of in a manner approved by the Village engineer or their designee. 
(b)  The applicant for a building permit (the "applicant") involving new construction shall certify to the director of development or their designee on a form provided by the director or designee that the landscape plan for the new construction was developed with cognizance and in consideration of drainage and grading regulations of the Village. The certification shall also apply to persons involved in major landscaping (any landscaping which would require application for and issuance of a grading permit). If the design of the proposed landscaping improvements leads to a change in the grade of a lot, approved drainage must be provided by way of the installation of drain pipe, or other appropriate means. 
(c)  Earth moving. It shall be unlawful to move earth by creating any excavations, cuts, filling, or otherwise, which, singly or in combination: 
(1)  Cumulatively, alters the existing natural grade by more than four inches in vertical height; or 
(2)  Alters any storm water conveyance system; or 
(3)  Cumulatively, covers more than 400 square feet in area, without first filing with the development department an application in writing and obtaining a grading permit therefore from said department. 
(d)  Required plans. No permit for earth moving shall be issued unless and until an application therefore shall be submitted to the development department and approved by the Village engineer. An application for a grading permit shall contain the following: 
(1)  Grading plan. A grading plan drawn to scale, with all dimensions figured, showing accurately the size and exact location of any contemplated excavation, cut or fill, including topographic detail to a level satisfactory to the Village engineer. 
(2)  Drainage plan. A drainage plan showing methods and facilities for the control and discharge of storm water, in such detail as determined satisfactory to the Village engineer. 
(3)  Least natural disruption. Facts demonstrating that the proposed earth moving plan, when compared to possible alternative plans which would serve the same function, shall result in the most natural appearance and the least possible disruption of natural terrain and water courses, to a level satisfactory to the Village engineer. 
(e)  The property owner or permit applicant for any building addition where the net impervious surface increases more than a net 400 square feet or any new single family residence, shall engage the design civil engineer to visit the site after the completion of construction, and prepare and submit to the Village an as-built plan showing the features listed in subsections 66-307(d)(1) and (2) of this chapter as they were actually constructed. The final certificate of occupancy for any building addition where the net impervious surface increases more than a net 400 square feet or any new single family home shall not be approved until the as-built plan is received and approved. 
(f)  Environmental and safety precautions. All persons performing any earth work under a grading permit shall put into effect all necessary safety precautions to minimize erosion, protect any watercourses and other natural features including trees, protect the health and welfare of all persons, and protect private and public property from damage of any kind, per the Engineering Standards Manual, latest revision. 
(g)  Conditions on permit. The director of development or their designee and/or the Village engineer may place such conditions on the time limits, drainage controls, safety measures, and necessary site restoration associated with a grading permit as will ensure compliance with paragraph (e) above. 
(h)  Persons responsible. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section, and any owner of the property upon which violations occur who has suffered or permitted such violations, shall be liable therefore, and shall be held subject to the remedies and penalties provided for violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 5094, § 2, 4-15-2008; Ord. No. 5468, § 2, 6-21-2011)  
Sec. 66-308. - Infill construction storm water management. 
(a)  In addition to the requirements set forth in section 66-307 of this chapter, no work requiring a permit under the Building Code shall be issued for any infill construction on any Infill Construction Site without the applicant first submitting an Infill Construction Site grading and drainage plan for review and approval by the director of development or their designee. 
(b)  The grading and drainage plan submitted pursuant to subsection 66-308(a) of this chapter shall provide sufficient detail and information for storm water management on the Infill Construction Site based upon the following standards: 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection 66-308(b)(5), where the cumulative net increase in impervious surface on the Infill Construction Site is less than 400 square feet in area, the applicant shall construct and install, or cause to be constructed and installed, downspouts, yard drains, and driveway drains with unobstructed pathways to an existing storm water conveyance system located in the immediate vicinity of the Infill Construction Site. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection 66-308(b)(5), where the cumulative net increase in impervious surface on the Infill Construction Site is more than 400 square feet in area, and, in the determination of the Village engineer, an existing storm water conveyance system with available capacity is located in the immediate vicinity of the Infill Construction Site, the applicant shall construct and install, or cause to be constructed and installed, storm water drainage pipes and all related appurtenances on the Infill Construction Site and directly connect such pipes and appurtenances, including existing sump pump discharges altered as a result of the proposed improvements, to the storm water conveyance system, as required by subsection 66-308(c). 
(3)  Where the cumulative net increase in impervious surface on the Infill Construction Site is more than 400 square feet in area, and, in the determination of the Village engineer, no storm water conveyance system with available capacity is located in the immediate vicinity of the Infill Construction Site, the applicant shall construct and install, or cause to be constructed and installed, all necessary storm water management systems on the Infill Construction Site, including, without limitation, construction to off-site storm water conveyance and/or detention facilities and all related appurtenances, as required by subsection 66-308(c). No off-site improvements exceeding 200 feet from any property line shall be required. 
(4)  Any applicant required to construct and install off-site storm water management systems pursuant to subparagraph 66-308(b)(3) may apply for recapture fees related to the construction and installation of such off-site storm water management systems upon review and approval by the Village Board. 
(5)  The construction and installation requirements in subsections 66-308(b)(1) and (b)(2) shall not apply to infill construction that consists solely of the repair or expansion of an existing, or installation of a new, sidewalk, patio or driveway that will cause, or result in, a net cumulative increase in impervious surface on the Infill Construction Site of less than 400 square feet in area, provided that there are, or will be upon completion of construction, unobstructed pathways to an existing storm water conveyance system that is located in the immediate vicinity of the Infill Construction Site. 
(c)  Any and all construction and connections required pursuant to subsection 66-308(b) that are located on public property, will become public property, or will connect to off-site public infrastructure shall be approved in advance by, and performed to the satisfaction of, the Village engineer. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section 66-308, in no event shall the grade of an Infill Construction Site be increased without first obtaining a determination from the director of development or their designee, in their sole and absolute discretion, that the increased grade either: 
(1)  Is necessary for the protection of the building or structure to be constructed, altered, or repaired on such Infill Construction Site; or 
(2)  Will have a beneficial impact on the lots and parcels of land located adjacent to the Infill Construction Site. 
(e)  Any work within or adjacent to the floodplain, or regulatory floodway, shall comply with the Village's flood control ordinance, latest edition. 
(Ord. No. 5094, § 2, 4-15-2008; Ord. No. 5468, § 2, 6-21-2011)  
Sec. 66-309. - Notice requirements. 
(a)  Prior to the commencement of any Infill Construction on any Infill Construction Site that contemplates a net cumulative increase in impervious surface of more than 400 square feet in area, the applicant shall provide written notice of his or her filing of an application for a permit to the owners or occupants of all lots or parcels of land that abut the Infill Construction Site and to any other persons or entities that the director of development or their designee determines appropriate. Such notice shall be in a form provided by the Village and shall be given by regular first class U.S. Mail. For purposes of this subsection, a notice addressed to the name and address on the most recent Cook County tax records shall be deemed a satisfaction of the notice requirement. Furthermore, for purposes of this subsection, a lot or parcel of land shall be deemed to "abut" an Infill Construction Site if the lot or parcel of land shares a common boundary or point with the Infill Construction Site, or is separated from the Infill Construction Site by only a public or private right-of-way. The applicant shall file with the Village, within 14 days after the filing of the permit application; written certification that such notice has been properly delivered. Such certification shall be in a form provided by the Village. The Village shall not process, and shall return to the applicant, any permit application for which such notice was not given or for which such certification was not filed as provided in this subsection 66-309(a)(1). Nothing in this subparagraph shall be deemed as prohibiting the director of development or their designee from providing notice of contemplated Infill Construction work that is not specifically covered or required by this subparagraph. 
(b)  In the event that written notice has been provided pursuant to subsection 66-309(a) and the applicant desires to make any changes that significantly alter the amount of Impervious Surface on the approved final engineering plan or the approved grading and drainage plan submitted pursuant to subsection 66-309(a) of this chapter, which changes are necessitated by on-site conditions not reasonably anticipated when the final engineering plan was submitted for review and approval by the Village engineer, the applicant shall provide written notice of such changes in a manner conforming with subsection 66-309(a). 
(c)  Prior to the commencement of any Infill Construction on any Infill Construction Site that contemplates a net cumulative increase in impervious surface of less than 400 square feet in area, if determined by the director of development or their designee to be in an area of known drainage issues, the applicant shall provide written notice of his or her filing of an application for a permit in the same manner as provided in subsection 66-309(a) to the owners or occupants of all lots or parcels of land that abut the Infill Construction Site and to any other persons or entities that the director of development or their designee determines appropriate. Nothing in this subparagraph shall be deemed as prohibiting the director of development or their designee from providing notice of contemplated Infill Construction work that is not specifically covered or required by this subparagraph. 
(Ord. No. 5094, § 2, 4-15-2008; Ord. No. 5468, § 2, 6-21-2011)  
Sec. 66-310. - Construction traffic and parking. 
The applicant shall submit for review and approval by the director of development or their designee, a construction traffic routing and parking plan that shall designate certain prescribed routes of access to the Infill Construction Site for all construction traffic and the designated areas for the parking of construction vehicles, which shall provide for the protection of pedestrians and shall minimize disruption of traffic and damage to paved street surfaces. At all times during work on the Infill Construction Site, the applicant shall keep all routes used for construction traffic to be free and clear of mud, dirt, debris, obstructions, and hazards and shall repair any damage caused by such construction traffic. 
(Ord. No. 5094, § 2, 4-15-2008)  
Sec. 66-311. - Appeal process. 
Any person directly impacted by the issuance or the denial of a building permit by the director of development shall have the right to appeal such action, but only pursuant to and in accordance with the procedures set forth in this section 66-311. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  An application for appeal shall be in writing and on the form provided by the office of the Village engineer. 
(2)  An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this Code, or the rules legally adopted under this Code, have been incorrectly interpreted, or that the provisions of this Code do not fully apply. 
(b)  Appeal to Village Management Team. All appeals pursuant to this section shall be filed in the office of the Village engineer within 30 days after the date of the issuance or the denial of the building permit by the director of development. Within ten days after the Village engineer's receipt of a properly filed appeal, the Village engineer shall deliver all records and findings regarding the appeal to the Village Management Team, which shall consist of the Village manager, the director of development and the Village engineer. The Village Management Team shall consider and decide the appeal within 30 days after receipt of the properly filed appeal. The Village Management Team may: 
(1)  Affirm the decision of the director of development; or 
(2)  Overrule or modify the decision of the director of development and direct the issuance, or the revocation of a previously issued, building permit. 
At the expiration of the 30 day period, if the Village Management Team has not rendered a decision on the appeal, it shall be deemed that the Village Management Team has affirmed the decision of the director of development. 
(c)  Appeal to Village Board of Trustees. The decision of the Village Management Team may be appealed to the Village Board of Trustees (the "board"). The appeal shall be filed in the office of the Village manager and shall be on a form provided by the Office of the Village manager. Such appeal shall be submitted in writing within 30 days after the date on which the Village Management Team's decision is made, or is deemed to have been made. Within ten days after the board's receipt of a properly filed appeal, the Village manager shall deliver all records and findings regarding the appeal to the board. The board shall consider and decide such appeal at a regular or special meeting of the board within 45 days after receipt by the Village manager of the properly filed appeal. The board may: 
(1)  Affirm the decision of the Village Management Team; or 
(2)  Overrule or modify the decision of the Village Management Team and direct the issuance, or the revocation of a previously issued, building permit. 
At the expiration of the 45 day period, if the board has not rendered a decision on the appeal, it shall be deemed that the board has affirmed the decision of the Village Management Team. 
(d)  Successive Appeals. If (1) an appeal is not properly or timely filed, or (2) an appeal is filed and a final decision has been rendered by the Village Management Team or the board, then no new appeal shall be allowed to be filed, and no permit application shall be allowed to be resubmitted for a period of one year after the date of the director of development's decision or, if applicable, the Village Management Team or board's decision, except on grounds of new evidence or proof of changed conditions found to be valid by the director of development. 
(e)  Judicial Review. Any final decision of the board pursuant to this section shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101, et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 5094, § 2, 4-15-2008)  
Chapter 70 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 22. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Imposition of tax on gas gross receipts. 
A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling of gas for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the Village, and not for resale, at five percent of the gross receipts therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 1980, § 1, 4-19-1976; Ord. No. 4248, § 1, 12-19-2000)  
Secs. 70-2—70-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34. 
 
Sec. 70-31. - License fee. 
All corporations, companies and associations not incorporated under the laws of the State, and which are engaged in effecting fire insurance in the Village, shall annually pay to the Foreign Fire Insurance Board of the Village, at the time of filing the reports as set forth in this article, as a tax or license fee, a sum equal to two percent of the gross receipts for premiums received by such corporations, companies or associations, or their agency or agents respectively, for business effected, or agreed to be effected, for fire insurance on property situated within the Village for the year ending July 1 preceding. 
(Code 1959, § 6.51; Ord. No. 5445, § 7, 4-21-2011)  
Sec. 70-32. - Reports. 
(a)  Every person who shall act as agent or otherwise for or on behalf of any such corporation, company or association shall, on or before July 15 of each and every year, render to and file with the Village clerk, a full, true and just report, verified by his oath, of all premiums which, during the year ending on every July 1 preceding such report, shall have been received by him or any other person for him on behalf of such corporation, company or association, and shall fully and specifically set out in such report the amounts received as premiums for fire insurance. 
(b)  If the report required by subsection (a) of this section shall not be filed on or before July 15, or if the amount of rates for the tax or license fee shall remain unpaid after such date, it shall be unlawful for any such corporation, company or association to transact any business of fire insurance in the Village until the requirements of this article have been fully complied with; provided, however, that this subsection shall not relieve any such corporation, company or association from the payment of any loss upon any risk that may be taken in violation thereof. 
(c)  If any such corporation, company or association referred to in this article shall fail to file the report required by subsection (a) of this section by July 15, or if the amount of rates as set forth in section 70-31 shall remain unpaid after July 15 in each year, every such corporation, company or association shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-16 upon conviction for each and every offense. In addition to such penalty, the Village shall recover, in an action in its name and for its use against such corporation, company or association so failing to make such report or pay such rates, the full amount of such rates which may be due under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1959, §§ 6.52—6.54)  
Sec. 70-33. - Disposition of fund. 
Any and all sums received under the provisions of this article shall be used as set forth in chapter 2, [article V,] division 5 of the Municipal Code, Village of Glenview, Illinois. 
(Code 1959, § 6.55; Ord. No. 5445, § 8, 4-21-2011)  
Secs. 70-34—70-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL AND MOTEL TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. 
 
Sec. 70-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hotel and motel include every building or structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where lodging, or lodging and food, or apartments, suites or other accommodations are offered for a consideration, on a daily, weekly or monthly basis, to guests. 
Person means any natural person, trustee, receiver, administrator, executor, conservator, assignee, trust in perpetuity, trust, estate, firm, copartnership, joint venture, club, company, business trust, domestic or foreign corporation, association, syndicate, society or any group of individuals acting as a unit, whether mutual, cooperative, fraternal, nonprofit or otherwise. Whenever the term "person" is used in any clause prescribing and imposing a penalty, the term, as applied to associations, shall mean the owners or part owners thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 6.99) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-62. - Imposed; rate; responsibility. 
(a)  A tax is hereby levied and imposed upon the use and privilege of renting, leasing or letting of rooms in a motel or hotel in the Village at the rate of six percent of the gross room sale (rental) revenues from such rental, leasing or letting, exclusive of revenues received from food, beverage and other sales. For purposes of this section, the term "room sale (rental) revenues" shall include only the basic room charge, exclusive of meals, beverages and other package items; provided, however, a tax shall not be levied and imposed upon any person who works and lives in the same hotel or motel; and further provided, that the tax shall not be levied upon rooms rented or used by directors, officers, agents or employees of the owner of the hotel or motel when renting or using such rooms for, or in connection with, the transaction of business. 
(b)  The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of such tax shall be borne by the users, lessees or tenants of such rooms. The tax levied in this section shall be in addition to any and all other taxes. 
(Code 1959, § 6.98; Ord. No. 5080, § 2, 2-19-2008)  
Sec. 70-63. - Payment and collection. 
The owner, manager or operator of each hotel or motel shall bear, jointly and severally, the duty to collect the tax from each user, lessee or tenant of rooms in such hotel or motel. Every person required to collect the tax levied by this article shall secure such tax from the user, lessee or tenant of a room at the time that he collects the price, charge or rent to which the tax applies. Every user, lessee or tenant shall be given a bill, invoice, receipt or other statement or memorandum of the price, charge or rent payable, upon which the tax imposed in this article is computed, and the amount of the tax shall be stated, charged and shown separately thereon. The tax shall be paid to the person required to collect the tax as trustee for and on behalf of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 6.100)  
Sec. 70-64. - Enforcement officer of tax. 
(a)  The finance director of the Village hereby is designated as the administration and enforcement officer of the tax hereby imposed on behalf of the Village. It shall be the responsibility and duty of the finance director to collect all amounts due the Village from the owners, managers and operators of motels and hotels in the Village. 
(b)  A sworn monthly hotel and occupancy tax return, on a calendar month basis, shall be filed with the finance director by each owner, manager or operator of each hotel or motel in the Village, on forms prescribed by the finance director, showing all receipts from each renting, leasing or letting of rooms during the preceding month. Such returns are to be filed within 15 days after the end of the month covered by such return, with the tax imposed in this article due and owing as of the first day of the month following the month covered by such return. Each return shall be accompanied by payment to the Village of all taxes due and owing for the month covered by the return. 
(c)  During the normal business working hours of any such hotel or motel, the finance director or any person certified by him as his deputy or representative may enter the premises of any hotel or motel for the purpose of inspection and examination of the hotel's or motel's books and records for the proper administration of this article, and for the enforcement of the collection of the tax imposed by this article. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder or interfere with the finance director or his duly authorized deputy or representative in the discharge of his duties under this subsection. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of every owner, manager or operator to keep accurate and complete books and records containing all information necessary for the collection of the tax imposed by this article, to which the finance director or his duly authorized deputy or representative shall have full access at all times. Such records shall include a daily sheet showing the number of hotel or motel rooms rented during the 24-hour period, including multiple rentals of the same hotel or motel room when such occurs, and the actual hotel or motel room tax receipts collected for the date in question. If the inspection and examination by the financial director discloses a discrepancy in excess of five percent from the information furnished by the hotel owner, operator or manager, the cost of such inspection and examination shall be borne by the hotel owner, operator or manager. 
(Code 1959, § 6.101) 
Cross reference— Director of finance, § 2-521.  
Sec. 70-65. - Failure to pay or collect. 
Whenever any person shall fail to pay any tax provided for in this article, or when any owner, manager or operator of a hotel or motel in the Village shall fail to collect the tax imposed by this article from any person who has the ultimate liability for payment of the tax, the Village attorney shall, upon request of the Village manager, bring, or cause to be brought, an action to enforce the payment of such tax on behalf of the Village in any court of competent jurisdiction. If the Village president, after a hearing held by or for him, shall find that any hotel or motel owner, manager or operator has willfully evaded his responsibility to collect the tax imposed by this article, he may suspend or revoke all Village licenses, including, but not limited to, any liquor license issued under this Code, held by such person. Such person shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, to be held not less than five days after notice is given of the time and place thereof, addressed to him at his last known place of business. Pending notice, hearing and finding, any license which such person may possess may be temporarily suspended by the Village president. Any suspension or conviction resulting from such hearing shall not relieve or discharge any civil liability for nonpayment of the tax due. 
(Code 1959, § 6.102)  
Sec. 70-66. - Interest and penalties. 
In the event of failure by any hotel or motel owner, manager or operator to collect and pay to the finance director the tax required under this article within ten days after the tax shall be due, interest shall accumulate and be due upon such tax at the rate of one percent per month, commencing on the first day of the month following the month for which the tax was to have been collected. In addition, a penalty of ten percent of the tax and interest due shall be assessed and collected against any hotel or motel owner, manager or operator who shall fail to collect and remit the tax imposed by this article. 
(Code 1959, § 6.103)  
Sec. 70-67. - Proceeds. 
All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax under this article, including interest and penalties, shall be paid into the treasury of the Village and shall be credited to and deposited in the general fund of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 6.104)  
Sec. 70-68. - Violations; penalties. 
In addition to the other provisions of this article, any person found guilty in a court of competent jurisdiction of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting or refusing to comply with, or resisting or opposing the enforcement of, any provision of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 6.105)  
Secs. 70-69—70-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - AMUSEMENT TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Amusements and entertainments, ch. 10. 
State Law reference— Authority, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 70-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Admission fee or charge means any fee or charge made or received for admission to any amusement, whether or not represented by a ticket or admission stub or receipt of any kind. An admission fee or charge includes, but is not limited to, all fees or charges for seats, chairs, tables, benches, space to stand or sit, special seating area, tent, structure, booth or other similar accommodations made as described in this definition, for which there is a fee or charge. 
Amusement means any event, exhibition, performance, presentation or show for entertainment purposes which is exhibited or staged in the Village, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Any comedic, theatrical, dramatic, musical, opera or spectator performance or production, or similar live or recorded entertainment; 
(2)  Any show, motion picture show, antique or flower show, speech or lecture; 
(3)  Any exhibition of art, handicrafts or products; 
(4)  Any poultry or animal show, animal act, circus or rodeo; 
(5)  Any athletic contest, sport, game or similar exhibition, such as boxing, wrestling, skating, dancing, swimming, racing or riding on animals or vehicles, baseball, basketball, softball, football, tennis, golf, hockey, track and field games, bowling or billiard and pool games. 
Amusement patron means any person: 
(1)  Admitted to any amusement in the Village for which an admission fee or charge is imposed. 
(2)  Who purchases or otherwise acquires a ticket or pass of any kind from a place other than the location where such ticket or pass is purchased or acquired for admission to any amusement within the Village. 
Owner means: 
(1)  With respect to the owner of a place where an amusement is being held, any person with an ownership or leasehold interest in a building, structure, vehicle, boat, area or other place, who presents, conducts or operates an amusement in such place or who allows, by agreement or otherwise, another person to present, conduct or operate an amusement in such place; 
(2)  With respect to the owner of an amusement, any person who has an ownership or leasehold interest in such amusement or any person who has a proprietary interest in the amusement so as to entitle such person to all or a portion of the proceeds from the operation, conduct or presentation of such amusement, excluding proceeds from nonamusement services and sales of tangible personal property. 
Person means any natural individual, firm, society, foundation, institution, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint stock company, joint venture, public or private corporation, receiver, executor, trustee or other representative appointed by the order of any court, or any other entity recognized by law. 
Special seating area means an enclosed or substantially enclosed apartment-style room, containing or making available amenities for the exclusive use of the patrons thereof, whether denominated as luxury or super suites, or skyboxes, or by other similar terms. Such amenities may include, but are not necessarily limited to, a television (including closed-circuit capacity), bathroom, refrigerator, telephone service, storage sink, living room or lounge furniture, special spectator seating, food, heat, air conditioning and parking. 
(Code 1959, ch. 10, art. XV) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-102. - Imposed. 
A tax of four percent on the admission fee or charge is imposed upon every amusement patron for the privilege of admission to any amusement in the Village; provided, however, that the amusement tax shall not apply to the following and; provided, however, that the entities described in the following subsections (1)—(6) are not-for-profit institutions, organizations, groups or societies, where no part of the net earnings inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or person: 
(1)  Governmental or public agencies or institutions; 
(2)  Religious, educational and charitable institutions, societies or organizations; 
(3)  Societies or organizations for the prevention of cruelty to children or animals; 
(4)  Societies or organizations conducted for the sole purpose of maintaining symphony orchestras, opera performances and artistic presentations, including, but not limited to, musical presentations that receive substantial support from voluntary contributions; 
(5)  Societies or organizations conducted and maintained for the purpose of civic improvements; 
(6)  Fraternal organizations, legion posts, and social and political groups which conduct amusements, sponsored occasionally, but not more often than twice yearly, for periods of not longer than ten days; 
(7)  Organizations or persons in the armed services of the United States, or National Guard organizations, reserve officers' associations, or organizations or posts of war veterans, or auxiliary units or societies of such posts or organizations, if such posts, organizations, units or societies are organized in the State, and if no part of the proceeds of the amusement inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or person; 
(8)  Organizations or associations created and maintained for the purpose of benefiting the members, or dependents or heirs of members, of the police or fire departments of any political subdivision of the State, and if no part of the proceeds of the amusement inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or person; 
(9)  Initiation fees and membership dues paid to a health club, racquetball club, tennis club or a similar club or organization, when such club or organization is organized and operated on a membership basis and for the recreational purposes of its members and its members' guests. This exemption shall not be construed to apply to any fees paid or based upon, in any way whatsoever, a per event or per admission basis; 
(10)  Live performances or closed circuit sporting events which are conducted in an auditorium that has a maximum seating capacity of no more than 400 persons, as on file with the Village fire department, or in a restaurant, lounge or other place of business that has a maximum seating capacity of no more than 400 persons, as on file with the Village fire department; 
(11)  Fees or other charges paid by a patron for the privilege of witnessing or viewing an amusement, solely within the confines of such patron's home. For purposes of this exemption, the term "home" means the permanent dwelling residence of the patron. For patrons who live in condominium buildings, apartment buildings or other multiple-unit structures, the individual dwelling unit the patron occupies shall be considered as the patron's home; 
(12)  Eighty percent of the admission fees or other charges, including, but not limited to, the gross lease or rental amount, paid for the privilege of using special seating areas, tents, structures or other similar accommodations to witness or view an amusement. 
(Code 1959, ch. 10, art. XV)  
Sec. 70-103. - Computation. 
For the purpose of determining the amount of the amusement tax due under this article, admission fees or charges shall be computed exclusive of the amusement tax, any federal or State taxes imposed upon the amusement patron and any separately stated charges for nonamusement services or sales of tangible personal property. 
(Code 1959, ch. 10, art. XV)  
Sec. 70-104. - Collection, payment and accounting. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner, manager or operator of an amusement or a place where an amusement is being held to secure from each patron the tax imposed by this article and to remit the tax to the finance department of the Village not later than the last day of each calendar month for all admission fees or other charges received during the immediately preceding calendar month. A verified statement of admission fees or charges, in a form prescribed by the finance director, shall accompany each remittance. Acceptance by the Village of any amount tendered in payment of the tax shall be without prejudice to any claim, demand or right on account of any deficiency. 
(b)  Canceled admission tickets, stubs, receipts, and complete and accurate records, books and accounts, in detail, of all receipts shall be kept at the place of amusement or such other place in the Village as may be designated, in writing, by the person liable for collection of the tax, and addressed to the finance director. All such books, records and accounts shall be open to inspection by the finance director, or his designee, at all reasonable times during regular business hours. 
(c)  Every owner, manager or operator who is required to collect the tax imposed by this article shall be considered a tax collector for the Village. All amusement taxes collected shall be held by such tax collector as trustee for and on behalf of the Village. The failure of the tax collector to collect the tax shall not excuse or release the patron from the obligation to pay the tax. 
(d)  In order to permit sound fiscal planning and budgeting by the Village, no person shall be entitled to a refund of, or credit for, the tax imposed by this article unless the person files a claim for a refund or credit within one year after the date on which the tax was paid or remitted to the finance department of the Village. 
(Code 1959, ch. 10, art. XV)  
Sec. 70-105. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to produce, present or conduct any amusement, without collection of the amusement tax, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(b)  If the person required to collect the amusement tax fails to remit amusement to the finance department of the Village within ten days after such remittance is due, a penalty of ten percent of the amusement taxes due shall be assessed against such person. Additionally, interest shall be due upon any such unpaid amusement taxes at a rate of one percent per month, commencing on the first day of the month immediately following the month in which such amusement taxes were required to be remitted to the finance department of the Village. 
(c)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-16. Each fee or charge paid by a person for admission to an amusement without payment of the tax shall constitute a separate offense. All fines shall be in addition to the unpaid amusement taxes, plus interest and penalties. The payment of a fine shall not relieve the person fined from liability for the tax provided for in this article. 
(Code 1959, ch. 10, art. XV)  
Secs. 70-106—70-120. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[6] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 70-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gross receipts means the consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption and not for resale and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of the service, product or commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any other expenses whatsoever. Gross receipts shall not include amounts added to customers' bills under Section 9-221 of the Public Utilities Act. 
Municipal utility tax means any tax authorized under Section 8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2).

(Ord. No. 5917, § 2, 6-2-2015; Ord. No. 6009, § 1, 8-16-2016)

DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL CONSUMPTION 
 
Sec. 70-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Person means any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation, the State or any political subdivision thereof, and State university created by statute, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court or by operation of law. 
Person maintaining a place of business in this State means any person having or maintaining within the State, directly or by a subsidiary or other affiliate, an office, generation facility, distribution facility, transmission facility, sales office or other place of business, or any employee, agent or other representative operating within the State under the authority of the person or its subsidiary or other affiliate, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or other representative is located in the State permanently or temporarily, or whether such person, subsidiary or other affiliate is licensed or qualified to do business in this State. 
Purchase at retail means any acquisition of electricity by a purchaser for purposes of use or consumption, and not for resale, but shall not include the use of electricity by a public utility as defined in section 8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2, directly in the generation, production, transmission, delivery or sale of electricity. 
Purchaser means any person who uses or consumers, within the corporate limits of the Village electricity acquired in a purchase at retail. 
Tax collector means the person delivering electricity to the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 5, 8-18-1998) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-142. - Tax on purchase. 
A tax is hereby imposed on the purchase of electricity, in the manner and form provided for in this division. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 4, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-143. - Applicability of tax. 
The tax imposed under division 1 of this article shall not apply with respect to gross receipts pertaining to customer bills for the distribution, supply, furnishing or sale of electricity where the use or consumption of the electricity is subject to the tax imposed under section 70-142. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 2, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-144. - Tax obligation; application of credit under section 70-142. 
If a taxpayer obligated under division 1 to pay the tax provided therein for the distribution, supply, furnishing or sale of electricity is unable to use a credit as otherwise allowed under section 70-126 solely because such tax has been replaced by the tax imposed under section 70-142, then the taxpayer concerned shall be entitled to apply such credit against any tax due under section 70-142. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 3, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-145. - Use or consumption; rates; customer billing. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2) and any and all other applicable authority, a tax is imposed upon the privilege of using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail and used or consumed within the corporate limits of the Village at the following rates, calculated on a monthly basis for each purchaser: 
(1)  For the first 2,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.54 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(2)  For the next 48,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.355 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(3)  For the next 50,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.336 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(4)  For the next 400,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.335 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(5)  For the next 500,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.330 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(6)  For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.328 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(7)  For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.285 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(8)  For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.200 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(9)  For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month, $0.140 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(10)  For all electricity used or consumed in excess of 20,000,000 kilowatt-hours in a month, $0.080 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(b)  The tax imposed in subsection (a) of this section is in addition to all taxes, fees and other revenue measures imposed by the Village, the United States of America, the State or any other political subdivision of the State. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the tax provided for herein shall not be imposed if and to the extent that the imposition or collection of the tax would violate the Constitution or laws of the United States of America, or the constitution of the State. 
(d)  The tax provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be imposed with respect to the use or consumption of electricity by residential customers beginning with the first bill issued on or after September 1, 1998; and with respect to the use or consumption of electricity by nonresidential customers beginning with the first bill issued to such customers for delivery services in accordance with section 16-104 of the Illinois Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 6/16-104), or the first bill issued to such customers on or after January 1, 2001, whichever issuance shall occur sooner. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 6, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-146. - Collection. 
(a)  The tax imposed under section 70-145 shall be collected from purchasers by the person maintaining a place of business in the State who delivers the electricity to such purchasers. This tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser to the person who delivers the electricity to the purchaser and is recoverable at the same time and in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the electricity. 
(b)  Any tax required to be collected by this division, and any tax in fact collected, shall constitute a debt due and owing to the Village by the person delivering the electricity, provided that the person delivering the electricity shall be allowed credit for such tax related to deliveries of electricity the charges for which are written off as uncollectable after reasonable collection efforts have been made, and provided further that if such charges are thereafter collected, the person delivering the electricity shall be obligated to remit such tax to the Village. 
(c)  Persons delivering electricity shall collect the tax from the purchaser by adding such tax to the gross charge for delivering the electricity. Persons delivering electricity shall also be authorized to add to such gross charge an amount equal to three percent of the tax they collect to reimburse them for their expenses incurred in keeping records, billing customers, preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax, and supplying data to the Village upon request. Any partial payment of a billed amount not specifically identified by the purchaser shall be deemed to be for the delivery of electricity. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 7, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-147. - Tax remittance and return. 
(a)  Every tax collector shall, on a monthly basis, file a return in a form prescribed by the finance director. The return and the accompanying remittance shall be due on or before the last day of the month following the month during which the tax is collected or is required to be collected. 
(b)  If the person delivering electricity fails to collect the tax from the purchaser or is excused from collecting the tax; then the purchaser shall file a return in a form prescribed by the finance director and pay the tax directly to the Village on or before the last day of the month during which the electricity is used or consumed. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 8, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-148. - Resales of electricity. 
(a)  Electricity that is delivered to a person in the Village shall be considered to be for use and consumption by that person unless such person receiving the electricity has an active resale number issued by the finance director and furnishes that number to the person who delivers the electricity, and certified to that person that the sale is either entirely or partially nontaxable as a sale for resale. 
(b)  If a person who receives electricity in the Village claims to be an authorized reseller of electricity, that person shall apply to the finance director for a resale number. The applicant shall state in such application facts showing why he is not liable for the tax imposed by section 70-145 on any purchases of electricity and shall furnish such additional information as the finance director may reasonably require. 
(c)  Upon approval of the application, the finance director shall assign a resale number to the applicant and shall certify the number to the applicant. 
(d)  The finance director may cancel the resale number of any person if: 
(1)  That person fails to pay any tax payable under section 70-145 for electricity used or consumed by that person; 
(2)  The resale number was obtained through misrepresentation; or 
(3)  The resale number is no longer necessary because the person having obtained the number has discontinued making resales. 
(e)  If a reseller has acquired electricity partly for use or consumption and partly for resale, the reseller shall pay the tax imposed by this division directly to the Village on the amount of electricity that the reseller uses or consumes, and shall collect and remit the tax to the Village for the amount of electricity delivered by the reseller to a purchaser. 
(f)  Any person who delivers electricity to a reseller having an active resale number and complying with all other conditions of this section shall be excused from collecting and remitting the tax on any portion of the electricity delivered to the reseller, provided that the person reports to the finance director the total amount of electricity delivered to the reseller, and such other information that the finance director may reasonably require. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 9, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-149. - Books and records. 
Every tax collector, and every taxpayer required to pay the tax imposed by this division shall keep accurate books and records of its business or activity, including contemporaneous books and records denoting the transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise, to any tax liability under this division. These books and records shall be subject to and available for inspection by the Village at all times during business hours of the day. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 10, 8-18-1998)  
Sec. 70-150. - Credits and refunds. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, in order to permit sound fiscal planning and budgeting by the Village, no person shall be entitled to a refund of, or credit for, any tax imposed under this division unless that person shall have filed with the finance director a written claim for such refund or credit no later than one year after the date on which the tax was paid or remitted to the Village. 
(Ord. No. 3985, § 11, 8-18-1998)  
Division 3. - Municipal Gas Use Tax 
 
Sec. 70-151. - Short title. 
The tax imposed by this division shall be known as the "Municipal Gas Use Tax" and is imposed in addition to all other taxes imposed by the Village of Glenview, the State of Illinois, or any other municipal corporation or political subdivision thereof. 
(Ord. No. 5154, § 2, 10-21-2008)  
Sec. 70-152. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply: 
Person means any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
Public utility means a public utility as defined in Section 3-105 of the Public Utilities Act. 
Public Utilities Act means the Public Utilities Act as amended, (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.). 
Retail purchaser means any person who purchases gas in a sale at retail. 
Sale at retail means any sale of gas by a retailer to a person for use or consumption, and not for resale. For this purpose, the term "retailer" means any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas. 
(Ord. No. 5154, § 2, 10-21-2008)  
Sec. 70-153. - Tax. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by this division, a tax is imposed on the privilege of using or consuming gas in the Village that is purchased in a sale at retail at the rate of 4.50 cent(s) per therm ($0.0450). 
(b)  The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is on the retail purchaser, and nothing in this division shall be construed to impose a tax on the occupation of distributing, supplying, furnishing, selling or transporting gas. 
(c)  The retail purchaser shall pay the tax, measured by therms of gas delivered to the retail purchaser's premises, to the public utility designated to collect the tax pursuant to section 70-154 of this division on or before the payment due date of the public utility's bill first reflecting the tax, or directly to the Village Finance Department on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is delivered to the retail purchaser if no public utility has been designated to collect the tax pursuant to section 70-154, or if the gas is delivered by a person other than a public utility so designated. 
(d)  Nothing in this division shall be construed to impose a tax upon any person, business or activity which, under the constitutions of the United States or State of Illinois, may not be made the subject of taxation by the Village. 
(e)  A person who purchases gas for resale and therefore does not pay the tax imposed by this division with respect to the use or consumption of the gas, but who later uses or consumes part or all of the gas, shall pay the tax directly to the Village Treasurer on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is used or consumed. 
(f)  The tax shall apply to gas for which the delivery to the retail purchaser is billed by a public utility on or after November 1, 2008. 
(g)  If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this division, whether as a result of mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be (i) credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this division from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment or (ii) subject to a refund if no such tax is due or to become due; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three years prior to the filing of a claim therefore shall be so credited or refunded. 
(h)  No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this division shall be commenced more than three years after the due date of such amount. 
(i)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 5154, § 2, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 6009, § 3, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 70-154. - Collection of tax by public utility.
