The building sewer, when laid in filled ground, shall be of vitrified clay pipe, laid on a bed of approved grillage or concrete, or of cast iron pipe, American Society of Testing Materials' (ASTM) approved standards. 
(Code 1959, § 21.67)  
Sec. 82-147. - Dead ends; alterations to branch drains. 
(a)  In the installation of any sewerage or plumbing system, no dead ends will be permitted, except on such repair work where an antisiphon trap is to be used as provided in this article. 
(b)  In making alterations of any old plumbing or sewerage system, or upon removing any old fixture connected at the end of a branch drain, soil or waste pipe, such branch shall be removed for its entire length, or provision shall be made for a free circulation of air through such branch. When such pipe is cut off where it branches from the main, the opening shall be properly closed in accordance with the State plumbing code. 
(Code 1959, § 21.68)  
Sec. 82-148. - Wastes containing greasy matter. 
Waste from any kitchen sink, floor drain or other fixture that is likely to contain greasy matter from hotels, apartment houses, restaurants, butcher shops, packinghouses, lard rendering establishments, manufacturing establishments, bakeries, laundries, cleaning establishments, garages, service stations, stables, yard and floor drains and drains from gravel roofs shall be made through intervening receiving basins in accordance with the State plumbing code. 
(Code 1959, § 21.69)  
Sec. 82-149. - Steam or heating boiler intercepting basins. 
Intercepting basins for stream or heating boilers, or such basins, constructed for any purpose, shall not be placed closer than two feet to the wall of any building or area unless properly tested, and when such a basin is placed where the cover of such basin will be in the line of any sidewalk, the cover shall be made of extra heavy cast iron, or when such basin shall be within the lines of any road or driveway, such cover shall be a cast iron manhole cover and frame. 
(Code 1959, § 21.70)  
Sec. 82-150. - Floor and area drains. 
(a)  Floor drains may be installed by means of Y fittings inserted in the building drain and provided with a four-inch cast iron deep seal trap and fitted with a heavy barred strainer and back water valve or a screw type plug that is normally closed. 
(b)  Where the floor of an entrance area to a basement or a ground floor is more than four inches lower than such basement or ground floor, an area drain may be installed. The opening of the area drain shall be four inches in diameter and provided with a heavy barred strainer set so that it cannot be easily removed. The outlet pipe shall be of cast iron and shall be connected into the sewer through a frostproof trap. All such area drains shall be provided with an approved back water valve, set where it can be conveniently reached for cleaning. All area drains located outside of buildings shall be connected to the storm drain whenever the grade of the main storm sewer will permit. 
(Code 1959, § 21.71)  
Sec. 82-151. - Roof and paved area drainage. 
All roofs and paved areas, yards, courts and courtyards shall be drained into the stormwater system, but not into sewers intended for sanitary sewage only. 
(Code 1959, § 21.72)  
Sec. 82-152. - Subbuilding drains. 
(a)  All subbuilding drains shall discharge into an airtight sump or receiving tank located so as to receive the sewage by gravity, from which sump or receiving tank the sewage shall be lifted and discharged into the building sewer by pumps, ejectors or any equally efficient method. Such pumps shall be either automatically discharged or be of sufficient capacity to receive the building sewage and wastes for not less than 24 hours. 
(b)  The soil or vent pipe leading to an ejector or other appliance for raising sewage or other waste matter to the public sewer shall, where a water closet is installed, be provided with a vent pipe of not less than four inches in diameter, and where fixtures other than water closets are installed, the waste and vent pipe shall be the same diameter as the waste pipe. 
(Code 1959, § 21.73)  
Sec. 82-153. - Motors, air compressors and air tanks. 
All motors, air compressors and air tanks shall be located where they are open for inspection and repair at all times. The air tanks shall be proportioned so as to be of equal cubical capacity to the ejectors connected therewith, in which there shall be maintained an air pressure of not less than 2.3 pounds for each foot of height the sewage is to be raised. 
(Code 1959, § 21.74)  
Sec. 82-154. - Subsoil drains. 
Subsoil drains below the building sewer level shall discharge into a sump or receiving tank, the contents of which shall be automatically lifted and discharged into the drainage system above the cellar through some properly trapped fixture or drain. 
(Code 1959, § 21.75)  
Sec. 82-155. - Disposals into the sewer system. 
All disposals by any person into the sewer system is unlawful, except discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the federal act and more stringent State and local standards. 
(Code 1959, § 21.76)  
Sec. 82-156. - Permitting documentation and approval of appropriate governing agencies required; supplementation of permit application; permit and inspection fee; permit condition. 
(a)  The Village shall require proper permitting documentation and approval of appropriate governing agencies. 
(b)  The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the Village. 
(c)  A permit and inspection fee of $100.00 for a residential or sewer permit shall be paid to the Village at the time the application is filed. 
(d)  The industry, as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics and type of activity. 
(Code 1959, § 21.77)  
Sec. 82-157. - Demonstration of reserve capacity. 
A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. 
(Code 1959, § 21.78)  
Sec. 82-158. - Cost and expense of maintenance, installation and connection; indemnification from loss or damage. 
(a)  The cost and expense incidental to the maintenance, installation and connection of a building sewer shall be borne by the owner. 
(b)  The owner shall indemnify the Village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Code 1959, § 21.79)  
Sec. 82-159. - Use of old building sewers. 
(a)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the Village, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(b)  It shall be the obligation of the owner, builder or developer to provide the Village with documentation that demonstrates the old sewer can meet the requirements of this article. 
(c)  It shall be at the sole option of the Village, that based on the information presented, to require the owner, developer or builder to either replace or reline the sanitary sewer for the building up to and including the point of connection with the sanitary sewer main. 
(Code 1959, § 21.80)  
Sec. 82-160. - Conformance with ASTM standards. 
The size, slope, alignment and materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling of the trench shall all conform to the appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials (ASTM), Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9 and the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. 
(Code 1959, § 21.81)  
Sec. 82-161. - Elevation; lifting of sanitary sewage. 
Sanitary wastes below the sewer shall comply with the requirements of the State plumbing code, as adopted in section 18-421 et seq. 
(Code 1959, § 21.82)  
Sec. 82-162. - Sump pump connections. 
(a)  No person shall make or maintain via sump pump connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, driveway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(b)  For sump pump connections to a storm sewer or natural outlet, maintain a two-inch minimum air gap between the discharge pipe from the structure and the receiving pipe drain that goes underground. 
(Code 1959, § 21.83)  
Sec. 82-163. - Specifications for connecting into the public sewer. 
The connection of a building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9 and the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the Village before installation. 
(Code 1959, § 21.84)  
Sec. 82-164. - Connections. 
The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the Village when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the village engineer and director of building and zoning. 
(Code 1959, § 21.85)  
Sec. 82-165. - Guarding of excavations; restoration of disturbed property. 
(a)  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village engineer. 
(Code 1959, § 21.86)  
Sec. 82-166. - Breaks and cracks. 
Whenever any length of the public sewer or building sewer becomes broken or cracked, such defective length shall be entirely replaced. No patching of such break or crack will be accepted. 
(Code 1959, § 21.87)  
Sec. 82-167. - Installation and maintenance. 
(a)  All building sewers shall be installed and maintained at the cost to the owner of the premises to be served thereby. All such installations shall be under the supervision of the director of building and zoning. 
(b)  The building owner shall bear full responsibility and liability for maintaining the building sewer from the building up to and including the point of connection to the public sewer. 
(Code 1959, § 21.88)  
Sec. 82-168. - Repairs. 
The Village may, in case of emergency, but shall not be obligated to, repair any building sewer, but any repairs made by the Village shall be at the cost and risk of the owner of the premises to be served, and the Village shall not be liable for any damage resulting from the undertaking or making by it of repairs, nor for any damage caused by or resulting from obstructions in such branch or house drain sewer or from any disrepair thereof, or from failure to make needed repairs. 
(Code 1959, § 21.89)  
Sec. 82-169. - Separate and independent building sewers required; exception. 
A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, and for every unit in a commercial building, except that, where one building stands at the rear of another or an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(Code 1959, § 21.90)  
Secs. 82-170—82-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - INSPECTION PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 82-191. - Establishment. 
It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his duly authorized representative to establish an inspection program and undertake an inspection of all private properties connected to the sanitary sewer system for the purpose of ascertaining whether all connections to the sanitary sewer system are installed and are operating in compliance with this article; and whether there are illegal connections to the sanitary sewer system or any clear water inflow, materials or other substances as defined by this article being discharged into the sanitary sewer system. Such inspections may be undertaken in the company of State or federal Environmental Protection Agency representatives and representatives of the MWRD (Metropolitan Water Reclamation District), and such inspections shall include observation of the sanitary sewer system and such measurements, sampling and testing as the inspector deems necessary to ascertain that substances and materials discharged into the sanitary sewer system are in compliance with the provisions of Ordinance No. 2748. 
(Code 1959, § 21.114)  
Sec. 82-192. - Authority to enter private property. 
The director of public works or such other representative authorized in this division to conduct inspections shall be authorized and permitted to seek entry into and upon private property at reasonable times, upon prior notice, if possible, for the purposes set forth in section 82-191. The person conducting the inspection shall provide the property owner with proper credentials and identification, and shall inform him of the purpose of such inspection. 
(Code 1959, § 21.115)  
Sec. 82-193. - Refusal to allow entry for inspection. 
(a)  Where a property owner fails or refuses entry to his property to an authorized representative of the Village for the purpose of inspection as provided in this division, then the Village is empowered to shut off the water supply to the property according to the following shutoff policy of the Village: 
Action 	Penalty 	Cumulative Days 
First notice 	— 	— 
Second notice 	— 	25 
Third notice 	— 	56 
Fourth notice—Door hanger 	Stated in 
section 30-1 	66 
Water shut off 	Stated in 
section 30-1 	67 
 
(b)  Where a property owner fails or refuses consent to the entry on his property for the purpose of inspection as provided in this division and the property is not connected to the Village water system or it is in the best interests of the Village to not shut off the water supply of the property, then no entry or inspection shall be made without the procurement of a warrant from the circuit court of the County. Cause for issuance of a warrant shall be deemed to exist in light of reasonable legislative and administrative standards which show that there is reason to believe that a condition of noncompliance exists with respect to a particular property in violation of this article, and for such purpose, the court may consider the visual observations of violations in plain view, citizen complaints, violations apparent from examining Village records of the property, documented violations of similar properties in the area, previous violations on the property itself and the passage of time since the property was last inspected. 
(Code 1959, § 21.116; Ord. No. 6026, § 2, 11-15-2016)  
Sec. 82-194. - Notice of violation. 
If a connection to the sanitary sewer system of any property within the Village is found, upon inspection, to be in violation of the provisions of this article, and particularly in violation of the permissible connections or of the discharge requirements contained in this article or as set forth in Ordinance No. 2748, then the director of public works or his authorized representative shall furnish the property owner with a notice, in writing, setting forth the substance of the violation and giving the owner a period of 60 days to correct the violation. Compliance shall be ascertained by the director of public works or his authorized representative by further inspection at the termination date of the compliance period set forth in the notice. 
(Code 1959, § 21.117)  
Sec. 82-195. - Remedies for failure to comply. 
If a violation is not corrected during the period of time set forth in the violation notice, or the director of public works is not permitted to inspect the premises to ascertain whether or not compliance has been achieved, then the Village may pursue such legal remedies as it deems necessary to achieve compliance, including, but not limited to, court action to enjoin such violation, or further administrative action pursuant to the notice and hearing provisions of section 82-194 to shut off water service to the property in question until the violation has been corrected. These remedies are not mutually exclusive and the pursuance of one remedy does not preclude pursuant of one or more additional remedies at the same time. 
(Code 1959, § 21.118)  
Sec. 82-196. - Roof water and sump pump discharges. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to direct the flow of roof water or sump pump discharge water in such a manner so that it creates a nuisance to adjacent property owners or occupants of such adjacent property or creates a public nuisance. Property owners must make reasonable efforts to contain the roof water or sump pump discharge water on their own property insofar as possible. In no event should the point of discharge be within ten feet of the property line unless, in the opinion of the director of public works or his authorized representative, no reasonable alternative exists. 
(Code 1959, § 21.119)  
Sec. 82-197. - Fire hydrants on private property. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his duly authorized representative to establish an annual inspection program and undertake an inspection of all fire hydrants on private property on water lines connected to the Village water system for the purpose of ascertaining whether such fire hydrants are in proper working order. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of any fire hydrant located on private property to: 
(1)  Maintain such fire hydrants in proper working order as established by the department of public works; 
(2)  Notify the fire department that a fire hydrant is not working; 
(3)  Repair such fire hydrants promptly; 
(4)  Maintain the area around each fire hydrant free from obstructions; 
(5)  Permit the department of public works and fire department to inspect such fire hydrants as needed; and 
(6)  Allow the Village to repair a fire hydrant when, in the judgment of the fire department, the immediate repair is necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(c)  Property owners will be notified of any fire hydrant found inoperative or in poor working order by the village director of public works. Owners of such fire hydrants shall be given written notice by the director of public works that the broken fire hydrant must be repaired within five days. The fire hydrant owner may choose to request that the Village water department repair the fire hydrant and should notify the Village of such choice within the five-day period. Failure to so notify the Village within the five-day period may result in the Village water department performing the repairs on a time and material basis. In addition, the property owner shall be subject to a fine of $200.00 if the Village is not notified within the five-day period as forth in this subsection. Routine maintenance may be performed by Village employees. 
(Code 1959, § 21.124)  
Sec. 82-198. - Fire hydrant rules and specifications. 
The department of public works may establish rules and specifications for the physical characteristics of fire hydrants, which may include the color of the hydrants, clear distance and height. 
(Code 1959, § 21.125)  
Sec. 82-199. - Fire hydrant maintenance and repairs. 
The Village shall, on a yearly basis, perform routine maintenance of fire hydrants at no charge to the property owner. The maintenance shall include inspection, painting, flushing and any minor repair. Any other repairs shall be billed to the owner of such hydrant on a time and material basis. 
(Code 1959, § 21.126)  
Sec. 82-200. - Refusal to allow fire hydrant inspection or maintenance. 
When a property owner fails or refuses to allow fire hydrant inspection and/or maintenance by an authorized representative of the Village as provided in this division and/or to notify the Village as provided in section 82-197, the Village may then repair the fire hydrant and charge the property owner on a time and material basis. In addition, the property owner shall be subject to a fine of $200.00 for failing or refusing to allow inspection and/or maintenance of the fire hydrant as provided for in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 21.127)  
Sec. 82-201. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this division shall, upon conviction, be subject to section 1-16. Each day that a violation of the provisions of this division exists or occurs shall constitute a separate violation for which a separate fine or other penalty may be imposed. 
(b)  In addition to being subject to a fine, any person who violates any of the provisions of this division may be subject to injunctive relief to enjoin the continuance of such violation. 
(c)  In addition to being subject to a fine, any person violating any provision of this division shall be subject to the shutoff of water service to the property of such person whereon the violation exists until such time as the violation has been corrected. Such shutoff of water service shall be accomplished in accordance with the notice and hearing requirements set forth in section 82-194. 
(d)  Any property owner found to have reconnected the source of clear water inflow into the sanitary sewer system after having been required to disconnect such source shall be subject to the maximum penalty of $750.00 per day, with each day constituting a separate violation and the shut off of water service according to the hearing requirement set forth in section 82-194. 
(Code 1959, § 21.120)  
Secs. 82-202—82-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 82-231. - Findings; operation. 
(a)  It is hereby found, determined and declared necessary for the best interests of the Village that the existing waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system of the Village be combined into a single utility to be known and designated as the "Combined Waterworks and Sewerage System of the Village of Glenview." 
(b)  All property, real, personal and mixed, comprising the waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system of the Village as described in subsection (a) of this section is hereby found, determined and declared to constitute the properties of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the Village. 
(c)  From and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, such existing waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system shall be owned and operated by the Village as a combined utility to be known as the "combined waterworks and sewerage system of the Village," and all improvements and extensions to such waterworks and/or sewerage system shall be considered as improvements and extensions to such combined utility, and all the properties, assets, obligations and liabilities of all kinds of such waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system, existing, outstanding and accruing or to accrue, shall be held, used, confessed and acknowledged as the properties, assets, obligations and liabilities of such combined utility. 
(d)  The Village waterworks and sewerage system shall be operated as part of the department of public works. Except as otherwise provided in this article, the director of public works shall direct all operations of the waterworks and sewerage system, and shall exercise control and management thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 21.1)  
Sec. 82-232. - Application for water service; payments; fixtures; procedure for plan approval, construction, inspection and acceptance of mains and extensions. 
(a)  No water shall be supplied to any building, structure or premises in the Village from the waterworks system, nor shall any person be permitted to tap any main or make any connection with any supply pipe or service pipe for the purpose of furnishing any water to any building, structure or premises, or for any other purpose, until an application, in writing, shall first have been made to the director of public works by the person desiring such building, structure or premises to be supplied with water, or desiring to tap any such main or make connection with such service pipe or supply pipe. Such application shall set out the full name and address of the applicant and shall state fully all purposes for which a water supply is desired, or for which it is desired to tap such water main or make connection with such service pipe or supply pipe, and the number of feet of frontage and depth of the lot included in the premises to be serviced, and, provided further, that any deposits or payments required to be made have been made by the applicant. Thereupon, such applicant shall be permitted to have water supplied to his building, structure or premises from the waterworks system and to tap any such water main or make connections with any such service pipe or supply pipe, as requested in such application and in accordance with the direction of the director of public works and under his supervision, and to his satisfaction and approval, provided that the tapping of any water main shall be done only by a tapper who is an employee or is duly authorized by the Village. 
(b)  Should the Village install any water main for the purpose of extending the Village waterworks system, wherein water fund revenues are used, any applicant whose building, structure or premises directly benefits from such main extension shall pay with such application a pro rated share of the cost of construction and engineering in accordance with a recapture ordinance on file with the village manager. Such payment shall be in addition to any other connection, tapping or meter fees in force at the time of application. 
(c)  All plumbing fixtures installed within the Village water service area, whether inside or outside of the Village corporate limits, must be water saving fixtures in conformance with the requirements of the Village plumbing code. 
(d)  Should the applicant install any water main or extension for the purpose of connecting to the Village waterworks system, the procedure for plan approval, construction, inspection and acceptance of such mains or extensions will conform to the following: 
(1)  The system shall be constructed in such a manner to provide each lot with a separate connection. The water mains shall extend to the extremities of the applicant's property and shall be designed and constructed in conformance with the requirements of the State Environmental Protection Agency and the Village. 
(2)  Prior to review of the plans and specifications by the Village, a cash review fee of one percent of the estimated construction costs of the required mains will be paid to the Village. 
(3)  A performance bond approved by the village manager shall be posted only in cash sufficient to cover estimated construction expenditures of the required main or extension. If a contract exists, the performance bond shall be 100 percent of the contract and ten percent for contingencies. In the absence of a contract, the estimate of the applicant's engineer shall be used, which shall include ten percent for contingencies. In addition to the bond, the applicant will post with the Village four percent of the first $50,000.00 of construction costs and three percent of the construction costs above $50,000.00 to cover the cost of inspection services by the Village. Such cash shall be posted only after the plans and specifications have been approved by the village engineer and before a construction permit is issued. During the period that such cash shall remain on deposit with the Village, the Village shall have the right and authority to deposit or invest the amount thereof in depositories or securities authorized by law and to retain for its own use and benefit all interest and income therefrom. 
(4)  All main extension plans, costs and estimates shall be checked and approved by the village engineer, and all improvements shall be inspected by him during and after completion of all construction. The applicant's engineer, with the approval of the village engineer, may make alterations and corrections where such are required to conform to existing field conditions. Changes from original plans shall only be approved when accompanied by an adjustment in the cash deposit. Changes, where made, shall be shown on the original working drawings as revisions, and noted "as-built," and signed and sealed by the subdivider's engineer. Before the completed improvements are accepted by the board of trustees, the applicant shall file one sepia copy of as-built working drawings, together with a duly executed bill of sale, in satisfactory form, granting, transferring and conveying to the Village, with proper warranty free of any claims of encumbrances, good title to the water main or extensions and any and all easements required by the Village for maintenance and repair of such mains. 
(5)  Payments from the cash escrow account shall be made periodically upon the certification of the applicant's engineer to the contractor constructing the improvement. Upon final payment to the contractor, any remaining balance shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(6)  If the applicant fails to complete the construction in accordance with the requirements of this article within two years of the date of the cash deposit agreement, the cash deposit shall be forfeited and the Village shall use all or such part of such deposit as may be required to complete the project in accordance with the approved working drawings. The two-year time limit may be extended by the Village when to do so is in the public interest. In the event of such forfeiture, the applicant shall only be entitled to the refund of that portion, if any, of the cash deposit that remains in escrow after completion of the project. 
(Code 1959, § 21.2)  
Sec. 82-233. - Water service pipes supplying two or more premises. 
No service pipe shall be laid or used to supply water to two or more distinct premises or buildings unless separate stopcocks for each of the premises or buildings shall be placed in the parkway outside of such premises as provided in this article and a permit fee shall be charged for each service. 
(Code 1959, § 21.10)  
Sec. 82-234. - Water service pipes for automatic sprinkler systems. 
Water pipes entering premises and used for fire protection only and connected with automatic sprinkler devices shall be supplied from a separate pipe having an independent connection with the main and shall be provided with an outside controlling valve and a meter of a type, design and size to be approved by the director of public works, all at the expense of the person using the automatic sprinkler system, and shall be constructed so as to permit, in the case of necessity, an uninterrupted flow of water. 
(Code 1959, § 21.11)  
Sec. 82-235. - Testing of sprinkler systems. 
Whenever the owner of a sprinkler system desires to make a test thereof, he shall first notify both the director of public works and the chief of the fire department, in writing, to that effect, at least 24 hours prior to the time of such test. All water used in connection with such test shall be measured and paid for by the owner of such sprinkler system. 
(Code 1959, § 21.12)  
Sec. 82-236. - Obstructing access to stopcocks, hydrants, etc.; interfering and obstructing with flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water. 
(a)  No person shall, in any manner, obstruct the access to any stopcock, hydrant or valve, or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street, alley, public grounds or place connected with or a part of the water system or plant, nor pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article, thing or hindrance whatsoever thereon, so as to, in any manner, hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire department in reaching such equipment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to, in any manner, interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water system, plant or water main, hydrant, service pipe, water meter, shutoff box, public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the water system or plant, or to cause, suffer or permit any of such things to be done. Any person who shall perform any act in violation of this section shall be punished as provided in this article, and shall, in addition, be liable for actual damage done or caused to be done. 
(Code 1959, § 21.13)  
Sec. 82-237. - Responsibility for keeping certain pipes, etc., in good repair; failure to repair leaks. 
Every person supplied with water from the village waterworks system shall keep his own service pipe and any stopcocks, buffalo or shutoff boxes and all appurtenances to his service pipe in good repair and protected from the frost at his own expense, and shall also prevent the waste of water by reason of defective pipes or stopcocks; and in case any portion thereof shall be in a leaky or defective condition, such person shall be notified by the director of public works, either in person or in writing, of such leaky or defective condition; and if the leak or defective condition is not repaired within 30 days after such notice, the water supply shall be shut off and shall not be again turned on until such person has complied with all the conditions of this article applicable thereto, except that the village water department will repair service pipe leaks at its own expense when such leaks occur between the water main and the buffalo or shutoff box and shall thaw frozen service pipes between the water main and the buffalo or shutoff box when it shall be proved in the presence of a water department representative that the water flow is not reestablished by first attempting to thaw the service pipe between the buffalo or shutoff box and the meter, and that the water flow is subsequently reestablished by thawing of the service pipe between the buffalo or shutoff box and the water main. Nothing in this section shall relieve the person supplied with water from the responsibility of replacing the service pipe between the water main and the buffalo or shutoff box if notified, in writing, by the director of public works that such portion of such service pipe is defective and in need of replacement; nor shall such person be relieved of the obligation or expense of lowering a shallow service pipe between the water main and the buffalo or shutoff box to prevent repeated freezing of such service pipe. If, upon receipt of written notice from the director of public works to lower or replace a service pipe between the water main and the buffalo or shutoff box because of a defect or shallow location, such person fails or refuses to take appropriate corrective action as requested, then the Village will not accept further responsibility for freezing or repairs of leaks. 
(Code 1959, § 21.14)  
Sec. 82-238. - Licensed plumbers to lay private supply lines, etc. 
No private supply pipe shall be laid or connection made thereto by any other person than a duly licensed or appointed plumber acting under authority of the permit for the laying of such private supply pipe or connection therewith or thereto, as provided in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 21.15)  
Sec. 82-239. - Buffalo or shutoff box. 
(a)  Any building, structure or premises with which it is desired to make connection with the Village waterworks system shall be provided with and shall have installed, at the expense of the owner, occupant or person in charge or control thereof, a buffalo or shutoff box, and such buffalo or shutoff box shall be constructed or located to the satisfaction and approval of the director of public works. No permit shall be issued to connect any building, structure or premises with the waterworks system unless such connection shall be equipped with a buffalo or shutoff box in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install a water service pipe from the water main to the buffalo box in any street or alley in the Village unless such service pipe shall be of copper or ductile iron and of at least one inch internal diameter. 
(Code 1959, § 21.16)  
Sec. 82-240. - Failure of water user to give notice of vacation of premises. 
If any person vacates any premises where water and/or sewerage service is used without notifying the director of public works and paying the balance of the charge due therefor, then the new owner or occupant of the premises shall be liable for and obligated to pay such delinquent charge. 
(Code 1959, § 21.18)  
Sec. 82-241. - Permit required for disturbing or opening streets to lay or make connections with water and sewer pipes. 
No street, alley, public ground or place shall be disturbed or opened for the purpose of laying water or sewer pipes, or making connections with water or sewer pipes unless a permit is first obtained from the department of public works. Such permits shall be granted only to licensed plumbers. The provisions of this section are not intended to apply to the department of public works. 
(Code 1959, § 21.20)  
Sec. 82-242. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished in accordance with section 1-16, and in case of the failure to make repairs after notice to do so, a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which such violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1959, § 21.21)  
Secs. 82-243—82-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - METERS 
 
Sec. 82-261. - Generally. 
(a)  All water consumers supplied by the Village shall be supplied through meters only, and shall pay for the water at the rates and in the manner specified in this article. 
(b)  All meters must be purchased through the department of public works, and the kind and pattern of such water meters shall be as determined by the president and board of trustees. No other kind of meters shall be installed or used. 
(c)  All meters shall be a remote style water meter and shall be installed in a secure and protected area. A one-half-inch electrical metallic tubing raceway shall be installed through the exterior wall of a building to be located adjacent to the gas meter for remote meter wiring. The raceway shall be accessible from where it exits the building to the water meter location after building construction has been completed. The electrical metallic tubing raceway shall be installed in accordance with the Village National Electrical Codes. 
(d)  There shall be no unauthorized connections and/or valves placed in the service line from the buffalo box to the water meter. In cases where this subsection may be inapplicable, the director of public works will prescribe such placement. 
(e)  The owner of any building or premises supplied with water shall ensure that such meters are kept and remain free from obstruction on or about the meters and that such meters are conveniently accessible, as determined by the director of public works or his/her designee, at all reasonable times for the purpose of reading, inspecting or repairing the meters. For purposes of this division, repair shall include, to the extent necessary as determined by the Village, replacement. 
(f)  A duly authorized employee or contractor of the Village shall be permitted at all reasonable hours to inspect or examine such meters for the purpose of reading or repairing the meters. Refusal to permit such inspection, examination, reading or repair shall be unlawful and shall be punished in accordance with Section 1-16, and it shall be lawful for the director of public works or his/her designee to cut off the supply of water to the premises. 
(g)  After the meter is placed, only officers, employees of the department of public works, or authorized contractors of the Village shall be allowed to repair, remove or in any manner interfere with the meter. A full throat ball valve shall be placed on each side of the meter. 
(h)  The cost of such meter and the installation thereof shall be paid by the applicant or the owner of the premises where the meter is placed. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, mar, destroy or in any manner interfere with any such meter. It shall be the duty of such owner of or applicant for such meter to promptly notify the department of public works of all defects in any such meter or its failure to properly register the quantity of water used. 
(Code 1959, § 21.22; Ord. No. 5896, § 2, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 82-262. - Responsibility for installation. 
All meters shall be installed by the department of public works or an authorized contractor of the Village and shall be charged to the owner or occupant of the premises to be supplied with water. All water service pipes shall be of copper or ductile iron, and of such size and weight as the director of public works shall determine. 
(Code 1959, § 21.23; Ord. No. 5896, § 2, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 82-263. - Repairs; replacements; testing. 
The department of public works or an authorized contractor of the Village shall make all repairs on meters, charging the owner of the property with the expense of the cost of repair and parts supplied. If the meter is damaged beyond repair, a new meter shall be installed at the owner's expense, upon notice to such owner. All meters shall be installed under the direction of the director of public works or his/her designee and properly sealed and registered. 
(Code 1959, § 21.24; Ord. No. 5896, § 2, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 82-264. - Failure to operate. 
Whenever any meter, by reason of its being out of repair or for any cause, fails to properly register the water passing through it, the consumer shall be charged at the rate shown for a corresponding time of a previous year under similar conditions. If no record of a previous year exists, then it shall be the duty of the director of public works to estimate or determine, as far as possible, the amount of water consumed during the time such meter fails to operate and the consumer shall pay the amount estimated by the director of public works. 
(Code 1959, § 21.25)  
Sec. 82-265. - Water main connection charges. 
Wherever any permit for a connection with a water pipe is issued, the director of public works, or a person authorized by him, shall tap the main of the system or plant where such connection is to be made and shall insert the corporation stop. All applicants shall be charged as provided in section 30-1 for such connection, in addition to paying any and all fees for materials and labor related to such connections, as established in the Village plumbing code, as amended, and all such fees and charges shall be paid at the time the application provided for in this section is made. 
(Code 1959, § 21.26; Ord. No. 5411, § 9, 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 82-266. - Taps and meters. 
The fees for water main taps and meters, which shall be in addition to connection fees, shall be as outlined in chapter 30-1. 
(Ord. No. 4552, § 3, 8-5-2003; Ord. No. 5113, § 12, 6-17-2008)  
Secs. 82-267—82-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AIR CONDITIONING AND REFRIGERATING SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 82-291. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air conditioning system and refrigeration system includes any combination of equipment, whether compressor or other type, by which heat is removed from the air, wholly or partially, by the use of water. 
Building commissioner means the building commissioner of the village, or such officer or agent as shall be duly authorized to act in the enforcement of this division. 
Person means all users of water from the public supply, including natural persons, partnerships, corporations or associations. Whenever used with respect to a penalty, such term, as applied to a partnership or association, means the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
Rated capacity in tons means: 
(1)  The total maximum Btu per hour of capacity of the installation, divided by 12,000; 
(2)  The nameplate horsepower of any compressor prime mover unit for any comfort air conditioning installation, or two-thirds for any comfort air conditioning installation; or 
(3)  Two-thirds the nameplate horsepower of subsection (2) of this definition for any refrigeration installation. 
System means a single air conditioning refrigerating unit, a group or collection of such units or any other combination of air conditioning or refrigerating apparatus, or both, supplied with water through any single customer service pipe connected to the public water supply system. 
(Code 1959, § 21.27) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 82-292. - Installation permit required; exception; notice of completion of work. 
No person shall install, remodel, add to or operate any air conditioning system or refrigeration system which uses water from the public supply without first having procured a written permit from the building commissioner. All persons are required to give notice of completion of the installation. This section shall not apply to systems with a total rated capacity of less than two tons per 24 hours. 
(Code 1959, § 21.28)  
Sec. 82-293. - Notice or existing installations in lieu of permit. 
All persons who have installed air conditioning system and refrigeration system equipment prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived shall, in lieu of a permit, notify the building commissioner of such existing installation. Failure to give notice shall be considered a violation of this division. 
(Code 1959, § 21.29)  
Sec. 82-294. - Equipment and specifications. 
No water from the public supply shall be used by any air conditioning system or refrigeration system having a total rated capacity of two tons or over per 24 hours unless such air conditioning system or refrigeration system is equipped with evaporative condensers, cooling towers, spray ponds or other water cooling equipment and water conservation devices. Such equipment shall be of a sufficient capacity to ensure that the maximum requirements for makeup water, when operating under full loading at maximum summer temperatures, will not exceed 0.2 gallon per minute, per ton of capacity; however, a system with a total rated capacity of less than two tons per 24 hours may use water from the public supply if equipped with an automatic valve on each unit which will stop the flow of water when the unit is shut down and throttle the flow of water down to the momentary requirements of the system. 
(a)  The director of public works and persons designated by him shall at all reasonable hours have free access to premises supplied with water for air conditioning purposes in order to examine the equipment and ascertain if there is more water being used than allowed by this section. 
(b)  Water regulating devices which will minimize the waste of water shall be installed on all manufacturing processes which require the use of water from the public supply. 
(c)  On all installations using water from a source other than the public supply, there shall be a break between such installations and the public supply so as to prevent back siphonage into the public supply. 
(Code 1959, § 21.30)  
Sec. 82-295. - Use of water permissive only. 
The use by any person of water from the public supply for air conditioning or refrigeration systems is hereby declared permissive only. 
(Code 1959, § 21.31)  
Sec. 82-296. - Payment for water consumed. 
Payment for the water consumed by any air conditioning system or refrigeration system shall be paid for by the user at the rates in force in the Village at the time of such consumption. 
(Code 1959, § 21.32)  
Sec. 82-297. - Revocation of permissive use. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees is hereby authorized to revoke the permissive use of water referred to in section 82-295 by any person from the public supply at any time, if, in its judgment, such revocation is necessary to protect the public health, welfare and safety. The following shall be deemed grounds for revocation of permissive use: 
(1)  Water supply emergency or an impending water supply emergency. 
(2)  Physical conditions hazardous to the potable water supply either within the premises or in the supply mains. 
(3)  Unnecessary waste of water. 
(4)  Continued or willful violations of the terms of this division. 
(b)  If any person fails to discontinue such permissive use after ten days' written notice, the director of public works may order the entire service of such person to be disconnected. 
(Code 1959, § 21.33)  
Sec. 82-298. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any of the terms of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such under this section. 
(Code 1959, § 21.34)  
Secs. 82-299—82-320. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - FIRE HYDRANTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34. 
 
Sec. 82-321. - Opening. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than public officers in the performance of their duties, to open any fire hydrant in the Village without first having complied with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1959, § 21.35)  
Sec. 82-322. - Permit to draw water required; contents. 
Any person, other than a duly authorized employee of the Village or a member of the fire department, desiring to draw water from any fire hydrant in the Village for any purpose whatsoever shall first make application to the director of public works for a permit to draw water from the water system of the Village. 
(Code 1959, § 21.36)  
Sec. 82-323. - Deposits required. 
Applications for permits required by section 82-322 shall be signed by the person desiring to withdraw water or by a fully authorized agent and presented to the director of public works. Prior to the issuance of such permit, a deposit is required by such person or a fully authorized agent of a sum of money sufficient to ensure the payment of the cost of replacing or repairing any part of the fire hydrant or meter that may be broken or damaged by such use. Such deposit shall be the amount provided for in section 30-1 of the Municipal Code. A further deposit as provided for in section 30-1 for a hydrant wrench shall be required to be used therewith. The deposit shall be returned to the depositor upon the return of the wrench and meter and upon inspection of the fire hydrant by the director of public works, showing that no damage was done thereto by such use. Any cost incurred in the replacement or repair of any part of any fire hydrant or meter shall be deducted from the deposit provided in this section. 
(Code 1959, § 21.37; Ord. No. 5411, § 9, 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 82-324. - Issuance of permit. 
Upon compliance with the provisions of sections 82-322 and 82-323, a permit to draw water from the mains through the fire hydrant designated shall be given by the director of public works, and properly executed by him. Such permit shall state, in substance, the manner in which the water is to be withdrawn and the period for which the permit is issued. The person to whom such permit is issued shall have the permit available for inspection by the officials of the Village, upon demand. The permit fee for rental of the fire hydrant, hydrant meter and the water usage fee shall be as provided in section 30-1 of the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1959, § 21.38; Ord. No. 5411, § 9, 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 82-325. - Prerequisites to openings. 
Upon the deposit of such sums as required by section 82-323, the permittee shall make proper connection to the hydrant; provided, however, that such fire hydrant shall not be opened until the permittee shall be satisfied that the connection thereto has been properly made so as not to interfere with the use of the public streets or injure the parkways of such public streets, compromise the water system or public safety, or in any manner impair the efficient operation of the fire hydrant in the event of fire; and that suitable platforms be constructed there to convey drip water to the gutter of such street if such street is paved, or into the nearest suitable culvert if such street is unpaved. 
(Code 1959, § 21.39)  
Sec. 82-326. - Additional applications and deposits. 
Upon the time designated in such application for its termination, the director of public works or his agent shall examine such fire hydrant meter. If the meter shall still be in use, he shall require a further application for a permit, stating the estimated additional time to be required for the use of such fire hydrant meter and shall require a new permit. Upon receipt of such application and the payment of a new permit fee, the director of public works shall thereupon renew the permit for the use of such fire hydrant for the time stated in such supplemental application. 
(Code 1959, § 21.40)  
Sec. 82-327. - Water no longer needed. 
When any person withdrawing water from a fire hydrant shall cease to require the further use of such fire hydrant, or if the time limited in the application shall have expired and no renewal is requested, such person shall immediately notify the director of public works of such fact and return the meter and wrench. The director of public works will compute the sum of money due the Village for the use of such water withdrawn from its mains, and shall give to such person a bill for the water consumed. 
(Code 1959, § 21.41)  
Sec. 82-328. - Disposition of fees and deposits. 
The director of public works shall promptly, upon final settlement with such persons using water under this division, notify the finance director of the amount of payment due for the water consumed and the amount of the deposit to be returned. 
(Code 1959, § 21.42)  
Secs. 82-329—82-350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - WATER USE RESTRICTIONS 
 
Sec. 82-351. - Water supply emergency. 
The president of the village or a duly authorized official of the Village is authorized and empowered, from time to time, as he, in his discretion, may see fit, should he find and determine that a water supply shortage exists in the Village, to meet the health, sanitary, safety, fire protection and public welfare needs of the people of the Village, to declare that a water supply emergency exists and to prohibit the drawing from the water supply lines of the Village or use of such water for any of the following purposes during such emergency period: 
(1)  Sprinkling; 
(2)  Car washing; 
(3)  Air conditioning or cooling; 
(4)  Commercial or industrial uses beyond requirements for sanitation or preserving health; 
(5)  Any other use that is not directly connected with the preservation of health, sanitation, safety or public welfare. 
(Code 1959, § 21.43)  
Sec. 82-352. - Sprinkling restrictions. 
(a)  From May 15 through September 15, lawn sprinkling shall not be permitted between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., within or outside the Village limits, when supplied through the Village water system. No lawn sprinkling is permitted on the 31st day of any month. 
(b)  Lawn sprinkling is based on an odd/even day system. The last digit of an address determines the day. If an address ends in an even number, the resident can water on even calendar days; if the address ends in an odd number, the resident can water on odd calendar days. 
(c)  Watering of newly laid sod, hydroseed, trees and shrubs will be allowed a 90-day exemption to the restrictions set forth in subsections (a) and (b). 
(Code 1959, § 21.44; Ord. No. 5932, § 2, 9-1-2015)  
Sec. 82-353. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person charged with a violation of this division, who shall be found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined not less than $50.00, nor more than $500.00 for each such offense. Each day a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 21.45)  
Secs. 82-354—82-370. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - RATES AND CHARGES 
 
Sec. 82-371. - Sufficiency of rates. 
The rates for water and sewer services shall be sufficient at all times to: 
(1)  Pay the cost of operation and maintenance of the combined waterworks and sewerage system; 
(2)  Provide an adequate depreciation fund; and 
(3)  Pay the principal of and interest on all revenue bonds issued for the construction and maintenance of the Village combined waterworks and sewerage system. 
(Code 1959, § 21.4)  
Sec. 82-372. - Rate amounts. 
Owners and tenants of premises sold, delivered or furnished with water and/or sewerage facilities by the Village shall pay rates as outlined in chapter 30-1. 
(Code 1959, § 21.5; Ord. No. 4403, § 1, 6-4-2002; Ord. No. 4474, § 1, 12-3-2002; Ord. No. 4536, § 1, 6-17-2003; Ord. No. 4658, § 1, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 4723, § 1, 12-6-2004; Ord. No. 4782, § 2, 8-2-2005; Ord. No. 4877, § 2, 6-20-2006; Ord. No. 4878, § 2, 6-20-2006; Ord. No. 5064, § 2, 12-3-2007; Ord. No. 5065, § 2, 12-3-2007; Ord. No. 5113, § 12, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 5167, § 2, 12-9-2008; Ord. No. 5168, § 2, 12-9-2008)  
Sec. 82-373. - Payment of charges. 
Any person becoming liable under section 82-372 for a charge for water or sewerage service in accordance with the rate provisions set forth in such section shall pay the full amount of such charge within 21 days after the date of mailing of the bill, or such charge shall become delinquent. Failure to pay the charge within the time specified shall subject the violator to a penalty of ten percent of the unpaid amount of such delinquent charge, which shall be collected as part of the delinquent charge. Any person who specifies a valid reason why such penalty should be waived because of unusual circumstances may obtain a waiver for the amount of the penalty upon application to the village manager; provided, however, that such person has not incurred a penalty or received a waiver during the preceding four quarters. 
(Code 1959, § 21.6)  
Sec. 82-374. - Shutoff of water for nonpayment of bills. 
In case of failure of any person to pay the water or sewerage rate charged against any building, structure or premises owned or occupied by him/her or in his/her possession, charge or control, the water on such premises shall be shut off and shall not be turned on until all bills and claims by the Village shall have been paid in full. The owners of the property shall be held liable for all charges until paid, and it shall be lawful for the director of public works of the Village to cut off or withhold the supply of water from such premises without any liability whatsoever against the Village or him/her-self. The fees for water shut-off and water restoration, which shall be in addition to all bills and claims owed the Village, shall be paid as outlined in section 30-1 of the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1959, § 21.7; Ord. No. 5411, § 9, 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 82-375. - Recovery of monies due. 
If any water or sewerage bill remains unpaid for more than 30 days after the date upon which the bill is due and payable to the Village, the village manager is hereby authorized, in accordance with law, to file notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds or registrar of titles of the County to foreclose the lien, and to sue the occupant or user of the real estate in a civil action to recover the money due for services rendered, plus reasonable attorneys' fees, to be fixed by the court. Any such judgment shall be enforced in accordance with law. In addition to the charges and penalty due, the Village is entitled to collect the costs of filing the notice of lien, foreclosing the lien and litigation costs, together with all legal expenses incurred in connection with the collection of the amount due. 
(Code 1959, § 21.8)  
Sec. 82-376. - Responsibility for payment of bills; reduction or rebate for leakage; notice to department of public works of vacation of premises. 
(a)  The owner and/or tenant of premises supplied with water and/or sewerage service shall be held responsible for all water registered by the meter and for all maintenance and/or repair charges levied and/or incurred by the Village to maintain the apparatus which supplies water and/or sewer service, including, but not limited to, water meters, water service lines, buffalo boxes and sewer service lines. 
(b)  No reduction shall be made or rebate allowed to any consumer on account of leakage or alleged leakage in any pipe, tank or other apparatus or device. 
(c)  Should the owner or tenant of a premises supplied with water and/or sewerage service not pay the charges for such water and/or sewerage services within 60 days from the date that a bill for such services is mailed to the owner or tenant, then and in such event the water supplied to such premises shall be terminated under order of the director of public works not less than ten days after written notification of such water shutoff is mailed by regular mail to the owner or tenant. 
(d)  Any person who shall vacate any premises or enter upon and occupy any premises shall immediately, before vacating or moving from such premises, notify the director of public works and request a reading of the meter. The person responsible for the payment of the water and sewerage bill shall pay in accordance with the actual amount of water used, and the village manager shall apply as much of the deposit required by section 82-232 as is necessary and shall return the balance, if any, to the person making such deposit and take a receipt therefor. 
(Code 1959, § 21.17)  
Sec. 82-377. - Sanitary sewer user charge. 
(a)  Sanitary sewer enterprise fund. The sanitary sewer enterprise fund established by Village Ordinance No. 2629 is hereby continued, and shall be supported by the sanitary sewer user charges established from or after the effective date of such ordinance utilized exclusively for the operation and maintenance, including replacement, of the sanitary sewer system of the Village. 
(b)  Established. There is hereby established a sanitary sewer user charge, which shall be based upon the actual or estimated use of the sanitary sewer system of the Village. Such charge is intended to require each user of the sanitary sewer system to pay their proportionate share of the operation and maintenance costs, including replacement, of the sanitary sewer system of the Village. Such charges are detailed in section 82-372. 
(c)  Computation. The sanitary sewer user charge rate shall be computed as follows: 
(1)  The projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the sanitary sewer system for the year, including a replacement fund, will be determined. 
(2)  The volume of wasterwater expected to flow through the system will be estimated. 
(3)  The cost per 1,000 gallons of flow through the system will be computed. 
(d)  Review and revision. The sanitary sewer user charge shall be reviewed annually and revised as necessary to reflect any change in operation, maintenance and replacement. 
(e)  Measurement of flow. The volume of flow used for computing the total user charge shall be metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of 1,000 gallons; provided, however, that: 
(1)  The measurement of flow of any person discharging wastes into the sanitary sewer system who procures any part or all of his water from sources other than the Village water supply system, all or part of which is discharged into the sanitary sewer system, shall be estimated on a per capita consumption basis. 
(2)  Water used for yard sprinkling, if measured by a separate irrigation meter, shall be exempt from the sewer user charge. The irrigation meter must be installed in a manner deemed appropriate by the Village. The cost of installation, maintenance and replacement of such irrigation meter shall be borne by the property owner. 
(f)  Co-rated. The rates to be charged for sanitary sewer service are detailed in section 82-372. 
(Code 1959, § 21.109)  
Sec. 82-378. - Revenues. 
(a)  All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewerage account of the sewerage fund. All such revenues and moneys shall be held by the finance director separate and apart from all other funds of the Village. 
(b)  The finance director shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other funds and moneys incident to the operation of such system as they may be delivered to him, and he shall deposit such amounts in the account of the fund designated as the sanitary sewer enterprise fund of the Village. The finance director shall administer such funds in every respect in the manner provided by statute. 
(Code 1959, § 21.110)  
Sec. 82-379. - Accounts; audit. 
The finance director shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to an audit by an independent auditing concern to be made of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the sewerage fund. The financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following: 
(1)  Billing data to show the total number of gallons billed. 
(2)  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year. 
(3)  Number of users connected to the system. 
(Code 1959, § 21.111)  
Sec. 82-380. - Access to books, documents, papers and records. 
The State Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the Village which are applicable to the Village system or user charges for the purpose of making audits, examinations, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions of any State grant. 
(Code 1959, § 21.113)  
Secs. 82-381—82-400. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 82-401. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Agency means the State Environmental Protection Agency. 
Approved means backflow prevention devices, methods or installations approved by the Village based on the Research Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern California, American Water Works Association, American National Standards Institute or American Society of Sanitary Engineering, or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation. 
Auxiliary water system means a source of water outside of the Village's public water supply system. No connection to the Village's public water supply system shall be made with any other water system without the approval of the local authority. 
Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the intended source of the potable water supply. 
Backflow prevention device means any device, method or type of construction intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All devices used for backflow prevention in the State must meet the standards of the State plumbing code and the State Environmental Protection Agency. 
Consumer and customer mean the owner, official custodian or person in control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system. 
Consumer's or customer's water system means any water system serving the premises, commencing at the outlet side of the service pipe shutoff valve location as stated in this division. 
Contamination means the introduction into water of micro-organisms, chemicals, wastes or wastewater in a concentration that makes water unfit for its intended use. 
Cross connection means any connection through which a supply of potable water could be contaminated or polluted. 
Double check valve assembly means an assembly composed of single, independently acting check valves, including the shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing the water tightness of each check valve. 
Fixed air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the receptacle. 
Health hazard means any condition, device or practice in a water system or its operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well-being of consumers. The term "severe," as used to qualify the term "health hazard," means a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in death or significant reduction in the quality of life. 
Inspection means a plumbing inspection to carefully and critically examine all materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of a plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the State plumbing code, 77 Ill. Admin. Code 890. 
Local authority means the village president and board of trustees and their duly authorized agents. 
Nonpotable water means water not safe for drinking, personal use or culinary use as determined by the requirements of 35 Ill. Admin. Code 604. 
Plumbing means the actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension of a plumbing system by any person. Such term includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including, without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems from the source of a private water supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to within and about any building where persons live, work or assemble. Such term includes all piping from the discharge of the pumping unit to and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Such term includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a building drain and a sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building where persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system five feet beyond the foundation walls. 
Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
Potable water means water which meets the requirements of 35 Ill. Admin. Code 604 for drinking, culinary and domestic purposes. 
Potential cross connection means a fixture or appurtenance with a threaded hose connection, tampered spout or other connection which would facilitate extension of the water supply line beyond its legal termination point. 
Process fluid means any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, pollutional or system hazard if introduced into the public or a consumer's potable water system, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Polluted or contaminated waters; 
(2)  Process waters; 
(3)  Used waters originating from the public water supply system, which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; 
(4)  Cooling waters; 
(5)  Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams or irrigation systems; 
(6)  Chemicals in solution or suspension; 
(7)  Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes. 
Public water supply system means all mains, pipes and structures owned and/or maintained by the Village through which water is obtained and distributed to the public, including wells and well structures, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing potable water. 
Reduced pressure zone principle backflow prevention device (RPZ) means a device containing a minimum of two independently acting check valves, together with an automatically operating pressure differential relief valve located between the two check valves. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between the two check valves shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the check valves at less than the supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks. 
Service connection means the physical connection to the water main, including all fittings and appurtenances, through which water is supplied to the consumer. 
Survey means the collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping system regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and must include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of all cross connection control devices and methods located within the customer's piping system. The survey shall be completed on a form supplied by the Village. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § A) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 82-402. - General policy. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of the rules and regulations set forth in this division are to: 
(1)  Protect the public water supply system from contamination or pollution by isolating within the customer's water system contaminants or pollutants which could backflow through the service connection into the public water supply system. 
(2)  Promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections, actual or potential, between the public or consumer's potable water system and nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems containing substances of unknown or questionable quality. 
(3)  Provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross connection control which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the public and consumer's potable water systems. 
(b)  Application. The rules and regulations set forth in this division shall apply to all premises served by the public potable water supply system of the Village. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § B)  
Sec. 82-403. - Prohibited connections. 
(a)  No person shall establish or maintain, or permit to be established or maintained, any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply, other than the regular public water supply of the Village, may enter the supply or distribution system of such municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved, in writing, by the director of public works and/or plumbing inspectors and the State Environmental Protection Agency. 
(b)  No connection shall be permitted between the public water supply system and any other water supply not of equal or better bacteriological and chemical quality as determined by inspection and analysis by the agency and/or the Village. 
(c)  There shall be no arrangement or connection by which contamination may enter the public water supply system. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § C)  
Sec. 82-404. - Surveys and investigations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works to cause surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties and premises served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated as often as the director of public works shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. 
(b)  The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the certified cross connection control device inspector or his duly authorized agent (CCCDI) for the inspection of the presence or absence of cross connections within the consumer's premises and testing, repair and maintenance of cross connection control devices within the consumer's premises. 
(c)  On request by the director of public works or his authorized representatives, the consumer shall furnish information regarding the piping system for water use within the consumer's premises and cross connection inspection results. The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the director of public works and/or his duly authorized agent for the verification of information submitted by the consumer regarding the piping system for water use and cross connection inspection results. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to arrange periodic surveys of water use practices on the consumer's premises to determine whether there are actual or potential cross connections to the consumer's water system through which contamination or pollution could backflow into the consumer's or the public potable water system. All cross connection controls or other plumbing inspections must be conducted in accordance with 225 ILCS 320/3(1). 
(e)  It is the responsibility and financial obligation of the water consumer to prevent backflow into the public water supply system by ensuring that: 
(1)  All cross connections are removed, or approved cross connection control devices are installed for control of backflow and backsiphonage. 
(2)  Cross connection control devices are installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
(3)  Cross connection control devices are inspected at least annually by a CCCDI. The inspection of mechanical devices shall include physical testing in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
(4)  Testing and recording is accomplished as follows: 
a.  Each device shall be tested at least annually or more frequently if recommended by the manufacturer or director of public works. 
b.  Records submitted to the director of public works shall be available for inspection by agency personnel in accordance with 415 ILCS 5/4(e). 
c.  Each device shall have a tag attached, listing the date of the most recent test, name of the CCCDI, and type and date of repairs. 
(5)  A maintenance log is maintained, which shall include the following: 
a.  Date of each test; 
b.  Name and approval number of the person performing the inspection or test; 
c.  Test results/inspection; 
d.  Repairs or servicing required; 
e.  Repairs and dates completed; and 
f.  Services performed and dates completed. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § D)  
Sec. 82-405. - Backflow prevention devices.
