(a)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each water service line to a consumer's water system when, in the judgment of the director of public works or his authorized representative, based upon State Environmental Protection Agency regulations, an actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system may exist. 
(b)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each water service line to a consumer's water system where the following conditions exist: 
(1)  A premises having an auxiliary water system, unless such auxiliary water system is accepted as an additional source by the director of public works and the source is approved by the agency and local authority. 
(2)  A premises where any substance exists which can create an actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system. 
(3)  A premises having internal cross connections that, in the judgment of the director of public works, are not correctable or intricate plumbing arrangements which make it impractical to determine whether or not cross connections exist. 
(4)  A premises where, because of security requirements or other prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a complete cross connection survey. 
(5)  A premises having a repeated history of cross connections being established or reestablished. 
(c)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each water line to a consumer's water system serving, but not necessarily limited to, the following types of facilities unless the director of public works determines that no actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system exists: 
(1)  Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics or nursing homes. 
(2)  Laboratories. 
(3)  Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or stormwater pumping stations. 
(4)  Food or beverage processing plants. 
(5)  Chemical plants. 
(6)  Metal plating industries. 
(7)  Petroleum processing or storage plants. 
(8)  Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors. 
(9)  Carwashes. 
(10)  All commercial, retail and industrial accounts, all water services larger than two inches, all irrigation lines and all fire sprinkler lines. 
(d)  Where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or within any premises, such pump shall be equipped with a low pressure cutoff device designed to shut off the booster pump when the pressure in the service line on the suction side of the pump drops to 20 pounds per square inch (psi) or less. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the water consumer to maintain the low pressure cutoff device in proper working order and to certify to the director of public works at least once a year that the device is operable. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § E)  
Sec. 82-406. - Type of protection required. 
(a)  The type of protection required shall depend on the degree of hazard which exists, as follows: 
(1)  An approved fix air gap shall be installed where the public water supply system may be contaminated, causing a severe health hazard. 
(2)  An approved fixed air gap or an approved reduced pressure zone principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the public water supply system may be contaminated, causing a system or health hazard. 
(3)  An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure zone principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the public water supply system may be polluted with substances that could cause a pollution hazard not dangerous to health. 
(b)  The type of protection required under section 82-405 shall be an approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device. 
(c)  Where a public water supply or an auxiliary water supply is used for a fire protection system, reduced pressure principle backflow preventors shall be installed between the fire sprinkler systems connected to the public water supply system, when: 
(1)  The sprinkler system contains antifreeze and/or chemical additives; 
(2)  Water may be pumped into the system from another source and can be connected to the sprinkler system. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § F)  
Sec. 82-407. - Approval required. 
All backflow prevention devices, methods, installations and maintenance required by this division shall be approved by the Village based on the Research Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern California, American Water Works Association, American Society of Sanitary Engineering or American National Standards Institute, or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation to be in compliance with applicable industry specifications. The manufacturer's maintenance manual shall be available on-site. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § G)  
Sec. 82-408. - Inspection and maintenance. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the consumer at the premises on which backflow prevention devices required by this division are installed, to have inspections, tests, maintenance and repairs made in accordance with the following schedule or more often where inspections indicate a need or are specified in the manufacturer's instructions: 
(1)  Fixed proper air gap separations shall be inspected at the time of installation and at least annually thereafter. 
(2)  Double check valve assemblies shall be inspected and tested for tightness at the time of installation and at least annually thereafter, and required service performed within 15 days. 
(3)  Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention devices shall be tested at least annually or more frequently if recommended by the manufacturer. 
(b)  Testing shall be performed by a person who has been approved by the agency as competent to service the device. Proof of such approval shall be in writing. 
(c)  Each device shall have a tag attached, including the information required in sections 82-404(e)(4)c. and 82-404(e)(5). 
(d)  Whenever backflow prevention devices required by this division are found to be defective, they shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the consumer within 15 days or as specified by the director of public works. 
(e)  Backflow prevention devices shall not be bypassed, made inoperative, removed or otherwise made ineffective without specific authorization by the director of public works. 
(f)  Copies of all test results shall be forwarded to the director of public works at the time of each inspection as described in section 82-404. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § H)  
Sec. 82-409. - Corrective actions. 
Nothing in this division shall prevent the Village from taking such other action as it deems necessary to prevent or remedy a violation of this article. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § I)  
Sec. 82-410. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The director of public works may deny or discontinue, after ten days' prior written notice to the occupants thereof, the water service to any premises wherein any backflow prevention device required by this division is not installed, tested, maintained and repaired in a manner acceptable to the director of public works, or if it is found that the backflow prevention device has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross connection exists on the premises, or if a low pressure cutoff required by this division is not installed and maintained in working order. 
(b)  In the case of an identified cross connection, the director of public works or his duly authorized representative shall take immediate action to terminate the potable supply of water to the premises, without notice; provided, however, that written notice shall be given to the owner or occupant of the premises as soon as practicable under the circumstances as exist at the time such water service to the premises is terminated. 
(c)  Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the consumer has corrected or eliminated such conditions or defects in conformance with this division and to the satisfaction of the director of public works, and the required reconnection fee is paid. 
(d)  Any person charged with a violation of this division, who shall be found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined as provided in section 1-16. Each day a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, ch. 21, art. VIII, § J)  
Chapter 86 - VEGETATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 86-1—86-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TREES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 86-31. - Purpose. 
The regulation of trees by this article, supplemented by the Tree Standards Manual, is intended to accomplish the protection, preservation, replacement, planting and maintenance of trees within the Village and the following related goals: 
(1)  Protect and enhance the quality of life and the general welfare of the Village and its residents, and conserve and enhance the Village's physical and aesthetic environment by: 
a.  Reducing energy consumption by providing summer shade and blocking winter wind; 
b.  Providing a buffer and screen against noise, and light pollution; and 
c.  Reducing air pollution through the removal of carbon dioxide, generation of oxygen and the precipitation of dust and other airborne pollutants. 
(2)  Protect and increase property values in a manner that maintains each property owner's enjoyment of his/her property. 
(3)  Recognize historic significance and maintain the natural heritage of the community. 
(4)  Protect and enhance our natural environment by: 
a.  Providing habitat and food that are essential for wildlife, including migratory and nesting birds, to sustain them and the many benefits they provide, including control of insects. 
b.  Stabilizing topsoil by preventing or minimizing soil erosion and sedimentation. 
c.  Controlling stormwater runoff through the detention and absorption of water. 
(5)  Eliminate trees that constitute a threat, danger or nuisance to the public or property in the Village, or that may be dangerous to the health of other trees and vegetation in the Village. 
(6)  Protect and restore, to the greatest extent possible, denuded soil that results from construction and grading work, and protect existing healthy trees during the course of development. 
(7)  Ensure diversity of tree species within individual neighborhoods and the Village of Glenview as a whole. 
(8)  Utilize best efforts to ensure an aesthetically pleasing landscape design and maintain neighborhood characteristics. 
(Code 1959, § 20.1; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Construction means any manmade change, other than maintenance of existing structures, paved areas or utilities, to improved or unimproved real estate, including, without limitation, the construction or installation of new or enlargement of existing structures, streets or utilities; dredging, filling, drilling, mining, grading, paving or excavating operations; demolition; and open storage of materials. 
Damage means to take any direct or indirect action that causes, or is reasonably likely to cause, the death of a tree or a significant loss of a tree's structural integrity, including, without limitation, destruction, poisoning, carving, mutilating, girdling or severing the main trunk, leader or large branches, touching with live wires, crushing or exposing the roots, digging or drilling any hole or trench within the root zone, filling with soil or other materials within the root zone, compacting a substantial portion of the soil in the root zone or moving a tree to another location. Without limitation of the foregoing, such term does not include the pruning of trees in accordance with national pruning standards. 
Diameter at breast height (DBH) means the diameter of the trunk of a tree, measured in inches, at a point four and one-half feet above the existing grade at the base of the tree (or circumference divided by pi). 
Diseased tree means any of the following types of trees: 
(1)  Trees infected with Dutch elm disease or oak wilt, as determined by laboratory analysis or by any other reliable means or positive field test. 
(2)  Trees, or parts thereof, in a dead or dying condition that may serve as breeding places for the European elm bark beetle, Dutch elm disease or oak wilt, or phloem necrosis. 
(3)  Trees of any species or variety infected with the Asian long horned beetle or the Asian cerambycid beetle (anoplophora glabripennis). 
(4)  Trees of any species or variety infected with any other disease known or which may be discovered in the future which may threaten the health of other trees or vegetation in the Village. 
Invasive species means a plant that has a tendency to spread and which is believed to cause damage to the environment, human ecology and/or human health. 
Landmark trees means all non-nuisance species, varieties and cultivars of the trees listed in the species list in the Village Tree Standards Manual, of a size as follows: 
(1)  Class A, 16 inches DBH; 
(2)  Class B, 16 inches DBH; and 
(3)  Class C, 20 inches DBH. 
National pruning standards means the most current ANSI A300 standards (referred to in this article as "pruning standards") and all updates as described in the Village Tree Standards Manual, which are incorporated into this article by this reference. 
Nuisance tree means an invasive species or the following species of trees: 
(1)  Buckthorn; 
(2)  Russian olive; and 
(3)  Ailanthus/tree-of-heaven. 
Nursery stock standards means the American Standards for Nursery Stock, as approved by the American Standards Institute, Inc., issued as ANSI Z60.1990, as such standards exist on the date of adoption of this Code, and all updates as described in the Village Tree Standards Manual, which are incorporated into this article by reference. 
Public tree means any tree located on right-of-way of the Village or any other jurisdiction, or any other tree owned by the Village. 
Public works means the department of the Village that is responsible for the administration of this article. 
Regulated tree activity means any activity specified in Section 86-33. 
Remove and removal mean the physical detachment or elimination of a tree, or the effective detachment or elimination of a tree through damage or otherwise. Without limitation of the foregoing, such terms do not include the pruning of trees in accordance with the pruning standards. 
Root zone means the area inscribed by an imaginary circular line on the ground beneath a tree, having as its centerpoint the center of the trunk of the tree and a radius equal to one foot for each inch of tree diameter. 
Subdivision code means Chapter 66, and the subdivision and engineering guide, as amended. 
Tree means a self-supporting, woody plant, together with its root system, having a well-defined stem or trunk or a multi-stemmed trunk system, a more or less well-defined crown and a mature height of at least eight feet. Such term shall not include trees in containers or nursery stock trees maintained for resale. 
Tree emergency means the existence of any tree within the Village, that has become an immediate danger or hazard to persons or property as a result of any tornado, windstorm, flood, freeze, or other natural disaster. 
Tree permit means the permit required pursuant to Section 86-61. 
Tree permit application means the application required for issuance of a tree permit pursuant to Section 86-62. 
Tree replacement list means the list of species eligible as tree replacements as set forth in the Village tree standards. 
Village Manager means the Village Manager or designee. 
Village tree standards means the standards, rules, applications and tree replacement lists contained in the tree value classes and specifications for public and private improvements, as amended. 
Zoning code means Chapter 98, as amended. 
(Code 1959, § 20.2; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 86-33. - Regulated tree activities. 
The following activities are regulated tree activities: 
(1)  Any activity that anticipates or involves the actual or reasonably likely damage or removal of a landmark or public tree. 
(2)  Any application for approval of a subdivision of land, as defined in the subdivision code, that anticipates or involves the actual or reasonably likely damage or removal of any landmark or public tree. 
(3)  Any application for a special permit or site plan review for development under the zoning code, that anticipates or involves the actual or reasonably likely damage or removal of any landmark or public tree. 
(4)  Any application for a building or demolition permit under this article, that involves the construction, alteration or enlargement of any building, structure or surface by adding an impervious area of 400 square feet or more to the land on which it is located and that anticipates or involves the actual or reasonably likely damage or removal of any landmark or public tree. 
(Code 1959, § 20.3; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-34. - Lien for abatement costs. 
(a)  Whenever billing for the removal or abatement of an illegal tree under this article, by or under the supervision of Village personnel, remains unpaid 60 days after billing for such service has been rendered, the village manager may file a statement of lien claim with the recorder of deeds of the County. Such statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the billing, plus administrative costs, and a notice that the Village claims a lien for the total amount. 
(b)  If the resident whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the village manager has knowledge thereof, notice shall also be mailed to the owner of the premises. 
(c)  The failure of the village manager to mail such notice or the failure of the owner of the premises to receive such notice shall not affect the right of the Village to foreclose the lien for the unpaid services rendered. 
(d)  The village attorney may institute foreclosure proceedings, in the name of the Village, in the circuit court, against any property for which a lien claim for unpaid service charges and administrative costs has been duly filed. 
(Code 1959, § 20.50)  
Sec. 86-35. - Tree value classes. 
(a)  The following four tree value classes are recognized based on their aesthetic and ecological value, rate of growth and whether they create nuisance conditions: 
(1)  A, outstanding quality; 
(2)  B, good quality; 
(3)  C, moderate quality; and 
(4)  N, nuisance. 
(b)  The following trees are classified as set forth in this subsection: 
Ailanthus/tree-of-heaven 	N 
Apple 	B 
Arborvitae 	A 
Ash 	B 
Aspen 	C 
Bald cypress and metasequoia 	B 
Birch 	B 
Black locust 	C 
Box elder 	C 
Buckthorn 	N 
Catalpa 	B 
Cherry 	B 
Cottonwood 	C 
Douglas fir 	B 
Elm (native species) 	B 
English elm 	B 
Fir 	B 
Hackberry 	B 
Hawthorn 	B 
Hickory 	A 
Honey locust 	B 
Horse chestnut and buckeye 	B 
Ironwood (hop hornbeam) A 	
Kentucky coffee tree 	B 
Linden/basswood 	B 
Magnolia 	B 
Mulberry 	C 
Oak (red oak subfamily) 	A 
Oak (white oak subfamily) 	A 
Pines 	B 
Russian olive 	N 
Siberian elm 	C 
Silver maple 	C 
Spruces 	B 
Sugar maple 	B 
Sycamore 	B 
Walnut 	B 
Willow 	C 
 
(Code 1959, Attachment A)  
Sec. 86-36. - Violations. 
(a)  Penalties. Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $1,000.00, in addition to the applicable tree replacement fee as provided in subsection (b). Each day such violation or failure to comply is permitted to exist after notification thereof, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Tree replacement fee. In addition to the penalties described in subsection (a), any person who violates this article by destroying or removing a protected tree shall pay a tree replacement fee. The tree replacement fee shall be set forth in the Village Tree Standards Manual. 
(c)  Suspension or revocation of business license. Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article two or more times during any 18-month period shall be subject to the suspension or revocation of their business license pursuant to Chapter 22. 
(Code 1959, § 20.60; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Secs. 86-37—86-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LANDMARK TREES 
 
Sec. 86-61. - Permit. 
(a)  When required. Except as expressly provided in subsection (b), tree permits shall be required: 
(1)  To remove a landmark tree; and 
(2)  Prior to the commencement of any regulated tree activity involving a landmark tree. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Pruning. A tree permit shall not be required for the pruning of any landmark tree in compliance with the pruning standards. 
(2)  Tree emergency. 
a.  In the case of a tree emergency, the Director of Public Works is hereby authorized to: 
1.  Issue a tree permit without a tree permit application; 
2.  Waive the requirement for a tree permit set forth in this section; or 
3.  Waive any of the other regulations of this section or this article. 
b.  Notwithstanding any other regulations of this article, if a tree emergency occurs, the person endangered by the tree emergency may take any reasonable action necessary to avoid or eliminate the immediate danger or hazard. The action taken shall be an action that is least likely, under the circumstances, to cause damage or removal of any tree, and the Village assumes no responsibility or liability for any such action taken. The person taking such action shall document the reasons for the tree emergency by photograph or videotape of the tree emergency condition and the damage or hazard created by such condition, and shall report the action taken to any of the above Village officials within 48 hours after the action is taken. 
(Code 1959, § 20.10; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-62. - Permit application. 
(a)  Submission. Applications for a landmark tree permit shall be submitted to the Village on a form provided by the Director of Public Works as set forth in the Village Tree Standards Manual. 
(b)  Approval and issuance. Upon receipt of a landmark tree permit application, the Director of Public Works or his designee shall, at his discretion, visit and inspect the property, and contiguous and adjoining lots in order to evaluate the tree permit application. The Director of Public Works shall approve a tree permit application and issue a tree permit if, based on the tree permit application, inspection of the property and all other reliable and relevant information, the Director of Public Works determines that all of the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  The proposed regulated tree activity has been planned and will be performed in such a manner, to such a degree and with such equipment and personnel so as to: 
a.  Reasonably involve the least amount of damage or removal of the tree; and 
b.  Not defeat or be inconsistent with the purposes and intent of this article as set forth in Section 86-31. 
(2)  The tree permit application, including, without limitation, the construction activity protection plan, if required, satisfies the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Conditions. As a condition of the issuance of a tree permit, the Director of Public Works may require one or more of the following: 
(1)  Any landmark or public tree that may be affected by such regulated tree activity be preserved and protected; and 
(2)  Any or all landmark or public trees that may be affected by such regulated tree activity be replaced in accordance with the tree replacement standards set forth in section 86-64. 
(d)  Denial. If the tree permit application, inspection of the property and consideration of all other reliable and relevant information reveal that the applicant has not satisfied the conditions of subsection (b) or has not otherwise justified the damage or removal of trees to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works, then the Director of Public Works shall promptly notify the applicant that the tree permit application is denied and that no tree permit shall be issued. 
(e)  Appeals. 
(1)  Decisions of Director of Public Works. Appeals from any decision of the Director of Public Works issuing or revoking a tree permit, denying a tree permit application, or granting or denying an exemption pursuant to subsection (e) shall be heard by the Natural Resources Commission. All decisions made by the Natural Resources Commission will be recommended to the Village Manager for final decision. Appeals of the Village Manager's decision shall be heard by the Village Board of Trustees. 
(2)  Decisions of Village Manager. The decision of the Village Manager may be appealed to the Village Board of trustees, but the board of trustees is not obligated to consider the appeal. 
(3)  Stay of regulated tree activities. The filing of a written notice of appeal pursuant to this subsection shall stay all regulated tree activity and other activity for which a tree permit subject to the appeal has been granted or sought. 
(f)  Term, expiration and renewal. Tree permits shall have no expiration dates unless otherwise indicated. 
(Code 1959, § 20.11; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-63. - Permit revocation and remedies. 
Tree permits shall be subject to the same provisions for revocation and other remedies as are applicable to building permits issued pursuant to chapter 18. 
(Code 1959, § 20.12; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-64. - Protection and preservation. 
(a)  Required. 
(1)  Regulated tree activities. All regulated tree activities shall be planned and performed in such a manner, to such a degree and with such equipment and personnel so as to: 
a.  Reasonably involve the least amount of damage or removal of landmark or public trees; and 
b.  Not defeat or be inconsistent with the purposes and intent of this article as set forth in Section 86-31. 
(2)  Construction activity. To ensure the protection of landmark and public trees before, during and after construction activity, a construction activity protection plan shall be required in accordance with Section 86-65. 
(b)  Replacement. 
(1)  Exemptions. The Director of Public Works shall have the authority to waive tree replacement requirements if he or she determines that any of the following circumstances exist: 
a.  A landmark or public tree, due to natural causes, is dead, dangerous or interferes with any existing or proposed public improvements, is in dangerous proximity to any public utility lines or related facilities, or is a diseased tree or otherwise unsafe, unhealthy or insect-infected and constitutes a hazard to persons, property or other trees. 
b.  A landmark or public tree, due to natural causes, obstructs any street, sidewalk or pedestrian path, to such an extent that such protected tree interferes with free passage and clear view along such street, sidewalk or pedestrian path and at any street or driveway intersection. 
c.  Removal of a landmark or public tree is necessary to properly enhance the health and appearance of existing trees, shrubs and other vegetation in a manner to implement a landscaping scheme that the Director of Public Works determines complies with the current standards generally observed by professionals in the arboriculture, forestry, landscaping and landscape architecture professions. 
d.  The applicant demonstrates a hardship or special and unique circumstances. 
(2)  Replacement. 
a.  Required; exceptions. 
1.  Replacement shall be mandatory for the damage or removal of any landmark or public tree in the course of a regulated tree activity, except in the following instances: 
i.  Damage or removal of a nuisance tree. 
ii.  Damage or removal of a landmark or public tree which, due to natural causes, is dead, dangerous or interferes with any existing or proposed public improvements, is in dangerous proximity to any public utility line or related facility or is a diseased tree or otherwise unsafe, unhealthy or insect-infected and constitutes a hazard to persons, property or other trees. 
iii.  Where a landmark tree is lawfully removed, and where, following such removal, the remaining trees on the property on which it was located total at least 16 inches DBH for every 1,000 square feet of land area in the combined area of the required front yard and buildable area of the lot, and, further provided, that a minimum of 16 inches DBH of remaining trees is located in the required front yard of the property. 
2.  Tree replacement shall be required regardless of whether the landmark tree that is damaged or removed is located on the same lot on which the regulated tree activity takes place. 
b.  Formula. Landmark and public trees shall be replaced by trees as specified in the Village Tree Standards Manual. 
c.  Specifications. All tree replacements shall conform to the specifications set forth in the Village Tree Standards Manual. 
d.  Fee in lieu of replacement. An applicant may request that the Village accept a tree replacement fee in lieu of the required tree replacement. Acceptance of such a request shall be in the discretion of the Director of Public Works. If a request is accepted, regulations shall apply as set forth in the Village Tree Standards Manual. 
(Code 1959, § 20.13; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-65. - Construction activity protection plan. 
A construction activity protection plan shall be filed with all landmark tree permit applications in which the proposed regulated tree activity is construction activity as defined in Section 86-33. The requirements for the construction activity protection plan shall be as found in the Village Tree Standards Manual. 
(Code 1959, § 20.14; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Secs. 86-66—86-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PROTECTION DURING CONSTRUCTION 
 
Sec. 86-91. - Construction activity tree permit. 
(a)  Required. Except as expressly provided in subsection (b) of this section, construction activity tree permits shall be required prior to the commencement of any activity that involves the construction, alteration or enlargement of any building, structure or surface by adding an impervious area of 400 square feet or more to the land on which such activity located and that anticipates or involves the actual or reasonably likely damage or removal of any tree which is greater than ten inches DBH. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Pruning. A tree permit shall not be required for the pruning of any tree in compliance with the pruning standards. 
(2)  Tree emergency. 
a.  In the case of a tree emergency, the director of public works is hereby authorized to: 
1.  Issue a tree permit without a tree permit application; 
2.  Waive the requirement for a tree permit set forth in this section; or 
3.  Waive any of the other regulations of this section or this article. 
b.  Notwithstanding any other regulations of this article, if a tree emergency occurs, the person endangered by the tree emergency may take any reasonable action necessary to avoid or eliminate the immediate danger or hazard. The action taken shall be an action that is least likely, under the circumstances, to cause damage or removal of any tree, and the Village assumes no responsibility or liability for any such action taken. The person taking such action shall document the reasons for the tree emergency by photograph or videotape of the tree emergency condition and the damage or hazard created by such condition, and shall report the action taken to any of the above Village officials within 48 hours after the action is taken. 
(Code 1959, § 20.20)  
Sec. 86-92. - Permit applications. 
(a)  Submission. Applications for a construction activity tree permit shall be submitted to the Village on a form provided by director of public works as set forth in the Village tree standards. 
(b)  Approval and issuance. Upon receipt of the construction activity tree permit application, the director of public works shall, at his discretion, visit and inspect the property, and contiguous and adjoining lots in order to evaluate the tree permit application. The director of public works shall approve a construction permit application and issue a tree construction activity permit if, based on the permit application, inspection of the property and all other reliable and relevant information, the director of public works determines that all of the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  The proposed construction tree activity has been planned and will be performed in such a manner, to such a degree and with such equipment and personnel so as to: 
a.  Reasonably involve the least amount of damage or removal of trees; and 
b.  Not defeat or be inconsistent with the purposes and intent of this article as set forth in section 86-31. 
(2)  The construction activity protection plan satisfies the requirements of the Village tree standards. 
(Code 1959, § 20.21)  
Sec. 86-93. - Permit revocation and remedies. 
Construction activity tree permits shall be subject to the same provisions for revocation and other remedies as are applicable to building permits issued pursuant to chapter 18. 
(Code 1959, § 20.22)  
Secs. 86-94—86-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PARKWAY AND PUBLIC TREES 
 
Sec. 86-111. - Protected. 
Parkway trees and other trees owned by the Village shall be treated in the same manner as set forth for landmark trees in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 20.23; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Secs. 86-112—86-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - DUTCH ELM AND OTHER DISEASES 
 
Sec. 86-131. - Enforcement; interference. 
The Village Manager is charged with enforcement of this division. To that end and subject to constitutional limitations, he may authorize an appropriate Village employee or officer to enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for purposes of inspecting trees thereon and for the removal of such specimens as are required for purposes of analysis to determine whether or not the specimens are infected. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the Village Manager or designee from entering on private property for purposes of carrying out his duties under this division or to interfere with the Village Manager or designee in the lawful performance of his duties under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1959, § 20.40; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-132. - Control and eradication. 
(a)  Trees of all species and varieties of elm, zelkova and planera that are affected with fungus ceratostomella ulmi, as determined by the Director of Public Works, are hereby declared to be illegal and shall be removed and disposed of within 30 days following notification of the discovery of such infection. It shall be unlawful for any person who owns property on which such a tree is situated to possess or keep such tree after the expiration of 15 days following notification of the discovery of the infection. 
(b)  Trees, or parts thereof, that are infected by the European elm bark beetle, scolytus multistraitus, are declared to be illegal. It shall be unlawful for the person owning property whereon such infected trees, or parts thereof, are situated to possess or keep such infected trees, or parts thereof. 
(c)  Trees, or parts thereof, that are infected by the Asian long horned beetle or the Asian cerambycid beetle, anoplophora glabripennis, are declared to be illegal. It shall be unlawful for the person owning property whereon such infected trees, or parts thereof, are situated to possess or keep such infected trees, or parts thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 20.41; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-133. - Abatement. 
(a)  The Village Manager or designee shall give to the owner of the premises where the nuisances described in this division are found a written notice of the existence of such tree requiring the removal and lawful disposal of such tree within ten days following such notice. Such removal and disposal shall be done under the direction and supervision of the Village Manager or designee. The notice shall also notify the owner of such premises that unless such tree is removed in compliance with the terms thereof within such ten-day period, the Village will proceed with the removal and disposal of such tree, and assess the cost thereof against the property owner. 
(b)  Service of the notice shall be by personal service or certified mail, addressed to the owner at his last known address. 
(c)  Upon service of such notice, it shall become the duty of the owner of the premises to cause such tree or breeding place to be removed and lawfully disposed of, under the direction and supervision of the Village Manager or designee. If the Village shall remove and dispose of any tree or breeding place, all expenses incurred in connection therewith shall be assessed against the property owner. 
(Code 1959, § 20.42; Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Sec. 86-134. - Lien for abatement costs. 
(a)  Whenever billing for the removal or abatement of a nuisance tree under this article, by or under the supervision of Village personnel, remains unpaid 60 days after billing for such service has been rendered, the Village Manager may file a statement of lien claim with the recorder of deeds of the County. Such statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the billing, plus administrative costs, and a notice that the Village claims a lien for the total amount. 
(b)  If the resident whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the Village Manager has knowledge thereof, notice shall also be mailed to the owner of the premises. 
(c)  The failure of the Village Manager to mail such notice or the failure of the owner of the premises to receive such notice shall not affect the right of the Village to foreclose the lien for the unpaid services rendered. 
(d)  The village attorney may institute foreclosure proceedings, in the name of the Village, in the circuit court, against any property for which a lien claim for unpaid service charges and administrative costs has been duly filed. 
(Ord. No. 5882, § 3, 1-6-2015)  
Chapter 90 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Food delivery vehicles and mobile food units, § 38-211 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 42; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; vehicles for hire, ch. 94. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alley means a public way within a block, generally giving access to the rear of lots or buildings and not used for general traffic circulation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-102. 
Authorized emergency vehicle means emergency vehicles of municipal departments or public service corporations as are designated or authorized by proper local authorities, police vehicles, vehicles of the fire department and ambulances, vehicles of the State emergency management agency and vehicles of the department of nuclear safety. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-105. 
Bicycle means every device propelled by human power, upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels, except scooters and similar devices. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-106. 
Business district means the territory contiguous to and including a street when within any 600 feet along such street there are buildings in use for business or industrial purposes, including, but not limited to, hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings which occupy at least 300 feet of frontage on one side or 300 feet collectively on both sides of the street. (For repair of motor vehicles in gasoline service stations, see chapter 22, article IV, automobile repair shops.) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-108. 
Crosswalk means: 
(1)  The part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway, measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway, and in the absence of a sidewalk on one side of the highway, that part of the highway included within the extension of the lateral line of the existing sidewalk to the side of the highway without the sidewalk, with such extension forming a right angle to the centerline of the highway; 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface placed in accordance with the provisions in the manual adopted by the State department of transportation as authorized in 625 ILCS 5/11-301. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-113. 
Driver and operator mean every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-116. 
Fire lane means travel lanes for firefighting equipment, upon which there shall be no standing or parking of any motor vehicle at any time so that firefighting equipment can move freely thereon. 
Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two streets which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets joining at any other angle may come in conflict. Where a street includes two roadways 40 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided street by an intersecting street shall be regarded as a separate intersection. The junction of an alley with a street or highway does not constitute an intersection. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-132. 
Laned roadway means a roadway which is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-136. 
Loading zone means the space adjacent to a curb that is reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or material. 
Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels that are in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-147. 
Motor-driven cycle means every motorcycle and every motor scooter with less than 150 cubic centimeter piston displacement, including motorized pedalcycles. 
Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except for vehicles moved solely by human power and motorized wheelchairs. For the purposes of this chapter, motor vehicles are divided into the following two divisions: 
(1)  First division. Motor vehicles which are designed for the carrying of not more than ten persons. 
(2)  Second division. Motor vehicles which are: 
a.  Designed for carrying more than ten persons; 
b.  Designed or used for living quarters; 
c.  Designed for pulling or carrying freight, cargo or implements of husbandry; and 
(3)  Of the first division and are remodeled for use and used as motor vehicles of the second division. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-146. 
Muffler means a device consisting of a series of chambers or baffle plates, or other mechanical design, for the purpose of receiving exhaust gas from an internal combustion engine or turbine wheels, all of which are effective in reducing noise. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-148.3a. 
Owner means a person who holds the legal title of a vehicle, or if a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or if a mortgagor of a vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee, or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner for the purpose of this chapter. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-155. 
Park, when prohibited, means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading merchandise or passengers. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-156. 
Parking area means an area of land near or contiguous to a shopping center and used by the public as the means of access to and egress from the stores and business establishments at a shopping center and for the parking of motor vehicles of customers and patrons at a shopping center. 
Pedestrian means any person afoot, including a person with a physical, hearing or visual disability. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-158. 
Police officer means every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests and issue citations for violations of traffic regulations. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-162. 
Private road or driveway means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-163. 
Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-166. 
Railroad sign or signal means any sign, signal or device, other than an official traffic control sign, signal or device, erected in accordance with the laws governing such sign, signal or device, and intended to give notice of the presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-167. 
Residence district means the territory contiguous to and including a street not comprising a business district when the property on such street for a distance of 300 feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. For purposes of establishing maximum speed limits, a residence district shall be at least a quarter of a mile long with residences or residences and buildings in use for businesses spaced no more than 300 feet apart. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-172. 
Right-of-way means the right of one vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under such circumstances of direction, speed and proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the other. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-177. 
Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. If a street includes two or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" shall refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-179. 
School bus means every motor vehicle, except as otherwise provided in this section, owned or operated by or for any of the following entities for the transportation of persons regularly enrolled as students in grades 12 or below in connection with any activity of such entity: 
(1)  Any public or private primary or secondary school; 
(2)  Any primary or secondary school operated by a religious institution; or 
(3)  Any public, private or religious nursery school. 
The term "school bus" shall not include the following: 
(1)  A bus operated by a public utility, municipal corporation or common carrier authorized to conduct local or interurban transportation of passengers when such bus is not traveling a specific school bus route but is: 
a.  On a regularly scheduled route for the transportation of other fare paying passengers; 
b.  Furnishing charter service for the transportation of groups on field trips or other special trips or in connection with other special events; or 
c.  Being used for shuttle service between attendance centers or other educational facilities. 
(2)  A motor vehicle of the first division. 
(3)  A motor vehicle designed for the transportation of not less than seven, nor more than 16 persons and that is operated by or for a public or private primary or secondary school, including any primary or secondary school operated by a religious institution, for the purpose of transporting not more than 15 students to and from interscholastic athletic or other interscholastic or school sponsored activities. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-182. 
Semitrailer means every vehicle without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and constructed so that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-187. 
Shopping center means premises having one or more stores or business establishments in connection with which there is provided on privately-owned property near or contiguous thereto an area of land used by the public as the means of access to and egress from the stores and business establishments on such premises and for the parking of motor vehicles of customers and patrons of such stores and business establishments on such premises. 
Shopping center or property owner means the actual legal owner of the shopping center parking area, the trust officer of a banking institution having the right to manage and control such property or a person having the legal right, through lease or otherwise, to manage or control such property. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines and intended for the use of pedestrians. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-188. 
Stop, when required, means complete cessation from movement. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-199. 
Stop, stopping and standing, when prohibited, means any halting, even momentarily, of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-200. 
Street and highway mean the entire width between property lines of every way publicly maintained, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for the purposes of vehicular traffic. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-201. 
Suburban district means that portion of the Village, other than the business and residential districts. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-203. 
Through highway means every highway, or portion thereof, on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield the right-of-way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-205. 
Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street for purposes of travel. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-207. 
Traffic control devices means all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of the public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
Traffic control signal means any official traffic control device, other than a railroad sign or signal, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-208. 
Trailer means every vehicle without motive power in operation, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and constructed so that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle. 
Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway or requiring a certificate of title under 625 ILCS 5/3-101(d), except devices moved by human power, devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks and snowmobiles as defined in the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act, 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq. For the purposes of this chapter, unless otherwise prescribed, a device shall be considered to be a vehicle until such time as it either comes within the definition of a junk vehicle, as defined under this Code, or a junking certificate is issued for such device. For the purposes of this chapter, vehicles are divided into the following two divisions: 
(1)  First division. Motor vehicles which are designed for the carrying of not more than ten persons. 
(2)  Second division. Motor vehicles which are: 
a.  Designed for carrying more than ten persons; 
b.  Designed or used for living quarters; 
c.  Designed for pulling or carrying property, freight or cargo; 
d.  Of the first division and remodeled for use and used as motor vehicles of the second division; and 
e.  Of the first division, and used and registered as school buses. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/1-217. 
(Code 1959, § 11.1.1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 90-2. - Certain provisions of State vehicle code adopted by reference. 
Chapters 1, 4, 11, 12 and 15 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, specifically, 625 ILCS 5/1-100—5/1-1011, 5/4-1—5/4-307, 5/11-100—5/11-1515, 5/12-101—5/12-902 and 5/15-101—5/15-319, are hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length in this section. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt vehicle code by reference, 625 ILCS 5/20-204.  
Secs. 90-3—90-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 90-31. - Driving on right side of roadway required; exceptions. 
(a)  Upon all roadways of sufficient width, a vehicle shall be driven upon the right half of the roadway, except as follows: 
(1)  When overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction under the rules governing such movements; 
(2)  When an obstruction exists making it necessary to drive to the left of the center of the roadway, provided, any person so doing shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles traveling in the proper direction upon the unobstructed portion of the roadway within such distance as to constitute an immediate hazard; 
(3)  Upon a roadway divided into three marked lanes for traffic under the rules applicable thereon; 
(4)  Upon a roadway restricted to one-way traffic. 
(b)  Whenever there is a single track paved road on one side of the public highway and two vehicles meet thereon, the driver on whose right is the wider shoulder shall give the right-of-way on such pavement to the other vehicle. 
(c)  Upon all roadways, any vehicle proceeding at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place, and under the conditions then existing shall be driven in the righthand lane available for traffic, or as close as practicable to the righthand curb or edge of the roadway, except when overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction or when preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway. 
(d)  Upon any roadway having four or more lanes for moving traffic and providing for two-way movement of traffic, no vehicle shall be driven to the left of the centerline of the roadway, except when authorized by official traffic control devices designating certain lanes to the left side of the center of the roadway for use by traffic not otherwise permitted to use such lanes, or except as permitted under subsection (a)(2) of this section. However, this subsection shall not be construed as prohibiting the crossing of the centerline in making a left turn into or from an alley, private road or driveway. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-703.  
Sec. 90-32. - Passing vehicles proceeding in opposite directions. 
Drivers of vehicles proceeding in opposite directions shall pass each other to the right, and upon roadways having width for not more than one line of traffic in each direction each driver shall give to the other at least one-half of the main traveled portion of the roadway as nearly as possible. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-702.  
Sec. 90-33. - Overtaking and passing vehicles on the left. 
The following rules shall govern the overtaking and passing of vehicles proceeding in the same direction, subject to those limitations, exceptions and special rules otherwise stated in this chapter: 
(1)  The driver of a vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall pass to the left thereof at a safe distance and shall not again drive to the right side of the roadway until safely clear of the overtaken vehicle; 
(2)  Except when overtaking and passing on the right is permitted, the driver of the overtaken vehicle shall give way to the right in favor of the overtaking vehicle on audible signal and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle; 
(3)  The driver of a two-wheeled vehicle may not, in passing upon the left of any vehicle proceeding in the same direction, pass upon the right of any other vehicle proceeding in the same direction, unless there is an unobstructed lane of traffic available to safely permit such passing maneuver. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-703.  
Sec. 90-34. - Overtaking and passing vehicles on the right. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle with three or more wheels may overtake and pass upon the right of another vehicle only under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the vehicle overtaken is making, or about to make, a left turn; 
(2)  Upon a street or highway with unobstructed pavement of a sufficient width for two or more lines of vehicles moving in the direction being traveled by the overtaking vehicle; 
(3)  Upon a one-way street or upon any roadway on which traffic is restricted to one direction of movement, where the roadway is free from obstructions and of sufficient width for two or more lines of moving vehicles. 
(b)  The driver of a two-wheeled vehicle may not pass upon the right of any other vehicle proceeding in the same direction unless the unobstructed pavement to the right of the vehicle being passed is of a width of not less than eight feet. 
(c)  The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle on the right only under conditions permitting such movement in safety. Such movement shall not be made by driving off the pavement or main-traveled portion of the roadway. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-704.  
Sec. 90-35. - Limitations on overtaking on the left. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be driven to the left side of the center of the roadway in overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction unless authorized by this chapter and unless such left side is clearly visible and is free of on-coming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing to be completely made without interfering with the safe operation of any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction or any vehicle overtaken. In every event, the overtaking vehicle must return to an authorized lane of travel as soon as practicable and if the passing movement involves the use of a lane authorized for vehicles approaching from the opposite direction, before coming within 200 feet of any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be driven on the left side of the roadway under the following conditions: 
(1)  When approaching or upon the crest of a grade or a curve in the roadway where the driver's view is obstructed within such distance so as to create a hazard if another vehicle might approach from the opposite direction. 
(2)  When approaching within 100 feet of or traversing any intersection or railroad grade crossing. 
(3)  When the view is obstructed upon approaching within 100 feet of any bridge, viaduct or tunnel. 
(c)  The limitations set forth in subsections (b)(1)—(3) do not apply upon a one-way roadway, nor upon a roadway with unobstructed pavement of sufficient width for two or more lanes of moving traffic in each direction, nor to the driver of a vehicle turning left into or from an alley, private road or driveway when such movements can be made with safety. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.5) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-706.  
Sec. 90-36. - Driving on roadways laned for traffic. 
Whenever any roadway has been divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for traffic, the following rules, in addition to all others consistent with this section, shall apply: 
(1)  A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as practicable entirely within a single lane and shall not be moved from such lane until the driver has first ascertained that such movement can be made with safety. 
(2)  Upon a roadway which is divided into three lanes and provides for two-way movement of traffic, a vehicle shall not be driven in the center lane, except when overtaking and passing another vehicle where the roadway is clearly visible and such center lane is clear of traffic within a safe distance or in preparation for a left turn, or where such center lane is at the time allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the direction the vehicle is proceeding and is sign-posted to give notice of such allocation. 
(3)  Official traffic control devices may be erected directing specific traffic to use a designated lane or designating those lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center of the roadway and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such device. On multilane controlled access highways with three or more lanes in one direction or on any multilaned highway with two or more lanes in one direction, the State department of transportation may designate lanes of traffic to be used by different types of motor vehicles. Drivers must obey lane designation signing, except when it is necessary to use a different lane to make a turning maneuver. 
(4)  Official traffic control devices may be installed prohibiting the changing of lanes on sections of roadways and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such device. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-709.  
Sec. 90-37. - Required position and method of turning. 
(a)  In general. The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall do so as follows: 
(1)  Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the righthand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(2)  The driver of a vehicle intending to turn left at any intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme lefthand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such vehicle, and after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection in a lane lawfully available to traffic moving in such direction upon the roadway being entered. Whenever practicable, the left turn shall be made in that portion of the intersection to the left of the center of the intersection. 
(3)  The State department of transportation and the Village, in their respective jurisdictions, may cause official traffic control devices to be placed within or adjacent to intersections and thereby require and direct that a different course from that specified in this section be traveled by vehicles turning at an intersection, and when such devices are so placed, no driver of a vehicle shall turn a vehicle at an intersection other than as directed and required by such devices. 
(b)  Two-way left turn lanes. Where a special lane for making left turns by drivers proceeding in opposite directions has been indicated by official traffic control devices: 
(1)  A left turn shall not be made from any other lane. 
(2)  A vehicle shall not be driven in the lane, except when preparing for or making a left turn from or into the roadway or when preparing for or making a U-turn when otherwise permitted by law. 
(c)  When a motor vehicle and a mass transit bus are traveling in the same direction on the same multilaned highway, street or road, the operator of the motor vehicle overtaking such bus, which is stopped at an intersection on the right side of the roadway to receive or discharge passengers, shall pass to the left of the bus at a safe distance and shall not turn to the right in front of the bus at that intersection. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.7) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-801.  
Sec. 90-38. - Signals required when turning or stopping. 
(a)  No person may turn a vehicle at an intersection unless the vehicle is in the proper position upon the roadway as required in section 90-37, nor turn a vehicle to enter a private road or driveway, nor otherwise turn a vehicle from a direct course or move right or left upon a roadway unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. No person may turn any such vehicle without giving an appropriate signal in the manner as provided in this section. 
(b)  A signal of intention to turn right or left, when required, must be given continuously during not less than the last 100 feet traveled by the vehicle before turning within a business or residence district, and such signal must be given continuously during not less than the last 200 feet traveled by the vehicle before turning outside a business or residence district. 
(c)  No person may stop or suddenly decrease the speed of a vehicle without first giving an appropriate signal in the manner provided in this section to the driver of any vehicle immediately to the rear when there is opportunity to give such a signal. 
(d)  The electric turn signal device required in 625 ILCS 5/12-208 must be used to indicate an intention to turn, change lanes or start from a parallel parked position, but must not be flashed on one side only on a parked or disabled vehicle or flashed as a courtesy or "do pass" signal to operators of other vehicles approaching from the rear. However, such signal devices may be flashed simultaneously on both sides of a motor vehicle to indicate the presence of a vehicular traffic hazard requiring unusual care in approaching, overtaking and passing. 
(e)  Any stop or turn signal, when required in this section, shall be given either by means of the hand and arm or by a signal lamp or electrical signal device conforming to the requirements of 625 ILCS 5/12-208. 
(f)  All signals required in this section to be given by hand and arm shall be given from the left side of the vehicle and shall indicate and be given as follows: 
(1)  Left turn. Hand and arm extended horizontally. 
(2)  Right turn. Hand and arm extended upward. 
(3)  Stop or decrease of speed. Hand and arm extended downward. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.8) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-804—5/11-806.  
Sec. 90-39. - Vehicles approaching or entering intersection. 
(a)  When two vehicles enter an intersection from different roadways at approximately the same time, the driver of the vehicle on the left shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right. 
(b)  The right-of-way rule declared in subsection (a) of this section is modified at through highways and otherwise as stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.9) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-901.  
Sec. 90-40. - Vehicles turning left. 
The driver of a vehicle intending to turn to the left within an intersection or into an alley, private road or driveway shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is so close as to constitute an immediate hazard, but such driver, having so yielded, may proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.10) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-902.  
Sec. 90-41. - Driving while under the influence of alcohol, other drugs, intoxicating compounds or any combination thereof. 
(a)  A person shall not drive or be in actual physical control of any vehicle within the Village while: 
(1)  The alcohol concentration in the person's blood or breath is 0.08 or more based on the definition of blood and breath units in 625 ILCS 5/11-501.2; 
(2)  Under the influence of alcohol; 
(3)  Under the influence of any intoxicating compound or combination of intoxicating compounds to a degree that renders the person incapable of driving safely; 
(4)  Under the influence of any other drug or combination of drugs to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving; 
(5)  Under the combined influence of alcohol, other drug or intoxicating compound to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving; or 
(6)  There is any amount of a drug, substance or compound in the person's breath, blood or urine resulting from the unlawful use or consumption of cannabis listed in the Cannabis Control Act, 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq., a controlled substance listed in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, 35 ILCS 570/1 et seq., or an intoxicating compound listed in the Use of Intoxicating Compounds Act, 720 ILCS 690/0.01 et seq. 
(b)  The fact that any person charged with violating this section is or has been legally entitled to use alcohol, other drugs or intoxicating compounds, or any combination thereof, shall not constitute a defense against any charge of violating this section. 
(c)  Every person who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.11) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-501(a), (b).  
Sec. 90-42. - Reckless driving. 
(a)  Any person who drives any vehicle with a willful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property is guilty of reckless driving. 
(b)  Every person convicted of reckless driving shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.12) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-503(a), (b).  
Sec. 90-43. - Negligent driving. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon a public highway negligently, heedlessly and without due caution in a manner so as to endanger, or be likely to endanger, any person or property. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.12A)  
Sec. 90-44. - Following too closely. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such vehicles and the condition of traffic upon the roadway. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.15) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-710(a).  
Sec. 90-45. - Backing limitations. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not back the vehicle unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.16) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1402.  
Sec. 90-46. - Starting stopped, standing or parked vehicle. 
No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. 
(Code 1959, § 11.4.17) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-803.  
Sec. 90-47. - Operation of vehicles and streetcars on approach of authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle making use of audible and visual signals meeting the requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., or a police vehicle properly and lawfully making use of an audible or visual signal, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel, and as close as possible, to the righthand edge or curb of the highway clear of any intersection and shall, if necessary to permit the safe passage of the emergency vehicle, stop and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  This section shall not operate to relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway. 
(c)  Upon approaching a stationary authorized emergency vehicle, when the authorized emergency vehicle is giving a signal by displaying alternately flashing red, red and white, blue, or red and blue lights, or amber or yellow warning lights, a person who drives an approaching vehicle shall: 
(1)  Proceeding with due caution, yield the right-of-way by making a lane change into a lane not adjacent to that of the authorized emergency vehicle, if possible with due regard to safety and traffic conditions, if on a highway having at least four lanes with not less than two lanes proceeding in the same direction as the approaching vehicle; or 
(2)  Proceeding with due caution, reduce the speed of the vehicle, maintaining a safe speed for road conditions, if changing lanes would be impossible or unsafe. 
(d)  As used in this subsection (c), the term "authorized emergency vehicle" includes any vehicle authorized by law to be equipped with oscillating, rotating or flashing lights under 625 ILCS 5/12-215, while the owner or operator of the vehicle is engaged in his official duties. 
(Code 1959, § 11.9.1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-907.  
Sec. 90-48. - Following, etc., fire apparatus. 
The driver of any vehicle, other than one on official business, shall not follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than 500 feet or stop such vehicle within 500 feet of any fire apparatus stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Code 1959, § 11.9.2) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1411.  
Sec. 90-49. - Driving over fire hose. 
No vehicle shall be driven over an unprotected hose of the fire department when such hose is laid down on any street, private roadway or driveway to be used at any fire or alarm of fire without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Code 1959, § 11.9.3) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1412.  
Sec. 90-50. - Approaching, overtaking and passing school buses. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall stop such vehicle before meeting or overtaking, from either direction, any school bus stopped for the purpose of receiving or discharging pupils on a highway, on a roadway on school property or upon a private road within an area that is covered by a contract or agreement executed pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-209.1. Such stop is required before reaching the school bus when there is in operation on the school bus the visual signals as specified in 625 ILCS 5/12-803 and 5/12-805. The driver of the vehicle shall not proceed until the school bus resumes motion, the driver of the vehicle is signaled by the school bus driver to proceed or the visual signals are no longer actuated. 
(b)  The stop signal arm required by 625 ILCS 5/12-803 shall be extended after the school bus has come to a complete stop for the purpose of loading or discharging pupils and shall be closed before the school bus is placed in motion again. The stop signal arm shall not be extended at any other time. 
(c)  The alternately flashing red signal lamps of an eight-lamp flashing signal system required by 625 ILCS 5/12-805 shall be actuated after the school bus has come to a complete stop for the purpose of loading or discharging pupils and shall be turned off before the school bus is placed in motion again. The red signal lamps shall not be actuated at any other time, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  The alternately flashing amber signal lamps of an eight-lamp flashing signal system required by 625 ILCS 5/12-805 shall be actuated continuously during not less than the last 100 feet traveled by the school bus before stopping for the purpose of loading or discharging pupils within an urban area and during not less than the last 200 feet traveled by the school bus outside an urban area. The amber signal lamps shall remain actuated until the school bus is stopped. The amber signal lamps shall not be actuated at any other time. 
(e)  The driver of a vehicle upon a highway having four or more lanes which permits at least two lanes of traffic to travel in opposite directions need not stop such vehicle upon meeting a school bus which is stopped in the opposing roadway, and need not stop such vehicle when driving upon a controlled access highway when passing a school bus traveling in either direction that is stopped in a loading zone adjacent to the surfaced or improved part of the controlled access highway where pedestrians are not permitted to cross. 
(Code 1959, § 11.9.4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1414.  
Sec. 90-51. - Funeral processions. 
(a)  Funeral processions have the right-of-way at intersections when vehicles comprising such procession have their headlights lit, subject to the following conditions and exceptions: 
(1)  Operators of vehicles in a funeral procession shall yield the right-of-way upon the approach of an authorized emergency vehicle giving an audible or visible signal; 
(2)  Operators of vehicles in a funeral procession shall yield the right-of-way when directed to do so by a traffic officer; 
(3)  The operator of the leading vehicle in a funeral procession shall comply with stop signs and traffic control signals, but when the leading vehicle has proceeded across an intersection in accordance with such signal or after stopping as required by the stop sign, all vehicles in such procession may proceed without stopping, regardless of the sign or signal and the leading vehicle and the vehicles in the procession shall proceed with due caution.
