(h)  If required, arrangements shall be made by the permittee to have the proper utilities notified, property moved, bridges or highways analyses performed and completed in advance of any permit movement. 
(i)  All movements under the permit shall be made in accordance with all applicable Federal, State and Local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(j)  Permits are void if altered for the purpose of deception. The permits issued under this section constitute the grant of a privilege by the Village and may be denied or suspended for such reasons as the Village may deem rationally related to its governmental interests including, but not limited to: 
(1)  A permittee knowingly providing incorrect information in an applicant for a permit. 
(2)  A permittee, its agents or employees acting on a permit which has been altered for purposes of deception. 
(3)  Non-compliance by permittee, its agents or employees with Federal, State or Local ordinances pertaining to the transport of goods or operation of a vehicle engaged in the transport of goods. 
(4)  Moving on Village streets without a valid permit as required under this section. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 2, 3-18-2008)  
Sec. 90-332. - Application for permit. 
(a)  All applications for permits shall be given full consideration. Permits for proposed moves may be issued: 
(1)  When the Village roadways and bridges will not be unduly damaged; and 
(2)  When the safety of the traveling public will be adequately protected. 
(b)  Applications for a permit to move an oversized and/or overweight vehicle, and/or load, must be made to the traffic unit of the Village of Glenview's Police Department. The following information shall be included on the permit: 
(1)  Permittee's name. 
(2)  Fax and telephone number of applicant. 
(3)  Name of person making application. 
(4)  Description of hauling vehicle. 
(5)  Registration number of hauling vehicle and/or trailer. 
(6)  Description of load to be moved. 
(7)  Overall dimensions of vehicle and axle weight information. 
(8)  Village roadways to be traveled. 
(9)  Any special conditions. 
(10)  Permit type with corresponding fee due to the Village. 
(11)  Date Permit issued and expiration date. 
(12)  Time permit issued and by whom. 
(13)  Category of permit. 
(14)  State and/or County permit numbers if applicable. 
(c)  A schedule of overweight and oversize vehicle permit fees is contained in Section 30-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 2, 3-18-2008)  
Sec. 90-333. - Police escorts. 
Police escorts are required for certain vehicles and loads as indicated in subsection herein. The total number of officers necessary to provide for a safe move shall be determined by the traffic unit, based upon the size and weight of the permit move. Fees for escorts shall be in addition to the permit fees set forth in Section 30-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 2, 3-18-2008)  
Sec. 90-334. - Bonds, indemnification and insurance. 
(a)  The permittee shall assume total liability for any and all damages to streets, bridges, Village owned appurtenances and private or public property while engaged in a permit move. The measure of liability is the cost for all repairs or replacement of property damaged by the permittee. 
(b)  The permittee shall indemnify and hold harmless the Village from any costs, judgments or settlements, including attorney(s) fees, arising from physical injuries, including loss of life, or damage to or loss of property related to acts or omissions by permittee, its officers, agents or employees pursuant to the permit. 
(c)  Upon application for a permit(s) each applicant shall provide evidence of a valid comprehensive general liability insurance policy, with an insurance company approved by the Village, for protection against personal injury or property damage in the amount of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 2, 3-18-2008)  
Sec. 90-335. - Suspension and reinstatement. 
(a)  Suspension of a current permit shall be for the time determined appropriate by the traffic unit; however, reinstatement may be made upon condition determined by the Village and payment of all outstanding settlements or judgments. 
(b)  The charges for reinstatement are: 
(1)  Denial = No charge. 
(2)  Suspended = $50.00. 
(c)  The chief of police or their designee shall administer and enforce this section and shall have the authority to grant, deny or reinstate permits. Any applicant or permittee denied a permit or who has had a permit suspended, upon request, shall be given a hearing before the traffic unit of the Village of Glenview Police Department and, if applicant, or permittee desires, may appeal the decision of the traffic unit in a hearing before the chief of police and/or Village manager. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 2, 3-18-2008)  
Sec. 90-336. - Fines and bonds. 
In addition to other remedies the Village may seek, a permittee, its officers, agents or employees, found guilty of moving an over-dimension (oversized) or overweight vehicle or load on Village streets on a permit altered for purposes of deception or without a valid permit as is required under this section, shall be subject to a $500.00 fine for the first day during which a move was made and a $750.00 fine for each additional day during which a move was made. 
(Ord. No. 5082, § 2, 3-18-2008)  
Secs. 90-337—90-360. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - INOPERABLE OR ABANDONED VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 90-361. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned vehicle means any vehicle which is left at any location for a period of 14 days or more and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle to reasonably appear to have been abandoned. 
Inoperable motor vehicle means any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least 14 days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed or altered, damaged or otherwise treated so that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. Such term shall not include a: 
(1)  Motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations; 
(2)  Motor vehicle which is kept within a building when not in use; 
(3)  Historic vehicle over 25 years of age; or 
(4)  Motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. 
Not more than one currently unregistered or unlicensed vehicle shall be kept, parked or stored on any premises at any time, except as set forth in this definition. 
Property means any real property within the Village which is not a street or highway. 
Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power, designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides, and transport persons or property, or pull machinery, and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, tractors, buggies and wagons. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-40-3.  
Sec. 90-362. - Abandonment of vehicles. 
No person shall abandon any vehicle within the Village, nor leave any vehicle at any place within the Village for such a time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle to reasonably appear to have been abandoned. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.2)  
Sec. 90-363. - Leaving inoperable motor vehicle on street or highway. 
No person shall leave, for a period of more than 12 hours, on any street or highway in the Village, any vehicle which is in such a state of disrepair as to be incapable of being driven under its own motor power. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.3)  
Sec. 90-364. - Inoperable motor vehicles declared a nuisance. 
Inoperable motor vehicles, whether on public or private property, are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.4) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 38-281 et seq.  
Sec. 90-365. - Disposition of inoperable motor vehicles. 
All persons are required to dispose of any inoperable motor vehicle under their control upon written notice received from the corporate authorities or the chief of police, or any member of his department designated by him, commanding such disposition of such inoperable motor vehicle. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.5)  
Sec. 90-366. - Removal and impoundment. 
The chief of police or any member of the police department designated by him is hereby authorized to remove, or have removed, any vehicle left at any place within the Village which reasonably appears to be in violation of this article or which reasonably appears to be lost, stolen or unclaimed, or which is an inoperable motor vehicle. Such vehicle shall be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with 625 ILCS 5/4-201—5/4-213. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.6)  
Sec. 90-367. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding $500.00. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such under this section. 
(Code 1959, § 11.8.7)  
Secs. 90-368—90-400. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - MOTORCYCLES 
 
Sec. 90-401. - Operation. 
(a)  A person operating a motorcycle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, and such operator shall not carry any other person, nor shall any other person ride on a motorcycle unless such motorcycle is designed to carry more than one person, in which event, a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if such seat is designed for two persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the motorcycle at the rear or side of the operator. 
(b)  A person shall ride upon a motorcycle only while sitting astride the seat, facing forward, with one leg on each side of the motorcycle. 
(c)  No person shall operate any motorcycle with handlebars higher than the height of the shoulders of the operator when the operator is seated in the normal driving position astride that portion of the seat or saddle occupied by the operator. 
(Code 1959, § 11.11.1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1403.  
Sec. 90-402. - Eye protection devices. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Glasses means ordinary eye pieces, such as spectacles or sunglasses, worn before the eye, made of shatter-resistant material. The term "shatter-resistant material," as used in this subsection, means material manufactured, fabricated or created so that it substantially prevents shattering or flying when struck or broken. 
Goggles means a device worn before the eyes, the predominant function of which is protecting the eyes without obstructing peripheral vision. Goggles shall provide protection from the front and sides, and may or may not form a complete seal with the face. 
Transparent shield means a windshield attached to the front of a motorcycle, that extends above the eyes when an operator is seated in the normal, upright riding position, made of shatter-resistant material, or a shatter-resistant protective face shield that covers the wearer's eyes and face at least to a point approximately to the tip of the nose. 
(b)  Operators. The operator of a motorcycle, motor-driven cycle or motorized pedalcycle and every passenger thereon shall be protected by glasses, goggles or a transparent shield. Contact lenses are not acceptable eye protection devices. 
(Code 1959, § 11.11.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1404.  
Sec. 90-403. - Handlebars. 
No motorcycle may be operated with handlebars rising more than 15 inches in height above the level of the seat or saddle. 
(Code 1959, § 11.11.3)  
Secs. 90-404—90-430. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - BICYCLES 
 
Sec. 90-431. - Registration and tag. 
(a)  Every person residing within the Village who owns, possesses or regularly operates within the Village limits a bicycle with a wheel dominator of over 20 inches shall obtain from the chief of police a registration tag for each bicycle so owned, possessed or regularly used. A fee, as established from time to time by resolution of the president and board of trustees, shall be charged for issuing such registration tag. A registration tag may be transferred to another bicycle owned by a registrant without additional charge only upon proof that the original bicycle is no longer owned, possessed, used or offered for rent within the Village limits by the original registrant thereof, and the bicycle to which the registration tag is to be transferred complies with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Upon the receipt of the fees for such registration, the chief of police shall accept the bicycle for registration and issue a registration tag, bearing an identifying number, and attach the tag to the bicycle which meets the equipment standards for bicycles as set forth and published by the chief of police from time to time. The chief of police may require any bicycle to be reinspected from time to time. 
(c)  No bicycle rental agency operating within the Village limits shall rent, or offer for rent, any bicycle unless the bicycle is registered and a registration tag is attached thereto as provided in this section, and such bicycle is equipped as required by this article. 
(d)  The chief of police shall maintain such records as are necessary to carry out the requirements of this section. 
(e)  The chief of police may from time to time authorize such persons as, in his opinion, are necessary to perform the work necessary to carry out the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1959, § 11.12.1)  
Sec. 90-432. - Lamps and other equipment. 
(a)  Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a lamp on the front, which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type approved by the State department of transportation which shall be visible from all distances from 100—600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(b)  A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person use upon a bicycle, any siren. 
(c)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will adequately control movement of and stop and hold such bicycle. 
(d)  No person shall sell a new bicycle or pedal for use on a bicycle that is not equipped with a reflex reflector conforming to specifications prescribed by the State department of transportation, on each pedal, visible from the front and rear of the bicycle, during darkness, from a distance of 200 feet. 
(e)  No person shall sell, or offer for sale, a new bicycle that is not equipped with side reflectors. Such reflectors shall be visible from each side of the bicycle from a distance of 500 feet and shall be essentially colorless or red to the rear of the center of the bicycle and essentially colorless or amber to the front of the center of the bicycle. The requirements of this subsection may be met by reflective materials which shall be at least three-sixteenths of an inch wide on each side of each tire or rim to indicate as clearly as possible the continuous circular shape and size of the tires or rims of such bicycle and which reflective materials may be of the same color on both the front and rear tire or rim. Such reflectors shall conform to specifications prescribed by the State department of transportation. 
(f)  No person shall sell, or offer for sale, a new bicycle that is not equipped with an essentially colorless front-facing reflector. 
(g)  All bicycles shall have such other equipment as the chief of police may from time to time reasonably determine to be necessary for the safe operation of any bicycle; provided, however, a list of such equipment is published by the chief of police as provided in section 90-431(b ). 
(Code 1959, § 11.12.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1507.  
Sec. 90-433. - Operating regulations. 
(a)  The operator of any bicycle within the Village shall, in addition to the other provisions of this article, conform to the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq. 
(b)  No person shall ride a bicycle, except upon or astride the regular permanent seat attached thereto. 
(c)  No person shall carry upon a bicycle more persons than the number for which such bicycle has been designed and is properly equipped to carry, except that an adult rider may carry a child securely attached to his person in a backpack or sling. 
(d)  No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed faster or in any manner other than that which is reasonable and prudent with regard to the safety of the riders thereof and others using the roadway. 
(e)  No person shall ride a bicycle without having at least one hand on the handlebar or other steering device at all times. 
(f)  All bicycles shall be operated as near to the righthand curb as conditions will permit, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or a vehicle proceeding in the same direction. 
(g)  No person riding upon a bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach such bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle, or himself to any other moving vehicle. 
(h)  The operator of a bicycle on a roadway, when making a right turn, shall follow the righthand lane next to the righthand edge of the roadway. No operator of a bicycle shall suddenly start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn without first giving the standard signal required by State law for motor vehicles under the same circumstances. 
(i)  No bicycle shall have attached to it any other vehicle, such as a wagon or sled. 
(j)  No person shall ride a bicycle on any sidewalk or roadway on which the chief of police, by sign, has posted as "Bicycles Prohibited." 
(k)  Whenever a person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such person. 
(l)  No bicycle shall be left lying upon any street, sidewalk or alley or in such a position as to obstruct or interfere with the use of any street, sidewalk or alley. 
(m)  Proper hand signals should be used at all times by a bicycle operator. 
(n)  Every person operating a bicycle must obey all traffic signs. 
(Code 1959, § 11.12.3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1503, 5/11-1504.  
Sec. 90-434. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00, nor more than $100.00 for each offense, or have his bicycle impounded for a period not to exceed 120 days. 
(Code 1959, § 11.12.4)  
Secs. 90-435—90-460. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDESTRIANS 
 
Sec. 90-461. - Obedience to traffic control devices and traffic regulations. 
(a)  A pedestrian shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device specifically applicable to him, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic and pedestrian control signals as provided in 625 ILCS 5/11-306 and 5/11-307, but, at all other places, pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 11.13.1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1001.  
Sec. 90-462. - Right-of-way at crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic control signals are not in place or operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a moving vehicle which is so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(c)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the condition stated in 625 ILCS 5/11-1003(b). 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked or unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(e)  Whenever stop signs or flashing red signals are in place at an intersection or plainly marked crosswalk between intersections, drivers shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians as set forth in 625 ILCS 5/11-904. 
(Code 1959, § 11.13.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1002.  
Sec. 90-463. - Crossing at other than crosswalks. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked or unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  Between any intersections, whenever the board of trustees of the village shall determine, upon the basis of a traffic investigation upon any roadway under its jurisdiction, that crossing between intersections should be prohibited in the interest of public safety, pedestrians shall not cross at any place, except in a marked or unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, and that such prohibition shall be effective when appropriate signs giving notice thereof are erected. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn, when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child, or confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1959, § 11.13.3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1003.  
Sec. 90-464. - Visibly disabled pedestrians. 
The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian with clearly visible disabilities. 
(Code 1959, § 11.13.4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1004.  
Sec. 90-465. - Soliciting rides. 
No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. 
(Code 1959, § 11.13.5) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1006(a).  
Sec. 90-466. - Walking on highways. 
(a)  Where a sidewalk is provided and its use is practicable, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where a sidewalk is not available, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall walk only on a shoulder, as far as practicable from the edge of the roadway. 
(c)  Where neither a sidewalk, nor a shoulder is available, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall walk as near as practicable to an outside edge of a roadway, and, if on a two-way roadway, shall walk only on the left side of the roadway. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any pedestrian upon a roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(Code 1959, § 11.13.6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1007.  
Secs. 90-467—90-500. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - SHOPPING CENTER TRAFFIC 
 
Sec. 90-501. - Contract to regulate traffic. 
The corporate authorities of the Village and any shopping center owner located within the Village may, by contract, empower the Village to regulate the parking of automobiles and traffic at such shopping center. Such contract shall empower the Village to accomplish all or any part of the following: 
(1)  Erection of stop signs, flashing signals or yield signs at specified locations in a parking area and the adoption of appropriate regulations pertaining thereto, or the designation of any intersection in the parking area as a stop intersection or yield intersection and the ordering of like signs or signals at one or more entrances to such intersection, subject to the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Prohibition or regulation of the turning of vehicles or specified types of vehicles at intersections or other designated locations in the parking area. 
(3)  Regulation of the crossing of any roadway in the parking area by pedestrians. 
(4)  Designation of any separate roadway in the parking area for one-way traffic. 
(5)  Establishment and regulation of loading zones. 
(6)  Prohibition, regulation, restriction or limitation of the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified areas of the parking area. 
(7)  Designation of safety zones in the parking area and fire lanes. 
(8)  Providing for the removal and storage of vehicles parked or abandoned where they constitute an obstruction to traffic, and for the payment of reasonable charges as may be established from time to time by resolution of the president and board of trustees of the village for such removal and storage by the owner or operator of any such vehicle. 
(9)  Providing that the cost of planning, installation and maintenance of parking and traffic regulations pursuant to any contract entered into under the authority of this article shall be borne by the property or shopping center owner and the cost for the enforcement thereof shall be borne by the Village. 
(10)  Contracting for such additional reasonable rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this article, with respect to traffic and parking in a parking area as local conditions may require for the safety and convenience of the public or the users of the parking area. 
(Code 1959, § 11.15.1)  
Sec. 90-502. - Contract approval. 
Contracts entered into pursuant to this article must be approved by the board of trustees, signed by the president and attested to by the clerk. 
(Code 1959, § 11.15.2)  
Sec. 90-503. - Contract term. 
No contract entered into between the Village and any shopping center owner pursuant to this article shall exceed a period of 20 years. No lessee of a shopping center shall enter into such a contract for a longer period of time than the length of his lease. 
(Code 1959, § 11.15.3)  
Sec. 90-504. - Contract recording. 
Any contract entered into between the Village and any shopping center owner pursuant to this article shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of the County, and no regulation made pursuant to the contract shall be effective or enforceable until three days after the contract is recorded and the posting of signs indicating such regulation in the shopping center. 
(Code 1959, § 11.15.4)  
Sec. 90-505. - Violations; penalties. 
At such time as parking and traffic regulations have been established at any shopping center pursuant to the contract as provided for in this article, it shall then be an offense for any person to do any act forbidden or to fail to perform any act required by such parking or traffic regulation, and such violation is punishable by a fine of not less than $1.00, nor more than $200.00. 
(Code 1959, § 11.15.5)  
Secs. 90-506—90-540. - Reserved.

Sec. 90-543. - Parking prohibited at certain times.

Sec. 90-548. - Parallel parking. 
The 1700 block of Maclean Court (south side) shall be parallel parking. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 7A)  
Sec. 90-549. - Dead-end streets; U, Y and left turns. 
(a)  Sequoia Trail is hereby closed and shall become a dead-end street at its present intersection with the south right-of-way line of Chestnut Avenue in the Village, and vehicular traffic through such intersection point is hereby prohibited, except for emergency vehicles. 
(b)  Silver Pine Drive is hereby closed and is declared to be a dead-end street at its present intersection with the east right-of-way line of temporary East Lake Avenue in the Village, and there shall be no pedestrian or vehicular traffic through such intersection point. 
(c)  Swainwood Drive South is hereby closed and declared to be a dead-end street at its present intersection with the south right-of-way line of temporary East Lake Avenue in the Village, and there shall be no pedestrian or vehicular traffic through such intersection point. 
(d)  No vehicle shall at any time make a U or Y turn on the following streets: 
(1)  Glenview Road between Lincoln Street, Raleigh Road and Waukegan Road. 
Lehigh Avenue (northbound and southbound directions) between Prairie Street and the south driveway along Lehigh Avenue of the Village municipal parking at Lehigh Avenue and Washington Street. 
(e)  No vehicle shall at any time make a left turn: 
(1)  From River Drive onto Waukegan Road. 
(2)  When northbound on Waukegan Road onto westbound Glenview Road. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 8)  
Sec. 90-550. - One-way streets, alleys and parking areas. 
In the following locations, traffic shall move only in the directions indicated: 
(1)  River Drive, from the southern curb cut of the southern driveway of 990 River Drive to the north curb of Dewes Street. 
(2)  West Fork Green parking area, from the west driveway curb cut entrance off of Glenview Road to the east driveway curb cut exit onto Glenview Road. 
(3)  East Railroad Avenue, south from the south curb of Glenview Road to a point 215 feet south of the south curb. 
(4)  South lane of Pleasant Drive (divided), eastbound only from Waukegan Road to Sunset Ridge Road. 
(5)  North lane of Pleasant Drive (divided), westbound only from Sunset Ridge Road to Waukegan Road. 
West Lake Avenue, eastbound only from 407.5 feet west of the centerline of Pfingsten Road to Pfingsten Road. 
(6)  Pine Street Municipal Parking Lot, enter only on Dewes Street and exit only on Pine Street. 
(7)  There shall be a 20-foot easement running north from Woodlawn Avenue to Glenwood Avenue. 
(8)  Train station drop-off, temporary parking area on Lehigh Avenue (east side of street) from a point 210 feet from the centerline of Prairie Street to a point 360 feet from the centerline of Prairie Street. 
(9)  Sixth Street, southbound, Sunset Mobile Home Park. 
(10)  Seventh Street, northbound, Sunset Mobile Home Park. 
(11)  Eighth Street, southbound, Sunset Mobile Home Park. 
(12)  Ninth Street, northbound, Sunset Mobile Home Park. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 9)  
Sec. 90-551. - Left and right turns only. 
Traffic must turn either left or right: 
(1)  Onto Waukegan Road when exiting from Overlook Drive. 
(2)  Onto Waukegan Road when exiting from the driveway directly opposite Overlook Drive. 
(3)  On the north end of the 20-foot concrete easement, where it exists, onto Glenwood Avenue. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 10)  
Sec. 90-552. - Towaway zones. 
In accordance with section 90-192 and when signs are erected giving notice thereof, the duly designated and authorized agents of the Village shall be empowered to remove illegally parked motor vehicles from the following places by towing such vehicles to a place designated by the Village police department: 
Dewes Street from the west curb of Waukegan Road to the east curb of Washington Street. 
Jefferson Street (both sides at all times), from the east edge of Monroe Avenue to a point 285 feet east of the east edge of Monroe Avenue on the south side of Jefferson Avenue and a point 500 feet east of the east edge of Monroe Avenue on the north side of Jefferson Avenue.

(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 11)  
Sec. 90-553. - Left turn prohibited during certain times. 
(a)  Except for school buses, traffic shall not turn left onto Happy Hollow Road from Willowbrook Circle between the hours of 8:00 a.m.—9:00 a.m. and 2:30 p.m.—3:30 p.m., on days when school is in session. Traffic shall not turn left onto Willowbrook School Circle from Happy Hollow Road. 
(b)  Traffic shall at all times, not turn left from Overlook Drive onto the two driveways on the south side of Overlook Drive, adjacent to the residential development at 195 Waukegan Road. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 12; Ord. No. 4995, § 2, 6-19-2007; Ord. No. 5663, § 2, 4-16-2013; Ord. No. 5880, § 4, 1-6-2015)

Sec. 90-562. - Construction traffic in Indian Ridge Subdivision. 
(a)  No construction traffic is allowed in the use of any residential street included in an area known as the "Indian Ridge Subdivision" for purposes of either entering or exiting any construction area adjacent to the Indian Ridge Subdivision. 
(b)  Indian Ridge Subdivision is a residential section of single-family dwellings located on the west side of Landwehr Road, with an entrance/exit at Indian Ridge Road. The streets included in the Indian Ridge Subdivision are: 
(1)  Indian Ridge Road; 
(2)  Osage Drive; 
(3)  Saranac Lane; 
(4)  Mohawk Lane; and 
(5)  Iroquois Drive. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "construction traffic/vehicle" means any vehicle used for the purpose of providing material for construction sites, vehicles hauling, or towing on a trailer, other motorized machinery commonly used for construction purposes, or any vehicle used for the sole purpose of construction efforts. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 22)  
Sec. 90-563. - Three-hour parking limitations. 
There is a three-hour parking limitation on Waukegan Road (west curb), from a point 30 feet north of the north curb of Henley Street to a point 70 feet south of the south curb of Dewes Street, between the hours of 8:00 a.m.—6:00 p.m., Monday—Saturday, inclusive. 
(Code 1959, ch. 11, art. XIX, app. no. 23)  
Sec. 90-564. - Residents only parking permits. 
(a)  Residents may obtain a resident only parking permit from the Village manager's office by presenting evidence of residency as may be determined by the office of the Village manager. 
(b)  The residents only parking permits provided for in this section are to be affixed to the lower lefthand corner of the front windshield on the driver's side of the vehicle for which the permit has been issued.

Editor's note— Ord. No. 5213, § 4, adopted May 5, 2009, repealed § 90-568. Former § 90-568 pertained to disabled parking and was derived from Ord. No. 5198, § 3, 3-3-2009.  
Sec. 90-569. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5482, § 4, adopted Sept. 20, 2011, repealed § 90-569, which pertained to permit parking and was derived from Ord. No. 5213, § 5, adopted May 5, 2009; Ord. No. 5232, § 4, adopted June 2, 2009; Ord. No. 5413, § 4, adopted Dec. 13, 2010; and Ord. No. 5478, § 3, adopted Aug. 2, 2011.  
Sec. 90-570. - Disabled parking. 
It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not properly displaying registration plates or decals issued to a person with disabilities, as defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-159.1, pursuant to section 90-191 and 625 ILCS 5/3-616, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609, in the two eastern most parking spaces on the north side of Stevens Drive. 
(Ord. No. 5325, § 2, 4-6-2010)  
Secs. 90-571—90-575. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - MOTOR DRIVEN SCOOTERS 
 
Sec. 90-576. - Definitions. 
Motor driven scooter defined. For the purpose of this article, a "motor driven scooter" is defined as any electric or gas driven wheeled scooter, motor driven cycle or other similar motor driven vehicle for which the State of Illinois does not issue a title document, and does not issue license plates or registration documents. 
(Ord. No. 4725, § 1(11-15-1), 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 90-577. - Operation of motor driven scooters restricted. 
No person shall operate a motor driven scooter upon any public street, sidewalk, parking lot, bike path, park or on any other public property. 
(Ord. No. 4725, § 1(11-15-2), 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 90-578. - Exemptions. 
The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained in this article: 
(1)  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, special district vehicle, vehicle owned by another unit of State or local government, operated by an employee in the course of his or her duties. 
(2)  Motorized wheelchairs. For purposes of this article, a motorized wheelchair means any motorized vehicle designed for and used by a person with disabilities. 
(3)  Electric personal assistive mobility devices, as defined in section 625 ILCS 5/1-117.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 4725, § 1(11-15-3), 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 90-579. - Penalties. 
Any person 18 years of age or older who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. An offense committed by a minor under the direct control or with the consent of a parent or guardian may subject the parent or guardian to the penalties provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 4725, § 1(11-15-4), 12-6-2004)  
Chapter 94 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; vehicles and traffic, ch. 90. 
 
Sec. 94-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Glenview chauffeur's license or chauffeur's license means a license issued to an individual and authorizes the individual to operate a taxicab or limousine within the Village. 
License year means January 1 through December 31 of each year. 
Livery operator's license means a license issued to the owner of a livery service that is eligible to operate livery vehicles or limousines within the Village. 
Livery vehicle means any public passenger vehicle transporting passengers for hire on a pre-arranged contract, trip, and hourly or daily non-mileage metered basis and may also be referred to as a limousine. 
Livery vehicle license means a license issued for a public passenger vehicle allowing the vehicle to operate as a limousine within the Village. 
Owner means any person having the use or control of one or more taxicabs or livery vehicles as herein defined. 
Owner, applicant or licensee means every person, firm or corporation having the use or control of one or more taxicabs or livery vehicles as herein defined, including an association of taxicab owners or livery owners, together with all partners, shareholders, officers and directors where a firm or corporation is involved. 
Public passenger vehicle means taxicabs and livery vehicles used for transportation of passengers for hire. 
Public passenger vehicle license means a taxicab vehicle license or a livery vehicle license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
Taxicab means any public passenger vehicle equipped with a taximeter and used for the carriage of passengers for hire to or from destinations as directed by such passenger(s) and any vehicle registered as a taxicab by the Secretary of State. 
Taxicab operator's license means a license issued to the driver of a taxicab that is eligible to operate as a taxicab within the Village. 
Taxicab vehicle license means a license issued for a public passenger vehicle which allows the vehicle to operate as a taxicab within the Village. 
Taximeter means any mechanical or electrical device attached to a taxicab that records and indicates a charge or fare in dollars and cents measured by distance traveled or waiting time or both. 
Taximeter testing means a taximeter service center designated by the Village manager to conduct testing, certification and sealing of taximeters required by this chapter. 
Vehicle testing station means those facilities designated by the Village manager pursuant to this chapter that conduct the safety inspections required or provided for by this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 19.1; Ord. No. 4684, § 1, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 4902, § 2, 8-1-2006) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 94-2. - Licensing and enforcement. 
The licensing of taxicab operators, livery operators, public passenger vehicles, the examination of applicants for chauffeur's licenses and issuance of chauffeur's licenses to operate said vehicles, and the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, shall be under the control and supervision of the Village manager. The Village manager shall have the authority to designate such persons as deemed necessary to perform the duties that are under the control and supervision of the Village manager. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 2, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-3. - Licenses required. 
(a)  Taxicab service operation. It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate a taxicab service within the corporate limits of the Village without having first obtained a taxicab operator's license. Each taxicab operator's license shall specify the maximum number of taxicabs that may be operated by the taxicab service. 
(b)  Livery service operator. It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate a livery service within the corporate limits of the Village without having first obtained a livery service operator's license. Each livery service operator's license shall specify the maximum number of limousines that may be operated by the livery service. 
(c)  Taxicab vehicle license. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to solicit business, to accept for transportation any passengers within the Village boundaries, or to otherwise operate as a taxicab within the Village unless the vehicle has been issued a valid Village taxicab vehicle license. 
(d)  Livery vehicle license; exception. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to solicit business within the Village, or to accept for transportation any passenger or to otherwise operate as a livery vehicle within the Village unless either: 
(1)  The vehicle has been issued a valid Village livery license; or 
(2)  Arrangements for the transportation of the passenger were made in advance by the passenger, or someone acting on the passenger's behalf. 
(e)  Chauffeur's license. Except as provided in section 94-3(f), it shall be unlawful for: 
(1)  Any person to drive or operate a public passenger vehicle within the Village unless such person currently holds a valid Village chauffeur's license; and 
(2)  Any person owning or controlling any public passenger vehicle to employ or permit any person to operate such vehicle for hire within the Village unless the driver has a valid Village chauffeur's license. 
(f)  Exceptions to licensure requirements. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Prevent taxicabs and limousines licensed by other municipalities from entering the Village limits for the purpose of depositing passengers who were legally picked up outside the Village; or 
(2)  Taxicabs and limousines that do not stop within the Village for the purpose of picking up or depositing passengers. 
(Code 1959, § 19.13; Ord. No. 4684, § 3, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-4. - Applications for licenses. 
(a)  Application forms. Applications for all licenses required by this chapter shall be made upon forms furnished by the Village. 
(b)  Application fees. The annual fee for all licenses under this chapter shall be established by the annual fee ordinance. All fees shall be prorated if the license is issued for a partial license year. 
(c)  General application requirements. All applications for any license under this chapter shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  The full name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  Where the applicant is not an individual, the form and state of organization (i.e. corporation, partnership) and the name, title and telephone number of the contact person for the applicant. 
(3)  Whether the applicant has previously received licenses under this chapter. 
(d)  Additional requirements for chauffeur's license. All applications for chauffeur's licenses under this chapter shall demonstrate compliance with all of the following requirements: 
(1)  That the applicant is at least 18 years of age. 
(2)  That the applicant is not afflicted with any infirmity of body or mind which may render him or her unfit for safe operation of a public passenger vehicle as evidenced by presentation of: 
a.  the results of a medical examination, including tests for drug and alcohol consumption, that was conducted by a licensed physician not more than 13 months in advance of the date of application, and 
b.  the results of tests for drug and alcohol consumption that was conducted by a licensed physician not more than 90 days in advance of the date of application. 
(3)  That the applicant has a valid Illinois driver's license. 
(4)  That the applicant has not been convicted of a Class A misdemeanor or felony charge within the last five years, or show a previous background that indicates a tendency to act in a manner that may place the public at risk. 
(5)  That the applicant's driver's or chauffeur's license has not been suspended or revoked in any state within the last three years for any violation of law concerning the operation of a motor vehicle other than a single failure to comply with emissions testing requirements. 
(6)  That the applicant has had no more than two convictions for violation of traffic regulations governing the movement of vehicles within one year prior to the date of application. 
(7)  That the applicant has never caused, through the unlawful operation of a motor vehicle, an accident resulting in the death of any person. 
(8)  That the applicant is able to understand, communicate, read, write and speak the English language at a level of expertise sufficient to effectively function as a public passenger vehicle operator. The applicant must pass a written examination that tests the applicant's knowledge of the English language, local geography and traffic laws. No applicant may take the examination more than four times in any 180 day period. 
(9)  Photograph and fingerprints may be taken of all applicants and shall be required every other year. 
The Village manager may, after completion of a background check and investigation, waive some or all of the requirements of this subsection based upon the demonstration that the applicant's driving habits are not careless or reckless and that a responsible driving record has been maintained for at least five years preceding the date of application. 
(e)  Additional requirements for livery vehicle and taxicab licenses. Application for a livery vehicle or taxicab license shall be made by the owner of the vehicle upon forms furnished by the Village. Such application shall identify the vehicle owner, and contain a complete description of the vehicle or taxicab including make, model, year, color, State registration number, vehicle identification number, livery or taxicab company name, company assigned vehicle number, copy of vehicle registration card and copy of document containing evidence of required insurance. The application shall also include a copy of the vehicle inspection form from the vehicle testing station. 
(f)  Additional requirements for taxicab service operator's and livery vehicle service operator's licenses. Application for a taxicab service operator's license or a livery vehicle service operator's license shall be made by the owner, or person with legal control over, taxicabs or livery vehicles operating within the Village. Such application shall identify all vehicles proposed for use in service in the Village, including the status of licensure of such vehicles, shall identify all drivers of such vehicles, including the status of all Village chauffeur's licenses for such persons, and shall include a schedule of rates for various services offered. The application shall also provide the legal relationship of the applicant to such listed vehicles and drivers. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 4, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-5. - Term, issuance, display and transfer of licenses. 
(a)  All licenses provided for under this chapter shall be valid only for the license year for which or during which the license was issued. 
(b)  The public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license shall bear the permittee's name and photograph. Such permit shall be prominently displayed in the vehicle operated by the chauffeur at all times. 
(c)  All taxicab vehicle and livery vehicle licenses shall be permanently affixed to the front lower left windshield of the vehicle for which it is issued. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to transfer any license issued under this chapter from one person or vehicle to another. 
(e)  Any person issued a chauffeur's license must inform the Village within ten days after any change of name, address or phone number. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 5, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-6. - Renewal. 
(a)  Chauffeur's license. Any person requesting that a chauffeur's license be renewed shall submit an application to the Village prior to the date of expiration of the chauffeur's license. No chauffeur's license shall be renewed until after the Village has conducted a review of the renewal applicant's driving record and criminal background. No chauffeur's license will be renewed unless the Village manager determines that the applicant for renewal continues to meet the requirements for receiving a chauffeur's license. 
(b)  Vehicle licenses. Any person requesting that a vehicle license for a vehicle licensed under this chapter be renewed shall submit an application to the Village prior to the date of expiration of the vehicle license. No vehicle license will be renewed unless the Village manager determines that the vehicle continues to meet the vehicle license requirements. 
(c)  Operator's licenses. Any person requesting that a taxicab operator's or livery vehicle operator's license be renewed shall submit an application to the Village prior to the date of expiration. No such license will be renewed unless the Village manager determines that the operator continues to meet the taxicab operator's license or livery vehicle operator's license requirements, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 6, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-7. - Public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  No public passenger vehicle operator's license shall be issued unless the Village manager, after a hearing, shall declare that public convenience and necessity requires the operation of the proposed service for which application for license is made. 
(b)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the issuance of a public passenger vehicle operator's license, the Village manager shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require the proposed or additional service within the Village. 
(2)  The financial responsibility of the applicant. 
(3)  The kind, number, type of equipment and color scheme to be used by the applicant. 
(4)  The increased traffic congestion that may result. 
(5)  Whether the safe use of the streets by vehicular or pedestrian traffic will be affected by the granting of such additional license. 
(6)  Any other relevant facts that the Village manager may deem advisable and necessary. 
(c)  No such declaration of public convenience and necessity shall be necessary for the renewal of a public passenger vehicle operator's license for the maximum number of vehicles for which the applicant has already received declaration of public convenience and necessity. 
(Code 1959, § 19.22; Ord. No. 4684, § 7, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-8. - Taxicab service and livery service. 
(a)  All public passenger vehicles shall be operated in accordance with this chapter and all other applicable laws, statutes, ordinances, cedes, rules and regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab or limousine upon the streets of the Village unless such person and the vehicle being operated comply in all respects with the applicable state and Village laws, statutes, ordinances, codes, rules and regulations pertaining thereto. 
(c)  Every operator and chauffeur of a public passenger vehicle is required to furnish clean, comfortable, and safe service. 
(d)  Every taxicab operator and livery operator shall provide to the Village manager a schedule of rates and charges not less than ten days prior to such rates becoming effective. 
(e)  Every taxicab service and every livery service which is licensed by the Village shall keep in operation at all times regular telephone service within the Village so that a person desiring to hire a public passenger vehicle may call the taxicab or livery service. The owner of the taxicab or livery service shall list the telephone number in the local and regional telephone directories which are published for the Village by the phone company which furnishes local telephone service. 
(f)  Every taxicab service which is licensed by the Village shall operate public passenger vehicles regularly in the Village so as to meet the public demand for passenger service. They shall maintain a central place of business available for receiving telephone calls and dispatching vehicles 24 hours a day or, provide, at a minimum, telephone service consisting of an automatic answering device which refers the public to a taxicab service licensed by the Village providing the desired 24-hour service. 
(g)  Every livery service which is licensed by the Village shall operate public vehicles regularly in the Village so as to meet the public demand for passenger service. They shall maintain a central place of business available for receiving telephone calls and dispatching vehicles during normal business hours. 
(h)  Every taxicab service and every livery service which is licensed by the Village shall answer all calls received for service within the Village as soon as possible: If the service cannot be rendered within 20 minutes, it will notify the customer of such delay and given an estimated response time and all reasons for the delay. It shall be unlawful for any taxicab service or livery service which is licensed by the Village to refuse to accept a request for service anywhere within the Village at any time vehicles are available to provide the service. 
(i)  It is unlawful for any taxicab service or a livery service which is licensed by the Village to knowingly encourage or allow a vehicle to operate as a taxicab or limousine without having first obtained the appropriate type of public passenger vehicle license. It is unlawful for any taxicab service or livery service which is licensed by the Village to knowingly encourage or allow a person to operate a taxicab or limousine in violation of the previous sections of this chapter. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab or livery vehicle to be used in the perpetration of a felony, misdemeanor or violation of a Village ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 8, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 4902, § 3, 8-1-2006)  
Sec. 94-9. - Insurance. 
(a)  All taxicab and limousine services based in the Village shall carry public liability insurance for bodily injury liability and for property damage in the amount established by the annual fee ordinance. Such insurance policy shall be issued by a company authorized to do business in the state of Illinois and shall be approved by the Village manager, and shall include the Village as an additional insured thereon. Evidence of insurance shall be filed with the Village manager. 
(b)  No person will be issued a Village chauffeur's license and no taxicab vehicle license or livery license shall be issued until all the requirements of the state laws concerning insurance issued to compensate any person who may suffer damage as a result of operation of the vehicle have been met. 
(c)  There shall be affixed on a conspicuous part of each public passenger vehicle a sticker which indicates that the vehicle has complied with the requirements of Sections 8-101 through 8-116 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/8-101 through 8-116). 
(Code 1959, § 19.25; Ord. No. 4684, § 9, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-10. - Public passenger vehicle requirements. 
(a)  All public passenger vehicles licensed by the Village shall meet the following criteria in addition to complying with all other requirements of this chapter: 
(1)  All applicable and valid state, municipal or county licenses and the Village public passenger vehicle license must be permanently affixed to the front lower left windshield of the vehicle for which it is issued. 
(2)  All applicable equipment must comply with the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(3)  It shall be "FULL SIZE" design or larger which includes van styles. The Village manager may determine that motor vehicles other than "full-size" or larger automobiles and vans may be licensed as public passenger vehicles in the Village, provided that all public safety, equipment and comfort concerns are met. 
(4)  All doors shall be operable. 
(5)  It shall have a compartment to contain and transport luggage or similar items. 
(6)  There shall not be any significant rust on the exterior or interior of the vehicle. 
(7)  The body and interior of the vehicle shall not have any major damage or defects. The exterior surfaces on the body of the vehicle must be painted so that colors used in different areas of the vehicle body match or provide a coordinated color scheme. 
(8)  All windows in the vehicle shall be in proper working condition and shall not contain any cracks or holes. 
(9)  All lights on the exterior and lights on the interior of the vehicle shall be in proper working condition. 
(10)  The upholstery of the vehicle shall not be ripped, torn or otherwise damaged. 
(11)  The exterior of the vehicle must be maintained in a clean condition taking into account weather conditions. 
(12)  The interior of the vehicle must be maintained in a clean condition. There shall be no litter, garbage or other debris inside the vehicle. There shall not be any pungent odors emanating from within the interior of the vehicle or from the vehicle itself. 
(13)  All mechanical components of the vehicle shall operate properly. The vehicle shall not emit any noise or fumes which are not consistent with those emitted by a vehicle that is in excellent operating condition. 
(14)  The vehicle must be equipped with an operating heater and an operating air-conditioning system. The interior of the vehicle while transporting a passenger must be maintained at a temperature that is not less than 65 degrees Fahrenheit or more than 75 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(b)  The Village manager shall have the authority to issue additional regulations which contain requirements relating to the condition in which vehicles licensed as public passenger vehicles must be maintained and operated, provided that such regulations are consistent with the provisions of this chapter including, but not limited to, regulations which restrict or limit the items and materials which may be displayed on the exterior or interior of the vehicle licensed as a public passenger vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 10, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-11. - Public passenger vehicle operation. 
(a)  No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall carry more than the rated passenger load per vehicle. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(b)  After a public passenger vehicle has been hired by one or more persons traveling together, the operator shall not pick up other passengers. 
(c)  It is the duty of the driver of any public passenger vehicle licensed on the Village to accept as a passenger any person who seeks service provided that the person conducts himself in an orderly manner. 
(d)  No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall receive or discharge passengers in an established traffic lane of any roadway. Passengers shall be received and discharged at street curbs or on shoulders of roadways. 
(e)  The driver of a public passenger vehicle shall transport his passenger to the point of destination by the most direct route available. 
(f)  No person shall operate a public passenger vehicle within the Village who is under the influence of an intoxicating beverage or a controlled substance or who at any time within 90 minutes prior to operating such vehicle has consumed an alcoholic beverage or a controlled substance. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any operator of a public passenger vehicle to shout or call to prospective passengers, to use obscene or profane language in the presence of any passenger, to litter or to disturb the peace in any way. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicles licensed by the Village to advertise for the purpose of business or commercial uses unrelated to the public passenger vehicle company. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicle that transports passengers to convey toxic, hazardous or biological waste at any time. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicle operator or company to use a radio frequency scanner or scanning type radio to monitor the radio frequency of competing company for the purpose of stealing the fares of the scanned company. 
(k)  It shall be unlawful for any public passenger driver or company representative to offer compensation to the employees of any business in the Village in order to direct prospective customers to that driver or company. It shall be unlawful for any person to accept or solicit compensation from a public passenger vehicle driver or company representative in return for directing prospective customers to that driver or company. 
(l)  The operator of a public passenger vehicle shall be courteous to passengers, prospective passengers and other drivers at all times. 
(m)  The operator of a taxicab may demand an advance payment of an estimated fare of the person desiring to be transported by such taxicab and may refuse to convey any person who refuses to comply with the demand. 
(n)  Any taxicab passenger paying a fare shall, upon request, be given a receipt indicating the amount paid. 
(o)  The driver of any public passenger vehicle, while posted at any location in the Village awaiting a fare, shall remain in or in close proximity to the vehicle he is operating. He may leave his vehicle unattended for a period of no longer than ten minutes. 
(p)  A public passenger vehicle which has not been issued a public passenger vehicle license pursuant to this chapter shall not stand or park on any privately owned or privately controlled property except as follows: 
(1)  A livery vehicle may stand or park on privately owed property provided that the operator of the livery vehicle is waiting for a passenger and provided that the operator shall remain in or in close proximity to the vehicle he is operating and does not leave the vehicle unattended for a period of longer than ten minutes. 
(2)  A public passenger vehicle may stand or park in a parking lot which is located on the same promises as a restaurant for a period of not longer than 30 minutes. 
(3)  A public passenger vehicle may stand or park in a parking lot which is located on the same premises as a grocery store, delicatessen or convenience food store for a period of not longer than 15 minutes. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 11, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-12. - Taxicab vehicle licenses; inspections. 
(a)  Upon original issuance, renewal or transfer of a license and before operation there under, the licensee shall present each taxicab authorized to be operated under said license to the Village manager, or his designee, for inspection. Prior to presentation, each such taxicab must have obtained evidence of satisfaction vehicular inspection from a vehicle testing station. 
(b)  Safety inspection stickers shall be displayed on the certified inspection plate on the front lower left windshield and are not transferable from one vehicle to another. A safety inspection sticker shall not be affixed to any vehicle other than the vehicle for which the sticker was originally issued. 
(c)  When a taxicab is removed from service by the owner, the taxicab vehicle license issued to that vehicle must be immediately surrendered to the Village manager. 
(d)  Taxicabs shall be inspected two times in a license year, with not less than 90 days and not more than 150 days between consecutive inspections. The license of all taxicabs not inspected as required within that period shall be subject to suspension. Such inspections shall include, but need not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Vehicle make, year and vehicle identification number; 
(2)  State license number and year; 
(3)  Village vehicle license number and year; 
(4)  Vehicle color; 
(5)  Vehicle number; 
(6)  Company name; 
(7)  Service brakes; 
(8)  Emergency brakes; 
(9)  Horn; 
(10)  Rear view mirror; 
(11)  Windshield wipers and washers; 
(12)  Headlights; 
(13)  Tail lights; 
(14)  Stop lights; 
(15)  Turn signals; 
(16)  Speedometer; 
(17)  Taximeter; 
(18)  Rates displayed; 
(19)  Steering; 
(20)  Interior condition; 
(21)  Exterior condition; 
(22)  Windows; and 
(23)  Tires. 
(e)  Any taxicab failing to pass the inspection will be given a period of five working days to allow for repairs. The taxicab cannot be used as a public passenger vehicle for hire until repairs have been completed and it passes re-inspection. If the taxicab does not pass re-inspection within the five working day period, the taxicab license may be suspended by the Village manager. 
(f)  The Village manager shall prescribe reasonable standards that taxicabs must satisfy to pass the inspections required by this chapter, which standards shall be designed to assure that taxicabs licensed by the Village are mechanically dependable, safe, clean and satisfy the requirements of this chapter. 
(g)  Any time a taxicab is involved in an accident that causes damage that may affect the safety of present or perspective passengers, it must be taken out of service immediately, repaired and reported to the Village. Before such vehicle may be returned to service, it must be certified at a Village designated safety inspection station and re-inspected by the Village. 
(h)  The owner of any vehicle for which a Village taxicab license has been issued must keep thorough and complete records related to the maintenance of the vehicle and make such records available upon request of the Village manager or his designee. The maintenance records shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The type of maintenance work performed; 
(2)  The location where the maintenance work was performed; 
(3)  The date the maintenance work was performed; and 
(4)  The mileage of the vehicle when the maintenance work was performed. 
The owner must also maintain, for a period of not less than two years, all work orders, receipts and other documents relating to any maintenance work performed on the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 12, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-13. - Taxicab stands. 
(a)  The Village manager shall designate taxicab stands in the number and location deemed appropriate. Each such taxicab stand shall be appropriately marked by signs erected by the Village. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle other than a licensed taxicab in any taxicab stand. A licensed taxicab may be parked in any cabstand while such taxicab is in the charge of its driver on duty awaiting a fare. 
(b)  The Village manager shall have the authority to create on public property and, with the permission from the owner, on private property, taxicab stands where cabs licensed by the Village may wait for passengers. The Village manager may limit the number of taxicabs permitted to use a taxicab stand at any given area. 
(c)  Rules of conduct at taxicab stands shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Taxicabs entering a taxicab stand or line shall take the rear positions. Overcrowding taxicab stands or lines is prohibited. 
(2)  While taxis occupy designated taxicab stands, no other taxi shall bypass the taxicab line and accept passenger for service. 
(3)  The first cab in line shall be eligible for the first available fare, unless a passenger indicates a preference for another cab in that line. 
(4)  No taxicab shall accept a load along side of, in front of, or adjacent to an established occupied taxicab stand. 
(5)  Livery vehicles shall not park in taxicab stands. 
(6)  Public passenger vehicle drivers shall not sleep or lounge while posted in a taxicab stand. 
(7)  There shall not be more than two occupants in any vehicle posted at a taxicab stand. 
(Code 1959, § 19.9; Ord. No. 4684, § 13, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-14. - Taximeters. 
(a)  No taxicab shall be issued a Village taxicab vehicle license until its taximeter is tested, sealed, and certified to be accurate. 
(b)  No taxicab shall operate for hire in the Village unless the taximeter is accurately recording the fare to be charged. 
(c)  The taximeter will be located so that its face can be seen by any passenger riding in the taxi. 
(d)  Each taximeter will display a "vacant" sign when the taxicab is engaged. 
(e)  Adequate illumination shall be provided for the face of the taximeter so that it may be read by the passenger whenever the vehicle is in operation. 
(f)  The Village manager may designate an official taximeter testing center. 
(g)  No person operating or owning any taxicab shall transfer any taximeter to any other vehicle unless the meter is inspected, reprogrammed and certified at the authorized taximeter testing center. 
(h)  If a taxicab has service performed on or changes made to the transmission, any drive train component, or the size of the tire, the owner of the taxicab must have the taximeter inspected, reprogrammed and certified at the authorized taximeter testing center. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful to have more than one taximeter in any taxicab. 
(j)  Any person convicted of tampering with or otherwise manipulating a taximeter will be subject to a fine as established in this code. In addition the public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license of such person will be revoked for a second offense. 
(k)  The Village manager shall have the authority to require that taximeters be recertified on a semiannual basis. The Village manager shall also have the authority to require that a taximeter be recertified any time the Village manager has reason to believe that the taximeter may not be accurate or that there may have been tempering with or an unauthorized adjustment made to the taximeter. 
(l)  Any taxicab which has a taximeter found to be in violation of any provisions of this chapter may be immediately removed from service. 
(Code 1959, § 19.20; Ord. No. 4684, § 14, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-15. - Fixing of rates. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation licensed under the provisions of this chapter to conspire among themselves or with other persons to fix or control rates for public passenger vehicles within the Village. It is the purpose of this chapter to provide for free and uncontrolled rates. Any scheme, device or other subterfuge employed by any person to evade this purpose shall be deemed to be in violation of this chapter and grounds for revocation. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 15, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-16. - Rates of fare. 
Every taxicab operator and livery operator shall furnish safe and adequate service at equitable and accurate rates within the Village as may be required to meet the public demand for taxicab and livery service. The following information must be prominently and accurately displayed in the interior of each taxicab and clearly visible to all passengers at all times: 
(1)  The entire schedule of rates and charges for services provided and recorded by the taximeter; 
(2)  All nonmetered service charges imposed, including, without limitation, waiting time, premium service hours or days and excess baggage; 
(3)  The telephone number where service complaints will be received; and 
(4)  The chauffeur's permit of the on duty operator. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 16, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-17. - Taxicab license sticker and display. 
(a)  A taxicab vehicle license issued by the Village shall be in the form of an adhesive sticker which shall contain the official license number of the public passenger vehicle. 
(b)  Taxicab vehicle licenses shall be of a distinctly different color and/or design every year. Taxicab vehicle licenses must be affixed to the lower left portion of the windshield of the vehicle for which the license has been issued. 
(c)  A taxicab vehicle sticker is not transferable to any vehicle other than the vehicle for which it has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 17, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-18. - Vehicle identification. 
(a)  Every taxicab licensed in the Village shall bear on all sides of the vehicle in a color contrasting to that of the vehicle itself the name and phone number of the company which it serves. The lettering shall be a minimum of two inches in height and ¼ inch brush stroke. 
(b)  The identification number assigned to the taxicab by the company shall be affixed to the exterior of the vehicle on all sides of the vehicle. These letters must be a minimum of two inches in height and ¼ inch brush stroke. 
(c)  No taxicab shall be painted or labeled so as to be similar to the vehicles of any other person or business which has been issued a Village taxicab operator's license. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 18, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-19. - Livery vehicle licenses; inspections. 
(a)  No livery vehicle license shall be issued for any vehicle which is not owned or affiliated with a livery service which has been licensed by the Village. 
(b)  No livery vehicle shall be licensed until it has been thoroughly and carefully examined at a vehicle testing station and found to be in safe condition for passengers, of good appearance, and well painted. 
(c)  Livery vehicles shall be inspected three times a year. The license of all livery vehicles not inspected as required within that period shall be subject to suspension. Such inspections shall include, but need not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Vehicle make, year and vehicle identification number; 
(2)  State license number and year; 
(3)  Village vehicle license number and year; 
(4)  Vehicle color; 
(5)  Vehicle number; 
(6)  Company name; 
(7)  Service brakes; 
(8)  Emergency brakes; 
(9)  Horn; 
(10)  Rear view mirror; 
(11)  Windshield wiper and washers; 
(12)  Headlights; 
(13)  Tail lights; 
(14)  Stop lights; 
(15)  Turn signals; 
(16)  Speedometer; 
(17)  Taximeter; 
(18)  Rates displayed; 
(19)  Steering; 
(20)  Interior condition; 
(21)  Exterior condition; 
(22)  Windows; and 
(23)  Tires. 
(d)  Any livery vehicle failing to pass the inspection will be given a period of five working days to allow for repairs. The livery vehicle cannot be used as a public passenger vehicle for hire until repairs have been completed and it passes reinspection. If the livery vehicle does not pass reinspection within the five-working day period, the livery vehicle license may be suspended by the Village manager. 
(e)  The Village manager shall prescribe reasonable standards that livery vehicles must satisfy to pass the inspections required by this chapter, which standards shall be designed to assure that livery vehicles licensed by the Village are mechanically dependable, safe, clean and satisfy the requirements of this chapter. 
(f)  Any time a livery vehicle is involved in an accident that causes damage which may affect the safety of prospective passengers, it must be taken out of service immediately, repaired and reported to the Village. Before such vehicle may be returned to service, it must be certified at a state safety inspection station and reinspected by the Village. 
(g)  The Village manager, or his designees, shall have the authority to immediately remove from service any livery vehicle which has been designated unfit for service or unsafe. 
(h)  The Village manager may require a livery vehicle to be reinspected as a result of a complaint by any person, or if the Village manager has reason to believe that the condition of the livery vehicle may pose a threat to the safety of its passengers or has reason to believe that the livery vehicle is not in compliance with provisions of this chapter. 
(i)  Upon passing all test categories at an approved vehicle testing station, the livery vehicle will be issued a safety inspection sticker to indicate that it has been deemed street worthy. Said sticker must be prominently displayed in the lower left of the windshield. It is unlawful for any livery vehicle for which a livery vehicle license has been issued by the Village to operate without a valid safety inspection sticker displayed as required by this chapter. 
(j)  Any livery vehicle that does not pass a safety inspection for any reason shall be immediately taken out of service until the livery vehicle passes the safety inspection. 
(k)  Safety inspection stickers are not transferable from one vehicle to another. A safety inspection sticker shall not be affixed to any vehicle other than the vehicle for which the sticker was originally issued. 
(l)  When a livery vehicle is removed from service by the owner, the livery vehicle license issued to that vehicle must be immediately surrendered to the Village manager. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 19, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-20. - Penalties. 
Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the fines and penalties established in section 1-16 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 20, 9-21-2004)  
Sec. 94-21. - Suspension and revocation of licenses. 
(a)  In any licensee is found guilty of violating any Village ordinance, or State or Federal law while operating a taxicab within the Village of Glenview, the Village manager may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Prior to suspending or revoking a license, the Village manager shall conduct an informal hearing. Notice of the date and time of the hearing shall be delivered to the licensee or mailed to the licensee's last known address on file with the Village not less than five days before the date of the hearing. The licensee shall be entitled to present testimony and documentary evidence at the hearing as to why the license should not be revoked or suspended. The licensee shall have the right to cross examine any person who testifies against the licensee during the hearing. The licensee may be represented at the hearing by counsel. The decision of the Village manager shall be in writing and shall be delivered or mailed to the licensee's last known address on file with the Village. 
(Ord. No. 4684, § 21, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 4902, § 4, 8-1-2006)  
Sec. 94-22. - Immediate removal from service. 
(a)  Where this chapter provides that a public passenger vehicle shall be or may be immediately removed from service, the vehicle may be removed from service by towing by a person of the licensee's choosing or by the Village. 
(b)  If a vehicle is removed from service, the owner or operator is wholly responsible for any towing and impound charges that the Village may incur for such removal from service, unless the Village manager determines that there was no basis for removing the vehicle from service.
